HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees' Stottlemyre Appears Set to Return

BYLINE: By BUSTER OLNEY 

 BODY:
Mel Stottlemyre, treated for bone-marrow cancer during the past season, is leaning toward returning to the Yankees next season, according to friends of the pitching coach.
Stottlemyre, who turns 59 next week, left the team for a stem-cell transplant Sept. 11 and did not return to his duties full time for the rest of the regular season and the postseason. Stottlemyre said last month that he was not sure if he would return for the 2001 season, but in his time away from the team, he found that he missed baseball and missed being around the team. "I think he's feeling pretty good about coming back," said one friend. 
 Club officials are sorting through possible personnel changes. Glenallen Hill, the designated hitter who slugged 10 homers in 51 at-bats, will take a physical in the next 48 hours -- primarily to check the condition of his knees -- and if the Yankees are satisfied he is healthy, they are expected to exercise a $1.5 million option on Hill for the 2001 season.
The Yankees have begun negotiations to keep the relief pitcher Jeff Nelson but are exploring possible trades for more pitching depth in the event they cannot re-sign Nelson, who asked for a four-year, $16 million deal last spring. As expected, David Cone filed for free agency yesterday, along with the utility infielder Luis Sojo. Depending on developments with the rest of the team, the Yankees may eventually offer both players low-budget contracts; Cone could be back if the team's plans for acquiring more pitching fall through.
Club officials have touched base with representatives for a number of free agents, including pitchers Mike Hampton, Denny Neagle and Kevin Appier. But their most prominent target is Mike Mussina, the All-Star pitcher, and the Yankees are expected to meet with Mussina shortly -- perhaps within the next week -- and possibly use some of their veteran players to recruit the right-handed pitcher.
Mussina has a six-year, $72 million offer in hand from the Orioles, but the Baltimore owner, Peter Angelos, has said flatly that if the Yankees offer a six-year, $90 million deal to Mussina, then he would not match that proposal. The Yankees' preference is to add a star pitcher to a rotation that already includes Roger Clemens, Andy Pettitte and Orlando Hernandez, but if Mussina opts to play elsewhere, then outfielder Manny Ramirez would come into the picture. Ramirez reportedly is seeking a deal for between $18 million and $20 million per year, and his negotiations with the Cleveland Indians seemed stalled.
Indians General Manager John Hart spoke carefully about the talks yesterday in a conference call, but added that just as Ramirez will consider all his options on Saturday -- the first day free agents will be free to negotiate with other teams -- then Cleveland would look elsewhere as well.
The general perception of Ramirez -- on his own team and around baseball -- is that he wants to stay with the Indians. Hart sounded unsure. "They've made it very clear that this is going to be an economics-driven contract," said Hart, referring to Ramirez's representatives.
Chris Chambliss was fired as the hitting coach last week, and on Monday, Manager Joe Torre spoke with Mattingly and asked him if he would be interested in being interviewed for the job. Mattingly thanked Torre but reiterated that at this point in his life, he prefers to be at home with his children.
Stottlemyre, whose positive demeanor never changed even as he was going through the first stages of cancer treatment in the first four months of the season, said in late October that he felt good. Stottlemyre adhered to the advice of his doctors, but it was apparent during the World Series that he badly missed his work. Doctors warned him against sitting amid large groups of people because of the risk of infection, and so in the early innings of World Series Games 1 and 2, Stottlemyre watched on television in Torre's office and chatted with pitchers between innings.
Some members of the Yankees' organization believed that once Stottlemyre left the team in September, then he would never return on a full-time basis. But Stottlemyre has felt great, friends say, and his intention is to come back next year. Stottlemyre said last month that doctors saw no reason why he could not return to the Yankees if he wanted.

HEADLINE: Cairo Journal;
American Headstones Tugging at Egypt's Memory

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Behind a high stone wall, in twin graveyards shaded by the heavy branches of gnarled ficus and eucalyptus trees, lie the missionaries and mercenaries who were the first Americans in Egypt.
Their epitaphs read like poetry. Their stories, dating back 150 years, hint of romantic folly or grand adventure. Their lonely marble tombs, hidden from the bustle of the living city, draw few visitors besides the songbirds that hide in the green canopy. 
 Still, at a time of deep ambivalence here toward the West, the overgrown cemeteries stand as quaint testimonials to a forgotten era -- a time when an American in Egypt was a welcome curiosity and the United States was seen as a disinterested bit player in the colonial intrigues to dominate the Arab world.
"I like everything that is American," an Egyptian landowner once confided to Frederic Courtland Penfield, the United States diplomatic agent and consul general to Egypt in the 1880's, a compliment that Mr. Penfield duly recorded in his turn-of-the-century memoir. "In that country, all things are magnificent and marvelous."
It would be hard to find an Egyptian these days who holds such unequivocal admiration. The United States is an imperialistic, meddlesome and overbearing force in the region, according to the popular -- and to a great extent, the official -- view. The State Department, wary in the face of a surge of anti-American feeling in recent weeks, has warned Americans in Egypt and elsewhere in the Middle East to exercise caution as they travel or go about their daily lives.
How unimaginable such worries must have been back in the Victorian Age, when hard-bitten Civil War veterans sailed to Egypt to take up arms in the Khedive Ismail's army and Midwestern evangelists settled along the Nile to convert Egyptian Coptic Christians to Protestantism.
"To us, America was a new country and a new continent, another young nation that was helping us assume our independence from these dying British and French empires," said Samir Raafat, a Cairo historian and preservationist, putting himself in the place of a 19th-century Egyptian seeing Americans for the first time.
"At the time, America was the hope -- a people that was going to help liberate us from these old empires. Today, of course, we look at America the way we looked at the British Empire back then -- as an economic and military power that is out to rule the world and subjugate us to its own ways."
Mr. Raafat, an urbane student of those early ambassadors of the New World, paused in front of a marble obelisk during a stroll through the quiet Protestant cemetery the other day. "Erastus Sparrow Purdy Pasha," he read from the inscription on the dusty white column. "Born in the state of New York in 1838. Died in Cairo the 21st of June 1881."
Mr. Purdy was the archetype of the early American expatriates on the Nile, so well-regarded in Egypt that he appears to have been awarded the supreme Ottoman title of "pasha," although it is not clear whether it came during his lifetime or posthumously.
He was one of 50 veterans of the American Civil War, both Northerners and Southerners, who came to Cairo in the early 1870's at the invitation of Khedive Ismail, then the nation's ruler, to serve in the Egyptian Army.
It was a time of energetic exploits. Ismail was finishing the construction of the Suez Canal, a project that would drive his nation into such bottomless debt that he would be forced to turn Egypt over to British colonial rule. French construction companies fanned through the country. European explorers ventured into Africa.
Before his extravagance caught up with him, Ismail briefly tried to challenge them through his American employees. Mr. Purdy, not yet a pasha, and other Civil War veterans were dispatched to explore East Africa and to lay claim to parts of it for the khedive.
But his American soldiers brought Ismail no lasting acquisitions. "It didn't work," Mr. Raafat mused, kicking at the dead leaves that cover all the graves in the cemetery. "The British were not going to allow an upstart like Egypt to control the source of the Nile."
Around the same time, American Protestant missionaries were settling in the largely Coptic Christian cities of Upper Egypt, following in the footsteps of Catholic and Orthodox missionaries from European churches who had been proselytizing for centuries.
The graves of missionaries and their families dominate the oldest part of the American cemetery. The inscriptions tell the tales: born in Brooklyn, N.Y., died in Cairo; born in Ohio, died in Cairo; born in Stony Point, N.Y., died in Cairo.
Finally, at the end of a row of simple headstones just past a towering mango tree, sits a shadowed marble crypt carved in the shape of a scroll. The Rev. Andrew Watson, place of birth in the United States unknown, lies beneath it. Born in 1834. Died in Cairo in 1916. "For 55 years," his tombstone says, "a missionary of the Cross in the Valley of the Nile."
The American missionaries are now remembered, if at all, for the schools they built, which were considered at the time to be beacons of progressive thinking and openness, said Mr. Raafat. Foreigners are no longer permitted to try to convert Egyptians, and these days American aid to Egypt's schools is regularly criticized in the newspapers as improper "American Zionist influence."
"Back then, though, a lot of people found this American evangelical system as a way out of the dogma of their own churches," said Mr. Raafat. "American education was more liberal. It was co-educational. It was new and modern."
By the end of the century, Egypt and its tourist sites became a favored destination for wealthy Americans. In the decades that followed, transportation improved enough so that American families could bring back the bodies of their dead for burial at home.
A few contemporary graves dot the cemeteries. A group of Americans, inspired by Mr. Raafat's research, this week rededicated the tomb of Purdy Pasha, but the caretakers of the cemeteries, who are illiterate and cannot read either the English or Arabic inscriptions, know as little about the new arrivals as they do about the old.
"They bury their dead," said Soliman Abdallah Moawad, who tends the plots in the Protestant cemetery, "and never come back."

HEADLINE: Chief U.S. Mediator in Mideast Plans to Leave in January

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
On the eve of what may be the last attempt by the Clinton White House to revive peace talks between the Israelis and Palestinians, Dennis B. Ross, the leading American mediator for more than a decade, announced that he would leave at the end of this administration.
The plan for the departure of Mr. Ross, who has served under Presidents Reagan, Bush and Clinton, did not come as a complete surprise. But because of his background with Republican administrations, there had been speculation that he might stay on if Gov. George W. Bush became president. 
 In keeping with his low-key style, Mr. Ross, 51, did not make a formal announcement but mentioned his plans in answer to a question on Monday night at the Los Angeles World Affairs Council. And in keeping with his experience as a negotiator, Mr. Ross spoke of intent rather than making a definitive statement: "I intend to work through the end of this administration, but I don't intend to stay for the next one."
Mr. Ross said the stress on his family from 12 years of travel was the main reason for his decision.
Colleagues of Mr. Ross said, however, that it was fairly clear that after the recent collapse of the Clinton administration's peace efforts, a new president would seek new faces for Middle East diplomacy.
Mr. Ross has been at President Clinton's side at the two major Middle East diplomatic drives this year: the meeting in Geneva with President Hafez el-Assad of Syria, and the Camp David summit meeting in July. Neither produced the results Washington had hoped for, though the Camp David talks pushed consideration of the most tendentious issues further along than expected.
After those two setbacks and the violence of the last five weeks, Mr. Ross and his colleagues largely concluded that the comprehensive peace settlement they were seeking this year would take much longer.
Mr. Ross, who began in government in the Reagan administration as an expert on the Soviet Union, came into his own as a Middle East expert on the National Security Council from 1986 to 1988. He then served Secretary of State James A. Baker III as a close aide, working with him to convene the landmark talks in Madrid in 1991 that brought Israelis and Palestinians together.
President Bush recommended to Mr. Clinton that he keep Mr. Ross, and so Mr. Ross glided seamlessly to become the Clinton administration's special Middle East co-ordinator. He has won praise as indefatigible, though paying, perhaps, too much attention to the gritty details.
"Dennis is a great public servant who did more to push the process along than anyone could imagine," said Leslie H. Gelb, president of the Council on Foreign Relations. "But we got swept up by the negotiations, with not enough attention paid to the substructure on the ground, and what was in people's lives and people's heads."
More could have been done, for example, to reduce bitterness by encouraging Israeli-Palestinian-Jordanian economic projects, he said.
Mr. Ross will be closely involved in the last-chance Middle East effort by Mr. Clinton, which begins on Thursday when the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat is due at the White House. Prime Minister Ehud Barak follows on Sunday.
Mr. Clinton will be in a listening mode, aides insisted, trying to figure out whether the two leaders are interested in pursuing any kind of peace settlement -- major or minor -- before the end of his presidency.
Administration officials said the major mystery is Mr. Arafat, who has yet to make clear whether he is interested in negotiating even a limited deal while Mr. Clinton remains in the White House. In contrast, Mr. Barak is expected to argue that he joined forces with the rigorously Orthodox Shas Party in Israel -- rather than to continue pursuing a national unity government -- in order to try to negotiate, the officials said.

HEADLINE: Attack on Clean Air Act Falters in High Court Arguments

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The most potent legal attack on the Clean Air Act in the statute's 30-year history, startlingly successful in a federal appeals court here 18 months ago, floundered visibly at the Supreme Court today.
In an intense two-hour argument, justice after justice expressed the view that whatever the burdens and uncertainties of life under the sweeping statute as it is currently interpreted, alternative approaches would not solve those problems and might well create new ones, for other federal regulatory laws as well as for the Clean Air Act. 
 The case brought two closely intertwined issues before the court. One was whether the law, as interpreted by the Environmental Protection Agency, provides so little guidance on how to set permissible levels of pollutants as to amount to an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power to the executive branch.
This question reached the Supreme Court as an appeal by the Clinton administration from a ruling in May 1999 by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The appeals court invoked the long-discredited "nondelegation doctrine," which the Supreme Court had last used to strike down a federal statute in 1935, to invalidate standards for ozone and small airborne particles that the Environmental Protection Agency had issued in 1997.
The second issue, brought before the justices by the coalition of industry groups that had been successful at the appeals court, offered a way to preserve that victory while at the same time avoiding the constitutional earthquake that could result from striking down the clean air standards -- and, by implication, many other federal regulations -- as reflecting impermissible delegations of Congressional authority.
The industry group is arguing that a new interpretation of the Clean Air Act to require the agency to weigh the costs and benefits of each regulation would provide the statutory guidance the appeals court found lacking, thus avoiding the nondelegation analysis that was unlikely to attract a Supreme Court majority in any event.
"We're talking about a world of limited resources," Edward W. Warren, representing the American Trucking Associations, the United States Chamber of Commerce and other industry groups told the court. Without a cost-benefit requirement, he said, "the agency has the freedom to take us all the way down to de-industrialization, and that can't be."
The approach was creative, but the allies that Mr. Warren needed on the bench did not materialize. "I don't see how it helps your delegation problem to add 'the economy' to the ineffable pot of things the administrator is supposed to consider," Justice Antonin Scalia said. He added: "If you're going to stop a cough, is $1,000 too much? What does it cost to stop a cough -- $2,000? $3,000? It's just as indeterminate."
Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who before he joined the court had written approvingly of using cost-benefit analysis in administrative law, echoed Justice Scalia.
"I could ask the same question about picking out trucking routes or airline routes," he said, adding, "There's no scale in heaven, or anything other than judgment." Later in the argument, he told Mr. Warren that cost-benefit analysis was a "formal discipline" and added, "I don't see how you import cost-benefit analysis into the statute."
Mr. Warren replied that he was not suggesting "econometrics" but rather "a common sense way" of evaluating "competing considerations in a systematic way."
"That's all we're talking about," he said.
"It seems to me you're creating another morass," Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said at one point. What exactly did he want the agency to do, she asked.
"What every other health, safety, and environmental agency does," Mr. Warren replied, adding, "The norm is to do the kind of weighing and balancing I'm talking about."
Complicating this already complicated case is the fact that the District of Columbia Circuit, in a 1980 decision known as Lead Industries, interpreted the Clean Air Act to bar the kind of cost-benefit analysis for which Mr. Warren was arguing.
Although the Supreme Court declined at the time to review that decision, it remains binding as precedent on the appeals court, which is why the appeals court used nondelegation rather than statutory analysis to reach the result of invalidating the 1997 standards.
The industry coalition is asking the justices to disavow the appeals court's 1980 ruling. It derives its statutory argument from the language of the Clean Air Act, which requires the Environmental Protection Agency to set air quality standards at levels "requisite to protect the public health." Mr. Warren told the court that public health itself is a discipline that incorporates a cost-benefit analysis as it considers how to achieve the greatest public good with limited resources.
However, the justices appeared quite resistant to placing on "public health," which is not defined in the statute, the full weight of the industry's argument.
"In one sentence, what is your proposed standard?" Justice Sandra Day O'Connor asked Mr. Warren. She said, "I've listened to a lot of vague language from you, and I don't understand what you're saying."
Mr. Warren replied, "Public health contemplates the consideration of competing factors, including costs, in seeking to decrease population sickness and increase longevity." He added, "I don't know how you can live in a world of limited resources" without weighing costs and benefits.
"Well, we have lived with it for 20 years," Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist commented dryly.
The justices were attentive to Solicitor General Seth P. Waxman's two-pronged presentation. He argued that the Clean Air Act, properly interpreted, did not use cost considerations in the standard-setting process but that the statute gave enough guidance to the Environmental Protection Agency in other ways to avoid a delegation problem. The solicitor general relied on the same statutory phrase as Mr. Warren, "requisite to protect the public health," but to very different purposes.
"Requisite means sufficient but not more than necessary," he said. The heart of his argument was that in the Clean Air Act, Congress established a two-part regulatory process. In the standard-setting phase, he said, the agency was to use the latest scientific knowledge to protect the public from the effect of air pollution.
"Congress made a rational decision as to the most serious problem facing America in 1970, air pollution," Mr. Waxman said. He said Congress created an "expert agency" and gave it the mission: "Just tell us, based on your best judgment, what level would be safe to set for the whole country."
Consideration of costs and technical feasibility are supposed to come in at the second phase, he said, that of deciding how and on what schedule the standards should be put into effect. In the ensuing 30 years, Mr. Waxman said, Congress has "adjusted implementation in response to problems of cost and feasibility" but has never changed its instructions to the agency on how to set the actual standards.
If the agency prevails in Browner v. American Trucking Associations, No. 99-1257, that will not be the end of the case, or the end of judicial review for the new ozone and particle standards. The standards would still be open to challenge before the appeals court under the Administrative Procedure Act, a law that applies to nearly all federal regulations and that authorizes federal judges to invalidate agency action as "arbitrary and capricious."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Pets.com Plans to Close And Sell Most of Its Assets
Pets.com announced it was shutting down its operations. The company, which sells pet food and other supplies over the Internet, was losing money and found itself unable to raise more cash or to find a buyer.
Pets.com said it was laying off about 255 of its 320 employees and would sell most of its assets, including rights to its popular sock puppet. The company plans to shut down its Web site tomorrow. Page C4. 

MetLife Reports 26% Rise in Profit
MetLife, which converted from a mutual insurer through an initial public offering in April, said its third-quarter earnings rose 26 percent as it sold more insurance and retirement products to individuals and to companies. Shares of MetLife, which is based in New York, rose 94 cents, to $27. They have climbed 91 percent since their stock market debut. C12.
 
Creditors Delay Daewoo Decision
Creditors of Daewoo Motor, the troubled South Korean automaker, postponed until this afternoon a decision to declare the company bankrupt. Talks continued with unions over the submission of a written agreement guaranteeing their willingness to cooperate with drastic restructuring plans, which would entail large layoffs and pay cuts. C2.
 
Earnings Double at BP Amoco
BP Amoco said that its third-quarter profit doubled thanks to sharply higher oil and natural gas prices and savings. The results were in line with expectations and followed similar results from BP Amoco's leading rivals, Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell. C2.
 
British Telecom Nears Revamping
British Telecommunications is expected to separate its wholesale operations from its other business units as part of a long-awaited revamping plan, executives close to the company said. World Business, Section W.
 
Slowdown Seen in Consumer Credit
Consumer credit increased in September at the slowest pace in five months, a sign consumer spending could start to cool, Federal Reserve statistics showed. C2.
 
The Payoffs From Risk Taking
Mireille Guiliano, chief executive of Clicquot, the United States arm of the French Champagne company, says she took a chance in moving to America. "But as my mother would say, 'What's the worst that can happen?' It is a good question to ask at turning points in your life," she said. The risk paid off. "It is doubtful I would have risen to the post of C.E.O. in France," she said. "There, I studied language, and I would have been allowed to be a professor or a translator. But head of a company? Probably not." The Boss. C8.
 
Stocks Unchanged in Light Trading
Stock prices were little changed in slow trading as investors awaited results from the presidential election. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 25.03 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,952.18. The Standard & Poor's 500 slid 0.32 of a point, closing at 1,431.87. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.4 point, to 3,415.79. C14.
 
Transmeta Soars on 1st Trading Day
Shares of Transmeta, a designer of microprocessors fighting for a piece of the laptop computer market with Intel, more than doubled on their first day of public trading. C4.
 
Abitibi Officials Fight for Jobs
Executives of the newsprint producer Abitibi-Consolidated of Canada are fighting for their jobs in presentations to institutional investors across North America after an attempt by its largest minority shareholder, Quebecor, to remove them. World Business, Section W.
 
2 Charged With Insider Trading
A former NationsBank executive and an accountant who was his friend were charged with insider trading in what prosecutors said was a three-year scheme that produced more than $1.2 million in illegal gains. C10.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: THE POLLING;
An Electorate Largely Split Reflects a Race So Very Tight

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
In the end, the portrait of the voters showed what a brutally competitive race it had been.
Vice President Al Gore carried the votes of women, Gov. George W. Bush carried the votes of men. 
 Mr. Bush edged Mr. Gore among white voters, while Mr. Gore carried roughly 9 of 10 black voters and nearly two-thirds of Hispanics.
Mr. Bush ran better among parents and gun owners. Mr. Gore ran better among gays and self-described moderates. And the two candidates split the votes of Catholics and people over 60, essentially fighting each other to a standstill among those segments of the electorate, according to interviews with voters leaving the polls around the country yesterday.
In some ways, it was a polarizing outcome, with few signs of the crossover voting that once framed American elections. Each of the two men won about 9 of 10 votes in his own party, and they split the independent vote.
Yet many voters ended the election campaign as many began: with lingering doubts about the candidates. Four in ten said they had cast their votes with reservations. And about half said they would be concerned, or even downright scared, at the prospect of a President Bush or a President Gore.
Voters were generally in a contented mood as they cast their ballots, but there were also signs of Clinton fatigue: in their negative judgment of the president's character and in the priority many put on straight talk and honesty.
When given a choice, a plurality of voters -- about a fourth -- rated honesty a more important consideration than experience or an understanding of the complex issues of the day, according to the voter polls. And those people tended to vote for Mr. Bush, who also had an edge among those who considered strong leadership most important.
But Mr. Gore had a big edge among those who considered experience and the mastery of complex issues most important. Mr. Bush was never able to shed the perception that he was not as well prepared as Mr. Gore for the responsibilities of the presidency, although he did manage to get 1 in 10 of the votes of people who judged him ill equipped.
The polls also suggested a profoundly ambivalent attitude toward the era just ending. People became more contented during the Clinton years: two-thirds of respondents said the country, enjoying a record economic boom, was going in the right direction over all. But 6 in 10 said it was on the wrong track morally.
Mr. Clinton's job approval rating stayed fairly high, but his personal unfavorability rating was equally high in the surveys, taken as voters were leaving polling places in 300 precincts across the country. Most voters said they would remember Mr. Clinton more for the scandals of his presidency than for any leadership he provided. Yet most also said a president's ability to manage the government was more important than his ability to provide moral leadership.
The ambivalence about the status quo may help explain the race's closeness, which was sustained in the voter surveys throughout the afternoon and early evening. Though Mr. Bush had an edge for several days leading up to the election, the later deciders largely voted for Mr. Gore, a development that helped explain the final surge the Democrats enjoyed in many polls.
But there were signs in the surveys taken at polling places yesterday that Mr. Bush had succeeded in changing the public agenda, to his advantage. When the campaign started, voters showed little enthusiasm for tax cuts. By the end, they put tax cuts near the top of their priorities for the budget surplus -- ahead of debt reduction, a goal that Democrats repeatedly warned could be undone by Mr. Bush's promise of a tax cut worth $1.3 trillion over 10 years.
At the same time, the surveys suggested that Mr. Gore had regained the edge on economic stewardship, and was running well on issues that Mr. Bush had tried to make his own, notably education and Social Security.
Mr. Bush's argument that government's role in public life needed to be reduced clearly resonated. Much of his campaign revolved around his proposals to inject private-market forces into entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare. That philosophy of restricting government was shared yesterday, at least in the abstract, by many voters; just over half said they agreed that government should be doing less.
Another sign that at least some voters were in a mood for a less activist government: when asked to choose between protecting the environment and fostering economic growth, people were evenly divided between the two.
When asked what the new president should do first, the number who said he should cut taxes was equal to the number who said he should improve education.
Voters often express a preference for the checks and balances of divided government, with one party controlling the White House and the other Capitol Hill. But they indicated yesterday that they were ready for a change. Perhaps in reaction to the brutal partisan warfare that characterized the last six years of Mr. Clinton's administration, capped by his impeachment, voters said they thought it would be better if the president and the Congressional majority were from the same party.
The polls yesterday found Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore splitting the support of the baby boomers and those who came of age during the Reagan years.
The polls also suggested that Mr. Bush's efforts to ease the fears of less conservative voters about his opposition to legalized abortion had paid off. Despite an intense campaign by abortion rights and family planning groups, which maintained that he was a staunch conservative whose court appointments could jeopardize a constitutional right to abortion, more than a quarter of the people who support legal abortion voted for him anyway.
Union households, on the other hand, stuck with Mr. Gore. Organized labor had mounted an immense get-out-the-vote campaign, and the surveys suggested that Mr. Gore was getting well over half the union vote.
Mr. Bush was running well among conservative Christians, and among voters who once considered themselves supporters of Senator John McCain, his main rival in the Republican primaries. More than half of McCain backers gave their support to Mr. Bush, as against more than a third to Mr. Gore.
The voter surveys were conducted by the Voter News Service, a consortium of the television networks and The Associated Press.
 
How the Polls Were Conducted
The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations across the United States and also in 15 individual states.
The polls were conducted by Voter News Service, a consortium formed by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, Fox News, NBC News and The Associated Press.
The national exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by 12,361 voters in 300 randomly selected precincts across the country. Individual state surveys of voters leaving the polls included 831 to 1,943 voters in 20 to 50 precincts within each of 14 states. In Oregon, where voting is done by mail, no precincts were open on Election Day; there the poll was done by telephone with 638 voters.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by only a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all voters who turned out in each constituency yesterday.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, like the reluctance of some voters to take the time to fill out questionnaires, may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
Professor Helmut Norpoth of the State University of New York at Stony Brook assisted The Times in its polling analysis.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST

 BODY:

MICHIGAN
All year, Michigan voters kept the nation guessing, and the suspense continued late last night, as the presidential race and the fourth-most-expensive United States Senate campaign remained too tight to call. 
 Voters had their hands full keeping track of the mudslinging between Senator Spencer Abraham, a freshman Republican, and his scrappy opponent, Representative Debby Stabenow. They continually traded the lead in the polls. Mr. Abraham focused on his record, including blocking lower prison sentences for crack dealers. Ms. Stabenow, whose Congressional raise paid for whistles for Detroit schoolgirls after a series of attacks, ran as an education ally.
Of Michigan's 16 Congressional races, the most contentious was in the Eighth District, the seat vacated by Ms. Stabenow. There, Democrat Dianne Byrum, a hardware store owner turned state representative, was running neck and neck with Republican Mike Rogers. Democrats were trying hard to hold on to that seat to help guarantee them a a House majority.
Voters blocked a school voucher initiative.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: THE REFERENDUM;
Voters Weigh Initiatives On Spending For Transit

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
New Yorkers last night rejected what would have been the largest bond issue in state history, a plan intended to jump-start work on a Second Avenue subway but one which critics argued would have added to the state's already perilously high debt load.
On a similar transportation question on the New Jersey ballot, voters overwhelmingly approved a measure that will free up money for roads, bridges and transit by redirecting existing taxes to a dedicated transportation fund. 
 New York voters have turned down bond acts more often than they have approved them, with a traditional split between upstate voters, who generally dislike borrowing measures, and those in the New York City metropolitan region, who have tended to favor them.
That scenario played out again yesterday. Upstate voters rejected the measure more than two to one, while New York City voters supported it in equal measures. It won narrow approval among voters in the city's suburbs.
The measure was arguably the least visible bond act New York voters have ever been asked to approve. Many top elected officials -- including those whose conceived of the bonds as a compromise to pay for expensive transportation projects -- did not campaign vigorously for it. And even its ardent supporters had reservations about the amount of debt it would incur.
The two transportation measures -- each of which totaled about $3.8 billion -- were clear signals of the deepening struggle to find ways to pay for the vastly expensive upkeep of aging transportation networks that are integral to both state's economies.
In New Jersey, the measure dedicates hundreds of millions of dollars a year in sales taxes and taxes on wholesale petroleum products to state transportation projects over four years. Currently, those taxes are unrestricted and can be tapped for any program, depending on budget needs.
By dedicating the taxes to the transportation fund and providing it with a reliable revenue stream, the state can leverage even more money because it will have the ability to issue more transportation bonds.
In New York, the measure would have allowed the state to raise $3.8 billion through general obligation bonds with $1.6 billion going to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the city's mass transit systems. The measure would have allocated an additional $1.9 billion for the state highway program, with the remaining $300 million for upstate transit systems, bridges and for other purposes.
The bonds were seen as especially crucial for the M.T.A., which needs a reliable chunk of money for a $17.1 billion, five-year capital plan. The plan has been widely criticized because it relies on expensive refinancing of old debt and requires the agency to issue bonds for new debt on top of that.
The capital plan calls for upgrading the region's rail and bus system, including new subway cars and buses, rehabilitation of subway stations, the first work in a generation on a Second Avenue line and the start of work on a connection between the Long Island Rail Road and Grand Central Terminal.
Supporters characterized the bond act as the only realistic way to pay for badly needed transportation improvements. Last night, they criticized Gov. George E. Pataki, who controls the M.T.A., as not supporting the measure aggressively enough.
"The defeat of the bond is a defeat for Governor Pataki and his ambitious plans to improve transportation in New York," said Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a transit watchdog group.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NEW JERSEY -- THE HOUSE;
New Jersey Voters Return Incumbents to Congress in Several Closely Watched Races

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
After a night of shifting leads, one of the most closely watched House races in New Jersey was too close to call, as former Representative Dick Zimmer was in a virtual tie with Representative Rush Holt, a first-term incumbent in the 12th District. Michael Ferguson, a political newcomer, won the open seat in the 7th.
It appeared that, as many Democrats had feared, Ralph Nader and the Green Party siphoned votes away from Mr. Holt. Mr. Holt was 56 votes ahead, but neither he nor Mr. Zimmer had conceded. Carl Mayer, a perennial political hopeful running as a Green this year, had nearly 5,500 that the Democrats are sure to say would otherwise have been theirs. 
 Mr. Zimmer did not claim victory or defeat when he joined a small band of supporters who waited through the evening. He said there had been some miscounts and other errors that made the race still too uncertain.
"I won't be declaring victory -- it is too close," Mr. Zimmer said at 12:30 a.m. "I have had a conversation with Rush Holt and we want to make sure of the numbers. I think we pulled it out, but we want to be sure."
Mr. Ferguson had an easier time of it, leading Maryanne Ms. Connelly throughout the night and claiming victory shortly after Ms. Connelly conceded at 12:30 a.m.
"Tonight is our night!" Mr. Ferguson shouted with glee to his cheering supporters.
Standing with his wife, Maureen, and two children, he spoke of his great-grandparents arriving in the country 100 years ago, and added: "They knew the streets were not paved with gold, but that they were full of opportunity. They would be proud, and perhaps surprised, to see their great-grandson standing here tonight."
The vote count in the 12th was Mr. Zimmer with 140,620, Mr. Holt with 139,889 and Mr. Mayer with 5,490.
The two races were winnable by both sides in the battle for control of the new House of Representatives, and the two parties' national organizations spent heavily in the contests. In the end, it appeared that Mr. Ferguson's sharp move from the conservative positions he had once espoused was enough to protect him against accusations of carpetbagging and election finance fraud from Ms. Connelly.
Ms. Connelly conceded at midnight. Her campaign manager, Sujata Tejwani, said Mr. Ferguson's personal fortune, much of it coming from his parents in a disputed gift, had overwhelmed the Democrat.
"We were out-communicated by quite a bit," Ms. Tejwani said.
While state returns showed a convincing majority of New Jersey voters choosing Vice President Al Gore for president, it was clear that farther down the ballot they were often splitting their votes, returning veteran Republicans and Democrats alike to Congress.
All the state's other incumbent congressmen were easily re-elected. In the Third District, Representative H. James Saxton easily turned aside a well-financed challenge from Susan Bass Levin, the mayor of Cherry Hill. Besides Mr. Saxton, the Republicans Frank A. LoBiondo, Chris Smith, Rodney Frelinghuysen and Marge Roukema were all returned.
Similarly, the Democrats Robert E. Andrews, Frank Pallone Jr., William J. Pascrell Jr. and Steven R. Rothman won re-election.
In the 12th, Mr. Zimmer, who had held the seat until 1996, evidently profited from being taken for the incumbent, his staff believed.
Ms. Connelly went to her campaign celebration at 11:30 last night and told her supporters that they were going to have to wait a little longer to learn the outcome. "Anyway," she said, "have we ever done anything the easy way?"
Ms. Connelly, 55, made her second try at winning the seat. Mr. Ferguson emphasized his youthfulness and his family-oriented platform of education issues, while Ms. Connelly stressed her roots in the community and her experience in local affairs.
The Republicans have felt that the 12th District should be theirs, because demographics and the district's history favor Republicans. But Mr. Holt, 52, had worked the district assiduously in his two years in Washington, stressing his concerns for quality-of-life issues like the environment, and his interest, as a physicist, in strengthening the district's big technical and research installations.
Even before the tickets were decided in the June primary, the fights for the 7th and the 12th Congressional Districts were under political microscopes in Trenton and in Washington, as politicians looked for clues to whether New Jersey Democrats would be able to break out of their urban and inner-suburb base and run strong in the state's political heartland, its suburbs.
Both districts fit the statewide pattern of moderate suburban Republicanism, the 12th even more than the 7th. The 12th stretches from the Delaware River in Hunterdon County nearly to the Atlantic, and its voters range from the wealthy, conservative horse country residents of Somerset, through the liberals in Princeton to the increasingly tax-phobic strivers in the mini-mansions of Ocean County to the east.
The Republicans have dominated the district far more than might be suggested by their lead in voter registration, 20 percent to 19 percent for the Democrats. Most 12th District voters supported Chuck Haytaian for the United States Senate in 1994 over Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the incumbent, even though Mr. Haytaian, who was then Assembly speaker, had no strong ties to the area. The district voted for President Clinton in 1996, but went overwhelmingly Republican in state legislative races the next year.
Moreover, many Republicans believe the 12th District seat should have remained theirs in 1998 but for the conservative views of Michael Pappas, who replaced Mr. Zimmer, 56, when Mr. Zimmer lost his bid for the United States Senate in 1996. Mr. Pappas's views, including his opposition to abortion and gun control, were too far to the right for the voters there.
Mr. Holt had since maintained that his brand of Democratic politics, stressing fiscal restraint, education, economic stability, health care and women's issues, would control the middle ground in suburban New Jersey and leave no place for the Republicans.
But in a race that was often acrimonious -- a local cable outlet refused to carry one of Mr. Holt's attacks on Mr. Zimmer on the ground that it was untrue -- Mr. Zimmer worked the area well to the left of the easy target Mr. Pappas had presented. He softened the tax-cutting rhetoric that worked so well for him during the state's tax revolt 10 years ago, and focused on his record of fighting wasteful spending and balancing the federal budget and his support for higher standards in schools and protecting the environment.
And after Mr. Zimmer's years in Congress, his name was arguably better known than Mr. Holt's.
If the 12th is a Republican district that sometimes leans Democratic, the 7th District is one where the Democrats have more registered voters, 24 percent to 19 percent for the Republicans, but which nevertheless has voted strongly Republican in state legislative races for several elections.
Ms. Connelly ran a surprisingly strong race against Mr. Franks two years ago, and in June, after overcoming the party favorite in the primary, she was able to count on fairly high voter recognition.
Mr. Ferguson moved to the district only last winter after Mr. Franks announced he would be giving up the seat.
A retired AT&T nutritionist and human relations executive, Ms. Connelly made much of Mr. Ferguson's newcomer status in her campaign. Mr. Ferguson ran and lost in the adjoining Sixth District two years ago. He has never held elected office.

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton's Victory

 BODY:
Completing an extraordinary metamorphosis from political neophyte to polished candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton -- the first first lady ever to run for office -- defeated Representative Rick Lazio yesterday in a closely fought race for Daniel Patrick Moynihan's Senate seat from New York. If Mrs. Clinton brings to the Senate the intelligence and energy that she brought to her campaign, she should make a worthy successor to the estimable Mr. Moynihan, who is retiring after 24 honorable years of service.
Meanwhile Jon Corzine, a Democrat and a multimillionaire who spent nearly $60 million of his own money, will succeed Frank Lautenberg as senator from New Jersey. Mr. Corzine now holds the dubious distinction of having contributed the most personal money of all time to win a Senate seat. 
 Mrs. Clinton's victory is the more remarkable. She arrived in New York as an ambitious amateur, bruised by her husband's personal lapses, branded as a carpetbagger and burdened by the ethical legacies of her Arkansas and White House years. She was also largely untutored in New York's economic and social needs. But there was never any doubt about her intellectual capacity. She proved a quick study and, in time, a sure-footed campaigner.
It is true that she profited greatly from Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's decision to retire from the race for medical reasons, as well as Representative Lazio's late start, which put him at a disadvantage financially and in terms of name recognition. But Mr. Lazio, a Republican moderate who built a creditable record in the House on a variety of issues, proved a vigorous opponent. He wasted too much energy in a fruitless effort to portray himself as the only true New Yorker in the race, and discovered to his dismay that the anti-Hillary sentiment nationwide produced more money than votes. He never really found his voice, but he pushed Mrs. Clinton on the issues and undoubtedly furthered her political education in the process.
The only regrettable aspect of the campaign was that it lapsed near the end into name-calling, with Mr. Lazio trying to draw connections between Mrs. Clinton's fund-raising and terrorists who bombed the U.S.S. Cole, while Mrs. Clinton launched a harsh last-minute commercial that accused Mr. Lazio of trying to gut funding for breast cancer treatment. The ad, meant for the suburbs where Mrs. Clinton was not doing as well as expected, distorted Mr. Lazio's record on breast cancer.
Too much money dominated both the New York and New Jersey races, but the excesses in New Jersey were unprecedented. Mr. Corzine used his considerable fortune to swamp his underfinanced opponent, Representative Bob Franks, a hard-working but colorless moderate, with ads, donations to churches and political organizations and, more recently, "walking-around money" of $50 to $75 to hordes of political workers hired for the day. This page opposed Mr. Corzine for just that reason, but expects him to deliver on his promises to vote progressively and to work for campaign finance reform.
In addition to her distinction as the first first lady to run for office, Mrs. Clinton is also New York's first woman senator. For years she has been a vigorous proponent of reform in health, education and child care, but always as an unelected advocate. Her election gives her, for the first time, a legislative arena in which to champion her causes.

HEADLINE: Election Day Suspense

 BODY:
After a vote count that stretched into this morning, Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore were locked in one of the most closely contested presidential contests in decades. Mr. Bush's highly provisional lead arose in dramatic fashion, when Florida tilted back toward Mr. Bush's column after the networks had predicted that it would go to Mr. Gore. Then, after 3 a.m., Mr. Gore closed within a few hundred votes in Florida.
As these events attested, it was an election that overturned cliches about voter apathy. But it also reflected tension within the American public on whether to choose Mr. Bush's personality and promises of leadership over Mr. Gore's experience and knowledge of government. 
 The closeness of this first race of the new century recalled two historic elections of the 1960's, both involving Richard Nixon. He suffered a razor-thin loss to John F. Kennedy in 1960, and then scored a narrow victory over Hubert Humphrey in 1968. In 1960, in a contest decided by 113,000 votes, or one-half vote per precinct, Nixon did not concede victory to Kennedy until noon on the day after the election. In 1968, the television networks did not declare him the winner until 8 a.m. the next day.
The struggle for control of Congress in yesterday's election was also close. The Republicans have maintained an increasingly fragile majority for the past six years, and absentee ballots may play an important role in these elections. In California, for example, a state that may end up deciding the balance of power in the House of Representatives, voters requested a record 3.2 million absentee ballots, of which at least 2.7 million are expected to be returned. It may take until Friday to count them.
While the vote count remained uncertain far into the evening, the money count was easier to estimate. This campaign was far and away the most expensive in history. In the last few days alone, nearly $100 million has been spent in a widespread effort to propel the party faithful to the polls and change the minds of the undecided voters. As if the voters had not already heard enough from the candidates themselves, the two parties and their allies bombarded voters with millions of phone calls, tons of pamphlets, e-mail messages and door-to-door visits from thousands of volunteers. All told, this campaign will soak up an unprecedented $500 million in so-called soft money, and if Senator John McCain's recent prediction is right, about $1 billion will have been spent on television advertising.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush campaigned with extraordinary intensity and discipline. They offered a clearly delineated choice between personal appeal and suspicion of big government on Mr. Bush's side and experience and promises of aggressive attacks on social problems on Mr. Gore's. Their clash revealed a country almost evenly divided as to its preferences. Both aimed at the center of the political spectrum, but with significant differences. Mr. Bush spoke of privatizing part of Social Security, which may well have cost him support in Florida. Mr. Gore attacked Mr. Bush's tax cut, which hurt the vice president in the Sun Belt but attracted union voters in key battleground states like Michigan, Illinois and Pennsylvania.
Union workers and other mid-to-low-income voters were the keys to Mr. Gore's greater success in those three crucial states. Mr. Bush was clearly more popular in the South and West, where he piled up electoral numbers from a long list of smaller states. As the count tightened, there was one cheerful note for those weary of the impact of big-dollar politics. In the closest states the outcomes seemed to depend on such old-fashioned qualities as turnout, party loyalty and economic interests.
As daylight neared, the contest was so close that the networks backed off their projections and the candidates delayed plans for a concession statement on Mr. Gore's part and a victory statement from Mr. Bush. That brought to a prudent point a political suspense story that may not be resolved until recounts take place in Florida and other closely fought states.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Voters Remain Divided, to the Very End

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
After all the dollars and debates, after all the ads and adjectives, the country still found it immensely difficult to make up its mind.
And so the race for the presidency, which had seemed to teeter on a knife edge for the last few weeks of the campaign, teetered a bit more as the polls closed across the country. 
 The lead in the popular vote switched back and forth throughout the night, with Gov. George W. Bush holding a narrow lead over Vice President Al Gore as the count went into its final hours. The all-important battle for supremacy in the Electoral Ccollege came down to Florida, and early this morning, Gov. Jeb Bush seemed to have delivered a hair's-breadth victory to his brother in that fast-growing state, putting him over the top.
But Mr. Bush's margin dwindled and dwindled until only a handful of votes separated the two candidates, throwing the picture into confusion.
No overarching national themes emerged from the voting, but a few things were clear as the last ballots were tabulated, including these:
*Neither of the candidates, for all their exertions, ever closed his deal with the American public. Each candidate won overwhelming majorities among voters in their own parties, but independent voters -- the crucial quarter of the electorate that decides so many elections -- split evenly.
*In the final stages of the race, Mr. Bush faded. Among those who made up their minds in the last week, the surveys showed, slightly more than half went to Mr. Gore; among those who decided earlier, a bare majority ended up favoring Mr. Bush.
*Mr. Bush, who announced early on that he was a compassionate conservative, did a good job of rubbing the rough edges off his ideology, a better job than his rival. Voters were more likely to see Mr. Gore's positions as too liberal than to see Mr. Bush's views as too far to the right.
*To a degree difficult to quantify, President Clinton appeared to have been a drag on Mr. Gore's candidacy. Fully 60 percent of the voters interviewed from coast to coast, a startling figure, said they disliked Mr. Clinton as a person, whatever they thought of his policies. They said they will remember the president more for the scandals that plagued him than for anything else, and some of that seemed to brush off on Mr. Gore, whom voters found less honest and trustworthy than Mr. Bush.
Almost one voter in five said their vote had been cast to register opposition to Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Bush gained valuable support from the pivotal border states, running a strong campaign in Missouri, Kentucky and West Virginia. Mr. Gore put on a powerful showing in the hard-fought Great Lakes States.
Suburbanites, so avidly pursued by both nominees, split 50-50. The suburbs cast well over 40 percent of the total vote in yesterday's election.
Without the backing of labor Mr. Gore would have been in deep trouble. Mr. Bush took 60 percent of the vote in nonunion households nationwide. On the other hand, Mr. Bush was heavily dependent on the white religious right, gaining the votes of three of four people who so identified themselves.
A number of important questions remained unanswered last night, quite apart from the victor's identity.
*With neither nominee within reach of a big popular majority, and the polls suggesting a close electoral contest as well, how would the winner lead? As John F. Kennedy showed after winning in a squeaker in 1960, leaders can lead whatever their majorities, but it is hard for those who win narrowly to push broad legislative programs. Many Kennedy administration ideas came to fruition only after Lyndon B. Johnson's landslide victory in 1964.
*Is American politics entering a nonideological or an anti-ideological phase? Only six years ago, the Republicans swept into control of the House on a radical right-wing program. But they were able to enact relatively little of it, and in this election, Congressional and presidential candidates alike did their best to skitter toward the center.
*What does the country want? The candidates enunciated different views of government, with Mr. Gore espousing a more activist philosophy. When voters were asked which candidate shared their view of government, about a third said Mr. Gore, about a third said Mr. Bush, and the rest said both or neither. Yet in response to other questions, as they left the polls, voters said that they wanted less government and that they preferred economic growth to protecting the environment, another small-government view.
Mr. Bush received the votes of most people who disliked Mr. Clinton, who made their decisions on the basis of personality and who wanted across-the-board tax cuts. No surprises there. Mr. Gore won his backing among those who put the greatest emphasis on experience, grasp of the issues, targeted tax cuts and promises of health care reform. Mr. Bush had hoped that his promise of a radical overhaul of Medicare would prove popular.
Signs of confusion flowed through the voters' responses. In the surveys, almost two-thirds of the respondents said the country was on the right track as opposed to headed in the wrong direction. But in moral terms, close to 60 percent said the country was on the wrong track.
The political map and political convention were knocked askew by the results. Mr. Bush won in Florida, where his brother is governor, and Mr. Gore lost Mr. Clinton's home state, Arkansas, but his own, Tennessee. In Tennessee two-thirds of those polled said it made no difference in their voting decision that Mr. Gore was from their state.
No president has been elected without carrying his home state since Woodrow Wilson, a former governor of New Jersey, lost that state in the 1916 election.
Changing patterns of opinion formation were reflected in the survey. More than 60 percent of those questioned said they used the Internet on a regular basis, and almost 30 percent said they sought political information when they did so.
A slim majority of those who said they used the Internet cast their votes for Mr. Bush.
One big winner was the political polling trade. For weeks, as surveys disagreed with one another and showed large swings in some states, their methodology was questioned. But most of the final surveys, completed in many cases Sunday and Monday, came remarkably close to the actual votes, state by state.
The final CBS News survey, released on Election Day morning, showed Mr. Gore with a lead of one percentage point in the popular vote.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk

HEADLINE: Just Beyond Paris, a Bountiful Wilderness

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

DATELINE: ROMORANTIN-LANTHENAY, France

 BODY:
IT is in the central market at Orleans that you get the first, tantalizing whiff of the Sologne. Amid the stalls selling marble-white pyramids of goat cheese, enormous pumpkin slices and fresh vegetables from all over the Loire Valley, the more primitive foods of the hunter-gatherer can be seen. There are robust pheasants, looking asleep rather than dead, their rust-colored feathers fluttering when a passing shopper stirs up a breeze. Up and down the market, butchers slice fat slabs of boar terrine and throw furry hares and rabbits on their scales. Wicker baskets overflow with mushrooms: preposterously large cepes, ocher girolles, chubby pieds de mouton (hedgehog mushrooms) and jet-black trompettes de la mort, or black chanterelles.
Autumn is in full swing, and the forests of the Sologne are alive. You see it in the markets, in the catering shops and in the restaurants all over this compact, diamond-shaped region that begins just below Orleans and runs south to the Cher River. It's a peculiar French backwater, a kind of wooded island, dotted with thousands of ponds, that has little in common with the sunny, tourist-pleasing Loire Valley of rolling farmland, Rapunzel castles and choice vineyards. 
 Until the 19th century, it was a desperately poor region of swamps and wasteland. Napoleon III drained the swamps and planted pine forests, but even today towns are small, the population sparse, the local economy powered almost entirely by the moneyed hunters who pay top dollar for the right to hunt on private land.
In France, where for centuries the nobility jealously preserved the right to hunt, game still exudes a mysterious attraction. It has the feel of luxury, of rare privilege. Americans do not get terribly excited about the thought of a good Brunswick stew made with fresh squirrel. But France is different. A juicy cut of beef is a fine thing, but the taste of wild meat taps deep into ancestral memory. It may account in part for the aura of terror and mystery that French writers have always woven around the Sologne, making it sound like Gallic "Blair Witch" territory. Barely beyond the Paris suburbs, it is the wild frontier, a place where civilized Frenchmen can enjoy, in the most decorous possible way, a weekend's worth of barbarism -- punctuated, of course, by very fine meals.
"You see the traffic?" said Jean-Claude Chesneau, a butcher in Lamotte-Beuvron, pointing at the town's main street outside his door. "Come the weekend, you start seeing the Rolls-Royces and the Bentleys driving past. The Sologne depends entirely on hunting."
All over the region, from October to December, hunters clad in olive green descend on the local inns, carrying their disassembled rifles in neat tan cases that make them look like students on the way to a bassoon lesson. The shop windows are filled with duck-themed suspenders, neckties and highball glasses. Socks and shirts share shelf space with cans of Italian rifle grease and bags of Hog Wild, an American grain mixture that's scattered on the ground to attract wild boar. Hikers walk with a wary tread. Many a tempting forest path displays the warning sign: "Today is a hunting day. Flying bullets." The Sologne is almost certainly the only region in France with a museum of poaching.
In the United States, drivers know they're in hunting territory when the highway signs show a leaping deer. In the Sologne, the signs show boar, deer and stag, stacked one on top of the other. And it's not false advertising. "If you walk by the rivers and canals in the morning, you'll see boars and pheasants and roe deer," said Dominique Clement, the chef and owner of La Solognote, an inn in Brinon-sur-Sauldre. His wife, Andree, nodded. "Take a walk around here, and it's like a safari," she said. "No giraffes, but just about everything else."
I don't hunt. I eat. I am happy to let the hunters do my work for me, bagging pheasant, partridge, hare, roe deer, boar, mallard, marcassin (junior boar) and the tasty local rabbit known as lapin de garenne. They do an excellent job. By the time the smoke clears away each year, 40,000 sharpshooters have brought down a million and a half game birds and thousands of boar and deer.
The local chefs know what to do with the meat. The Sologne is a wonderland of game pates and terrines, of sausages and bacons, of powerfully flavored dishes thick with blood and heady with the aroma of freshly gathered mushrooms. The cuisine is not fancy. A mainstay of the bread and pastry shops is pate a la citrouille, which is nothing more than a thick layer of rough pumpkin puree, onion and chopped parsley smeared between two layers of puff pastry. (The town of Millancay holds an annual festival devoted entirely to the pumpkin.) The equally popular galette de pomme de terre is, if possible, even humbler, a potato dough rolled out like puff pastry and baked until, like a peasant with big dreams, it rises and swells.
At its best, the Sologne offers honest, clearly presented food that draws its strength from fresh local raw materials and the fecundity of the surrounding Loire Valley. The area has a sprinkling of Michelin stars, places like Bernard Robin in Bracieux and the Lion d'Or in Romorantin-Lanthenay, where the catch from field and stream gets a refined reinterpretation. But the temperament here is earthbound, as rooted in the soil as the region's magnificent cepes and girolles. It is sometimes easy to forget that the local eels are superb, or that pike swim in rivers like the Beuvron and the Sauldre.
La Solognote's menu is almost emblematic. Poached eggs with creamed cepes, rabbit gelee with onion compote, squab in a spicy bouillon, roast partridge with sauteed potatoes and girolles, roe deer fillets in pepper sauce, roasted mallard duck with spiced grapes -- the distance between the kitchen and the forest just outside the door could not have been shorter. The mallard was a revelation. Succulent and tender enough to cut with a fork, it readjusted my mental reference points for the word "gamy," which too often fails to suggest freshness as well as intensity of flavor. It's the quality that makes you understand instantly why humans are carnivores.
Mr. Clement, who has been at the stove for 38 years at La Solognote, makes few claims for his cooking. "The main thing is to push the ingredients to the fore," he said with a shrug. "You just want to make them taste the way they taste."
It was at La Solognote that I encountered the first of several versions of lievre a la royale, something I had always thought of as a precious throwback to an era when diners worried about gout rather than cholesterol. It's a dish one hesitates to describe too vividly. A hare is required, of course. The animal is stuffed with a mixture of foie gras, truffles and its own innards and surrounded by a thick blood and wine sauce. In the Sologne, the dish is as common as cheeseburgers. It made a surprise appearance as a pate at Jean Frizot's takeout shop in Lamotte-Beuvron, stuffed in the center with duck liver, and an even more surprising appearance at Bernard Robin, where the hare and liver, after being braised, were shaped into what looks like a flat devil's-food cake and surrounded with a plate-filling slick of sauce. It came to the table looking like a triple-chocolate dessert, only more filling.
I tried to inventory the game dishes in the region, stopping in front of any restaurant that looked promising and jotting down the menu highlights. It became a hopeless and even painful task, an ever-lengthening scroll of dishes that would never be enjoyed, like the civet of boar with Bourgeuil sauce at Le Mouton in La Ferte-Imbault, the venison fillets with quince and blackberry gelee at Dahu in Lamotte-Beuvron, or the chartreuse of pheasant coated in molten foie gras and pistachios at Le Colombier in Romorantin.
I could always take some comfort in the food I actually was able to eat, like the concentrated hare consomme with stuffed cabbages and sliced chestnuts at Lion d'Or, served with croutons smeared with hare pate.
I did not even try to make a list of pates and terrines. But I did eat more than a dozen of them, from chunky, gnarly boar terrines to fine-grained, brick-colored venison terrines to pale rabbit pates, the blondes of the bunch. Rarely did they disappoint. Some were crude -- unsightly meat loaves in tin-foil tubs, surrounded by congealed fat. I bought several of these at the shop of Laurent Courcelle in Lamotte-Beuvron. ("They'll keep for 10 days," the woman behind the counter assured me.) The next day I was back, begging for the recipe for his rabbit terrine.
Right down the street, Mr. Chesneau, the butcher, displayed handsome-looking terrines in large ceramic containers. His were excellent, too, especially a flamboyant, multilayered rabbit pate en croute. Minced mushrooms and pistachios alternated with big chunks of rabbit, then a thick stripe of rabbit mousse and a layer of duck liver. On top was a shingled roof of shaved almonds, sealed into place artistically with a glistening gelee.
Mr. Chesneau's couture pate was an anomaly. This was a shop, after all, with a hairy boar carcass hanging over the sidewalk, flanked by a string of shiny mallards straight from local ponds. It's a sight to give city slickers pause, but in the Sologne, customers know how to deal with a dead animal (although I'm not sure how you stuff a 250-pound boar into a Peugeot), and the average cook can make short work of a fat, furry rabbit.
At the small central market in Romorantin, the selection looks a little thin on Wednesdays. The fruits and vegetables are sparsely displayed, and customers shuffle up and down the aisles with no great enthusiasm. One stand, however, was causing a stir the day I was there. Reaching into a big bag, a vendor was pulling out pheasants, partridges, ducks and rabbits one after the other, stacking them on a counter decorated with a prime pheasant, its feathers still glossy. A crowd gathered.
The vendor had the look of a woman who knows she's offering the prime stuff, and sure enough, the game disappeared as fast as she could put it out. It was an inspiring sight: nature on its way to being transformed into culture, a hundred pates in the making, the cuisine of the Sologne being built from the ground up.
 
PATE A LA CITROUILLE
Adapted from Aux Delices de Sologne
Time: 1 hour, plus overnight refrigeration
 
1 medium onion, peeled and finely chopped
1 pound pumpkin meat, cut into 1/4-inch dice
1 tablespoon finely chopped parsley
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
 1/2 pound puff pastry dough
1 to 2 tablespoons sugar
1 egg yolk beaten with 1 teaspoon water
Vegetable oil for baking sheet.
 
1. Fill a small pan with water, and bring to a boil. Add chopped onion, and simmer 5 minutes. Drain well.
2. In a medium bowl, combine onion, pumpkin and parsley. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Cover and refrigerate overnight.
3. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. On a lightly floured surface, roll out puff pastry dough very thinly to a rectangle about 14 by 16 inches. Spread half the dough with the pumpkin mixture, coming to within 1 inch of the edges. Sprinkle with 1 to 2 tablespoons sugar, depending on the sweetness of the pumpkin and personal preference.
4. Brush edges with water, and fold dough over to enclose the pumpkin. Pierce the top of the dough with a fork, and brush with egg yolk mixture. Transfer to an oiled baking sheet. Bake until surface is golden brown and the pumpkin is tender, about 30 minutes. Serve warm.
 
Yield: 8 to 10 servings.
 
LE CANARD AUX CEPES
Adapted from "Sologne-Berry" by Sylvie Girard (Editions du Fanal, 1996)
Time: 1 hour 15 minutes
 
1 5- to 6-pound duck, preferably wild
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 sprig fresh thyme
7 tablespoons butter
2 onions, peeled and minced
2 cups full-bodied red wine
1 3/4 pounds fresh cepe (porcini) mushrooms, cleaned and cut into quarters.
 
1. Trim all excess fat from the duck, and cut into 1/2-inch pieces; reserve. Salt and pepper the duck inside and out. Rub thyme in the interior of the duck, and leave thyme inside. Truss with kitchen twine.
2. Select an oval covered casserole just big enough to hold the duck. Place over low heat, and melt 3 tablespoons butter. Add duck, raise heat to medium-high, and brown on all sides.
3. Add onions and reserved duck fat, and stir until the onions begin to soften, about 1 minute. Add 1 cup wine, and stir to deglaze the pan. Cover, reduce heat to low and simmer 20 minutes. Stir in remaining 1 cup wine, cover and cook 10 minutes.
4. Remove duck from the pan, discard twine and thyme and cut into quarters; keep warm. Return pan to high heat, and reduce liquid by one-third. Strain liquid, and return it to the pan.
5. In a large skillet over medium-low heat, melt remaining 4 tablespoons butter. Add mushrooms; season with salt and pepper to taste. Saute until mushrooms are tender, 15 minutes. Discard any liquid in skillet, and add mushrooms to pan of wine sauce. Reheat sauce. To serve, place portion of duck on each of four plates. Top with mushrooms and wine sauce, and serve immediately.
 
Yield: 4 servings.
 
VELOUTE DE CHAMPIGNONS
Adapted from Lion d'Or, Romorantin-Lanthenay
Time: 2 hours
 
1 pound fresh cepe (porcini) mushrooms
1 pound fresh girolles (chanterelles)
1 pound black trumpet or oyster mushrooms
2 quarts chicken stock or canned chicken broth
1 2/3 cups heavy cream
3 large egg yolks
8 tablespoons butter
5 1/2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
Salt
Toasted garlic-rubbed croutons, for garnish.
 
1. Clean the cepes, girolles and black trumpet mushrooms, and place half of them in a medium soup pot. Add chicken stock, and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and simmer, covered, for about an hour. Line a strainer with cheesecloth, and ; place over a bowl. Strain mushroom broth, and discard cooked mushrooms or reserve for another use.
2. In a small bowl, combine heavy cream and egg yolks. Whisk until thickened but not stiff; reserve. Place a wide soup pot or flameproof casserole over low heat. Melt 4 tablespoons of butter, and whisk in flour. Continue to whisk until the mixture is smooth and blonde, about 1 minute; do not brown. Add a small amount of the mushroom broth, whisking vigorously to keep mixture smooth. Raise the heat to medium-high, and whisk in remaining broth. Whisk until the mixture comes to a boil, and then reduce heat to low. Cover, and simmer 15 minutes.
3. Slice remaining mushrooms into large pieces, keeping cepes separate. Place a large, heavy skillet over medium-high heat, and add remaining 4 tablespoons butter. Add the cepes and saute until they are lightly browned, about 2 minutes. Add the remaining mushrooms, and continue to saute until lightly browned, another 2 to 3 minutes.
4. Place the sauteed mushrooms in the bottom of a soup tureen. Reheat the mushroom broth, and remove from heat. Add the reserved cream mixture to the broth, and stir until blended. Season with salt to taste. Pour the broth into the tureen over the mushrooms. If desired, garnish with croutons. Serve hot.
 
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.
