HEADLINE: The Tax That Gave Birth to a Small Industry

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

 BODY:
High taxes help destroy jobs, right?
Not always. Some European taxes have actually created a flourishing cottage industry. 
 In the late 1980's, the European Union started allowing European and non-European tourists and businesses to reclaim the value-added tax levied on some products and services -- an amount that could be as much as 25 percent of the money spent.
But few people -- to the delight, presumably, of European tax collectors -- bothered to claim the money.
By the mid-1990's, John H. Powell calculated that as much as $10 billion was being left in European coffers.So Mr. Powell, who had become familiar with the intricacies of the value-added tax while working at Walt Disney's business development office in Europe, started a company in Seattle that produced software that enabled companies to trace and reclaim that money.
Yet by the time he started his company, Corporate VAT Management, in 1995, he was far from alone. Dozens of companies had sprouted up for the same purpose, though with different methods, and others have since joined the pack.
In the Netherlands, Luuk Vredeveld, a business consultant, began in the 1980's to help trucking companies reclaim taxes paid on, say, fuel. Today his company, Retourtax, has clients in various industries in the United States, Japan and Canada.
In Ireland, Fexco Tax Reclaim helps tourists and corporate customers get refunds.
In France, a company called Optisoft brought out a software package called Softax to perform essentially the same task.
Europe has long favored the value-added tax, a complex system in which products and services are taxed at each stage from production to final sale. Though American legislators have shied away from it, the system has gained favor in other nations, like Canada, South Korea and most recently Australia.
Some refunds -- for purchases at an airport, for example -- are immediately available, with little paperwork and fuss.
But claiming some other refunds can be a daunting task, even for a hardened accountant. For example, business travel expenses that qualify differ by country. In Britain, where the VAT rate is 17.5 percent, eligible expenses include hotel rooms, meals (though not those for entertainment) and car rentals. In Germany, they include hotels, car rentals and meals for business entertainment.
To qualify for a refund, a business traveler must submit invoices within a certain period, which can vary by country, together with a reclaim document in the proper language. A claim for meals eaten in Denmark, for instance, must be submitted in Danish in Copenhagen.
But for many companies competing for this business, the procedure has become assembly-line simple. Clients send their invoices, which are sorted to see which qualify for refunds, and then those that qualify are forwarded to tax authorities with a refund request. Typically, a percentage of the refunded tax money -- anywhere from 7 to 20 percent -- is withheld as a fee.
Mr. Powell of Corporate VAT Management said many companies had failed to claim VAT's because of paperwork lapses or uncertainty over which expenses qualified.
Corporate VAT's latest software is designed to be applied to expense and credit card records to ferret out refundable amounts, then automatically list them and fill out the claim forms -- in the right language. He is working to persuade banks, credit card and car rental companies to use his software to program accounts to trace refundable value-added taxes. These companies could then reclaim the VAT and pass all or part of the savings to clients.
One bank that has signed on is U.S. Bancorp of Minneapolis, which this summer did blind tests of the software on expense records of some big corporate clients. Robert T. Abele, president of corporate payment systems at U.S. Bancorp, said it was urging top corporate clients to test the software. "They can get significant savings," he said. "And when we say significant, I'm talking tens of thousands of dollars."
U.S. Bancorp is also the largest issuer of Visa corporate and purchasing cards, and Mr. Abele said he believed credit card companies would embrace similar software since the use of a single corporate payment system could allow companies to automate VAT claims.
Many companies in the reclaiming business are distinctly lower technology, with much of the work done by hand. Barry O'Sullivan, marketing director at Fexco's headquarters in Kerry, Ireland, said his company's level of computerization was "a lot less than we'd like it to be."
And some in the business say software is only part of the trick.
Meridian VAT Reclaim, which set up shop in New York in 1990 and now has 30,000 clients, is the market leader in VAT refunding.
Deborah Ferolito, Meridian's president, acknowledged that software like Autovat may be "the right product for simple bread-and-butter activities." But she said many companies also require tax consultancy and legal advice. Meridian employs about 400 people in 42 offices worldwide. Last year, revenue totaled about $33 million, and roughly 40 percent of its business is now done with European companies seeking refunds elsewhere in Europe.
Ms. Ferolito says many customers are not aware of what is refundable, and in some cases, may even have paid value-added taxes erroneously.
"Some European companies, if they're not sure, they charge it," she said.
Calculations become even more complex, she said, when non-European companies set up shop in Europe and must register to pay and levy the tax.
As in most businesses, the drive for economies of scale is leading to consolidation. Last year, Fexco teamed with Apax Partners, the venture capitalists, to acquire the Global Refund Group, a VAT refund specialist in Sweden, from Cendant.
At the same time, Meridian was acquired for $190 million by the Profit Recovery Group International, an Atlanta company specializing in account auditing. Ms. Ferolito said Meridian brought its client base to the marriage, while Profit Recovery brought experience in recovering misspent money in other areas of corporate accounting, like telecommunications and shipping.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

An article in the World Business section on Nov. 8 about businesses that help companies and individuals reclaim the value-added tax levied on some products and services in Europe referred imprecisely to remarks made by Barry O'Sullivan, marketing manager at Fexco Tax Reclaim. Mr. O'Sullivan, who said that the level of computerization for processing such claims was "a lot less than we'd like it to be," was referring to the industry as a whole, not to his company in particular.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 5; Circuits 

LENGTH: 3232 words

HEADLINE: M.I.T. Media Lab at 15: Big Ideas, Big Money

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
FOR 15 years, there has been one mantra at the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology: "Demo or die."
Day after day at this famous and flashy laboratory, students and professors have demonstrated their research, impressing industry sponsors and guests with invisible sensors and wearable computers, offering a close-up look at some of the lab's most notable innovations, like programmable Legos and electronic ink. 
 The constant demonstrations may sound like unusual behavior for an academic institution, but that is how the Media Lab survives: embarking on pie-in-the-sky research while simultaneously convincing companies that its ideas are worth the cost of sponsorship, which runs in the hundreds of thousands of dollars for each company each year.
On one show-and-tell day last month, those dual roles, and the complicated issues they raise, were on display. The laboratory had invited more than a hundred potential sponsors to see its latest research, and throughout the day a gaggle of guests padded around the lab's five-story building, peering at projects and gleaning ideas from researchers who seemed eager to offer them.
But by late afternoon, as the visitors trickled into a meeting in the building's auditorium, the academic atmosphere gave way to businesslike reality. Walter Bender, a founding member of the lab and its newly appointed executive director, took the stage.
"The Media Lab is changing," he said, beginning to make his pitch. "We are not a start-up organization anymore." He said it was time for Media Lab 2.0., a bigger, broader and more influential organization than ever before.The lab, he said, had more revolutionary ideas to offer and more technology to produce. But, he added, it needed money -- at least $250,000 a year, to be precise, from every organization represented in the room.
The auditorium filled with an uncomfortable silence. Unasked questions hung in the air: What would that money deliver? Would it be worth the price? And how exactly does the lab keep up this juggling act, serving commercial needs while trying to serve nonprofit ideals?
Those questions are at the heart of simmering debates about the laboratory, where there has seldom been a shortage of controversy, or publicity, since it was founded in 1985. Some of the issues are longstanding ones, raised by researchers at other institutions who wonder whether the Media Lab's innovations have made any substantial impact.
But the latest uncertainties have emerged from within the lab itself. Just as the Media Lab has decided to expand, its professors, students and even a few sponsors are starting to wonder how it can remain an open arena for exchanging ideas in an age of start-up companies, competitive research and sudden riches for those who turn their innovations into products.
Many students, for example, harbor hopes of turning their own ideas into companies, reaping the financial benefits of initial public offerings. Debates rage over whether new innovations should be freely disseminated or patented in hopes of generating royalties. And several professors have decided to join or start technology companies while maintaining their roles as Media Lab faculty members, leading to potential conflicts of interest.
That last development seems to be most disturbing to Nicholas Negroponte, the laboratory co-founder who, within technology circles, is nothing short of a celebrity. When asked how he felt about professors who started companies, he did not hesitate. "I get a level of heartburn," he said. "It is a very agonizing situation."
Clearly, at 15, the Media Lab is struggling through some awkward changes. The question is, What kind of an adult is it going to become?
When the doors opened to its white-tiled building on M.I.T.'s east campus in 1985, the Media Lab was an oddity. As an experimental blending of art and technology, it was led by Mr. Negroponte, a charismatic and visionary maverick from the architecture school who had started building a team of multidisciplinary researchers more than five years before. At the core of their mission was an exploration of Mr. Negroponte's insistence that text, video and sound would someday merge in digital unity.
Fifteen years later, Mr. Negroponte's vision is largely considered to have been on target. His 1995 book on the subject, "Being Digital," has been translated into 40 languages and by many measures, his laboratory has achieved overwhelming success.
 
Vision Confronts Reality
Today nearly 160 companies (as well as a few nonprofit organizations) are sponsors of the center, which is the academic home of about 400 students, professors and research scientists. Each year, as many as 10,000 people are guided through its dimly lit and seemingly chaotic chambers, where bean bags and stuffed animals share space with video screens, circuit boards and radio transmitters.
Some sense of the laboratory's ideals was incorporated into its physical shell, the Wiesner Building, which was named after Jerome Wiesner, the former M.I.T. president who founded the center with Mr. Negroponte. The building was designed by the architect I. M. Pei, and its internal structure was intended to be a symbol of openness.
There are no long hallways with closed doors. Instead, huge open rooms full of movable furniture make up its core, and many spaces are ringed by offices with interior walls of glass. The glass was intended to stimulate as much sharing as possible among the many disciplines that converged there -- whether electrical engineering or music -- while also offering visitors a chance to see what was being developed.
That same openness was supposed to be reflected in the Media Lab's policies on fund-raising and intellectual property. While other academic laboratories have come under fire for being too quick to coddle commercial interests, the Media Lab has always proclaimed itself to be different.
Elsewhere, technology professors have been accused of accepting corporate grants for research that merely serves companies' short-term needs or that restricts how much of their work can be shared with colleagues, even those in their own departments.
The Media Lab, by contrast, signs very few contracts for what is called directed research, in which companies tell university researchers to develop technology that will achieve a specific outcome. Instead, the Media Lab tries to have it both ways: it attempts to keep its research open-ended and accessible, even though 90 percent of the lab's $35 million budget comes from its sponsors.
In return for the money, sponsors have access to any innovations that come out of the lab. They may visit at any time and get royalty-free licenses for any technology that is patented during their membership. The pool of patents prohibits any sponsor -- whether it is Kodak, Motorola or any of the other mammoth companies that have joined -- to have an edge over any other. Contracts for exclusive access to patents are considered taboo. (The laboratory does, however, sign contracts that exclude companies that are not sponsors from licenses to Media Lab patents for a few years.)
"It means that I don't have to hide anything from anybody," said Dr. Justine Cassell, an assistant professor who leads research into how human gestures and expressions can be deciphered by machines and incorporated into computer interfaces.
Dr. Cassell, however, is one of the Media Lab professors who have not started their own companies. Others have, and though they stress that their primary allegiance is to the lab, no one disputes that their dual roles are a touchy subject. A recent article in Technology Review, an M.I.T. magazine, exposed some of that internal hand-wringing, and its publication has created an even more guarded and distrustful climate.
Dr. Joe Jacobson, for example, is the professor who led the lab's research into electronic ink, which responds to changing electromagnetic fields to form words or images that can be read on paper. Three years ago, he and two of his former graduate students, J. D. Albert and Barrett Comiskey, started E Ink, a private company in Cambridge. Today, Dr. Jacobson sits on its board.
The company is not a sponsor of the Media Lab (M.I.T. rules prohibit professors from having more than a 5 percent stake in a sponsoring company), and it uses some technology that was developed by Dr. Jacobson before he arrived at M.I.T. So when the lab's sponsors ask to use electronic ink, they often find that it is not exactly free for them to use at will. Instead, Dr. Jacobson refers them to his company, which can sell them the product or invite them to become investors.
"There is very nice cross-fertilization in that regard," Dr. Jacobson said.
The E Ink case "is one we are trying to learn from," said Bruce Bullock, the lab's managing director and moderator of its intellectual property committee. He added, "E Ink was done at an early time when a lot of these problems were not understood." The laboratory is now looking closely at the work conducted by incoming professors, Mr. Bullock said, to "make sure that doesn't happen again."
Yet even working with companies that are sponsors can cause conflicts. Last year, when Dr. Alex Pentland, the lab's academic chief, helped with a sponsor's exhibition at a large technology conference in New York, he had to shift between his role as a professor and his role as adviser to the company, now known as Charmed Technologies. He was wearing a denim jacket that showcased a Media Lab innovation: embroidery sewn with conductive thread, some of which served as a functional keypad. But because that e-embroidery was developed years before the company became a sponsor, it was not something that Charmed was allowed to call its own.
To avoid the appearance that he was providing that technology to Charmed, Dr. Pentland asked to be excluded from news media photographs. (Today, he said, he is no longer an adviser to the company.)
"Faculty operate with several hats on," Dr. Pentland said. "It is up to the faculty members to maintain a separation." In addition, professors at M.I.T. and elsewhere are bound by rules restricting the number of days per week they may spend as consultants; at M.I.T., the limit is one day in five.
Problems of intellectual property also arise when students want to start companies. Last year, when the technology market was at its peak, graduate students with innovative ideas started to think seriously about leaving the laboratory. Inside the Media Lab they were required to divulge their ideas to sponsors, who might have been potential competitors. But some graduate students reasoned that if they left, they could pursue their research in private.
To prevent a loss of talented students, faculty members at the Media Lab began to talk about giving graduates the same rights to intellectual property as the lab's sponsors. Then they ran into a roadblock. Granting alumni royalty-free access to patents ran counter to the university's patent policy, under which professors and students typically pay M.I.T. -- either in royalties, licensing fees or equity -- to use any technology they created during their tenure. .
 
Changing Course
In some ways, that Wednesday gathering in October was the laboratory's attempt to move away from that money-driven and conflict-laden world. Many of the people who were shifting uncomfortably in their seats during the laboratory's marketing pitch were representatives of nonprofit organizations or from governmental offices in developing countries like Ghana and Costa Rica. This was the official unveiling of Digital Nations, an attempt to use technology to tackle some of the developing world's most vexing problems, like illiteracy, poor health and economic instability.
To disseminate and finance its work, the laboratory is asking governments and nonprofit organizations to become members, either by paying the annual fee out of their own pockets or by finding foundations and companies to become their patrons.
But in fact, this latest project may lead the Media Lab into even more uncharted territory regarding ownership rights and the free dissemination of ideas. Because the laboratory is not yet sure about how -- or whether -- to grant countries access to its patents, it is giving them only the privilege of visiting and working with its professors, consulting style.
What's more, the laboratory may find that it is asking for a sharing of ideas among countries that may have few traditions of academic freedom or long histories of conflict with one another.
"We're treading into some dangerous waters here," Dr. Pentland said, adding that the tension between commercial and academic interests "may look mild in comparison."
Meanwhile, the laboratory is charging ahead with a major expansion. A $100 million seven-story building has been planned to augment the laboratory's Cambridge operations. A second laboratory is being erected in Dublin, in what was once a Guinness brewery. Several professors at the laboratory have talked about establishing similar branches in Asia and Latin America.
To cope with the Media Lab's swelling size, Mr. Negroponte has appointed Mr. Bender, a senior scientist who led the organization's electronic publishing work, as executive director. Mr. Negroponte -- a tall, commanding presence who is known for his crisp striped dress shirts and his talents of persuasion -- has become senior director and is continuing what he has been doing for the past several years: touring the globe to give keynote addresses and raise money.
The responsibility for the laboratory's day-to-day operations now falls to Mr. Bender, a low-key and amiable scientist who wears sweaters and khakis and happens to be a longtime co-captain of the laboratory's softball team. Like Mr. Negroponte, he also hails from the architecture school and, like many in that profession, does not have a Ph.D. But he has been doing research and teaching all his life. His primary goal, he said, is to see the Media Lab's hands-on, interdisciplinary model spread to other places.
 
Making Its Mark
He may first have to defend the laboratory from perennial accusations that it is little more than a publicity machine. Several laboratories conduct similar research but attract far less media attention, and their founders have been known to contend, however subtly, that their innovations are more substantial than those that emerge from under Mr. Negroponte's umbrella.
"Ideas come very quickly, but can you reduce it to practice and is it going to make a difference?" asked Dr. Dan Siewiorek, director of the Human-Computer Interaction Institute at Carnegie Mellon University. As an example, he described Carnegie Mellon research on robust wearable computers that are now being used by the U.S. Marine Corps..
Dr. Michael Dertouzos, the head of the M.I.T. Laboratory for Computer Science, said he credited the Media Lab, and Mr. Negroponte particularly, "with having seen, way back, the merger of media broadcasting and print." But Dr. Dertouzos also ticked off a list of new technology that had come out of his laboratory, such as Ethernet connections, computer time-sharing, spreadsheets and the core technology for an encryption system used widely on the Web.
"Our stuff is stuff that works," he said.
To be fair, the Media Lab has had its share of successful technological innovations, including safer air bags for automobiles. And one of the laboratory's first inventions was the technology behind Lego Mindstorms, programmable Legos that are considered one of the hottest toys of the decade.
A few companies have dropped their membership over the years, including Nike, Xerox and The New York Times Company.
But most sponsors say they find the laboratory's work worth the annual fee. For example, one of the newest sponsors, Saab Marine Electronics, has already decided to employ some of the laboratory's remote-sensing technology to determine precisely how much gasoline or oil is present in storage tanks without relying on gadgets that use moving parts or that could introduce contaminants.
Mr. Bender vigorously defends the laboratory's academic standards and professional reputation. All faculty members must meet the university's standards for tenure, he said, and graduate students as well as professors publish often in academic and professional journals.
When in 1996 the I.B.M. Systems Journal published an issue dedicated to research at the Media Lab, for example, it became the journal's most popular issue ever. At the beginning of November, the journal came out with yet another Media Lab extravaganza, containing 29 articles about research that included research on using hyperlinks in televisionbroadcasts and the creation of tiny computational devices.
 
The Challenges Ahead
Professors at the Media Lab also plead for perspective regarding its potential for conflicts of interest. If the Media Lab has hit its troubled teenage years, they say, it is merely a microcosm of a larger struggle being played out in universities everywhere. Forty years ago, research in science and technology was financed largely by the federal government, which was supposed to act in the public interest. Now as corporations fill more of that role, a question hangs over every project: whose interest is being served, the public's or the company's shareholders?
Add a culture of start-up companies to the mix, and academic ideals take an even harder pounding. "I had a student who once asked me to sign a nondisclosure form before I could grade her homework," said Dr. Randy Pausch, a professor of design and computer science at Carnegie Mellon.
Yet university laboratories do not seem to be shying away from corporate sponsorships and entrepreneurship. If anything, they are building more of these complicated relationships. Carnegie Mellon, which started a doctoral program this year in its Human-Computer Interaction Institute, is offering company-sponsored courses that have students design devices for those sponsors. And the Georgia Center for Advanced Telecommunications Technology at the Georgia Institute of Technology has dedicated the entire fourth floor of its building to assisting and sheltering new companies.
Mr. Negroponte has argued that the Media Lab's model of shared intellectual property is more likely to keep research open among professors, students and sponsors than exclusive agreements with companies. "Some are saying it's worn out its welcome," he said, referring to scientists at the laboratory who want to develop products outside the Media Lab. "I'm not so sure."
Few Media Lab professors are sure, either, of how the laboratory will weather the challenges it faces. But anyone visiting the Media Lab can at least get a look at its future physical presence. An architectural model of the new building, which is scheduled to open in 2004, sits in a glass display case on the Wiesner Building's lowest level. Like the current structure, it includes wide-open floors and staircases.
But on the outside, thin translucent shades -- something like venetian blinds -- hang against the building's surface. Are they supposed to be letting light in, or obscuring the view of what is inside? At this point, it is hard to tell.

HEADLINE: Coca Conflict in Colombia Snares the Innocent

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: SAN MIGUEL, Colombia, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The 16 cars were lined up in a row, their drivers pushed to the side of the road at gunpoint. Then the rebel leader waved his weapon and gave an order, "Get the gasoline, and start lighting."
Moments later, one vehicle after another was ablaze, with black plumes of smoke filling the blue sky. The Colombian guerrillas, AK-47's hanging from their shoulders, ran from exploding Toyota jeeps and old Ford trucks as the stunned owners watched silently. 
 The drivers had merely wanted to pick up some food and fuel in neighboring Ecuador and return to their homes. But in doing so they had flouted the most basic of laws here in Putumayo, a Vermont-sized province of coca-growing jungle and a crucial battleground in the country's civil conflict. The Marxist rebels have banned everyone from traveling Putumayo's rocky roads, strangling the local economy.
The upheaval underscores the challenge that President Andres Pastrana faces as he works with the American government in imposing a $7.5 billion plan to curtail the lucrative coca trade and weaken the rebels.
For all the financial and military aid that Washington is providing, much of the countryside in Putumayo is controlled by the rebels. Guerrillas patrol the smaller communities, and their roadblocks have resulted in dwindling food supplies in many communities.
Guerrilla checkpoints -- typically a handful of men standing by the side of the road with AK-47's and jugs of gasoline -- seem to pop up anywhere. Behind every turn a driver risks losing his car or worse.
"They just took it, and this is all I have, these keys," said Javier Pimiento, 22, who was only a few hundred yards inside Colombia from the bridge to Ecuador when he was ordered from his car. "I feel terrible. I can't even bring food home. They have a conflict going, but why get us involved?"
The rebels are unfazed by the fact that the villagers they profess to support have suffered in this latest of several vehicle burnings. They justified their actions by saying the drivers had been ferrying military provisions.
This sparsely populated corner of the country has become hotly contested because about half of Colombia's coca crop is grown here. With the province a major focus of the government's anti-drug plan, American-trained counterinsurgency battalions, working with the national police, will by next year take aim at the drug traffickers and laboratories that process coca leaves into the paste used to make cocaine.
But it won't be easy, the government concedes.
Col. Gabriel Diaz, commander of the Colombian military's 24th Brigade in Putumayo, said the burning of cars and trucks by the guerrillas was intended to make it more difficult for the government to attack the cocaine industry.
"They want the people to feel hunger," the colonel said, "and possibly provoke a protest and a confrontation with the government forces."
For their part, the rebels say the destruction is meant to send a message to the government in Bogota: rein in the paramilitary gunmen. Paramilitary forces have been battling the rebels in Putumayo in a series of ferocious skirmishes since September.
"We have to show them that we're a force," said a rebel leader who goes by the nom de guerre Olbani. "That we're capable of paralyzing the whole country."
He accused the Colombian forces of working with the notorious paramilitary gunmen of the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, who are the main challengers to the rebels' control of the coca fields here. Human rights groups say the Self-Defense Forces are responsible for widespread massacres of villagers and have ties to rogue elements in the military, a charge the government has long denied.
The stranglehold has been especially hard on towns like Puerto Asis, La Dorada and La Hormiga, which the rebels say are hotbeds of paramilitary activity. Asserting that the government has not done enough, despite airlifts to ease the food shortages, officials from across Putumayo are planning to travel to Bogota in a convoy of cars, possibily on Sunday, as a sign of protest.
But many people have given up on living here. At least 1,100 refugees now live in Lago Agrio, Ecuador, all but 38 of them in the homes of relatives or friends, according to the relief organization that has coordinated shelter for them. An estimated 5,000 to 10,000 more have avoided the roadblocks by traversing Ecuador and re-entering Colombia through the western province of Narino, where many have roots.
Jose Pablo Pascal, who fled La Dorada on Saturday to join his wife and five children in Ecuador, is now sleeping on the concrete floor of a friend's kitchen, next to a sack of potatoes and the refrigerator.
"What terrorized us was the fear," Mr. Pascal, 42, said. "You didn't know if when you went to sleep that something wouldn't happen. You couldn't even sleep."
At a small house in Lago Agrio that is sheltering eight families, refugees said that they were afraid of being attacked by guerrillas or paramilitaries operating in their communities.
"We were in the middle of the conflict, and so we had to get out," said Roberto Rosero. "Where we were, we had guerrillas and then just over the bend were the paramilitaries, and they were fighting all the time."
Relief workers in Ecuador have been working to complete four other shelters, which together will be able to house 230 people.
"We think that the problem is just starting, and it's going to get worse," said Gribaldo Cueva, one of the workers. "With the combat between the guerrillas and the paramilitaries in the countryside, more people will be coming."
Both the rebels and paramilitaries appear firmly established and prepared to fight for months on end. In the countryside, guerrillas are such a presence that they have taken part in the meetings farmers have lately held with local officials to discuss coca eradication efforts. In towns like Puerto Asis and La Hormiga, meanwhile, residents quietly point out the paramilitary gunmen drinking at the local bar or enjoying a snow cone in the town plaza.
The government, though, does have a presence, and engagements between soldiers and rebels are not unusual. This year, 22 guerrillas have been killed by the military in combat in Putumayo and 16 others have been captured, said Colonel Diaz, reading from the latest battlefield reports. But he acknowledges that his forces cannot be everywhere.
On Sunday, just a day after the burning of the cars, government counterinsurgency troops could be seen patrolling on foot stretches of road that rebels had occupied the day before. Near the community of El Tigre, a patrol leader was asked why the military had not stopped the rebels from burning the cars.
"We couldn't get there fast enough," he said. "It's too far, and you can't take the road anyway because of the ambushes."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
SOUTH

BYLINE: This report was written by Elizabeth Becker, John H. Cushman Jr., Nichole M. Christian, Abby Goodnough, Laura Mansnerus, Todd S. Purdum, Diana Jean Schemo, Jacques Steinberg, Matthew L. Wald, Amy Waldman and Kate Zernike.

 BODY:

NORTH CAROLINA BUSH
Gov. George W. Bush won North Carolina, but so did the Democratic candidate for governor, Attorney General Mike Easley. And heavy spending by the two parties' national Congressional campaign committees seemed to have little effect in races where they were trying to shift House seats from one party to the other. 
 Mr. Easley defeated Richard Vinroot, the former mayor of Charlotte, to fill the seat of Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., a Democrat, who is leaving because of a term limit. Partly on the strength of name recognition in the eastern part of the state, his home territory, Mr. Easley had led in the race from the outset. He put together a traditional Democratic coalition in an economically and culturally diverse state, and interviews with voters showed that he did especially well among liberals, African-Americans and the less affluent. He ran on a platform that resembled Al Gore's in some ways, such as his emphasis on prescription drug benefits, but with a tilt to the center that resembled George Bush's strategy of avoiding ideological extremes -- and it worked for him.
In two House districts, though, Republican incumbents held off Democrats who had been trying, despite Mr. Bush's coattails, to take away their seats.
In the 11th District, the incumbent Republican, Charles H. Taylor, defeated Sam Neill, a Democratic lawyer running for elected office for the first time.
And in the Eighth District, the freshman Republican incumbent, Robin Hayes, defeated Mike Taylor, the Democratic challenger.
North Carolina also approved $3.1 billion in bonds for higher education. It was the biggest bond issue in the state's history.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Honest brokers separate policy from sausage for the White House.

BYLINE: By Alan B. Krueger; This column appears here every Thursday. Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives.

 BODY:
NO president has been as well versed in economics as Josiah Bartlet, the character played by Martin Sheen on "West Wing." Bartlet, a former economics professor and Nobel prize winner, rarely needs advice on economics from his staff. Nonfictional presidents, however, must rely on their advisers to make decisions. The way economic advice is organized can determine the success of a president's program. The National Economic Council provides a good model for future White Houses. 
 During the 1992 campaign, Bill Clinton announced that he would create a National Economic Council to elevate economic policy in the White House to the same status as national security and to coordinate advice from cabinet secretaries on issues ranging from public investment and deficit reduction to free trade. In 1997 he called the council "the single most significant organizational innovation that our administration has made in the White House."
George W. Bush promised to pay attention to expert advisers in his campaign. Mr. Bush's advisers suspect that if elected he will create a coordinating body similar in several respects to the National Economic Council because he likes to hear competing views before reaching a decision.
Al Gore is sure to maintain the National Economic Council if he should pull out a Florida victory.
Robert E. Rubin was the first director of the council. Under Mr. Rubin and his successors, Laura Tyson and Gene Sperling, the council coordinated domestic and international economic policy. The director and staff of about 30 met frequently with six departments -- Treasury, the Council of Economic Advisers, the Office of Management and Budget, Commerce, Labor and the trade representative. Legislative and communications aides were added to this group. Other departments were consulted when issues in their realms arose.
Unresolved issues were addressed at the cabinet level. Competing options for handling major policy issues were presented to the president for his decision.
Economic policy increasingly involves complex issues that cut across federal agencies. Climate change policy, for example, involved nine departments. A coherent policy requires coordination and cooperation across diverse agencies.
Mr. Rubin said two elements were essential for an organization like the National Economic Council to be effective. First, beginning with the transition, the president-elect and his chief of staff must insist that cabinet members work within the council's framework instead of running to the president to plead their case. Second, the council's director must be perceived as an honest broker who fairly represents relevant cabinet members' views before the president, without exploiting his proximity to the president to advocate his own agenda.
"The N.E.C. at its core is a commitment to trust a fair and transparent process," Mr. Sperling said. This process involves common-sense practices, like allowing cabinet secretaries to send dissenting memos along with the council's decision memo to the president or encouraging agencies to review a council memo to make sure their views are accurately represented.
Trust in the process reduces the likelihood that cabinet secretaries will leak damaging information to the news media. Leaks can undermine policy initiatives, poison relationships and create unnecessary volatility in financial markets.
Roger B. Porter, a former assistant to President George Bush for economic and domestic policy and now a professor at Harvard, stressed that regardless of who wins, it is important for the president-elect to appoint individuals to various positions who will work together as a team.
One measure of the council's success is the rarity of public disputes among President Clinton's economic advisers. In his new book, "The White House Staff," which should be required reading for any transition team, Bradley Patterson observes that "the key to effective cooperation was not so much institutional arrangements but personal trust and respect."
"The main accomplishment of the N.E.C. process," said former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, "was the first budget, which launched the twin goals of reducing the deficit and shifting spending toward public investment in education, training, basic research and infrastructure." Its main disappointment: the failure to wrest coordination of the health care plan from Ira Magaziner.
Although longer lasting than its predecessors, the National Economic Council is not unique. Almost all presidents since Eisenhower have had a group that coordinated economic policy. President Gerald R. Ford described his Economic Policy Board, the closest cousin to the N.E.C., as "the most important institutional innovation of my administration."
But many presidents have relied on the Treasury secretary to coordinate economic policy. It is impossible for a cabinet secretary to be an honest broker and an advocate for his department. Budget policy was orchestrated almost exclusively by the O.M.B. in the Bush and Reagan administrations, with relatively little coordination or cooperation across departments.
Before the council was established, there was concern it would subordinate the Council of Economic Advisers, a small group of professional economists who provide technical analysis for the president.
Early on, however, the National Economic Council elevated the Council of Economic Advisers, freeing it to advocate efficient economic programs and ensuring that the president had its input. The influence of the Council of Economic Advisers waned over time but only partly as a result of the National Economic Council. The new administration could reverse this slide by reviving the Council of Economic Advisers' in-person weekly briefing of the president.
Why does it matter how the policy process is organized? Professor Porter gave three reasons. First, "the president needs and deserves a process that exposes him to all the views he should take into account, and the best views available in the government." Second, the process illuminates the interrelationship among various policies. Third, once a decision is made, the president needs a system to carry it out.
As President Bartlet acutely observed last season: "Decisions are made by those who show up." To be most effective, the White House must structure economic advice to the president so all relevant views are represented and vetted in a fair process. This is best accomplished if an honest broker close to the president is responsible for coordinating the economic policy process behind the scenes.

HEADLINE: Argentina, Wobbly, Clears a Borrowing Hurdle

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Argentina's auction of $1.1 billion in treasury bills this week has put the government over a major short-term financial hurdle, but the borrowing costs -- at rates reaching 16 percent -- reflect growing worries that even heavier political and economic hurdles lie ahead.
Of all the countries in South America, only Ecuador now has a higher risk premium than Argentina reflected in its interest rates. Colombia and Venezuela, two nations with many political uncertainties, now have an easier time borrowing money. 
 Some financial analysts are going so far as to warn that Argentina, Latin America's biggest borrower, could be the next emerging-market nation to suffer a financial crisis, one that could hurt the economy of neighboring Brazil and others beyond. On Tuesday, Brazil's currency declined further despite improving economic performance there, as currency traders watched the Argentine bond auction with trepidation.
"Argentina is now the focus of the emerging markets," said Tulio Vera, manager and chief debt strategist at Merrill Lynch. He added that while "it is a bit of a relief" that Argentina did not put off the auction and successfully rolled over debt, albeit at the highest rates of the year, "the concerns are still there and the risks are still there."
A wide range of Argentine economists say there is virtually no chance that the country, which has South America's second-largest economy, will default on its $123 billion of foreign debt, suspend payments or be forced to remove its currency's trading-rate link to the United States dollar.
But jitters grew over the last week, after Standard & Poor's placed Argentina on a credit watch, and former President Raul Alfonsin, a leader of the governing Alianza coalition, wondered aloud how much better Argentina would be if it could invest $20 billion next year rather than have to use it to pay interest on its debts.
Interbank interest rates here have now reached the highest levels since the Mexico peso crisis in 1995.
James Barrineau, vice president for emerging markets research at Alliance Capital Management, remarked: "After an extended period of time of waiting for growth, there is market skepticism that the Argentine model -- an inflexible exchange rate, raising taxes to cut the deficit -- works. And if it doesn't, eventually the market will not finance a growing debt burden with no growth."
Argentina is in the depths of recession. The economy shrank by 3 percent in 1999, though this year most economists project growth around 1 percent. The government forecasts 4 percent growth in 2001, with help from exports, including a hoped-for increase in farm prices and expectations that the value of the euro will firm up and help trade with European countries.
There are some recent signs of improvement in Argentine supermarket sales, construction and manufacturing output, as well as increases in private-sector borrowing, that suggest to some that the worst economic news may be over.
But tax receipts this year have been disappointing, and an unresolved Senate bribery scandal has led in recent weeks to the resignation of the vice president, a shake-up of the cabinet, and persistent doubts about President Fernando de la Rua's continued ability to govern.
Of the $1.1 billion in treasury bills auctioned on Tuesday, $500 million were priced to yield 16 percent, up from 8.9 percent when similar debt instruments were auctioned in July. The value of the Argentine bonds at one point during the trading session were driven down on foreign markets to the lowest level since Brazil devalued its currency in January 1999.
Argentina must raise $19.5 billion to finance its debt obligations next year. That should not be a major problem, most economists say, as long as President de la Rua can manage to keep the governing coalition together and push through Congress a 2001 budget including $700 million in spending cuts to meet fiscal targets of the International Monetary Fund.
Two weeks ago, the government shifted policy, announcing a new fiscal plan, including measures to reduce taxes on corporate debt payments and on payroll taxes for high-technology companies. Even critics say the new plan could decrease production costs in private industry by 2 or 3 percent, helping to make Argentine products more competitive on world markets.
The view from Argentina tends to be more optimistic than the perspective expressed by bond traders and analysts abroad. Argentine economists in and out of the government point out that bank deposits remain steady, unlike the situation in past crises when capital flight led to financial breakdown and devaluation.
"There is a very exaggerated pessimism outside the country with respect to the true situation in Argentina," said Domingo Cavallo, a former economy minister who now leads a conservative political party in Congress. "There is no reason Argentina cannot meet its obligations."
Mr. Cavallo, who was the chief architect of the dollar peg and other free-market changes in the early 90's, has been drawing closer to the government. This is expected to help in gaining passage of the budget and bolstering confidence in international markets for Mr. de la Rua and his beleaguered economy minister, Jose Luis Machinea.
Mr. Cavallo told reporters this week that Argentina can regain the 7 percent annual growth rate it enjoyed in the early 90's by making adjustments in policy, like reducing regulations and corporate taxes much further than the government now proposes.
There is growing talk that Mr. Cavallo could join the government economic team in coming months, with the government then shifting away from its emphasis on austerity in favor of a supply-side boost of domestic demand through sharply lower taxes and regulation.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A Bond Buyer's View Of the Close Election

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Bond traders are supposed to dislike uncertainty. Yet when they woke up the morning after Election Day still not knowing for sure who would occupy the White House next year, traders took the news in stride. As a result, interest rates and the dollar were little changed yesterday.
Why the minimal reaction? Because, traders said, for the last few weeks the bond market had been expecting Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to win the presidency. And the outcome, despite the narrowness of the race and the lingering doubt over the results in Florida, suggested to them that Mr. Bush was more likely than not to emerge victorious. 
 "The bond market is telling us today that there is a good shot that Bush is the guy," Thomas Connor, the head government trader at J. P. Morgan Securities, said.
Investors had sold bonds and pushed interest rates higher in recent weeks, analysts said, because Mr. Bush's promise of a $1.3 trillion tax cut was seen as a bigger threat to the projected government surpluses than Vice President Gore's budget proposals.
All during the campaign, Mr. Gore, with his promise to reserve more of the surplus to pay down the federal debt, was considered by traders to be somewhat better than Governor Bush for bonds. And if Mr. Gore does win the Florida recount and the presidency, there could be a rally in bonds.
But if Mr. Bush wins, the outlook in the bond market could then become cloudier as investors wait to see how a Republican Congress and the Republican president run Washington together for the first time since 1955.
There are several factors that limit any big move up in interest rates on a Bush victory, which is why traders and analysts do not expect interest rates to move much higher than their present levels for the time being. The yield on the Treasury's new 10-year note was at 5.84 percent in late trading yesterday, down from 5.86 percent on Tuesday but up from 5.62 percent Oct. 23.
Despite the difference between Republicans and Democrats on taxes and spending, the two parties have moved much closer on overall economic policy since Ronald Reagan won the presidency in 1980. In addition, the economy appears to be slowing from its brisk growth rate of the last several years, which should keep some downward pressure on interest rates. And no tax cuts or spending increases will be able to change that outlook immediately.
Lastly, the Federal Reserve is a formidable presence. Analysts do not expect any change that would divert the central bank from its mission of doing whatever is necessary to keep inflation in check.
The bond market, however, has been surprised before. During Bill Clinton's election race in 1992, the bond market sold off and long-term interest rates moved higher as it became clear that Mr. Clinton was going to defeat Mr. Bush's father.
But the new administration made clear quickly that its highest priority would be to reduce the deficit, a stance that pleased the bond market and set off a move that sent long-term interest rates in 1993 to their lowest levels in more than 25 years.
Now that interest rates are relatively low, if anything is likely to surprise the market over the next few months, analysts said, it would be evidence that Mr. Bush might be able actually to achieve much of the big tax cut he has proposed.
For investors in the bond market, further uncertainty rests on several crucial decisions Mr. Bush would have to make if he wins the White House. What kind of tax cut will he actually offer? Will he stick to the outline offered in his campaign, fearing the memories of his father's broken "read my lips" pledge?
For bond investors there is also a question of who the next Treasury secretary will be. The new president will also have two vacancies to fill on the Federal Reserve Board, which will send important signals about policy. And there is a question of what Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve will do. He is expected to stay on at least until his term as chairman ends in early 2004, but he will be 75 in March.
So despite the initial calm, there is still the possibility of significant volatility in the bond market. "And the uncertainty won't get resolved quickly," said Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Republican control of the White House and the Congress would rob investors of the gridlock, a divided government that made it difficult for either party to accomplish much, that many were hoping for. Wall Street, analysts mused in the weeks leading up to the election, preferred do-nothing to do-something.
While many analysts are saying that the very narrow margins of Republican control in the both the House and the Senate will keep Washington as close to gridlock as possible without a divided government, there is no assurance of that. Democrats may be willing to go along with substantial tax cuts, including a repeal of the so-called marriage penalty and a reduction, if not an elimination, of the estate tax. And Mr. Bush could be willing to give Democrats some of the spending increases they want in exchange for support. "It is not true that Bush wants his tax cut and the Democrats want fiscal rectitude," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company in Rye Brook, N.Y. "The Democrats simply have a different wish list."
In that case, Mr. Barbera said, Mr. Bush would be pursuing a budget that would stimulate the economy, even if the Federal Reserve might be seeking to slow growth. That is a combination bond investors would hate: the threat of new growth pushing inflation higher and the threat of the Fed's raising interest rates to keep growth and prices in check.
But if the economy has slowed enough to allow the Fed to shift its sights from curbing inflation to promoting growth again, then there will be little conflict.
Bond investors will also be waiting for a signal from a new Bush administration over its approach to buying back existing Treasury securities. The budget surplus, which is the reason for the buybacks, is projected to be $268 billion in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. That means the buybacks probably will continue, a positive for the bond market.
But the size of the surpluses in later years will depend on what Mr. Bush and a barely Republican Congress accomplish. Although some bond investors, like Mr. Connor of J. P. Morgan, expect them to disappear, it is still too early to handicap that prediction with any certainty.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
MIDWEST

BYLINE: This report was written by Elizabeth Becker, John H. Cushman Jr., Nichole M. Christian, Abby Goodnough, Laura Mansnerus, Todd S. Purdum, Diana Jean Schemo, Jacques Steinberg, Matthew L. Wald, Amy Waldman and Kate Zernike.

 BODY:

MINNESOTA GORE
Vice President Al Gore was declared the winner of Minnesota's 10 electoral college votes by less than 3 percent in the wee hours of Wednesday morning. But what was surprising was that he had to fight for them at all in such a liberal state. 
 Ralph Nader ran strong here, winning more than 5 percent of the vote. But exit polls showed he did not tilt the election away from Gore; he took as many votes away from Texas Governor George W. Bush.
Rather, analysts said, Mr. Gore alienated a lot of recreational hunters by suggesting that all guns, not just handguns, should be registered.
"Word of mouth on the gun position moves very quickly, and that really hurt him," said David Lanegran, a professor of geography at Macalester College in St. Paul, who has written on the state's politics. "These are people in the suburbs who hunt, not guys in the backwoods. A lot of moderate Republicans, who might have gone for the good economy and all those normal issues, he had to struggle for.
"We're a schizophrenic state, we're liberal and conservative," Professor Lanegran added. "The great liberal leaders of the past were so charismatic, they pulled a lot of people," he said. "The liberal people today are not charismatic. Even Jesse Ventura, for all his foibles, has charisma."
Those who voted for Governor Ventura in 1998 backed Mr. Gore in greater numbers, polls showed. The state allows voters to register at the polls, a tactic that helped Mr. Ventura, and may have helped Mr. Gore. Turnout was estimated at a stunning 87 percent.
Democrats picked up a Senate seat and a House seat as well, but not without cost. Mark Dayton, an heir to the Dayton-Hudson department store fortune, spent about $11 million of his own money to beat Senator Rod Grams. Senator Grams, a Republican, had been an easy target, starting the race with unfavorable ratings almost as high as his favorable ratings. (Early on, Mr. Dayton told a newspaper he was running because he was recently divorced for the second time and wanted something to do.)
But ultimately, the state may be headed more in a Republican direction. Minnesota is expected to be redistricted, and in the State Legislature, which will decide the new boundaries, the voters gave Republicans control.

HEADLINE: Gore Takes Beijing, Not That It Counts

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The Chaoyang District in this city is, of course, not the 51st state -- although with its ample sprinkling of Starbucks and McDonald's it bears at least a superficial resemblance to such a place.
So it was perhaps fitting that thousands of Chinese here donned red-white-and-blue campaign pins today and came out in record numbers to cast ballots for George W. Bush or Al Gore. And even as election officials in the United States grappled with a race that was too close to call, this mock election, sponsored by the American Embassy and American businesses, had unambiguous results: the votes went almost 2 to 1 for Mr. Gore. 
 "We're Gore supporters," said Ding Zhao, an 86-year-old retired engineer waving a Gore-Lieberman balloon, whose wife nonetheless sported a Bush-Cheney badge. "I think Clinton has been good to China, and I think Gore will continue that."
To mark each American presidential election over the past decade, the embassy and the local American Chamber of Commerce have sponsored an election night party, which -- with a 13-hour time difference -- takes place in the morning. This year it included the mock election, as well as a mock Uncle Sam whose pin declared, "Qing wen wo" (please ask me), and who was ready to dispense lessons about American democracy.
Past events have been poorly attended -- Chinese are often reluctant to be seen at embassy functions. But this year the party was clearly the hottest ticket in town. About 2,000 students, professors, business people, officials and others packed into a hotel ballroom stocked with Lays potato chips and Baskin Robbins ice cream -- and bedecked with posters, campaign leaflets, bunting and American flags.
With Chinese increasingly plugged into outside news via the Internet, and with China hoping soon to enter the World Trade Organization, many people in Beijing have become fixated on this faraway contest, even though most scholars here believe that the outcome will not drastically affect Chinese-American relations.
Those who cast their paper ballots today were opinionated and for the most part well informed. And, in a country whose citizens cannot elect their own leaders, the chance to debate politics and cast even a fake vote was clearly appealing.
"I think particularly young people have a very strong interest in East-West relations," said Wang Rujun, who works promoting China's special economic zones. Mr. Wang, in khakis and a windbreaker, stood undecided before the ballot box, but ultimately put his check beside Mr. Gore's name.
"I think that in the future we may have this kind of election here, too," he remarked.
Vice President Gore might have wished he was in Beijing today, as this was clearly Gore country; a cheer went up from the crowd as CNN announced that he had taken California. Not everyone who came to the party voted, but the final tally was: Mr. Gore, 762; Mr. Bush, 396; Ralph Nader, 23: Patrick J. Buchanan, 2.
The American Embassy and American businesses in China had faxed out thousands of invitations, but many people skipped class or work on this Wednesday morning to crash the party, after hearing about it from friends.
It was a typical campaign night scene, as the overflow crowd, a mix of tension and exuberance, bunched around televisions tuned to CNN for state tallies and commentary from Larry King.
"I voted for Gore today because I think he looks nice and Bush was not a good student -- a bad boy," said Georgie Yin, a journalist with a state newspaper. "Also, Gore has been vice president for eight years and has experience."
But, overhearing her comments, others piped up to disagree: "I like Bush because I think he's more realistic about U.S.-China relations," said Ma Zongshi, a senior researcher at a government research group, who was wearing a suit and a tan baseball cap. "I don't like his policy to get tough with China, but I don't think he'll ever send troops or anything like that."
But Mr. Ma forlornly predicted that America's prosperity would lead to a Gore victory, adding: "What is the expression you use? 'It's economics, stupid.' "
Many in the crowd said they had followed the election on the Internet and CNN, which is increasingly available in Beijing's upscale housing complexes. And while the crowd included a smattering of foreign policy experts who are paid to follow these things, it was more or less a cross section of young professional Beijingers who came because they were interested.
"I saw the last two debates on CNN," said Ma Zhong, an investment adviser in his 30's. "And I thought Gore did a better job."
He said he worried some about how the candidates would handle the delicate Taiwan issue. But, like most of the crowd, he said he did not take campaign statements too seriously. He predicted that the two candidates would maintain the policy of engagement, with American business interests taking precedence over partisan politics and ideology.
"Before they became president," Mr. Ma said, "both Bush -- the father -- and Clinton were very harsh toward China. But afterward they couldn't stay away."

HEADLINE: Brown U. Breaks Ground In Picking Black as Chief

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Ruth J. Simmons, the president of Smith College and the youngest of 12 children of a Texas sharecropper, is expected to be appointed the new president of Brown University today.
In voting yesterday afternoon to name Dr. Simmons the 18th president since the university's founding in 1764, the 54 officers of the Brown Corporation will make academic history: she will be the first black president of an Ivy League institution. 
 Dr. Simmons will succeed E. Gordon Gee, who left Brown's Providence, R.I., campus abruptly nine months ago, after only two years in office, to become president of Vanderbilt University, in Tennessee.
In choosing Dr. Simmons, 54, the members of the corporation said that they were impressed not only by her biography -- she was raised poor in Houston, and later received a doctorate in romance languages from Harvard -- but by the example that she would set for the student body, said Stephen Robert, the chancellor of the university and chairman of the presidential search committee.
"They say nothing is felt until experienced," said Mr. Robert, who graduated from Brown in 1962 and is the former chairman of the Oppenheimer Company, the investment bank and money management firm. "She's experienced the other side of this life. She knows what higher education accomplished for her."
Judith McLaughlin, who leads a seminar for new college presidents at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, said Brown's selection of Dr. Simmons represented "a wonderful statement in higher education," considering that "people look to the Ivy League as places of excellence."
"At the same time that there have been debates over whether access and excellence can coexist," Ms. McLaughlin added, "Ruth Simmons shows in her person that they can."
While at Smith, a storied women's college in Western Massachusetts whose 2,500-student campus is dwarfed by the 7,300 students who attend undergraduate and graduate classes at Brown, Dr. Simmons sought to improve academic life in a number of areas. During her five-year tenure, the endowment nearly doubled, to $900 million from about $450 million. She also garnered national attention by establishing the first engineering program at a women's college, instituting a curriculum-wide focus on public speaking and providing a paid internship for every undergraduate.
But in an interview yesterday, Dr. Simmons said she also took pride in less flashy accomplishments of her tenure, like creating the post of provost and simplifying the lines of administrative communication.
"That's the kind of thing I like, the hidden things," she said. "It's like cleaning. Some people clean just enough so that what you see looks good. I clean so that you can move the chair out of the way and not find dust bunnies under it."
Dr. Simmons' analogy was especially poignant because her mother, whose formal education ended in the seventh grade and who died when her youngest daughter was 15, had worked as a domestic.
Since Mr. Gee's departure, Brown has been led by an interim president, Sheila E. Blumstein. Upon Dr. Simmons's arrival on July 1, Dr. Blumstein will return to teaching linguistics and cognitive science. A spokeswoman said that she did not know Dr. Simmons's new salary but that Mr. Gee had earned about $300,000.
Brown officials had hoped to keep Dr. Simmons's appointment a secret until today's vote was concluded, but the student newspaper, The Brown Daily Herald, broke the story yesterday. As word of the uncertainty in the United States presidential election spread on campus, it was tempered by welcome news: that the instability touched off by Mr. Gee's sudden exit was nearing an end.
"I think she got the job because she can do the job well," said Matthew Shechmeister, 20, a sophomore from Menlo Park, Calif., who is studying political science. "Brown was liberal enough that it was willing to take a look at her."
But Mark Scott, 21, a junior from Montreal, said Dr. Simmons' race would be an asset to a school with a reputation as being among the most liberal in the nation. "Someone will step up and notice a black woman as president of an Ivy League university," he said.
At Smith, where word of Dr. Simmons' departure next summer had barely reached the student body, Milka Dennis, president of the Class of 2004, reacted with sad disbelief.
"I would be really heartbroken," said Ms. Dennis, an economics major from Miami. "She spoke at Discovery Weekend, an information session for prospective applicants of color, and influenced me to come to Smith College. If Smith deserved a great president like her, they deserved great students like me."
Still, Rachel Leifer, the features editor of The Sophian, the Smith student newspaper, said she had grown weary of Dr. Simmons's railing against college students' "mall speak," specifically their overreliance on "like" and "um."
"I'm not that upset to see her go," Ms. Leifer said.
Before becoming the first black woman to lead Smith, in 1995, Dr. Simmons made several critical stops in her journey through the academy.
As a high school senior, she won a $1,000 scholarship to Dillard University in New Orleans, from which she graduated, summa cum laude, in 1967. After getting her masters and Ph.D. at Harvard, Dr. Simmons taught French at the University of New Orleans.
She later served in several capacities at Princeton University: as the acting director of the Afro-American studies program and as assistant dean and associate dean of the faculty. In the early 1990's, she worked as the provost of Spelman College.
Perhaps mindful that a faculty can make or break a president's tenure before it begins -- and that Mr. Gee had alienated some professors -- Dr. Simmons said her priorities at Brown would include improving "faculty resources," which she defined as leaves, salaries and research support.
And even though Brown's endowment has grown to $1.5 billion, nearly double that of Smith's, it pales among those of other Ivy League institutions. She said she worried that it was too small to accomplish what she wanted.
"I know that sounds like a billionaire complaining he's not as rich as Bill Gates," she said, laughing. "It's not a dire situation, by any stretch."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Executive Assesses Her Adventure At a Dot-Com

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
When Heidi G. Miller quit her job in February as the highest-ranking woman at Citigroup to join Priceline.com, the online travel agency, her move was heralded as a stunning signal that the new economy was eclipsing the old one.
Now that Ms. Miller has abruptly resigned from Priceline and is looking for work, her brief adventure in cyberspace is being cited as confirmation that the dot-coms are dead. But Ms. Miller says that she never was a true believer -- and, likewise, that she has not lost all faith, despite the turnabout that has slashed Priceline's share price by more than 90 percent and left her options on the company's stock virtually worthless. 
 "The general perception was the dot-coms were all golden and now they're all dirt," Ms. Miller, 47, said in an interview this week. And though neither assessment was accurate, she added, the shift in investor thinking has greatly impaired the growth prospects of Internet-based start-ups and wiped away much of their appeal to experienced executives like her.
Ms. Miller walked away from Priceline's headquarters in Norwalk, Conn., last week after the company -- still struggling to turn a profit -- decided to retrench and lay off 16 percent of its employees.
Others also bailed out: Maryann Keller, a longtime Wall Street automotive analyst, quit as president of Priceline's online car-buying service, and Bill Pike, a financial executive who had followed Ms. Miller from Citigroup, also resigned.
Shares of Priceline fell $1.03, to $3.25, a new low.
"A workout situation requires a different type of team and attitude," Ms. Miller said. "I didn't want to do that at this time in my career."
The collapse of Internet stocks since last spring has slowed a brain drain from established companies that had caused headhunters to work overtime and propelled pay packages heavenward. The value of Ms. Miller's Priceline options briefly shot up to more than $40 million last March, before crashing to earth.
Even in that context, Ms. Miller's hasty retreat resounded through executive suites, because "Heidi was and is an 'A' player," said Rick Savior, an executive recruiter who specializes in technology companies at the Directorship Search Group in Manhattan. Ms. Miller said she was fielding offers from a variety of organizations, including philanthropic groups.
Ms. Miller expressed no sorrow for investors who had bought Priceline's stock on her arrival, having interpreted her move as a buy recommendation from a savvy Wall Street veteran. "Investment decisions are different from career decisions," she said, adding that she was motivated not by the lucre of Internet stock options but by "personal decisions about what I wanted to learn."
And learn she did, about electronic commerce and about building a consumer brand, Ms. Miller said. but she also found that dot-com enterprises are not all that different from more traditional established corporations.
In particular, she said, she no longer believed that the new economy was any more hospitable to women executives than the old one.
Shortly after she left Citigroup, Ms. Miller said of her experience there: "I know I've had a very good run, but that doesn't excuse what I know to be real bias." At the time, she said she expected a start-up like Priceline would be a better place for women to flourish.
Now, she says, she "never bought that idea." Describing herself as a radical feminist, Ms. Miller explained, "I don't think young men are any less biased than old men are." In that regard, she said, "dot-coms are smaller versions of big corporations." So would she join another Internet-based company? "Only if I were totally in control," Ms. Miller said.
She declined to talk about decisions made by her superiors at Priceline with which she disagreed, saying only that there were "differences of opinion about what the right thing might be."
Brian Ek, a spokesman for Priceline, said company executives would have no comment about Ms. Miller's departure beyond what Daniel H. Schulman, the chief executive, said in a statement last week. In part, Mr. Schulman said, "We know she is supportive of the long-term direction the company is taking and wish her the best in her future endeavors."
A lack of authority was one of Ms. Miller's reasons for leaving Citigroup. A favored lieutenant of the Citigroup chairman. Sanford I. Weill, Ms. Miller, as the financial company's chief financial officer, apparently wielded influence and had a bright future. Last year, Fortune magazine ranked her as the second-most-powerful woman in corporate America, behind Carly Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard.
But she found her job on Wall Street constricting, and has said that she was frustrated in her desire to run a business at Citigroup. "I had a great run at Citi and Sandy did lots for me," Ms. Miller said. "But at the end of the day, only one person makes the decisions."
Mr. Weill has not called, she said, but James Dimon, a friend and former colleague who is chairman and chief executive of the Bank One Corporation in Chicago, has. Mr. Dimon urged her to call him before making her next move, she said, though she indicated she had no intention of uprooting from her home in Connecticut to join him in Chicago.
She also played down the chances that she would return to being a corporate chief financial officer, saying "been there, done that." Otherwise, her future is not clear, she said.
She dropped this year to No. 20 on Fortune's list of powerful women, and she said she was not in a hurry to shoot back up that chart despite a ribbing from her son about why she had slipped so far.
"Career paths are not linear," she said. "It's not about going from No. 2 to No. 1 on a list, and the score is not about how much money you have."
She clearly bristles at being labeled an "Internet loser," a tag Forbes magazine stuck on her recently. But she said she was not looking back in anger at her colleagues at Priceline or friends who advised her to go there, like Nancy Peretsman, an investment banker at Allen & Company, and William Ford, a venture capitalist at General Atlantic Partners. Ms. Peretsman, an investor in Priceline, introduced Ms. Miller to Priceline's founder, Jay Walker, at a holiday party in 1999.
"I'm certainly smart enough to have understood what I was getting into," she said. "I don't feel I made a big mistake."
