HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Wall Street Wants a Winner

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Unnerved slightly by the unresolved presidential election and concerned about a slowdown in profit growth for technology stocks, investors sent the American financial markets lower in tepid trading yesterday.
For much of the day, the unanswered question of whether Gov. George W. Bush or Vice President Al Gore would replace Bill Clinton in the White House did not seem to bother investors. 
 Stocks opened broadly higher, though the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index quickly turned sour after an analyst published a negative report on optical networking companies, some of the Nasdaq's most important stocks.
But stocks slid lower throughout the afternoon and closed down across the board. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 22.59 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,409.28, while the Nasdaq plunged 184.09 points, or 5.4 percent, to 3,231.70. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 45.12 points, to 10,907.06, a 0.4 percent drop. Treasury bonds and the dollar showed little change.
Investors still appear to believe that Mr. Bush will win, since cigarette and energy companies and drug makers, which are perceived as likely to benefit if Mr. Bush is elected, all rose. Philip Morris, the leading tobacco company, rose $1.75, to $36.75, while the drug maker Merck leaped $3.81, to $90.81.
But the closeness of Tuesday's vote has denied either Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore a mandate for their proposals, professional stock strategists and money managers said. After a day of uncertainty, Wall Street does not particularly care who wins, as long as the election is quickly resolved, they said.
"Markets hate uncertainty," said Fred Kobrick, chief executive of Kobrick Funds, which manages more than $1 billion. "This was a worry day; a lack of leadership; don't know where the market is going; may take forever to get a president."
In another sign of Wall Street's confusion, Microsoft, which investors believe would benefit from a Bush victory, rose as high as $72.38, a $1.88 rise, before giving up its gains on broader concerns about technology stocks. It closed the day at $69.44, down $1.06. Other technology companies fared much worse.
The chip maker Intel sagged $3.50, to $42.69, while the computer storage manufacturer EMC slid $7.50, to $90.
Optical networking equipment companies, which are among the most highly valued and volatile Nasdaq stocks, fell heavily in the face of a report from Bluestone Capital that warned of waning demand and called the stocks overpriced.
Cisco Systems fell $4.63, to $52.13, while Juniper Networks plunged $22.50, to $188.19.
The weakness in technology stocks was mainly unrelated to the election, said Byron Wien, strategist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "There were still some excesses in the Nasdaq," Mr. Wien said. But he warned that the markets were likely to remain unsettled until Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore was declared the winner.
Once that happens, investors may return to stocks again, said Charles Pradilla, chief investment officer at SG Cowen. Like other analysts, Mr. Pradilla assumes that the close election means more gridlock in Washington, with neither big tax cuts nor big new spending programs on the horizon.
And with the United States in the midst of the longest economic expansion in its history, investors should be happy with a stalemate, he said. "This is the best of all possible results," Mr. Pradilla said. "The background economics remain superb, and if you want to keep those unmolested, this political outcome is the best that you could have."
Wall Street's conventional wisdom is that a Bush victory will provide a short-term boon for stocks, especially those of the drug makers, tobacco companies, health maintenance organizations, energy companies and military contractors.
Neil B. Sweig, an analyst at Ryan, Beck & Company, said drug stocks rose yesterday because investors continued to believe that Mr. Bush would win. But if Mr. Gore is declared the winner, "drug stocks will come crashing down," he said. "We're truly in a twilight zone."
A Bush victory might hurt bonds, because the big tax cut that Mr. Bush has proposed could eat up the federal government's surplus. Such a tax cut could also stimulate excessive economic growth and inflationary pressures, forcing the Federal Reserve's policy makers to raise short-term interest rates to slow the economy.
Financial stocks, which might suffer if rates rise, also dropped slightly, though it was unclear whether the drop was related to fears of a Bush tax cut or broader investor unease about the election. Chase Manhattan dropped $1.26, to $43.63, while Citigroup dropped $1.69, to $53.06.
Because stocks are unlikely to rise for very long if bond yields increase and prices fall, investor euphoria over a Bush victory may not last, said Hugh Johnson, chairman and president of First Albany Asset Management, which invests $630 million.
If Mr. Bush wins, "life is going to be made more difficult for the Federal Reserve," Mr. Johnson said.
On the other hand, bond investors may view a Gore victory as more positive for bonds, because Mr. Gore has proposed smaller tax cuts than Mr. Bush has.
But Mr. Gore has unnerved some investors, who are concerned he may be unfriendly to business. Mr. Gore proposed an expansion in Medicare prescription drug benefits that the pharmaceutical industry fears and has sharply attacked big oil companies. He is also part of an administration that has sued to force the breakup of Microsoft.
Now, neither candidate can claim much support for his proposals, Mr. Johnson said. "There's pretty clearly no mandate -- that's the understatement of the year," he said.
If Mr. Gore wins, he will have to work with Republican majorities in both the House and Senate to pass legislation, which will force sides to moderate their policies, Mr. Johnson said.
If Mr. Bush wins, the Republicans will control the presidency and the Congress for the first time since the 1953-1955 period.
But they will have tiny majorities in both houses of Congress, and Mr. Bush will have won despite receiving a minority of the popular vote. That hardly indicates overwhelming support for Mr. Bush's proposed tax cuts, said Jeff Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers.
"The notion that Congress is going to pass a $1.3 trillion tax cut in the first three months of 2001 is just out the window," Mr. Applegate said. "Rather than a landslide, we got a mudslide -- a mudslide that effectively submerges the prospect of any significant change in U.S. fiscal policy."

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans a Lottery System To Cut La Guardia Flights

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it planned to reduce the number of flights at La Guardia Airport to relieve congestion until it could find a way to restructure airport fees nationwide to discourage gridlock during peak flying times.
At La Guardia, the rationing plan is expected to force the cancellation of more than 75 flights a day, some that are already in operation and others that airlines have sold tickets for and that are scheduled to begin over the next three months. 
 The F.A.A. and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the region's three largest airports, said they would not know which flights would be canceled for at least a month, until they begin to allocate takeoff and landing slots to airlines by lottery. A lottery has been used only rarely in the past to distribute precious landing slots at overcrowded airports.
Federal officials acknowledged that the cancellation of flights would be painful, especially as the holiday season was approaching, but they said that it was the only way to bring some temporary relief to the airport, until a more sweeping solution could be found.
"The F.A.A. recognized that if we did not act, this situation could only worsen," said Eliot Brenner, a spokesman for the agency. "The reality of flying into La Guardia today is that a number of flights are getting canceled anyway because of the time length of the delays. So the issue of whether or not there might be flights canceled is -- I don't want to say moot -- but not as important as it might seem."
Federal officials said the Port Authority, which in September announced a moratorium on any more flights being added at La Guardia, had recently proposed the idea of using a lottery to ration slots.
The F.A.A. agreed because of how rapidly conditions at La Guardia were worsening, contributing to delays at other airports across the country.
The quick rise in flights at La Guardia began about six months ago, the result of a federal law passed in March that partly lifted flight restrictions at the busy airport. That measure created more slots, mostly for smaller regional jets that fly to underserved cities.
Airlines rushed to grab the slots, the first new ones in decades because La Guardia's traffic had long been limited to about 600 daily flights under federal law. But the new flights began to swamp the airport.
As of last week, about 100 new daily flights -- meaning 200 takeoffs and landings -- had been added at the airport, which was already near maximum capacity. Airlines had filed requests to add as many as 300 total new daily flights, and were beginning to schedule and sell some of those.
But the plan announced yesterday would restrict the number of new flights to about 75. The lottery, which federal officials say they hope will be held at the end of this month in New York, would give priority to the newest airlines at La Guardia. It would also favor those carriers providing regional service, the kinds of airlines that were supposed to be helped by the federal legislation passed in March.
The officials stressed, however, that the lottery rationing plan would be only temporary, probably lasting until the middle of September 2001. After that, the F.A.A. said, it plans to begin a nationwide plan for changing the way airlines are charged for takeoff and landings.
The main idea being considered, known as congestion pricing, is a favorite of many economists and has been debated by the federal government and airports for years. In the late 1980's, Logan International Airport in Boston tried a version of it, imposing new landing fees to try to discourage private airplanes and small commercial airlines from using the airport during peak times. But the Reagan administration overruled that plan, saying that the fees illegally discriminated against the small planes and airlines.
The Port Authority, which has been contending with increasing delays at all three of its airports, has long been considering some form of congestion pricing. The idea would be to charge airlines more for landing during peak times or to use other fees that would give airlines incentives, for example, to schedule flights during less busy times or to use larger planes. Traditionally, airport landing fees have been based on a plane's weight, with higher costs for larger planes.
Airlines point out that higher fees during peak times would most likely be passed along to passengers.
The fact that federal officials now seem to be seriously considering what they call market-based ways to reduce the nation's growing air delays is a clear indication of the extent of the problems nationwide.
And the F.A.A. regards La Guardia as a kind of bellwether. During September, there were 9,000 flight delays at the airport, up from 3,108 in the same month a year before. The delays were so extensive, in fact, that they accounted for fully a quarter of all the flight delays in the country in September.
"These delays are translating into disrupted airline schedules, cancellations and frustrated air travelers across the U.S.," wrote Jane F. Garvey, the F.A.A. administrator, in a letter sent yesterday to Robert E. Boyle, the executive director of the Port Authority. Mr. Boyle characterized conditions at the airport as intolerable.
The airlines that serve La Guardia reacted cautiously yesterday after a two-hour meeting in which they were presented with the lottery rationing idea by officials from the Port Authority and the F.A.A.
In a prepared statement, Delta Airlines signaled gently that it questioned whether the F.A.A.'s plan violated the spirit, if not the letter, of the federal law that created more slots.
"We're studying the proposal to determine whether an approach that would significantly reduce operations achieves our mutual goals and preserves the mandate of the legislation to increase access and service from La Guardia to small, underserved markets," the airline said.
But F.A.A. officials emphasized yesterday that they were given power under the legislation to make changes if the amount of traffic created by the law began to overburden airports.

HEADLINE: U.S. Taking Mexico Phone Dispute to W.T.O.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
Trade officials in Washington made good on a threat yesterday and decided to bring Mexico, the United States' second-largest trading partner, before the World Trade Organization and accuse it of failing to open the $12 billion Mexican telecommunications industry to competition.
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, announced that despite a brief thaw last month that lowered tensions between the two countries over the longstanding dispute, Washington would file a complaint against Mexico for hearing by a dispute-settlement panel of the W.T.O. "While some progress has been made," Ms. Barshefsky said in a statement, "Mexico's failure to take additional actions has left us no choice but to request a W.T.O. panel." 
 Jorge Nicolin, president of the Federal Telecommunications Commission in Mexico, said that the complaints made by Ms. Barshefsky's office were unfair and that Mexico would successfully defend its position before the W.T.O.
"They are pressing us because of the coming end of the administration," he said. When asked whether he was referring to the remaining time of President Ernesto Zedillo's government, which ends on Nov. 30, or of President Clinton's, Mr. Nicolin responded, "Both."
The cross-border feud over phone rates and the opening of the market has gone on most of this year, with each side accusing the other of not living up to international trade standards. In recent weeks, Mexican regulators issued rules instructing Telefonos de Mexico, the privatized company that dominates long-distance and local service, to lower its fees for connecting rivals' long-distance calls to its local network.
The regulators also tried to force Telmex to comply more fully with measures to allow competitors greater access to Mexico's telephone system, over which Telmex exercised a monopoly until 1997.
But soon after the new regulations were issued, Telmex filed legal challenges against them in the Mexican courts. In addition, United States officials say Mexico enforces telecommunications regulations reluctantly and allows Telmex to use its market strength to preserve its dominant position and deny competitors timely connections to its network.
Its two principal competitors in long-distance service, Alestra and Avantel, are partly owned by American telecommunications giants that have brought their complaints before the trade representative's office. They argued that the rates Telmex charged to connect long-distance calls to the local network were too high. They also contended that Telmex, asked to provide access, offered inferior lines and on occasion denied access altogether.
AT&T, which holds a 49 percent stake in Alestra, and WorldCom, a 45 percent partner in Avantel, have argued that Mexican regulators are allowing Telmex to obstruct competition and keep the bulk of the Mexican market to itself.
While no longer a state monopoly, Telmex has given up little ground to the newcomers since 1997, when competition was first allowed in long-distance service. It now controls 81 percent of long-distance customers and more than 95 percent in local service, where independent companies arrived just last year.
After a series of meetings and consultations, Mexico issued rules last month to force Telmex to open itself more fully to competition. After regulators also lowered connection rates to 1.26 cents a minute from 3.36 cents, American officials decided not to go ahead immediately with a complaint against Mexico begun in August, though they threatened to resume the process if clear progress was not being made. Ms. Barshefsky also wanted Mexico to address concerns about the high rates charged for phone calls between the United States and Mexico.
Telmex's legal challenges, along with government inaction on rates, led Washington to act, Ms. Barshefsky said.
After receiving the complaint, the W.T.O. will form a dispute settlement panel to hear the complaints. Mexican officials will then have a chance to respond to the charges before a ruling is issued.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: THE VOTERS;
After Months of Uncertainty, 3 Votes Go to Mrs. Clinton

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
Doug Taggart had decided midway through the first debate between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio that Mr. Lazio was not fit to fill the United States Senate seat being vacated by Daniel Patrick Moynihan. That was the easy part.
Then he had to fight with his conscience, as he put it, about whether Mrs. Clinton had "earned" his vote, the high standard that Mr. Taggart, a Wall Street executive, says he applies each time he enters a voting booth. 
 Mr. Taggart has withheld his vote before, most recently in the acidic 1992 Senate race between Robert Abrams and Alfonse M. D'Amato. And he was still considering doing just that yesterday when he closed the curtain at his polling place in the Westchester County community of Cortlandt Manor. He was still undecided, he said, as he pulled the other levers -- for president, Congress, the State Legislature and the judiciary.
Only after all his other votes were cast did Mr. Taggart swallow hard, mentally review "all the negatives against Lazio and the absolute hatred for Hillary by his supporters" and choose the first lady.
"I did not feel satisfied except in exercising my rights as a citizen of the greatest country on earth," he said. "I hope I don't feel like a fool a few months or years down the line."
Mr. Taggart was one of 11 undecided voters who began sharing their thoughts on the Senate race with The New York Times last December. As Election Day drew near, only three remained uncommitted. All three, in the end, voted for Mrs. Clinton because, they said, despite their many reservations about her, she waged a dogged campaign, spent more time than her opponent speaking about the issues and less time on the attack.
Bob Harrison, a social studies teacher from Amsterdam, N.Y., an Albany suburb, said he arrived at his polling place free of angst. He had been edging toward a vote for Mrs. Clinton since deciding that her interest in the upstate economy was more sustained than Mr. Lazio's.
"I was positive what I was doing," Mr. Harrison said. "She's senatorial in terms of her policy and ideas about the economy, health care and education. She's going to do what's best for New York."
In Saugerties, N.Y., Tom Smith, a customer service manager at Wal-Mart, also said it "felt right," when all was said and done, to pick Mrs. Clinton. "I didn't like the way Lazio presented himself," he said. "He was so busy attacking that what he was going to do never came forth."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: THE BALLOT INITIATIVES;
Changes in Drug Policy And Gun Laws Are Picked

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Among the winners: drug policy reform, gun control, all-English education. Among the losers: school vouchers, gay rights, sprawl containment.
Such were the general outlines emerging today from votes on more than 200 state ballot initiatives around the country. 
 The initiatives addressed some of the knottier social issues facing the country, like doctor-assisted suicide -- which was narrowly voted down in Maine -- and universal health care coverage, which was also narrowly defeated, in Massachusetts.
Changes in state drug laws were approved in five states. California approved, by 3 to 2, a measure requiring people convicted of drug possession or use to get treatment rather than going to jail. The proposition calls for $120 million a year to be spent on treatment for the 36,000 people expected to qualify, but its supporters say it will save more than that in prison costs.
A measure in Massachusetts that would also have allowed some minor drug dealers to avoid jail was narrowly defeated after law enforcement officials warned that it was too easy on dealers. And in Alaska, voters overwhelmingly rejected a measure that would have made their state by far the most liberal in the nation when it came to marijuana. It would have legalized the use of marijuana for people age 18 and over, and granted retroactive amnesty to people who had been convicted of marijuana crimes in the past.
But those defeats were the exception on drug policy: In Nevada and Colorado, voters approved initiatives legalizing the medical use of marijuana, bringing the total of states with such laws to eight.
In addition, voters in Mendocino County in Northern California approved, 58 percent to 42 percent, a measure that would allow a resident to cultivate up to 25 marijuana plants and directing sheriffs to make the arrest of small-scale growers their lowest priority. The initiative does not overrule state and federal laws, so it is largely symbolic, but it does mark a first in local marijuana measures, which have previously focused mainly on decriminalizing possession.
Colorado and Oregon easily passed ballot initiatives to require background checks of buyers even at gun shows, where federal law does not require such investigations. They passed despite heavy spending by gun advocates and amounted to a popular rebuke to legislatures that had rejected such measures.
In Colorado, where the massacre at Columbine High School left 15 dead last year, the measure passed 70 percent to 30 percent, spurred on in part by the parent of a Columbine victim. And in Oregon, where 15-year-old Kipland P. Kinkel went on a shooting rampage in 1998, killing his parents and two others, it passed 61 to 39 percent.
Arizona voters passed an initiative that would replace bilingual education with one-year immersion classes meant to bring pupils up to speed in English. The measure was backed by a businessman who supported a similar measure in California two years ago, with similar success.
School voucher advocates had no such success. In California, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist, Timothy Draper, spent millions pushing for a measure giving a $4,000 voucher to every schoolchild, but voters rejected it by a margin of 71 percent to 29 percent. A proposition in Michigan, which would have given vouchers worth about $3,300 only to pupils in bad school districts, went down to defeat by a margin of 69 percent to 31 percent.
Votes against gay rights in three states might not have been as bad a sign for their supporters as they looked, some advocates say.
In Maine, voters narrowly defeated a measure that would have made it illegal to discriminate against gays and lesbians in housing, employment and other spheres. Maine's legislature had passed such an anti-discrimination measure in 1997, but it was then narrowly repealed in a special referendum vote in 1998. This latest ballot initiative had been a chance for Mainers to rethink that repeal, but apparently too few people changed their minds.
Tony Giampetruzzi, the spokesman for advocates of the anti-discrimination measure, said the campaign had been hurt by shortfalls in fund-raising but also because "this time they had that little extra bit of ammunition regarding Vermont."
Vermont's decision this year to legalize marriagelike civil unions for gay couples also changed the context for two measures directly concerning gay marriage: the measures barring the recognition of gay marriage passed in both Nebraska and Nevada by the same margin, 70 percent to 30 percent.
But in a narrow victory for gay rights, Oregon voters apparently rejected a measure that would have banned any teaching in public schools that sanctioned homosexuality. According to unofficial returns, it went down 51 percent to 49 percent.
As for sprawl, proposals to require growth management plans for many communities each received support from only 30 percent of voters in Colorado and Arizona. Opponents had warned that caps on urban growth could mean limits on economic growth in general.
"We still consider the election a victory," said Elise Jones, a spokeswoman for the anti-sprawl campaign in Colorado. "We fundamentally changed the debate on growth in Colorado forever."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: THE VICTOR;
First Lady Emerges From Shadow And Begins to Cast Her Own

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER and DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton began the remarkable transition yesterday from a quarter-century of derivative power as a political spouse to a potent force in her own right. The world's most famous first lady and senator-elect held a love-fest of a news conference, said that her first bill would be to improve the upstate economy and fended off the inevitable question about whether she would seek the White House in 2004.
"No," she said briskly in otherwise relaxed remarks to reporters at the Grand Hyatt in Manhattan yesterday afternoon. "I'm going to serve my six years as the junior senator from New York." 
 Although there were few in New York who believed that a woman who routinely attracts a presidential-size flotilla of news media would ever really operate as "junior," Mrs. Clinton began turning her attention yesterday to the practicalities of hiring a Senate staff, perhaps as few as 25 people in Washington, that will face demands like no others on Capitol Hill. If Al Gore loses, Mrs. Clinton will be perhaps the most important Democrat in the country. She will lose that status if Mr. Gore wins, but then she will have more power in Washington.
"She's going to be under incredible scrutiny, and she's still a polarizing figure to some degree in the state," one of Mrs. Clinton's advisers said shortly after the first lady's victory speech on Tuesday night. "She needs knowledgeable people who really know the Hill, Washington and New York."
Mrs. Clinton also said that over the next two months she would try to balance her remaining time as first lady with the preoccupations of a senator-elect. Today, for example, Mrs. Clinton is to attend a White House dinner as the wife of the president. Tomorrow she is to be the senator-elect on a statewide fly-around, thanking New Yorkers for a 12-point margin of victory over Representative Rick A. Lazio that almost no one expected. Next week, Mrs. Clinton will again be first lady as she accompanies her husband on a trip to Vietnam.
At the same time, Mrs. Clinton extravagantly thanked the president, who had operated throughout the race as her chief political adviser, for his help.
"I would not have been standing there without the support and work of my husband," she said. "And I don't think as a New Democrat I would have been standing there without his leadership of the Democratic Party and our country. You've heard me say many times over, and I absolutely believe it, that his leadership made a tremendous difference in our nation."
The first lady also said that she would welcome less attention at the close of the most obsessively covered Senate race in history. "I don't expect this much attention after today," Mrs. Clinton said, looking out at a room so full of journalists and camera crews that many were standing outside the doors. "So I think I will have more of an opportunity to get down to the work of becoming a senator and becoming effective."
But many New York Democrats viewed Mrs. Clinton's words as nothing more than wishful thinking, and said that she and her sometimes rocky marriage would always be a staple of the supermarket tabloids. Hundreds of supporters at the first lady's election night celebration could not help noticing that Mrs. Clinton -- perhaps in an effort to underscore that the Senate victory was hers alone -- made no effort to pose next to her husband in the signature victory photograph with arms raised. Instead, she stood between the Clintons' daughter, Chelsea, and Senator Charles E. Schumer. But in a more private moment afterward, she took the hand of the president as the two left the stage.
Friends say that the first lady's acquisition of power as the president gives up his will require inevitable adjustments in the Clintons' marriage -- something that the first lady joked about last month. "He has said he is looking forward to being a member of the Senate spouses' club," Mrs. Clinton said in Queens on Oct. 26. "I am sure, given his organizational abilities and his energy, the spouses' club will never be the same."
Although the Senate campaign degenerated in its final weeks into a series of angry, partisan exchanges about Palestinian terrorists, campaign contributions and character, Mrs. Clinton said yesterday that she was ready to work with Republicans. She said she had already spoken on the phone with Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Republican from Utah, and also Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, her Senate opponent before he dropped out of the race, citing prostate cancer.
"He and I talked about what we could do in the remaining year of his term," Mrs. Clinton said in describing her conversation with the mayor, who will leave office on Dec. 31, 2001.
Mr. Giuliani, who for the last year and a half roared at the first lady as a carpetbagger whose candidacy made no sense in New York, was suddenly lamblike yesterday morning as he spoke of the new political colleague who was replacing the retiring Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
"I told her that I would do everything that I could as the mayor of New York City to work with her, for the good of the city and the state," Mr. Giuliani said in a news conference at City Hall.
Mr. Giuliani also congratulated Mrs. Clinton on her victory. "She is entitled, as I told her, to a great deal of credit," he said. "She ran a very, very strong, tough campaign, she worked very hard, and when you are in this business you can admire even people who are on the other side, and adversaries, when they have a very, very strong work ethic as she does."
One of Mrs. Clinton's first tasks in the next few months is to find a place to live in Washington after she leaves the White House. Although Mr. Schumer, who lives with his family in Brooklyn, has shared the same small house on Capitol Hill with two colleagues for two decades, friends said it was unlikely that the first lady would adopt a similar arrangement, largely because of the security requirements of also housing a former president. But in the short run, said Mrs. Clinton's White House press secretary, Lissa Muscatine, temporary arrangements would do.
"I don't think she's had time to focus on where she wants to live," Ms. Muscatine said. "If worse comes to worse, I'm sure she has plenty of friends who would let her sleep on their sofas for a few nights."
Friends also said they expected the Clintons to keep their $1.7 million, five-bedroom Dutch Colonial in Chappaqua as their primary residence, even though there have been reports in The New York Post, denied by Mrs. Clinton's campaign, that the couple is looking for an apartment in New York City.
As for the presidency, Mrs. Clinton's disclaimer has done little so far to tamp down speculation that she will be a candidate -- if not in 2004, then in 2008, or later.
"Of course she'll run," said Mr. Moynihan.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

New York Officials to Issue Rules on Insurance Privacy
New York is taking the lead among other states as insurance regulators issue new rules on privacy now that banks, insurance companies and brokerage firms can be jointly owned.
New York will permit insurance companies to share financial details about a customer unless the customer specifically objects. Taking a tougher stance on health information, the state will not permit sharing unless a customer specifically grants permission. Both consumer advocates and insurers immediately raised objections. Page C7. 

Argentina Clears Financial Hurdle
Argentina's auction of $1.1 billion in treasury bills this week has put the government over a major short-term financial hurdle, but the borrowing costs -- at rates reaching 16 percent -- reflect growing worries that even higher political and economic hurdles lie ahead. Tax receipts this year have been disappointing, and a still-unresolved Senate bribery scandal has led in recent weeks to the resignation of the vice president, a shake-up of the cabinet and persistent doubts about President Fernando de la Rua's ability to govern. C7.
 
Creditors Pull the Plug on Daewoo
Creditors cut off the money that was keeping Daewoo Motor afloat, forcing it into bankruptcy. The move came after Daewoo's union refused to accept layoffs and pay cuts aimed at making it an attractive acquisition for General Motors. World Business, Section W.
 
U.S. to Bring Mexico Before W.T.O.
Trade officials made good on a threat and decided to bring Mexico -- the United States' second-largest trading partner -- before the World Trade Organization and accuse the nation of failing to open its $12 billion telecommunications industry to competition. C6.
 
Profit Off 10% at News Corporation
The News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said that its first-quarter profit fell 10 percent because of lower ratings at the Fox television network. C15.
 
New Index on Internet Sponsorships
A system to measure the effectiveness of Internet sponsorships as a brand-building tool for advertisers is being introduced this week. The index measures variables like product awareness and intends to address the concerns of marketers about Internet advertising as the medium comes under scrutiny as never before. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C15.
 
Interbrew to Offer Stock to Public
Interbrew said it would seek to raise as much as $2.8 billion by selling an initial public offering in December of about 21 percent of its shares. World Business, Section W.
 
Federated Posts Big Quarterly Loss
Federated Department Stores, the parent of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, reported a huge loss for the third quarter, brought about by sluggish sales and problems at its Fingerhut catalog business. Excluding the $795 million in charges taken in the third quarter for Fingerhut, Federated reported earnings that beat consensus estimates for the quarter, posting a profit of 26 cents a share, well above the 20 cents a share Wall Street had been expecting. Its shares fell 25 cents, to $34.19. C2.
 
A Model for Future White Houses
When it comes to economics, presidents must rely on their advisers to make informed decisions. The way economic advice is organized can determine the success of a president's program. The National Economic Council, formed by Bill Clinton in 1992, provides a good model. The idea was to elevate economic policy to the same status as national security and to coordinate advice from cabinet secretaries. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

SECTION: Section B; Page 19; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1211 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: POLITICAL MEMO;
Mrs. Clinton Found Right Mix in Fame and Upstate Focus

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
By the time the votes were counted, it was hard to see what Rick A. Lazio could have done to get out of the way. Hillary Rodham Clinton rode to victory on a wave created by a crack-the-whip, get-out-the-vote effort orchestrated by her friends at the labor unions, a swell in the number of registered Democrats in the state, and, perhaps most of all, the huge margin that Al Gore posted over George Bush in New York.
Mrs. Clinton won a contest that even some Democrats had once thought she would lose, by capitalizing on her celebrity, particularly by traveling to remote areas upstate where voters rarely saw a governor, much less a first lady. She identified herself with Democratic concerns in New York, from the economy upstate to health care downstate, in a way intended to erase lingering questions about her character. And in what might be the most instructive lesson of this campaign, particularly on the heels of Charles Schumer's Senate race in 1998, she demonstrated that upstate New York is not as safe a Republican region as had been assumed for so long. 
 Indeed, Mrs. Clinton defeated Mr. Lazio by 12 percentage points, a margin that surprised advisers to both candidates. But most revealing, she came within three points of Mr. Lazio upstate, an affirmation of her insistence on campaigning there so often. And turnout among black voters seems to have indeed increased as a result of the first lady's regular visits to black churches: blacks made up 11 percent of the electorate this year, compared with 9 percent in 1998, in a survey of voters leaving the polls on Election Day.
Still, in the end, all those forces seem to have had more to do with the magnitude of Mrs. Clinton's victory, as opposed to the victory itself. In truth, most of the polls taken from the moment Mr. Lazio got in the race last May, replacing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, suggested that there was never really that much variation in this contest, until the end. He always scored between 40 and 45 percent; in the end, he attracted 43 percent of the vote.
One of Mr. Lazio's advisers said yesterday that Mrs. Clinton's character, which Republicans had thought would be the hook with which they could bring her down, instead served to obscure their efforts the two times they sought to turn more to issues, in particular Mr. Lazio's tax cut proposal.
Mr. Lazio's consultants sought yesterday to blame factors beyond their control for his loss in a race that had been followed by Republicans across the country.
"It was a huge Democratic landslide in a big Democratic state," said Mike Murphy, Mr. Lazio's campaign consultant, in explaining a loss whose size he acknowledged had startled Mr. Lazio's aides.
The candidate's campaign manager, Bill Dal Col, offered a similar argument in an interview yesterday, saying that he believed it was impossible to win the race once it became clear that Mr. Gore was going to win the state by 1.5 million votes.
"When the numbers are as big as they are, it's not right or wrong," Mr. Dal Col said. "The math gets impossible."
Still, a number of Republicans argued that the candidate and his staff had only made things more difficult in the way they approached the contest. And as campaign workers began clearing out Mr. Lazio's offices on Park Avenue, there were accounts of turmoil and discord surrounding the campaign and the state Republican Party that Mr. Lazio's associates said undercut the campaign at a number of turns.
There was open dissent, for example, between Mr. Lazio's campaign staff and state Republican Party officials. State Republicans said yesterday they had told Mr. Lazio over the summer that he was making a mistake in keeping such a low profile for so long. Mr. Lazio's aides said he used the time to raise money, but his absence allowed Mrs. Clinton to make inroads upstate and to begin raising questions about Mr. Lazio's record with a series of negative commercials.
State Republicans also complained that Mr. Lazio recruited help from outside the state to run his campaign.
For their part, Mr. Lazio's aides blamed William Powers, the state Republican chairman, for what they contended was one of the biggest mistakes of the campaign: orchestrating telephone advocacy calls that sought to link Mrs. Clinton to the terrorist attack on the destroyer Cole in Yemen. "It was the single biggest blunder -- and it was by the local know-it-all New Yorkers," said one of Mr. Lazio's advisers. "The biggest blunder of the race was the brainchild of the local guys."
Mr. Powers did not return a call seeking comment yesterday.
There was tension between Mr. Lazio and his own advisers as well. His aides pressed him to deliver a series of six policy speeches in an effort to rebut attempts by Mrs. Clinton to portray him as an intellectual lightweight. Mr. Lazio delivered just three of them, as the candidate and his aides could not come to agreement on the language and even some of the proposals in the speeches.
Mr. Lazio and Mr. Murphy argued several times over advertisements that Mr. Murphy wanted him to broadcast: on at least two occasions, Mr. Murphy began running advertisements, one on television and one on radio, over the objections of Mr. Lazio, according to one of the candidate's aides. When Mr. Lazio confronted him, Mr. Murphy argued the ads were a key to defeating Mrs. Clinton, the aides said.
As it turned out, Mr. Lazio was forced to withdraw one of the ads, which attacked Mrs. Clinton for support a treaty on global warming, after he was criticized by environmental groups. Mr. Murphy declined to comment.
Even in defeat, Mr. Lazio did appear to have some success, notably, in undermining her support among Jews, by questioning her allegiance to Israel. The survey of voters leaving the polls found that Mrs. Clinton won the support of just 53 percent of the state's Jewish voters, an anemic showing for a Democrat. Typically, a Democratic candidate in a statewide race draws at least 60 percent of the Jewish vote.
Mrs. Clinton's advisers said that they had considered her weak among Jews from the start. But they made the calculation, they said, that they could counter this with a strong showing upstate.
Finally, perhaps the most successful strategy employed by Mrs. Clinton's associates was their attempt to erase the objection that Mrs. Clinton was trying to run from a state where she had not lived. To that end, they decided more than a year ago to simply have her spend as much time in New York as possible.
On the very last day of his campaign, Mr. Lazio assailed her again on the subject, as had Mr. Giuliani before him. If nothing else, the margin of Mrs. Clinton's victory suggests that this course of attack had at most limited appeal.
Mr. Dal Col, in an interview, acknowledged yesterday that the campaign had made several missteps, from the Cole calls to Mr. Lazio's decision to walk across the stage at the candidates' first debate and demand that Mrs. Clinton sign a pledge to bar the use of soft money. Still, he said after reviewing the numbers, none of that mattered much in the end.
"If you add up all these mistakes, they don't equal this race," he said. "It might get you five points. It doesn't get you the race. There was nothing fatal."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CALIFORNIA UTILITY SEEKS TO CHARGE CUSTOMERS $3 BILLION

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Pacific Gas and Electric, California's largest electric utility, sued the state in federal court, seeking freedom to charge customers more than $3 billion for the company's losses in open-market power purchases earlier this year. The company argued in its filing that the state made it sell its power plants and capped the rates it could charge, leaving it no way to avoid losses when wholesale power prices surge. The company, a unit of the PG & E Corporation, and its largest rival, Southern California Edison, a unit of Edison International, have asked the state utility commission to let it pass along the costs, so far without result. The uncertainty of when the issue will be resolved led Fitch Inc., a debt-rating agency, to downgrade PG & E and Edison's credit ratings.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: CHANGING CIRCUMSTANCES;
How Gore Stopped Short On His Way to Concede

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK and FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
When his limousine arrived at the War Memorial Plaza in Nashville, where a few thousand despondent, rain-soaked supporters awaited the concession, Vice President Al Gore assumed he had lost the election.
He had called Gov. George W. Bush at the Governor's Mansion in Austin, Tex., and extended his congratulations. He had written a short and gracious speech about moving the country forward and cooperating with the victor. 
 But several vans back in the motorcade, an aide's Skytel pager vibrated with a message to call Michael Whouley, a top Gore strategist who was monitoring Florida results at Gore headquarters. What Mr. Whouley had to say, the aide, Michael B. Feldman, recalled, was that the Florida secretary of state's Web page had winnowed Mr. Bush's advantage of 50,000 votes to 6,000, with precincts still to tally.
That changed everything.
About a half-hour later, at 2:30 a.m. Central time, Mr. Gore placed his second call of the evening to Mr. Bush.
From a holding room beneath the plaza, where he had gone to concede, Mr. Gore told his Republican rival that circumstances had changed in the last 45 minutes. The race, Mr. Gore said, was now too close to call, and there would be an automatic recount in Florida. He was going to wait it out.
"You mean to tell me, Mr. Vice President, you're retracting your concession?" Mr. Bush asked, his tone incredulous, one aide said. The Texas governor had already begun preparing his victory remarks.
"You don't have to be snippy about it," Mr. Gore responded, according to several of those who heard Mr. Gore's side of the conversation.
Mr. Bush told Mr. Gore that his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, had just assured him that Florida was his, Gore aides said.
"Let me explain something," Mr. Gore said. "Your younger brother is not the ultimate authority on this."
The conversation drew quickly to a close. The election did not.
After two sleepless days of campaigning, after a gut-wrenching night in which they had been convinced that they had won and then devastated that they had not, Mr. Gore and his aides were back in the game.
"I don't think there's ever been a night like this one," William M. Daley, the Gore campaign chairman, told the crowd at the plaza around 3:05 a.m.
No one in the Bush campaign would disagree with that assessment. Less than two hours earlier, around 1:15 a.m., when the television networks had called the election for Mr. Bush, he assumed he was the president-elect.
 
Watching and Waiting
In the upstairs living room of the Governor's Mansion, where he had passed the endless hours with his wife, his parents and Jeb Bush, family members hugged one another tight.
In Nashville at that time, Mr. Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, were watching CNN with a large group of aides in a seventh-floor suite at the Loews Vanderbilt Plaza hotel. The room grew silent.
Donna Brazile, Mr. Gore's campaign manager, sent the vice president a message at 1:20 a.m. Central time on his Blackberry, an instant messaging pager: "Never surrender. It's not over yet."
But ultimately, most in the group concluded that the networks had to be right. "They were just so damn positive," said Mr. Gore's brother-in-law, Frank Hunger. "And they were talking about 50,000 votes, and we never dreamed they would be inaccurate."
Mr. Gore went to his ninth-floor suite to break the news to his wife, Tipper, and his children, some of whom were sleeping, and some of whom cried.
At both the hotel and the campaign headquarters across town, depression took the place of the happier, more hopeful emotions that held sway six hours earlier, before the roller coaster of election night 2000 began screaming down the rails.
Around 7 p.m. Tuesday, the television networks put Florida, Michigan and Pennsylvania in the Gore victory column. With one more key tossup state, the deal would be sealed.
Some top Gore advisers were feeling good enough that they took a break to eat dinner in the hotel's steakhouse, where they could not even watch television.
It was the opposite of what was going on in Austin.
 
Hopes Dashed and Restored
For Mr. Bush, his advisers and his friends, confidence had been reigning for days. He spent Monday in Tennessee, Mr. Gore's home state, and in Arkansas, President Clinton's home state, and carried himself with the swagger of a certain winner.
But around 7 p.m. Tuesday, their optimism began to falter.
Mr. Bush was in a private dining room at the Shoreline Grill, a restaurant adjacent to the Four Seasons hotel in Austin, eating a dinner of parmesan-crusted chicken with his parents, his wife, his daughters and all of his siblings.
The news about Florida flashed on a nearby television set, casting a pall over the meal.
Mr. Bush had once joked that it would be a chilly Thanksgiving for his younger brother Jeb, if Florida did not tip into the Bush column. And now it had tipped in the other direction.
Joe and Jan O'Neill, two close friends of the governor's who were dining in another section of the restaurant, said the brothers shared an emotional moment.
"I heard that Jeb hugged George, literally in tears," Mr. O'Neill said.
Mrs. O'Neill added that the Florida governor told his brother he was sorry, which Jeb Bush confirmed yesterday. Then he left the room.
The Texas governor, his wife and his parents also left, heading back to the Governor's Mansion. They had intended to watch the returns with a group of relatives, friends and senior advisers in two suites on the ninth floor of the Four Seasons.
But now, several of Mr. Bush's aides said, he wanted peace and quiet.
Several aides said Mr. Bush had always kept open the possibility of going home.
But Mrs. O'Neill said that his change of plans was "not only last-minute, it was spur of the moment."
On the ninth floor of the Four Seasons and at the campaign headquarters, people channeled their tenuous hopes along two tracks.
They wondered if Mr. Bush could win so many smaller states that he could reach the magic number of 270 electoral votes without Florida, and they plotted the possibilities.
"Sometimes you could hear a pin drop in the room," said a family friend at the Four Seasons, "like when New Mexico was called for Gore. We all had our own written lists of the states he needed. We had all done our own electoral calculations."
Several blocks away, Mr. Bush's chief strategist, Karl Rove, and one of his deputies, Matthew Dowd, had done the same thing.
"Karl had actually formulated a strategy where the linchpin was the extra vote in Maine," said Stuart Stevens, one of the campaign's media advisers, referring to that state's ability to split its four electoral votes.
At the same time, Mr. Rove, Mr. Dowd and other Bush aides focused on Florida, gleaning information from the Internet and panicked phone conversations, and growing more and more convinced that the outcome was unclear.
Mr. Rove called several television networks to tell them they had acted early and perhaps erroneously and needed to amend their predictions.
Not everyone at the headquarters was convinced.
"It's the kind of thing you always do in a campaign, you grasp for any ray of hope," said Mark McKinnon, the chief media adviser. "It seemed like a thin ray, but it was one of the only ones we had."
Mr. Bush clung to it, encouraged by advisers. Every few minutes they called him with the latest updates, the latest calculations.
And around 9 p.m., in yet another twist, the networks announced that they were putting Florida back into the undecided column. Ecstatic shrieks filled the streets in front of the State Capitol, the halls of the Four Seasons and the campaign headquarters. "What do you call the things you put on a heart-attack victim?" Mr. McKinnon asked. "It was like the campaign had gotten those electric paddles to its heart."
 
A Celebration Cut Short
But if the Bush campaign felt revived, the Gore campaign did not yet feel moribund. They were also doing the arithmetic, and they were also sopping up all the information they could. The direction all of this was headed was ambiguous for a good long while.
For hours, there seemed to be plenty of room for hope. Mr. Bush had developed a lead in Florida, but it began to shrink.
Near midnight, Mr. Gore huddled with his top aides to discuss what they should do and decided he should go to the plaza and tell his supporters that the result might not be known until Wednesday. Then they decided to hold off for just a bit.
And then, seemingly inexplicably, Mr. Bush's margin in Florida ballooned.
Both in the seventh floor suite and at the campaign's headquarters downtown, depression set in. In the expansive white "boiler room" there, where aides had monitored returns, campaign workers began to cry. "A shock rippled through," one aide said.
They had worked down to the last minute. Only hours earlier, top-level strategists like Sarah Bianchi, a leading policy adviser, and Gene Sperling, the president's national economic adviser, on loan from the White House, had been making last-minute get-out-the-vote calls to Democrats on the West Coast.
"I felt so deflated," said Mark D. Fabiani, Mr. Gore's deputy campaign manager for communications. "It had been an evening where you won and then lost and winning felt a lot better than losing. You had been up and down and swung around and then dumped out on your head."
It had all come down to Florida, and advisers at the Bush campaign headquarters huddled over computer screens, clicking from one Internet site to another.
They factored in the voting histories of the counties to be tallied and punched numbers into calculators, desperate for an accurate prediction. They called Republican officials in the state. The hours and minutes crept by.
Mr. Bush remained at the mansion, where aides said his brother Jeb also kept an eye on the Internet.
In front of the State Capitol, various speakers took the microphone to try to enlist Bush supporters in what amounted to public prayers.
"We want Florida!" shouted George P. Bush, Jeb's oldest son. "We want Florida!" But the crowd -- rain-soaked, shivering and weary -- had gone limp.
Then, it happened. Around 1:15 a.m., the enormous television screens they were watching flashed that Mr. Bush would win not only Florida, but also the presidency. The loudspeakers blared the song "Signed, Sealed, Delivered."
At the Four Seasons, they roared, then filed into the buses waiting to take them to the State Capitol, about 10 blocks away. At the headquarters, they sobbed, then marched toward the same destination.
And at the Governor's Mansion, Mr. Bush, Jeb Bush and their proud parents hugged one another tight.
Mr. McKinnon took a turn in front of the television cameras, telling Candy Crowley, a correspondent for CNN, "I'm going to go to bed tonight and have a stiff drink as quickly as I can get off your set."
But then he saw a another network correspondent waving frantically, trying to deliver a piece of news that would delay that drink.
The seesawing state of Florida was decided anew, and the waiting had just begun.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
GROSS, MILTON S.

 BODY:
GROSS-Milton S., December 11, 1918-November 5, 2000. Long-time New York City high school teacher, dedicated teacher's union member, and Oberlin College graduate, Milton S. Gross, died peacefully at home in Berkeley, California, following a short illness. He was committed to civil rights, social and economic justice, and world peace. He was a faithful reader of the New York Times and always read the obituary page. His mother, Kathinka, was a great strudel maker. His father, Ernest, was a furrier and as a youth, a traveler and a pool shark. Milton loved books, good food, travel, the women in his life, his family, and friends. He could tell a story with the best of them, always delivered with zest and enthusiasm. He charmed us with his full-throated renditions of Hungarian songs. He is survived by his four children, Toni Gross of Oakland, California; Joe Gross of Berkeley, California; Billy Gross of Copenhagen, Denmark; and Judy Weisman of Plattsburg, New York; eight grandchildren, Jeanette, Kate, Lucia, Mickey, Gabe, Jazbo, Spencer, and Dana; one greatgrandchild, Damani, and two nephews and one niece, Ken, Larry, and Katherine Gross. He was a man well loved by all that knew him. Graveside services will be held at the Beth El Memorial Gardens in Portland, Maine, on November 10, 2000, at 11:00 AM. Milton requested that donations be directed to an organization that he supported: RESIST, 259 Elm Street, Somerville, MA 02144, Phone (617) 623-5110.

HEADLINE: Shock but No Longer Surprise Over Nursing Home Problems

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The criminal indictment of five nurses at a Long Island nursing home on Monday was shocking in its details: the authorities charged that a 97-year-old woman had died after being fed through a tube attached to an enema bag.
But the incident, however egregious, was also simply the latest of many problems uncovered in the industry in recent years: staff shortages, financial difficulties and, often, poor quality of care in some nursing homes. 
 From 1998 to 1999, the number of citations for inadequate care issued by the State Department of Health against the state's 676 nursing homes increased 30 percent, and the number of the most serious violations has almost doubled in the last year.
Many of those problems, according to experts and government officials, may stem from financial problems afflicting many of the nursing homes. Under a federal law enacted in 1997, Medicare reimbursement for nursing homes declined significantly. Faced with new financial constraints, many publicly traded nursing home holding companies have since filed for bankruptcy, and others are complaining of serious hardship.
At the same time, under that 1997 law, nursing homes were given far greater latitude in how they spent what government money they did receive. Homes are now reimbursed not for the care of each resident, but rather for their estimated needs of each. (In New York State, the same system is used under Medicaid.)
Under that arrangement, nursing homes may to spend this money as they choose, and many, industry experts say, are using it for administrative costs, executive salaries and profits rather than on direct care, like badly needed staff increases. The quality of care in some homes may have eroded as a result, the experts said.
"The idea of giving facilities flexibility with how they spend the money was supposed to be counterbalanced by government oversight of care given to residents," said Cynthia Rudder, director of the Nursing Home Community Coalition of New York State, a public watchdog group. "But that system has not been effective. There has been no real oversight of care."
Perhaps because they serve a population that has limited political power and consists of the frailest and most infirm of residents, nursing homes have long been an area of health care rife with abuse.
But lately, economic and other factors have aggravated the problems, and New York is immune to none of them.
A report issued this summer by the Health Care Financing Administration found that 54 percent of the country's nursing homes provide less than the minimal two hours a day of nurse aid care for each patient, and New York's nursing homes have similar statistics. Nurse aid positions are hard to fill, as they are labor-intensive and stressful but tend to pay poorly and provide few benefits, Ms. Rudder said.
At times, New York's problems have stood out even in the troubled national picture. Congressional investigators found this year that New York was among a handful of states with widespread violations of health and safety standards in nursing homes. And about 17 percent of homes on Long Island gave care that harmed or had potential to harm residents, according to a study conducted by the Democratic staff of the House Committee on Government Reform.
Long Island in recent years appears to have emerged as a markedly troubled part of the state when it comes to nursing home care. On Monday, Eliot L. Spitzer, the state attorney general, charged five registered nurses at the Townhouse Extended Care Center in Uniondale with tampering with documents to mask conduct and treatment that resulted in the death of a 97-year-old woman and serious injury to two other women, according to the indictment.
In October, federal regulators cited the A. Holly Patterson Geriatric Center, one of the largest centers on Long Island, with severe deficiencies, charging that the home's failure to monitor patients properly resulted in the death of one patient and the endangerment of others. The citation, which could have resulted in a loss of federal and state money, was lifted later that month after the home corrected its problems.
Also in October, the State Department of Health found that the Workman's Circle Nursing Home in Co-op City in the Bronx was one of two nursing homes in the state with the most egregious problems. According to the state's report, 50 residents were confined to the basement for 12 hours a day while the center was renovated. The home has since submitted a plan of correction to the department and is out of immediate danger of losing financing.
And two years ago, state and federal officials accused New York City of providing inadequate care at Neponsit Health Care Center, which was run by the public hospitals corporation.
Some of the problems at homes in the city and on Long Island may be a consequence of less than vigorous monitoring by state officials. The local Health Department unit charged with investigations into complaints made against nursing homes on Long Island finds merit in only one percent of those that are submitted to it, a rate 8 times lower than the state average. New York City sustains about 5.4 percent of its complaints, state documents show. State officials say those numbers do not include physical abuse.
Last month, the State Health Department began making its monthly inspections of nursing homes available to the public through its Web site and press releases. "We want to ensure that nursing homes are aware that we take our responsibilities seriously," said John Signor, a department spokesman.
The department is hiring 100 new inspectors for health care facilities, including nursing homes. In recent years, the department has failed to spend all its money from the federal government to conduct inspections. "We want to be able to respond to complaints more quickly and con

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-16
 
On Eve of U.S. Talks, 5 Die in Arab-Israeli Strife
Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, left to meet with President Clinton in Washington today, as new bloodletting broke out in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, leaving four Palestinians and one Israeli dead. Mr. Clinton is to meet with Prime Minister Ehud Barak on Sunday, but there was little expectation on either side of renewed peace talks anytime soon. A14 

U.N. to Weigh Palestinian Plan
The Security Council will hold a closed-door meeting tomorrow to hear Yasir Arafat and the Israeli ambassador debate a Palestinian proposal for a United Nations "protection force" in the West Bank and Gaza. Israel opposes the idea. A14
 
F.B.I. Role in Warship Inquiry
Yemen and the United States are discussing arrangements to let F.B.I. agents watch Yemeni officials interview suspects and pass written questions to the Yemeni investigators, who could put them to those under interrogation in the Cole bombing. A13
 
Power Shift Seen in Egypt
Egyptians voted in the final phase of parliamentary elections. Strong showings by opposition candidates are expected to diminish the majority held by the President Hosni Mubarak's governing party, which gave the president a virtual rubber stamp for his domestic programs. A14
 
Red Army Leader Arrested
The Japanese police arrested Fusako Shigenobu, founder of the Japanese Red Army, a radical group that carried out several international terrorist attacks during the 1970's. A6
 
Death Sentences for Corruption
Chinese courts convicted 84 people of corruption, smuggling and other charges, handing out 11 death sentences to officials involved in a multibillion-dollar smuggling operation in the port city of Xiamen. A16
 
Collision Theory Revived
Russia's deputy prime minister said divers probing the submarine Kursk had found "serious visual evidence" pointing to a collision. A5
 
Lockerbie Trial Resumes
Testimony resumed in the Lockerbie trial of suspects in the bombing of Pan Am 103 that killed 270 people, after a month's delay for lawyers to investigate new evidence. A11
 
World Briefing A10
 
NATIONAL A18-21
 
Officials Cleared in Waco But Prosecutor Is Indicted
John C. Danforth, the special counsel investigating the 1993 Branch Davidian confrontation, said in his final report that federal officials were not responsible for starting the fire that killed some 80 people. He also announced the indictment of Bill Johnston, a former federal prosecutor, on charges of obstructing justice and making false statements. A20
 
Graves Prevail Over Electricity
A federal court has forced a major shift in hydroelectric power operations along the Missouri River, in a ruling intended to provide at least temporary safeguards for Indian graves that are being exposed by record-low water levels. The ruling, which requires maintenance of the current water level at a South Dakota reservoir that is a source of hydroelectric power, will mean a power deficit that will have to be made up for with other sources. A18
 
ELECTION NEWS B1-24
 
Recounting Votes in Florida
Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore dispatched teams of lawyers to supervise a recount in Florida, whose 25 electoral votes appeared to be the key to victory. An incomplete count showed Mr. Bush leading Mr. Gore by 1,784 votes, or three one-hundredths of one percent of the votes cast. The Florida secretary of state said she would probably declare a winner today, but Democrats said they might challenge a Bush victory on other grounds in Florida, and officials in other close states were bracing for challenges, as well. A1
 
Some television network officials acknowledged critical blunders in their Election Night predictions. B1
 
Democrats gained at least three Senate seats and one or two in the House. With one Senate race undecided, Republicans had 50 seats and Democrats 49. House Republicans won an apparent majority of 221 to 211, with 2 independents and one seat undecided, with the Democrat leading. A1
 
EDUCATION
 
New President for Brown
Ruth J. Simmons, the president of Smith College and the daughter a Texas sharecropper, is set to be named president of Brown University today, becoming the first black to head an Ivy League institution. A18
 
NEW YORK/REGION D1-6
 
Plan to Ease Congestion Will Cut La Guardia Flights
The F.A.A. said it planned to reduce landing slots at La Guardia Airport to relieve congestion until it could find a way to restructure airport fees nationwide to discourage gridlock during peak flying times. The plan is expected to force the cancellation of more than 75 flights a day. D1
 
Life Sentence Without Parole
Peter Rollack, 26, who pleaded guilty to a federal racketeering indictment that charged him and 10 other members of his Bronx narcotics gang with a series of murders, was sentenced to life without possibility of parole. He will be barred from communicating with virtually any outsiders. D3
 
ELECTION NEWS B1-24
 
Clinton on Her New life
Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton began the process of hiring a Capitol Hill staff and said that her first bill would be intended to improve the upstate economy. She also said she had no plans to seek the presidency in 2004. B1
 
Close Congressional Races
There were several tight Congressional races in the New York region, and the closest, between Representative Rush Holt, a freshman Democrat in New Jersey's 12th District, and former Representative Dick Zimmer, awaited a recount. B23

Lab Rejects Scientists' Plea
The director of CERN, in Geneva, the leading European particle physics laboratory, will shut down a particle accelerator although scientists using it believe they are near discovering the particle that theorists think is the origin of all mass in the universe. A9

Men who exercised at least five times a week had a sevenfold less risk of sudden death than those who only exercised once a week. A20
