PUB-DATE: November 10, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 38; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4749 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If only a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman). 

 "GIORGIO ARMANI," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 17). The Guggenheim has served up another plateau of urban history: a retrospective of the Milanese fashion designer Giorgio Armani. What it lacks in depth it makes up for with sparkle, and Robert Wilson's architectural transformation of the museum's rotunda may be the best yet. In an inverted version of a life class, instead of the undraped body, the show offers just the drapes. The mannequins have been pared down to the edges of the costumes, and they cluster in groups in the building's structural bays, spatial modules with the proportions of shop windows. Hours and admission: See above (Herbert Muschamp).
 
 * "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with handwritten words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an ice-breaking introduction to an art that to anyone who doesn't know Chinese can seem unapproachable. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students 12 and older and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 "AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART: CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART," 2 Lincoln Square, at West 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Jan. 7). This show celebrates the largess of Mr. Nelson, a book editor and folk art collector who has given 113 objects to the museum with the promise of more. The works, from the late-18th to the mid-20th centuries, cover the traditional areas of folk art -- portraits, landscapes, sculptures, painted and decorated furniture -- but the focus is on American needlework: quilts, coverlets, blankets and the like. Among the quilt spectaculars is the "Samuel Steinberger Log Cabin Quilt, Courthouse Steps Variation," by a 19th-century immigrant. Painted furniture, too, shines in this show. The painting and sculpture pieces make a more modest impression, but over all, what's on view represents a refined, solid ensemble that is very visitable. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Grace Glueck).
 
 "HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Dec. 31). The complex cultural amalgam of music, poetry, break-dancing, art and fashion that is hip-hop poses a serious challenge to any art museum, but with the proper resources and curatorial expertise, it could have been done. Instead this show offers a partial outline of hip-hop history, conveyed by photographs, posters, magazine and album covers, memorabilia and monotonous expanses of clothes that make the show nearly indistinguishable from the gift shop. Garnished with graffiti art, it bypasses many other equally interesting connections to contemporary art. Because the show omits music videos, it manages to be virtually devoid of the sounds, words and moving bodies that are the essence of hip-hop. The results are a cross between a mall and a mausoleum. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 "IN THE PRESENCE OF SPIRITS: AFRICAN ART FROM THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ETHNOLOGY IN LISBON," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Dec. 31). The more than 140 objects on view relate to the secular and the supernatural in African culture: masks, power figures, dolls, decorated stools and chairs, pipes, posts and other artifacts. Outstanding is a group of initiation masks made from wood and more fragile materials like feathers, fabrics and barkcloth fibers. Ranging from fierce to benign in expression, they are giddily imaginative. Impressive, too, is a selection of dolls from the Ambo people of southwestern Angola. The objects in the show were chosen for their high aesthetic value, and it doesn't disappoint. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly; free on Sundays (Glueck).
 
 LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).
 
 "MOROCCO: JEWS AND ART IN A MUSLIM LAND," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Feb. 11). When Arab Muslims arrived in Morocco, Jews had already been living there for centuries, and the two cultures formed a cooperative and uneasy bond. Their relationship is explored in this show, which offers a little bit of many things, mostly dating from the 19th and 20th centuries. In elaborate jewelry, shimmering textiles, liturgical objects and folk amulets, Jewish and Islamic ingredients often form a distinctive hybrid blend. A selection of European Orientalist paintings by Delacroix among others provides a firsthand outsider view of a once-vibrant interaction. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students over 11 and the elderly (Cotter)
 
 "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000," the year-and-a-half-long millennium-marking rethinking of the Modern's permanent collection, is off and running. The dates covered are 1960 to the present, so there's some sense of how a bastion of modernism is dealing with a postmodern world. Pretty well, judging from recent acquisitions of work by Pipilotti Rist, Matthew Barney and Cai Guo-Qiang. The real interest is in smart theme shows that play with such contemporary fixations as childhood innocence and adult experience, and the blend of art, abjection and design. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 "PIERRE ET GILLES," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 7). No history of postmodern photography, fashion photography, celebrity portraiture, record album covers or the highbrow beefcake tradition would be complete without the work of the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles, who have collaborated on over-the-top, tightly styled, hand-finished photographs since 1976 and become wildly famous in Europe in the process. In their first American museum retrospective, their work feels more than a little embalmed, existing behind a not-so-invisible shield of artistic conservatism. Certain images come to life as art objects -- most notably, one of a beautiful young sailor up to his chest in water with an iridescent night sky behind him -- but those are few. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and the elderly (Smith).
 
 "POWER AND DESIRE: SOUTH ASIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE SAN DIEGO MUSEUM OF ART, EDWIN BINNEY 3RD COLLECTION," Asia Society at Midtown, 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Jan. 7.) The album-size paintings known as Indian miniatures, produced for an elite clientele who demanded the finest workmanship, are rightly renowned for their suave forms and brilliant colors. They also embody the moral values, political ambitions and personal aspirations of the culture that produced them. All of these ingredients come into play in this show of 67 top-of-the-line examples from the 16th to 19th centuries. They add up to a kind of grand but intimate theater, equal parts farce, melodrama and mystery play, where men strut like gods, gods have the failings of men, and nature is a gorgeous curtain behind which infinity lies. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 * BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but a beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 "ROMANTICISM AND THE SCHOOL OF NATURE: 19th-CENTURY DRAWINGS AND PAINTINGS FROM THE COLLECTION OF KAREN B. COHEN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 21). European Romanticism was like adolescence: alternately ecstatic and bummed-out, self-obsessed and cosmically empathetic. You get an instant sense of its dynamic in this handsome show, which ranges from exquisite Constable cloud studies, to a handful of I-can't-believe-that's-here Courbets, to the largest group of paintings and drawings by Delacroix in private hands, many of them promised gifts to the Met. And nature, as a scientific fact, a mood-changing drug or a mystical vision, is at the center of it all. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
 * SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 4). "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 21). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind of treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally, the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Met's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
 * EDWARD STEICHEN, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 4). A big, thorough exhibition, maybe a little too big and glossy, of one of the great photographers in American history, a restless, benign, flawed genius. Steichen also painted, made films, designed textiles, organized aerial reconnaissance photography in two world wars and put together the most popular photography exhibition ever, "The Family of Man." We'll see how people respond to someone whose eclectic work can look, if anything, almost too elegant and self-regarding. Steichen ultimately seemed to reduce everything and everyone to props to demonstrate his own refined and stage-savvy sensibility. But what refinement. His best work has a finesse that borders on the erotic. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * "UNTITLED PASSAGES BY HENRI MICHAUX," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through Dec. 20). The books of the Belgian-born French poet and writer Henri Michaux are not exactly unknown on these shores, but his considerable achievement as a visual artist -- a self-taught one -- has yet to gain a solid foothold. This exhibition of more than 100 works on paper should change things. Spanning the late 1920's to the late 1970's, it includes examples of his finely textured "mescaline" drawings, his raucous inkscapes and his animated, often preening calligraphies. It reveals an artist profoundly influenced by Asian art who assiduously mined the fault line between language and sign, text and drawing, image and abstraction, manifesting the flow of human thought and energy in different, often hypnotic ways. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. A related show, "Henri Michaux: Works on Paper," is at Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212) 988-1623, through Nov. 25 (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
JEAN ARP, "Line and Form," Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 744-7400 (through Nov. 18). Arp's art still looks fresh, sweet and humorously subversive, and it is well served by this 32-piece retrospective of drawings, paintings, reliefs and sculptures. Arp's two-dimensional works, like "Profile," an amoebic yellow head or puddle, are marvels of enigmatically suggestive economy. The smooth marble "Dream Flower With Lips," which looks like a female torso or an inverted cartoon leg, marries Grecian classicism and a wacky, polymorphous eroticism (Johnson).
 
 UGO MULAS, "Sequences," Leo Castelli Gallery, 59 East 79th Street, (212) 249-4470 (through Nov. 22). Roy Lichtenstein, Jasper Johns and Barnett Newman are the subjects of these informal but very intense shoots done in 1964 by the Italian photographer Ugo Mulas (1928-1973). The emphasis here is on the contact sheets that Mulas made of the artists at work, conveying in rapid-fire sequence the processes they went through to give material expression to their feelings. Apart from the action drama they convey, and the sense of exchange between the artist and photographer, the photographs evoke a poignant nostalgia for an art world that has long been subsumed by others (Glueck).
 
 W. EUGENE SMITH, Alan Klotz, 22 East 72nd Street, (212) 327-2211 (through Nov. 18). This is a fine small survey of images by the great photojournalist, who worked for Life and many other magazines and died in 1978. Smith's prints have a velvety richness and an unabashedly romantic humanity. The show includes war pictures shot in Japan, like the amazing "Soldier Finding a Baby;" near-visionary views of steelmaking in Pittsburgh; psychologically intense images from his famous series "The Country Doctor"; and meditative portraits of the jazz great Thelonious Monk (Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
"TRES COMPLEMENTAIRES," Mary Ryan Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 397-0669 (through Nov. 22). Time has dimmed the success story of two American artists, Maud Hunt Squire (1873-1954) and Ethel Mars (1876-1959), who expatriated themselves to France in 1906 and spent the rest of their lives there (except during World War I). This show, mounted in cooperation with the Susan Sheehan Gallery, is an attempt to re-establish their work, best represented by their early prints: Squire's color etchings and Mars's color woodblocks. In landscapes, portraits, domestic vignettes, street and cafe scenes, Mars's work is distinguished by its flat forms, bold simplicity of design and lively color. Squire's genre scenes rely more on drawing, done with a highly descriptive anecdotal line. Gravitating to Provincetown during World War I, the two made color woodblock prints that depicted local life, where Squire was in top form with simplified, heavily outline drawings of landscapes, figure and harbor scenes. After the war the two moved to the south of France, where they concentrated on drawing and painting, producing slight but charming scenes of beach and village life. But the early prints stand out (Glueck).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
SEONG CHUN AND DARO MONTAG, Caren Golden, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 727-8304 (through Nov. 25). Ms. Chun crochets thin strips of paper imprinted with writings by Mondrian into gridded compositions that look like deconstructed and slyly domesticated Mondrian paintings. Mr. Montag, a British photographer who does not use a camera, leaves pieces of organic matter -- kiwi slices in the works here -- on color negatives for a time. In the large prints made from these chemically altered negatives, haloed, radiating images in toxic colors glow out of deep black backgrounds (Johnson).
 
 SAM EASTERSON, Rare, 435 West 14th Street, (212) 645-5591 (through Nov. 25). Mr. Easterson went to the desert and attached small video cameras to live animals and plants -- an armadillo, a tarantula, a cactus -- to capture nonhuman points of view. The uneventful tapes are shown on monitors suspended over camera-equipped, stuffed animals surrounded by colored electrical cords arranged in topographical map patterns. Mr. Easterson is apparently serious, but his project looks like something made up by Monty Python (Johnson).
 
 ISA GENZKEN, AC Project Room, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 645-4970 (through Nov. 18). Ms. Genzken, a German sculptor who has been exhibiting since the mid-70's, presents an Arte Povera-style homage to New York City in the form of slapdash skyscraper models made of colored tape, sheets of colored plastic or Plexiglas and found things like a pizza box or oyster shells. A set of photographs of sleek office buildings offers a sharp contrast to the funky sculptural aesthetic (Johnson).
 
 ARTURO HERRERA, Brent Sikkema, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 929-2262 (through Nov. 25). This delightfully versatile and imaginative artist presents an expansive, tangled forest-scape cut from a single 20-foot length of black felt; a large, cut, layered and painted paper collage that has the decorative elegance of Matisse and the funky buoyancy of Elizabeth Murray; small dense paintings made of solid plastic shaped like cartoon fragments; and, on the floor, a sky-colored geometric object made of corrugated cardboard called "Hurry Home, Blue" (Johnson).
 
 DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111 (through Dec. 16). Welcome to the Damien Hirst Universe. It's a big shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and many large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
 MASAMI TERAOKA, Pamela Auchincloss, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 727-2845 (through Nov. 22). First known for crisp Pop-style paintings that mixed traditional Japanese and contemporary Western imagery, Mr. Teraoka has lately been painting large-scale allegories attacking mass-media American sexual hypocrisy in a style loosely derived from Bosch. In these crowded scroll-like pictures, giant naked, variously abused woman are assailed by clerics, politicians and demons of all sizes. Paintings by Mr. Teraoka are also be on view at Jay Grimm, 505 West 28th Street, (212) 564-7662, through Dec. 2 (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
GUDRUN MERTES-FRADY, Rosenberg + Kaufman, 115 Wooster Street, (212) 431-4838 (through Nov. 18). The works of this veteran abstract painter, who moved from Germany to New York two decades ago, are academic but sumptuous. She drags, squeegees and scrapes paint this way and that, creating layered, blurred, checkered surfaces that are richly material yet vaguely illusory, like paintings by a less adventurous Gerhard Richter (Johnson).
 
 DAVID RABINOWITCH, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Nov. 18). Restricting his vocabulary to circles, ovals and straight lines, and his means to pencil, ink or colored pencil, this Constructivist-Minimalist sculptor produced this series of extremely spare drawings during the early 1970's. Called "Construction of Vision," they are resolutely abstract and quasi scientific. But the ellipses and angled lines, cleanly drawn with mechanical drafting tools, have a subtly playful animation (Johnson).
 
 JASON RHOADES, David Zwirner, 43 Greene Street, (212) 966-9074 (through Nov. 18). In one room of Mr. Rhoades's latest essay in sculptural extravagance stands a sort of giant Tinkertoy sawmill -- Sutter's Mill, birthplace of the California gold rush -- made of polished aluminum pipes and clamps. In another room is an identical but incomplete version. During the exhibition, an assistant will always be building or dismantling one or the other mill, acting out a Sisyphean loop of construction and deconstruction (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
"PASTORAL POP!," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through Dec. 15). Nature-inspired kitsch is the theme of this delirious seven-artist show. It includes Rob de Mar's comical landscape in the form of a spindly tree, Lisa Ruyter's psychedelic update of Seurat's "Grande Jatte," Alyson Shotz's grove of weird plant machines, Peter Gould's transformation of the guard station into a bucolic cartoon, Jason Middlebrook's Styrofoam stonewall planter, Katrin Asbury's miniature diorama in a planter and Rachel Feinstein's suspended Rococo-style pitcher exploding flowers like a pinata (Johnson).
 
 "PHOTASM," Hunter College Times Square Gallery, 450 West 41st Street, (212) 772-4991 (through Nov. 18). "Photasm" is a lively, unpredictable exhibition of photographs by 14 sculptors, organized by Peter Dudek. Highlights include Jeanne Silverthorne's tiny, magically intimate studio views; David Shaw's digital, rainbow-hued, geometric mindscapes; Rachel Harrison's crazily cobbled-together sculptures incorporating badly exposed photographs; images of quirky, computer-generated geometric objects by David Schafer; and Bryan Crockett's large, ghostly rayogram of his viscerally baroque balloon sculpture (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
FRANCES BARTH, Donahue/Sosinski, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 226-1111 (through tomorrow). Ms. Barth's medium-large semi-abstract pictures are an odd combination of muted Color Field painting and geological diagramming. Sketchy topographical signs, patterns and textures scatter across broad, stained areas of canvas, and are set off against narrower bands representing stratified cross-sections. The paintings have a curiously dry yet somehow romantic eccentricity (Johnson).
 
 "A BRUSH WITH NATURE: THE GERE COLLECTION OF LANDSCAPE OIL SKETCHES," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Sunday). Most of the artists in this show -- English, French, Italian, German, Belgian and Scandinavian, from the 17th to the 19th centuries -- are barely known today. In their own age they did something quite offbeat: they left studios to paint outdoors, registering transient moments of light and atmosphere by sketching quickly in oil from nature. Until recently it was assumed that this plein-air approach, used to train hand and eye for more ambitious compositions, began with the Impressionists. These canvases today are sought-after prizes. The 68 on view here were assembled by a pioneering scholar and collector in the field, John Gere (1921-1995), former keeper of prints and drawings at the British Museum, and his wife, Charlotte. Mostly painted in Rome and the surrounding countryside, the works capture such painterly events as the seamed face of a rock, the rush of water through a valley, the play of sunlight on a ruin, the quirky architecture of a building or a wall. Tune your eye to small when you look at this show, and you'll find it a treasure. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $5 for students (over 10) and the elderly (Glueck).
 
 JAMES ESBER AND KATIA SANTIBANEZ, P.P.O.W., 476 Broome Street, (212) 941-8642 (through Nov. 11). Mr. Esber's paintings of distorted and fragmented cartoon characters look like collaborations by Peter Saul, Philip Guston and R. Crumb, but have their own creepy-comical sensibility. The best, made of colored modeling clay applied directly to the wall, have a weirdly vivid palpability. In Ms. Santibanez's neat, easel-size abstractions, color-coordinated grass made of strokes of gouache seems to grow from the seams of smooth, cool-white stripe, grid or nested square compositions, to quietly eye-buzzing effect (Johnson).
 
 ALEXIS ROCKMAN, Gorney Bravin + Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through Nov. 11). Inspired by a trip into South American jungles, Mr. Rockman's Pop-realist paintings depict a Northerner's lurid fantasies of tropical adventure and danger. One shows the artist himself gripped in the tentacles of a man-eating plant; another portrays him surrounded by parasites and dangerous fish. Something political about tourism is implied, but the satire is less biting than it should be, and the painting looks like overblown magazine illustration (Johnson).

HEADLINE: Hope for a Copper-Mining Renaissance in Zambia

BYLINE: By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: CHINGOLA, Zambia

 BODY:
Anglo American, the international mining giant based in South Africa, would be only too happy to see the world ignore its interests here in the northern tip of Zambia's Copper Belt. At least for now.
No one here, however, actually expects that to happen, and certainly not just seven months after the conglomerate completed a deal to buy back a big piece of what it lost when Zambia's mines were nationalized three decades ago. But the attempt by Anglo American, the world's largest mining company, to style itself as something less than a major player is an indication of just how much is at stake in the long-delayed privatization of Zambia's mines. 
 Zambia, once among the world's largest copper producers, was never able to parlay its metal riches into lasting prosperity. Today, the mines that were supposed to ensure that security are in shambles, neglected for years by the state mining company, Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines, known as ZCCM.
Losing about $1 million a day, the country's underperforming, overstaffed mines produced 270,000 metric tons of copper last year, and Zambia was the world's 11th-largest copper miner. That is down from more than 700,000 metric tons a year at their peak in the late 1960's, when Zambia was the third-largest copper miner, after the United States and the Soviet Union.
Demand worldwide for copper is solid. It is driven by continued growth in building construction and electronics production, especially of telecommunications equipment. According to the International Copper Study Group's latest report, released in October, the consumption of copper has been outpacing the supply since the second half of last year.
Zambia's volumes may never again reach the levels of its boom, said Willie R. Sweta, the country's mining director. But, he said, once the industry recovers, it should be able to mine more than twice as much as it did in 1999, the last full year of significant state control.
Now that the rich deposits rest squarely in private hands, so, in a sense, do the desperate hopes of this country, a place with profound economic troubles.
As much as they understand those hopes, however, the people who run Anglo's local subsidiary, Konkola Copper Mines, say they must focus on the expensive and complicated task of restoring the mines. Doing so, and forgoing the prominent role the mines have played in supporting the community is the only way to turn the operation around, said T.C.A. Wadeson, Konkola's chief executive.
So as Anglo re-establishes itself here, it is trying to walk softly, even as it wields a very big checkbook. It is spending tens of millions of dollars and making plans to spend even more in its effort to resurrect its chunk of the country's mines.
"We have endeavored to maintain a fairly low profile, which is easier said than done, because we are rather large in this industry," Mr. Wadeson acknowledged.
Here in Chingola, Konkola's newly acquired Nchanga operation, with its nearly 4,000-foot underground mine and sprawling 1,427-foot deep open air mine, has long been a crucial source of copper. For the next several years, it will remain the company's biggest producer.
At the mine's open pit, which is 2.6 miles long and nearly three-quarters of a mile across, work is again buzzing around the clock, now that the equipment is being repaired and the suppliers are being paid. As the setting sun slips beneath the horizon, building-sized dump trucks haul nearly 200 tons of rock at a time up the dusty hills out of the pit.
With its acquisitions, Konkola controls nearly two-thirds of copper production here. That puts it well ahead of the second-largest stakeholder, Mopani Copper Mines, a venture backed by First Quantum Minerals of Canada and Glencore International of Switzerland.
Anglo's history here stretches back several decades. It maintained a 27 percent stake in the state company, albeit without a management role.
The privatization of the mines was painstaking. The mines were put up for sale in 1996. The next year, a deal for several mines was in the works with a group of foreign mining houses, which chose to collaborate rather than compete with each other. But the mining houses, which offered $131 million, and the government, which held out for $500 million, could not close the gap, and the proposed deal eventually collapsed.
It would be many months and millions more dollars in losses before the sale of the mines was completed earlier this year. The largest stake went to Konkola, in which Anglo holds a 65 percent stake, for a net payment of $60 million. The next-largest stake went to Mopani for $43 million.
Anglo is paying $30 million up front, and beginning in 2006, it will pay an additional $60 million, spread over six years. But the initial $30 million payment is effectively canceled out by the $30 million that the government agreed to pay Anglo for the company's stake in ZCCM. Perhaps most critically, the state cut thousands of workers from the payrolls and assumed the reported $770 million in debt that ZCCM accumulated through years of low copper prices and flagging production.
Combined, the two deals will net the government barely $100 million, leaving the windfall from privatization far short of the government's original goal. Many people here have openly wondered how such a potentially precious asset ended up selling so cheaply and costing so many jobs. Some chastised the government, which has defended the deal and says it will benefit the country in the long term; others said Anglo had capitalized on the country's desperation.
Anglo expects to break even by the end of the year and to be turning a modest profit by this time next year. But Mr. Wadeson said it would be years before the company could expect the mines to begin showing sizable profits. And that would happen only after Anglo had spent enormous sums of money on repairing and replacing aging, neglected equipment and bringing in new, sophisticated machinery to exploit the untapped reserves it acquired about 15 miles north of here, in Chililabombwe.
"At this moment, we are producing copper at a cost rate greater than its selling price," he said. "We are dependent on shareholders to keep the company going."
"Anybody that suggests that Anglo got an absolute snip is misinformed," he said, using an expression meaning a very, good deal. "There are still significant risks."

HEADLINE: Beyond Manhattan: Help the Rest of New York

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Rising Cost of Luring People to New York" (news article, Nov. 4): the city needs to attract and keep not only top executives but also workers at every level. For most people in the middle, however, the struggle to keep or find housing in the city grows more and more daunting.
Virtually all of the Bronx, vast stretches of Brooklyn and Queens, and large sections of Manhattan have mistakenly been written off as places for working families. Only parts of Manhattan and a few other elite sections have benefited dramatically from the economic revival. 
 Giving outer-borough neighborhoods a fair share of police services, mass-transit improvements and renovated schools and parks would allow working families to live comfortably in their own city, while giving those who want to move here more options.
 
JOHN M. REILLY
Executive Director
Fordham Bedford Housing Corp.
Bronx, Nov. 6, 2000

HEADLINE: Job Loss Under George Bush Almost Cost His Son a Job

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
IT'S still the economy, stupid. Specifically, it's jobs.
The close election, which George W. Bush apparently will win if Florida does not turn around -- is being widely viewed as an indication that after nearly 10 years of economic growth voters are no longer so concerned about the economy. Indeed, the states that did best during the last eight years voted Republican. 
 But an analysis of the votes shows that Al Gore's strength came predominantly from the states that suffered the most during Bush I, the administration of George Bush, the father of the current candidate. People who lose their jobs, it would appear, have long memories. Moreover, states that improved the most under the Clinton administration tended to favor Mr. Gore this time.
During the Bush administration, which featured a brief recession in 1990-91 followed by a slow recovery, 11 states lost jobs. Of those 11, only New Hampshire voted for the younger Bush in this election. And the Granite State, normally a reliable Republican bastion, went for Mr. Bush by fewer than 8,000 votes.
Nationally, employment rose by 2.4 percent from 1988 to 1992, the worst performance for any such period since Dwight D. Eisenhower's second administration and far below the gains recorded during the last eight years. The poor performance under Mr. Bush was concentrated regionally, in the Northeast and some Midwestern states plus California. Because the states that suffered included many of the larger ones, most states -- 34, in fact -- did better than the national average.
Of those 34, just six backed Mr. Gore this year: Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, New Mexico, Washington and Hawaii. Only in Hawaii and Washington did Mr. Gore get at least 50 percent of the vote. Florida was one of the states that did better than the national average, although it underperformed most states.
At first glance, it might appear that Mr. Gore got no credit for the job growth during the last eight years. Every one of the 10 states with the fastest growth in jobs during the Clinton administration -- Nevada, Arizona, Utah, Colorado, Florida, Idaho, Georgia, Texas, Oregon and New Hampshire -- voted for Mr. Bush. But most of those states were doing quite well before Bill Clinton and Al Gore were elected in 1992 and thus could easily have felt their growth was not related to the administration. While government policies may influence the overall economy, they are less likely to determine which states can profit the most.
A look at relative performance, however, indicates that votes do follow jobs. Of the 10 states where job growth rose the most during the last eight years, as compared with their performance in the Bush administration, 8 backed Mr. Gore. (The exceptions were New Hampshire and Arizona.) Of the 10 states where job performance declined the most, 8 voted for Mr. Bush. (The exceptions were Hawaii and Washington.)
Jobs obviously do not explain everything. It would take an electoral tidal wave for a Democrat to carry Kansas or a Republican to win Massachusetts, regardless of boom or bust in those states. But it is interesting to note that among three Midwestern states that were widely viewed as swing states this fall, Ohio had the smallest improvement in jobs performance under Mr. Clinton, while Pennsylvania did a little better and Michigan was the best of the three. Mr. Bush won Ohio, while Mr. Gore carried the other two.
Jobs do matter, as the new president will learn if too few of them are created during the next four years.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
New Intervention Buoys Euro, And the Pound Also Rises

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The European Central Bank bought euros in the foreign-exchange market yesterday to support the weakened currency, the third such intervention in the last five trading days.
The euro gained more than half a cent against the dollar and rose as well against the Japanese yen after the central bank stepped into the market in early trading in New York. It settled at 86.68 cents compared with 85.58 cents late Wednesday. 
 The intervention briefly shook the market out of a torpor caused by the uncertainty over the United States presidential election.
"Clearly, they're trying to bring some stability to the euro and show that they're serious," said Jay Bryson, global economist at First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C. "If they keep coming in every few days, they'll show that they're willing to do what it takes to bring stability to the euro."
While the central's bank actions have kept the euro off its lows, they have not produced a sustained rebound. And some analysts said the euro-buying actions were losing their effectiveness with repetition. "The more frequently they do it, the less effective it's going to be," said John Rothfield, currency strategist at the Bank of America. "The market observes the price action that follows, and they get more comfortable in challenging the central banks."
The Europeans first intervened on Sept. 22, in a joint action with the central banks of Japan, Britain, Canada and the United States. They re-entered the market alone to buy euros last Friday and again on Monday.
Some analysts said that the three unilateral interventions indicate that the European Central Bank's aim is not to push the euro significantly higher, but simply to build a base and keep it from retesting record lows.
Marc Chandler, currency strategist with Mellon Bank, remarked, "E.C.B. officials have made it clear that the objective of the intervention was not to push the euro to some predetermined level against the dollar, but to underscore its belief that the single currency was undervalued."
In other trading yesterday, the dollar also retreated from seven-week highs against the British pound. In late New York trading, the pound settled at $1.4337, up from $1.4239 on Wednesday.
Earlier in the day, the Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 6 percent for the ninth month. The decision had been expected after Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said that his preliminary budget plan took a balanced approach to maintaining interest rate levels.

HEADLINE: Shares of Retailers Fall as Profits Turn Weak

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Shares of several prominent retailers fell yesterday after disappointing earnings results and a warning by Best Buy.
Gap Inc., hurt by sluggish sales in its Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic divisions, reported a 41 percent drop in third-quarter profit, but still met Wall Street expectations. 
 Kmart missed expectations, however, citing a wider-than-expected loss on its decision to reduce inventory. Lands' End also missed expectations, citing the dollar's strength overseas.
Best Buy, the nation's largest specialty chain, warned that third- and fourth-quarter earnings would fall well short of expectations, sending shares plunging 38 percent. The shares fell $19.88, to $32.50
Analysts said they believed that rising fuel prices, stock market volatility and declining consumer spending continued to take a toll on retailers, and they do not expect the problem to disappear anytime soon.
"The retail slowdown has become more widespread," said John Morris, an analyst at Gerard, Klauer Mattison. "It was first felt in the Midwest, but now you're seeing the party slow down on the East Coast."
Gap, based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it earned $186.3 million, or 21 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 28, compared with $315 million, or 35 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
The results were in line with estimates, according to First Call/ Thomson Financial.
Revenue increased 12 percent, to $3.41 billion from $3.05 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year were down 8 percent.
Shares of Gap fell $1.50, to $24.75.
Efforts by Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., to liquidate unwanted inventory led to a third-quarter loss of $67 million, or 14 cents a share, worse than Wall Street's estimates of a loss of 10 cents a share, according to First Call.
The loss in the 13 weeks ended Oct. 25 was in contrast to earnings of $27 million, or 5 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Third-quarter sales totaled $8.2 billion, up 3 percent from $7.96 billion. Kmart said same-store sales for the quarter increased 1.4 percent.
Shares of Kmart fell 13 cents, to $5.81.
Lands' End reported higher sales but lower earnings in the third quarter, in part because of weak foreign currencies.
The retailer, based in Dodgeville, Wis., said net income for the quarter ended Oct. 27 was $4.4 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $8.8 million, or 28 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 20 cents a share, according to First Call.
Revenue rose 3 percent, to $336.4 million from $326 million.
The company reported 5 percent growth in both its core and specialty business segments. Corporate sales had double-digit growth.
But international business sales were down 11 percent, compared with figures in the period a year earlier, mostly because of the dollar's strength abroad.
Shares of Lands' End fell $2.18, to $24.03.
Best Buy, based in Minneapolis, said that a slowing economy was forcing it to hold more sales and was expected to trim earnings for the quarter ending Nov. 25 to about 27 cents a share, far below analysts' forecasts of 44 cents a share, according to First Call.
Earnings for the quarter ending March 3, 2001, will be about 90 cents a share, compared with expectations of $1.02 a share, the company said.

HEADLINE: Funeral Business's New Look;
As Career Prospects Expand, Work Force Becomes Diverse

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: WEST WINDSOR, N.J.

 BODY:
Annette York's first body was heavier than she had ever imagined. She and a co-worker had just taken it, zipped up in white plastic, from the refrigerator of a Trenton hospital morgue. It was cold and felt like a sack of rocks.
Having spent most of her life working as a hairdresser, she was used to handling curlers, not cadavers. What would she say if the family was there, she thought. What if he smelled? 
 But Mrs. York, 42, a student in the funeral service program at Mercer County Community College, cracked a smile as she drove the body to the funeral home in a black station wagon. She liked working with her hands. She liked dealing with people. And maybe, just maybe, one day she would run her own funeral home.
"I really enjoyed doing it," she recalled of that first corpse removal, in 1996. "I don't know how to explain it. I just liked it. It gave me a feeling of satisfaction, much more so than I ever got from dealing with hair."
A few years ago, Mrs. York's dream of owning a funeral home might have seemed quaint, even quixotic. Sure, business was supposed to rise as the baby-boom generation aged. But the future of the industry seemed to belong to big corporations.
The Service Corporation International, the Loewen Group and others were buying up family-run funeral homes and consolidating them into chains that could benefit from economies of scale in everything from buying coffins to paying for advertisements.
But even as the corporations captured a fifth of the American market, earnings in the "death-care industry" failed to live up to expectations. Stock values plummeted. Service Corporation International's stock, which peaked at $47.13 in July 1998, closed on Nov. 9 at $2.56, a fall of 94 percent. Loewen's shares, which traded for as much as $43 before the company filed for bankruptcy protection in June 1999, closed at 27 cents.
"Competition for acquisitions led to overpayment," said Jennifer Childe, an equities analyst with Bear, Stearns. "That combined with negative publicity, an inability to raise prices and weakened death rates led to a deterioration of earnings."
All this has brightened the outlook for individually owned funeral homes. These days, students from widely varying backgrounds are enrolling in mortuary schools, which in turn have revamped curriculums to focus more on business-management skills.
Although the number of students entering the country's 52 accredited mortuary schools each year has remained at about 2,500 since the mid-1970's, their demographics are changing, said George Connick, executive director of the American Board of Funeral Service Education.
Less than a fifth come from families in the funeral business, he said, in contrast to half the students in the 1970's. Almost half the enrolled students last year were women, as opposed to 5 percent in 1971. And the average age is 25.
"The business has opened up," Mr. Connick said. "It's brought people into the field who have stronger academic backgrounds and stronger backgrounds in working with people. I think the quality of service will improve over time."
This new breed of student is choosing the profession at a time when jobs are abundant. Many people in the industry say that the 35,000 licensed directors now working will not be enough to meet the growing market. The number of deaths in the United States surpassed two million a year in 1983 and rose to 2.3 million in 1998, according to federal statistics. By 2020, the government forecasts the number of deaths will exceed three million, and peak at four million a year by 2040.
The growing demand for directors is reflected in recent salary surveys done by the National Funeral Directors Association. In 1996, a funeral director-embalmer's average annual salary was $32,000 to $33,500. Last year, the upper range increased to $37,000. Owner-managers of funeral homes made an average $48,000 to $57,000 in 1996. Last year, that was reported to be $53,000 to $72,000.
The Mercer County Community College program, founded in 1973, is a microcosm of what is happening in the industry. Only about half the full-time students come from families in the funeral business, said Robert Smith, director of the program. About a third are women. And many of them want to run their own home.
Mrs. York and two dozen other full-time students are enrolled in what, for most of them, is the third and final year of the funeral service program. Many of them have spouses and children and, looking to change careers, have spent two years completing 60 credits of preparatory courses at Mercer before being admitted to the funeral program.
Qualifications for a funeral director's license vary from state to state. New Jersey has relatively tough requirements. An applicant has to have an associate's degree in funeral service (meaning two years of college classes and a third year of funeral service classroom training), do a two-year internship and pass national and state exams. Most students start their internship while in their second or third year of classes.
Training for the profession has become more complex. Mortuary schools are concentrating more on the fundamentals of funeral home management partly because knowledge of the business is no longer necessarily being passed on within families.
"Curriculums have changed now so the programs are much more focused on the psychology of grief and on management skills," said John Horan, a funeral director who serves on the advisory board of the funeral service program at Arapaho Community College in Littleton, Colo. "I remember taking an accounting class when I was in mortuary science school where I felt better qualified to teach the class than the instructor."
From the beginning, Mrs. York knew it would be tough. Her husband and three children "were not too thrilled" with her career choice at first. It had been decades since she had cracked a textbook. She began taking preparatory courses in the summer of 1996. At that stage, science classes like anatomy and chemistry often weed out students.
But Mrs. York realized years ago, when both her parents died unexpectedly, that there had to be more to life than highlights and perms.
"Hair grows back and needs another cut," she said. "But when there's a death, that death stays with the family."
Many of Mrs. York's classmates also came to mortuary school looking for a more fulfilling career. Chris LaBree, 29, had worked for three years as a manager of CVS pharmacies in South Jersey. But he wanted to dispense the kind of pain relief that did not come in plastic bottles. He also wanted to work for himself.
"The minute I get a chance, I will own my own funeral home," he said. "You're your own boss. You're a slave to yourself."
Some of the classroom work covered what might be asked of the students on the board exams. On a recent afternoon, students taking the class called introduction to funeral service learned how much dirt should cover a coffin (at least four feet), the definition of cremation (dehydration of the body at 1,700 degrees Fahrenheit) and what to do after working on a corpse diagnosed with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a variant of mad cow disease (throw away the embalming instruments).
Other classes addressed the practicalities of business management. In funeral service law, for example, the students were taught a few basic rules for avoiding lawsuits: document everything; do not make promises you cannot keep; lock the doors of the funeral home.
The teacher, Deborah Tolboom, projected an equation onto a screen: "Mutilation + Malpractice = Mental Anguish + Money."
"Because of the nature of our business, anything we do could result in mental anguish for the family," she said. "We have to be very, very careful."
Ms. Tolboom has been teaching funeral law for two years. As many of her students had, she made a career switch. She went from being a registered nurse to working as a director at two funeral homes.
"I really hope that I can make a small impact on the future of this profession," she said. "Being female, being second career, I represent the new breed of funeral directors coming in."
Some of the students needed such role models. They said that although changes were taking place, they had run into old-school funeral directors stuck in their ways.
Mary Dempsey, 32, said that when she was looking for an internship, several male managers asked her a litany of questions: How old was she? Was she married? Did she plan to have children? If so, how many?
Mrs. York heard Ms. Dempsey tell this to a classroom visitor. She nodded. Mrs. York was the only student in the class who did not have an internship. She said she had applied to dozens of funeral homes in three counties and had been rejected by all.
Some potential employers asked her during the interview whether she was strong enough to lift a body, she said. At several homes that rejected her, she said, she later found out that they had hired men.
Because Mrs. York did not have an internship, she could not, by state law, take the embalming class this semester. "But I'm not giving up," she said. She was looking forward to taking restorative arts in the spring. Where her nimble fingers had once massaged scalps and trimmed bangs, they would soon be dressing cadavers and brightening their complexions.
Even a corpse has to look its best. Hair styles come and go, but death is forever.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
TV Host With a Sizable Confidence Factor

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
BILL O'REILLY describes himself as a poor prognosticator, a pundit more likely to pick the correct spread in a Jets game than to guess who might win a presidential race. So why is he boasting that he flat-out called Tuesday's (and Wednesday's and yesterday's) vote?
"I said early on that Bush is going to win by eight electoral votes," a tired-eyed Mr. O'Reilly said on Wednesday, as the Florida recount began. "If he wins Oregon and Florida, as I think he will, he'll be right at 278. Eight votes." 
 The math may or may not work out that way, but Mr. O'Reilly's confidence is unlikely to be shaken by anything as fickle as the closest political race in modern American history. Mr. O'Reilly, 51, the tough-talking commentator whose bully pulpit is a nightly program on the Fox News Channel called "The O'Reilly Factor," comes across as so confident that some viewers find him unbearably arrogant. Despite that, or perhaps because of it, Mr. O'Reilly is presiding over one of the fastest growing cable news programs.
During October, "The Factor," as Mr. O'Reilly calls it, ran a strong second in total viewership, according to the Nielsen ratings service, to Larry King, who has long reigned over the nightly cable talk show circuit. (In fact, Mr. O'Reilly's program was seen by a larger average percentage of houses that receive both CNN and Fox News.)
If that isn't enough to swell the head, Mr. O'Reilly is also the author of a best-selling book, bearing the same, slightly sinister-sounding title as the television show. All of which seems to have made this combative commentator slightly, well, humble. (But only slightly.)
"It's a miracle," he says, sounding almost sheepish.
Such a gee whiz description is not what his audience expects from Mr. O'Reilly, who has mastered a central occupational skill for a talk show host: concise answers to complex questions, delivered with swagger.
Take, for instance, the election -- who voted for whom, and why.
"A divided country, mostly along economic lines," he says plainly. "The median income in this country is something like $34,000 and if you break down the vote, most of the people below that vote for the Democrats and most above vote for Bush." Next question, please.
Mr. O'Reilly is blunt. "I ask very incisive, straight-to-the-point kind of questions," he said. "Not Jim Lehrer kind of questions."
For example, when George W. Bush appeared on his show in March, he took the governor to task for his record in Texas.
"I asked, 'If Jesus Christ is your favorite philosopher, what do you think he would think about you presiding over all these executions?' "
Mr. Bush would not speculate, said Mr. O'Reilly. But he added that he admired Mr. Bush for keeping his composure.
SUCH kind comments about a candidate who called himself a conservative have done little to dispel the impression, held by some, that Mr. O'Reilly's politics lean toward the Republican, though he denies that. "I'm an independent," he said. But Mr. O'Reilly seems to have little love for the Clintons; under his desk, for example, he keeps a "Hillary Clinton doormat," with the senator-elect's smiling face on it.
Still, with all the topics Mr. O'Reilly takes on -- class warfare, the media, the importance of good table manners -- he seems not entirely comfortable answering questions about his success. For instance, can this self-described "working class Irish-American" keep his blue-collar credentials now that the best-seller money is rolling in?
"Money doesn't mean anything to me," he said, sounding, for once, like a talk-show guest who knows the artful way to deflect a question.
Tall and gangly, with a Bill Bradley kind of build, Mr. O'Reilly, the son of an accountant and a homemaker, grew up in a middle-class family in Levittown, N.Y., playing football at his public school and painting houses for money during summer vacation. On family vacations, he says, the O'Reillys traveled by bus. He graduated from Marist College in Poughkeepsie, where he was the school's starting quarterback. (He keeps a framed letter M from his jersey on his office wall, alongside an autographed picture of Joe Namath.)
It was during a college year in London that his world view began to develop along "rich versus poor" lines, a position he still adheres to. "England is such a pronounced class society that you couldn't miss it," he says.
After a brief stint as a high school teacher, Mr. O'Reilly gravitated toward broadcast news. Over the next two decades, he worked at television stations "in all four time zones," eventually landing a job in 1989 as the host of the syndicated television program "Inside Edition."
In 1996, Mr. O'Reilly jumped to Fox, where he began to hone his skills as a kind of journalistic attack dog. Considering his reputation, why does he think people still want to come on his show?
"One, you come on to see if you can do it," he said. "And the second reason is that you're sincere in your beliefs. The point of the matter is if you believe in what you say you shouldn't have any fear to go on any program."
He considered that for a moment, then added with a smile, "I think had Al Gore come on 'The Factor' one time, he would have won."

HEADLINE: Rise in Producer Price Index Slowed to 0.4% Last Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Prices paid to manufacturers, farmers and other producers moderated in October, indicating that inflation remained in check.
The Producer Price Index rose 0.4 percent, after rising 0.9 percent in September. While the October gain was higher than forecasts, the core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, showed an unexpected decline of 0.1 percent. It was the third decline in the core rate since last November and followed a September increase of 0.3 percent. 
 The data largely confirm that inflationary pressures have been contained since the Federal Reserve raised interest rates six times between July 1999 and May. The only cloud has been a surge in energy prices, which have now settled down. Indeed, crude oil has been averaging $33 a barrel since October, down from $34 a barrel in September.
"Judging from where energy prices are now, the P.P.I. will fall outright next month," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York. "There's good news in the details that should satisfy the Fed."
Fed officials have indicated in recent speeches and interviews that the inflation risk has diminished and that higher energy and labor costs have not threatened the central bank's efforts to maintain low and stable prices.
Still, energy prices rose 1.4 percent in October after rising 3.7 percent in September, largely a result of a 5.2 percent increase in the cost of residential natural gas. Costs for gasoline and heating oil fell in October.
Food prices rose 0.8 percent in October, the second consecutive increase and the largest since a 1.1 percent rise in April. Egg prices accounted for much of the gain.
Passenger car prices fell 1.8 percent in October, the biggest decline in 10 years, after rising 1.4 percent in September, as automakers offered incentives to clear lots. Prices of light trucks fell 1.2 percent, the steepest decline in three years.
General Motors raised average incentives to about $2,200 in October and offered no-interest loans at Oldsmobile.
A separate report from the Labor Department today showed that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits jumped 35,000, to 344,000, the highest in almost two years. The increase was mostly a result of temporary dismissals by automakers, which closed factories to help reduce inventories.
Jobless claims have averaged about 313,000 a week the last three months and the four-week average for initial claims -- while higher last week at 317,250 -- barely exceeded that level, which suggests little change in the availability of workers.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Disliking Uncertainty, Traders Opt for Treasuries Over Shares

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as stocks fell and the presidential election's outcome remained unsettled. "The markets want resolution, not fighting," said Peter Cordrey, who bought Treasuries yesterday for the $125 billion he helps manage at Prudential Asset Management in Newark. "People don't want this to drag out and be made into a constitutional crisis."
The most-active 10-year note rose 10/32, to a price of 99 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.81 percent from 5.84 percent. The 30-year bond rose 10/32, to 105 19/32, while its yield fell to 5.85 percent from 5.87 percent. 
 Treasuries rose throughout the day after an unexpected drop of 0.1 percent in producer prices, excluding food and energy, combined with news that jobless claims rose a more-than-predicted 344,000. This decline caused speculation that the Federal Reserve's next move might be to lower interest rates.
Government debt prices improved, however, after William M. Daley, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, said the vice president would not concede even if the initial recount of Florida's vote showed Gov. George W. Bush winning the election. Investors are looking at stock declines and "making a run for Treasuries," said Brad Stone, a fixed-income analyst at Goldman, Sachs.
For the Treasury market, the election centered on which candidate would preserve more of the budget surplus, projected at $237 billion in the fiscal year ending on Sept. 30.
The vote left both the House and the Senate closer to evenly divided between Republicans and Democrats, making it less likely that the next president would be able to enact measures that would either erode the budget surplus or spur inflation.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Seesaw on Election News; Major Indexes Down Slightly

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Investors went into shock but quickly recovered yesterday as they faced the possibility that the still-undecided presidential election might remain in limbo for days or weeks.
Stocks plunged in the early afternoon, after William M. Daley, the campaign chairman for Vice President Al Gore, said in a news conference that Mr. Gore might challenge the election results in Florida even if Gov. George W. Bush continued to lead after the state concluded its vote recount. 
 Barring reversals of the outcome in other states, Florida's 25 electoral votes will prove decisive in the most closely contested election in 40 years. Mr. Bush holds a slim lead in Florida with the recount nearly concluded. But Democrats complain that a badly designed ballot in Palm Beach County caused thousands of voters to have their ballots discarded when they meant to vote for Mr. Gore.
After Mr. Daley made his comments about 1:30 p.m., Eastern time, the Dow Jones industrial average lost more than 150 points in 15 minutes. At that point, the index stood at 10,618.49 and had fallen almost 3 percent for the day. Over the same period, the Nasdaq composite index slid 60 points, or almost 2 percent, to an intraday low of 3,087.06, barely above its low for the year.
But as the afternoon progressed, investors' fears subsided. By 4 p.m., the end of regular trading, the major indexes were off less than 1 percent. The Dow closed down 72.81 points at 10,834.25, the Nasdaq ended at 3,200.35, a loss of 31.35 points, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.14 points, to 1,400.14.
After Mr. Daley's comments, "people got a wee bit excited," said David Wyss, chief economist for Standard & Poor's. "The blunt fact is there aren't going to be tanks on the streets."
As long as both Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore agree to abide by the final results of Tuesday's election, the dispute is unlikely to cause a serious shock to the economy or the markets, said Ed Yardeni, chief investment strategist for Deutsche Bank.
"This country is very level-headed, and at the end of the day we'll get this thing sorted out," Mr. Yardeni said.
But he added that stocks could be expected to remain unsettled until a winner was declared.
"Everybody's got some jitters waiting for this thing to be sorted out," Mr. Yardeni said. "There's some concern that the lawyers are going to take over and this thing is going to drag on for a while."
Investors are also worried that electoral uncertainty will be a drag on the already-slowing economy, said Robert Bacarella, co-manager of the $135 million Monetta Fund, which invests in small growth stocks.
Reflecting that nervousness, shares in consumer products companies like Coca-Cola and Kimberly-Clark rose yesterday as investors looked for companies more likely to post slow but steady growth in any economic or political environment. Coca-Cola gained $1.94, to $62.13, while Kimberly-Clark rose $1.63, to $66.13.
Many big technology stocks continued to suffer. Intel dropped $1.31, to $41.38, Sun Microsystems fell $2.69, to $97.63, and the EMC Corporation slid $4.75, to $85.25, though Microsoft gained $1.44, to $70.88.
"There's definitely a shift towards defensive stocks in the past six weeks," Mr. Bacarella said. "There's a general concern that the economy is slowing down, a shifting towards the foods and the drugs and the more predictable sectors."
Over the last month, Mr. Bacarella has increased the cash he holds in his fund from 5 percent to 25 percent. Although stocks have dropped during that time, he said he was not eager to start buying again. "We're just sitting, and I'm going to wait until I can see a definite bottom," he said. "I'm not going to be a hero."
Retailers and media companies, which are highly sensitive to economic growth, both had bad days. After warning that earnings for its December quarter would not meet analysts' estimates because of a slowdown in ad sales at its ABC network, Disney plunged $5.50, to $31.38, a 15 percent drop.
Other media companies also fell after a Merrill Lynch analyst, Jessica Reif, warned that the slowdown would not be confined to Disney. Viacom, which owns CBS, fell $4.19, to $53.38, while Fox Entertainment skidded $3.06, to $18, a 14.5 percent drop. Best Buy, a major retailer of consumer electronics, lost almost 40 percent of its value after warning that its earnings would fall short of expectations, closing at $32.50, a loss of $19.88.

HEADLINE: Japan Restates Economic Health

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Japan's government downgraded its official assessment of the economy slightly in a monthly report today, saying that it continues to move toward a self-sustaining recovery but improvements in the household sector are lagging.
Although slight, the downgrade was the first since September 1998. But a senior official of the Economic Planning Agency, which produces the report, denied it meant the economy was facing a downturn. 
 Haruhito Arai, director of the agency's domestic affairs, said: "We decided on a more cautious assessment. But that does not mean the economy is worsening. The recovery trend remains intact."
The agency said in its monthly report that "the economy has not emerged from a severe situation, with improvements in the household sector lagging, but overall a moderate improvement continues led by the corporate sector."
Mr. Arai said the agency wanted to draw a sharp contrast between the robust recovery in corporate spending and the lagging household sector, which includes personal consumption and employment conditions.
The agency left its assessment of personal consumption unchanged in the monthly report and upgraded the household income portion.
Core household spending, which excludes big-ticket items like automobiles, rose 0.9 percent in September from the previous month on a seasonally adjusted basis. But the gains in September failed to lift spending to positive territory for the July-to-September quarter.
Mr. Arai also cited a slowdown in exports and cautious corporate sentiment as factors for the downgrade in the overall assessment. "Exports to the United States and Europe are leveling off," he said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Original Sin

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
While no one still knows who won the election, I can tell you what the next cabinet should look like.
If George W. Bush is the winner, there is no doubt that his secretary of state should be Bill Clinton, his U.N. representative Joe Lieberman, his secretary of defense Sam Nunn and his secretary of the interior, unquestionably, Al Gore. The rest should be traditional Republicans. 
 If Al Gore is the winner, his secretary of state must be Colin Powell and his secretary of defense certainly Dick Cheney. Condi Rice would make a fine Gore U.N. representative, and you don't even have to ask who should be Mr. Gore's secretary of education -- George W. Bush. The rest should be traditional Democrats.
I'm serious -- sort of. When I was the Times correspondent in Jerusalem in the mid-1980's, I covered Israel's first non-wartime national unity government, which came about after Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Shamir tied in their election. They actually took turns ruling over four years. I never thought I would see that in America, but we may now need some version of national unity government.
A national unity government is deeper than mere bipartisanship. It is a government that reflects the fact that the electorate is so divided neither party has a mandate for its agenda and therefore must rule from the center, with a cabinet that looks like the electorate -- that is, with representatives from both parties.
Sadly, the next U.S. president, whoever he is, has been born in sin. There is no hope anymore for a virgin birth. Mr. Bush could reap a winner-take-all political harvest -- the House, the Senate and the White House -- without winning the popular vote and winning the Electoral College only because thousands of Gore voters in Palm Beach County had their ballots nullified or accidentally voted for Pat Buchanan. (Even Mr. Buchanan said yesterday that "most of these are probably not my votes.")
Mr. Bush can surely say, well, that's not my fault, and the election's over. Yet everyone will know that he did not win the popular vote or the Electoral College. And under those conditions the public would rebel -- I'm talking about mass protest not seen since the Vietnam War -- if Mr. Bush were to actually try to team up with conservative Republicans in Congress to ram through his agenda.
At the same time, Mr. Gore could mount a court challenge, but even if he wins, many Republican voters would feel they had been cheated by some legal ruse. And many others would feel uncomfortable with a judge's deciding the election. The G.O.P. Congress and Senate would rebel, and ensure that Mr. Gore's political life was miserable.
Either case is a prescription for malignant gridlock. The political analyst Kevin Phillips usefully points out there are two kinds of government gridlock: There is the gridlock the financial markets like -- benign gridlock -- in which the Republicans are blocked from implementing their most extreme tax cuts and Democrats their most excessive spending. And there is malignant gridlock, in which the parties are so at odds the government can't produce any coherent initiatives, at home or abroad.
We can't afford malignant gridlock for four years, and the world cannot afford malignant gridlock in America for four years. For everyone's sake, American democracy must be seen as being beyond manipulation. The stability of the world rests on that. That's why this unprecedented ending to a U.S. election calls for an unprecedented response -- some kind of national unity cabinet. George W. Bush boasted that he was the candidate who could actually bring people together. He may soon learn that such a unifying skill is no longer just a quaint virtue, but a necessity for governing. The same for Mr. Gore.
If both men understand that, there's hope that their presidency, though born in sin, can thrive. If they don't understand that, theirs, and ours, will be a bitter harvest.
P.S. My only hope is that no matter who wins, he will name Ralph Nader the first U.S. ambassador to North Korea. That way Ralph can spend his days with another egomaniacal narcissist, Dear Leader Kim Jong Il, and get a real taste of what a country that actually follows Mr. Nader's insane economic philosophy -- high protectionism, economic autarky, anti-markets, anti-globalization, anti-multinationals -- is like for the people who live there. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE 2000 ELECTION: PALM BEACH;
At the Epicenter of a Voting Dispute, a Chasm in the Streets

BYLINE: By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 9

 BODY:
As lawyers and election workers hovered gravely over disputed ballots inside Palm Beach County's government center, the scene outside dissolved into a debate over intelligence: one side ridiculed a candidate, the other side, the voters.
And so it went across the chasm of Olive Street, the usually quiet thoroughfare that cuts through downtown. 
 On one side of the road supporters of Vice President Al Gore gathered to demand a new vote across the entire county to undo the effects of the county's now-notorious ballots.
The Gore crowd chanted, "Re-vote! Re-vote!" and denounced Theresa LePore, the county supervisor of elections, who had approved the design of the ballots. The crowd swelled to several hundred by midday, when the Rev. Jesse Jackson stopped by to decry what he said was the denial of voting rights to many across Palm Beach County.
"There was a misalignment in the process," Mr. Jackson said. "If you drive your car down the road in a little car and your wheels are not aligned, you have a wreck. That was a wreck in West Palm."
But for many who came to demonstrate, the issue was less about the confusion of the ballots than about the presumed lack of intelligence on the part of Gov. George W. Bush. Many demonstrators waved signs that read, "Bush is too dumb to be president." Others talked of how the country's economy would slide if Mr. Bush entered the White House.
On the other side of Olive Street, the Republicans denounced those who complained about the ballots. They laughed at the Democratic demonstrators across the road and at those who had failed to figure out the ballot's instructions.
"I wasn't confused," several placards read.
Jack Rampriester, a mortgage broker from Boca Raton, said, "All you had to do was read the directions. Why is that only Democrats are complaining about the ballot language? Are they too dumb to read?"
Like many of those who marched and chanted outside the government center, Mr. Rampriester said he had decided to join the demonstration when he saw it on television at work. He and a friend, Pat Shanahan, put together a pair of homemade signs and jumped in their cars.
"Somebody had to come down here and tell the truth," Mr. Shanahan said. "The Democrats are talking a lot of nonsense. There wasn't anything wrong with those ballots."
Meanwhile, inside the government center, the woman everyone wanted to talk to -- Ms. LePore -- made her only public appearance at a press conference. And through her lawyer, Bruce Rogow, she declined a request for an interview.
Ms. LePore has been blamed for the ballot design that many say prevented them from selecting the candidate they wanted. She has said that she thought the design made the candidates' names easier to read.
"Hindsight is 20-20," The Palm Beach Post quoted Ms. LePore as saying, "But I'll never do it again."
While many people here said they respected Ms. LePore, some voters voiced their suspicions about the ballot design, spinning out theories of a conspiracy to throw the vote to Bush and the Republicans.
"She is the one who created this problem," said Edna Bookspan, who was playing bridge at the Fountains Condominium Complex, said of Ms. LePore, a Democrat. "I don't know why she did it, but I think ultimately Bush's people were behind it."
