HEADLINE: Thinkers on the Left Get A Hearing Everywhere but at Home;
Europeans, Wary of Globalization, Embrace American Economists Who Heed Social Needs

BYLINE: By ALEXANDER STILLE

 BODY:
James Tobin, a Nobel Prize winner who served as an economic adviser to the Kennedy administration in 1961 and '62, has lived in quiet retirement for more than a decade in New Haven. Yet thousands of French demonstrators are likely to invoke him as their intellectual champion next month during protests at the coming summit meeting of the European Union. They are members of a new organization formed expressly to promote the so-called "Tobin tax," a tax on foreign currency and international financial transactions that came within six votes of being adopted by the European Parliament this year.
In Britain, the Labor Party is contemplating a proposal to give $14,000 to every 18-year-old to invest either in his education or in a house -- a modified version of an idea proposed by Bruce Ackerman, a law professor at Yale University, in his book "The Stakeholder Society." 
 Meanwhile, "The Access Society," the latest book of Jeremy Rifkin, an outspoken American critic of genetically modified food and what he calls the new "hypercapitalism," is the No. 1 seller in Italy and No. 3 in Germany, even though it failed to make national best-seller lists in the United States.
The three men are examples of a curious trend: the popularity in Europe of left-of-center American economists and thinkers who are largely ignored at home.
With a mixture of puzzlement and amusement in his voice, Mr. Tobin said, "There are probably more members of Attac in France than people who know my name in the United States." He was referring to the Association for the Taxation of Financial Transactions for the Aid of Citizens, an organization -- now 27,000 members strong in France -- created to promote his tax proposal.
In the view of some American conservatives, Europe is simply behind the times, picking up ideas that have been discarded in the United States, in an effort to save the old European welfare state. "It's retrograde and reactionary mushy-headed liberalism," said Rudiger Dornbush, a professor of economics at M.I.T. "Europe tries to defend the status quo against the better sense of the free-market revolution." The European Wall Street Journal recently compared the resurgence of the Tobin tax in Europe to a vampire that keeps rising from the dead.
But others, like Bernard Cassen, the president of Attac, argue that Europe is in the vanguard of an effort to ensure that the current economic boom of globalization serves social ends. "Globalization was supposed to be the answer to everything," he said, "and what we see is growing inequality of wealth between nations and within nations, reduction of health and social benefits, greater job insecurity."
Europe is searching for alternatives to what it calls winner-takes-all capitalism, often referred to as the American model, and Mr. Cassen believes there is enormous symbolic value in linking a prominent American economist like Mr. Tobin to the growing movement to redirect the boom of globalization toward social ends. It shows that the movement is not anti-American, he said, and it gives what might otherwise appear like pie-in-the sky idealism grounding in the very specific proposals of a world-class economist.
To David Spector, a French economist teaching at M.I.T., one reason for American progressives' popularity is that they function as "American dissidents" serving France's critique of a phenomenon that is widely perceived as American in its origins. Thus, being able to cite American critics of globalization and contemporary American capitalism -- among them, besides Mr. Rifkin, the economists Lester C. Thurow, James K. Galbraith and Robert B. Reich -- is, for the European left today, a bit like the anti-Communists of the 1970's quoting Russian dissidents like Andrei D. Sakharov and Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn.
Mr. Rifkin agrees. "Generally," he said, "what they hear from us is: 'If you don't get with the program -- efficient markets 24 hours a day, 7 days a week -- you are going to get steamrollered. They are worried about being left behind economically, but they are also worried about keeping the quality of life in Europe, which in many ways is better than ours. For them to hear -- from other Americans -- that it's all right for them to be suspicious of the American model is very welcome."
Even more significant from an American perspective is that after taking the European tour, some of these ideas are finally getting a hearing in their birthplace. Mr. Rifkin said that after the protest against genetically modified food became big in Europe, major American companies like McDonald's and Archer Daniel Midland changed their policies. Similarly, he said, Washington was pressured to respond to the European campaign to forgive third-world debt, and objections from the European Community forced significant modifications in the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner. "Europe is not the mouse that roared," Mr. Rifkin said, "it's become the elephant that roared."
Next month, on a hectic schedule of European appointments, Mr. Rifkin will be meeting with the leadership of the French parliament. Mr. Rifkin's 1995 book, "The End of Work," with a 20-page introduction from the former French prime minister Michel Rocard, pushed the idea of a 35-hour work week, which is now French law. Italy's prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, dedicated most of an hourlong press conference to Mr. Rifkin's 1998 book, "The Biotech Century," when it came out in Italy last year.
Another reason American progressives are playing such a conspicuous role in Europe's efforts to come up with a "third way" between socialism and American-style capitalism, said Mr. Ackerman of Yale, is that they are not Marxists. The European left has been traditionally dominated by Marxism, and as it seeks to create an alternative kind of capitalism, it looks to left-of-center American economists have been working within the capitalist paradigm for their entire careers. "I think something we all have in common is that we accept the basic structure of capitalism while trying for a more democratic and egalitarian form of capitalism," Mr. Ackerman said.
The idea behind Mr. Ackerman's notion of giving every 18-year-old $80,000 is to create a contemporary version of the 19th-century homesteading notion of 40 acres and a mule. This, he reasons, would promote equality not by increasing government services but by making everyone a potential capitalist.
"There are a lot of people interested in a kind of realistic utopianism," said Mr. Ackerman, who recently returned from a conference in Germany at which he delivered the keynote address.
His ideas, he said, have attracted expressions of interest from politicians in such countries such as France, England, Germany and Brazil but nothing of significance from American politicians.
All the same, he maintains, his idea of giving people an $80,000 stake to invest is in certain ways not that conceptionally different from Gov. George W. Bush's proposal to allow young people to create investment accounts with their Social Security contributions, what Mr. Bush referred to in his campaign as "prosperity with a purpose." Mr. Ackerman said that in Alaska, each year, every citizen gets about $1,900 from oil revenues -- "and it's a Republican idea."
Mr. Tobin, who originally proposed the so-called Tobin tax in 1972 as a means of reining in unproductive currency speculation, has mixed feelings about his sudden burst of popularity abroad. "My name gets associated with some proposals that I never actually made," he said. "I was trying to stabilize the international monetary system and penalize speculation, since most foreign exchange transactions are reversed within the week if not within the day. Of course, the revenue it generates can be put to good purposes, and I have no problem with that, but I'm not against globalization. I'm a free trader."
Some $1.3 trillion changes hands each day in foreign currency transactions. The suggested Tobin tax of 0.25 percent would raise about $250 billion a year -- more than five times the current level of all international aid. But the idea is almost impossible for any single country to adopt on its own because currency traders would simply shift operations elsewhere. The French treasury minister, Laurent Fabius, a Socialist, rejected a proposed Tobin tax in August.
But Mr. Cassen argues that the plan will work only if all of Europe adopts it. "We see Europe as a Tobin zone," he said.
Mr. Dornbush said he considered the tax a bad idea but acknowledged that it does have a chance in the European Parliament: "They are the rear-guard of the future, the home of government intervenionism. They will tax anything that moves."
While the Tobin tax is unlikely to make headway here, there is evidence of a feedback loop between Europe and United States. Although Jeffrey D. Sachs, a professor of economics at Harvard, doesn't see Europe as in the vanguard, he said his own recent experience as chief economist to Jubilee 2,000, the movement to forgive third-world debt, confirmed the general notion that Europe is acting as a kind of testing ground for ideas that have then caught on in the United States.
"The thing that I found," he said, "is that something that is of only the most esoteric interest here -- forgiving third-world debt -- is a matter of everyday discourse in Europe. It became a genuine mass movement with huge demonstrations and became part of mass culture, showing up in movies and songs and then caught on here. The message came from Europe, but then it transferred to church groups and other groups here who then called and petitioned Congress."
Subsequently, Congress and President Clinton agreed to cancel some $435 million in debt, a measure signed by Mr. Clinton this week.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/South Amboy, N.J.;
A Blue-Collar Town Making a Comeback

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
WHEN the 5:05 a.m. New Jersey Transit train rumbles through South Amboy, N.J., on its way to Penn Station in New York, it rattles the windows of the five apartments above the Landmark Tavern and Cafe. "We don't charge our tenants for the wake-up call," the tavern owner, Robert Heiser, said. Just five feet from the tracks, the building is a symbol of the 1.8-square-mile city's bustling past and its ongoing revitalization.
Built in the late 19th century, the Landmark houses a collection of local memorabilia. A cigar store Indian graces its doorway, and the walls hold an 1883 Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen poster, photos of the city's old coal docks on Raritan Bay, a "Welcome Home" sign that greeted servicemen returning from World War II and a brass plaque that graced the front of a now-shuttered Jersey Central Power and Light generating plant. 
 Outside the bar, the city's restoration efforts are evident. Worn concrete sidewalks have been replaced with bricklike paving stones that are punctuated by Victorian-style street lights, both financed by a $2 million grant from the New Jersey Department of Transportation. A score of storefronts, including the Landmark, have new 19-century-type facades, most paid for by a six-year, $318,000 grant from the United States Department Housing and Urban Development and matching money from property owners.
"Six years ago, 65 percent of our stores were vacant, and a turnaround seemed all but impossible," Mayor John T. O'Leary said. "Now that we are cleaning up and redoing the downtown, 80 percent of the stores are occupied. We're gaining ground, but we're not yet where we want to be."
Among the new businesses to take their places among the two turn-of-the-century pharmacies, the bakery and the hardware store are an all-Irish boutique, the Broadway Diner and Harbor Lights Restaurant (steak and seafood). The mayor says he is trying to attract boutiques, service businesses and offices that can withstand the competition from the three malls within a 10 mile radius: Woodbridge Center to the north, Menlo Park to the west and Brunswick Square to the south.
The population mix has not changed much since the beginning of the 20th century, when Irish and Polish immigrants came to work on the three railroads that crisscrossed the city. Children still play stickball and basketball in streets, and newcomers are cautioned not to say anything derogatory about any resident because everyone is related to everyone else.
For its size, South Amboy has an inordinate number of liquor licenses -- 22 -- but this reflects a continuing decline from 1981, when the Rand McNally "Places Rated Almanac" listed the city as having 37 taverns -- the most per capita in the country, one for every 218 residents.
"We are a solidly blue-collar town," Mr. Heiser said. "But things are changing. Younger people support the revitalization efforts, and newcomers are starting to move in. Ten years ago, you'd never see a customer come in here with a book. Now they come in with laptop computers. And when the new housing is complete, we're expecting an accelerated rate of positive change."
Like the downtown, most of South Amboy's housing was built before 1920, when census figures showed a population of 7,898, about its current size. There are 3,500 single-family houses and 321 two-family homes. The houses consist mainly of older colonials and duplexes, with a few Victorians, bilevels and Cape Cods. Although neighborhoods have mixed housing styles and values, some of the largest houses -- including a number of fieldstone and stucco homes -- can be found on Pine Avenue and some the smallest brick and clapboard duplexes are on First and Second streets.
ACCORDING to the Middlesex County Office of Economic Development, housing prices range from $90,000 to $200,000. Currently, 18 houses are listed for sale on the Multiple Listing Service. They range from $89,900 for a fixer-upper near the shoreline to $172,000 for a bilevel on Bordentown Avenue near Broadway. Two-family homes are listed for $119,000 to $210,000.
Two-bedroom apartments in two-family homes or above stores along Broadway rent for an average of $850 a month, according to Arthur A. Gross, a broker-appraiser with Stern & Dragoset Inc., a realty company in neighboring Woodbridge. One-bedroom units rent for $650 to $700.
Joseph Harrigan, broker-owner of J. J. Harrigan & Company Realtors in Sayreville, said that his customers are often second and third generation South Amboy residents and that about one-fourth of the homes coming on the market receive multiple offers and sell near the asking price.
"It's a good, safe town and, compared to other towns nearby, it's affordable, which makes South Amboy a hot market," he said. "And the redevelopment of the town is already giving the market a boost."
Two years ago, the city received its first major new housing in 40 years, with the construction of Shore Gate, a four-story, 114-apartment condominium building for people age 55 and older, overlooking Raritan Bay, just off O'Leary Boulevard, a new road named for the mayor. The units -- all two bedrooms -- sell for $125,000 to $150,000 according to Tony Danza of North Haledon, N.J., who developed the property.
South Amboy began in the mid-17th century as a Dutch military settlement to protect New Amsterdam (now Manhattan) from the British. Among the earliest settlers was the Bloodgood family, ancestors of Robert Bloodgood, the current superintendent of schools, who grew up in the city. During the Revolutionary War, a local tavern owned by a Tory named John Rattoone catered to soldiers from both sides and was the venue for the transfer of notes between the turncoat Continental general Benedict Arnold and the British.
The city began taking shape in 1831, with the arrival of the Camden and Amboy Railroad, which was later taken over by the Pennsylvania Railroad. By the turn of the century, the Raritan River and the Central New Jersey Railroads had also arrived, and South Amboy was transformed into a transportation and industrial powerhouse. Its Eastern Coal Docks on Raritan Bay transferred Pennsylvania coal and other goods from trains to barges for distribution all along the East Coast. It also had cigar, paint, terra cotta and textile plants that provided thousands of jobs.
By the early 1970's, most of the factories had closed, and in 1982 South Amboy lost more jobs when the coal docks shut down. As if to seal the town's fate, the Army Corps of Engineers all but destroyed the city's shipping capability by dredging the Raritan Bay channel and dumping the silt along the South Amboy coastline, creating an additional 66 acres of land.
Now, this 66-acre landfill site is one of the cornerstones of the city's redevelopment, which is to include enhanced train service, a high-speed ferry to Manhattan, 1,000 new homes and three million square feet of office space. Because of its strategic location just across from Manhattan and less than 10 miles from the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike, South Amboy has been designated by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman as one of five New Jersey "transit villages," making it eligible for increased state aid. New Jersey Transit has committed to spend $18.2 million in the next three years to build a five-block-long elevated train platform. Congress has awarded the city $14.2 million for road improvements, including an access road across the landfill to the bay, which will allow for construction of the ferry terminal.
THE landfill is also the focus of municipal and private development. A complex built five years ago on O'Leary Boulevard includes the high school, public library and youth center. Next to Shore Gate, developers have just broken ground on a 114-unit town house complex and are soon expected to start a 73-unit single-family development.
In addition, Middlesex County has just completed the 136-acre Raritan Bay Waterfront Park. Although most of the park is in neighboring Sayreville, the entrance and the gazebo are in South Amboy. The park, which is the city's largest recreational site, contains two multipurpose fields, a lighted baseball field, a football stadium, a soccer field, beach front and a wildlife preserve. The county and the city are discussing the incorporation of an additional 22-acre parcel of city-owned land into the park.
The new development will be felt in the 1,200-student South Amboy Public School System, which consists of the 720-student South Amboy Elementary School for prekindergarten through sixth grade and the new 480-student South Amboy High School for grades 7 through 12. The average class size in the two schools is 20, which is one student less than the state average. Computers are introduced in prekindergarten, with every classroom throughout the system having at least one terminal.
"Our educational philosophy is that it takes a village to raise a child and that healthy schools help keep the community healthy," Mr. Bloodgood said. "Being a small system allows us to get to know all of the families. We have five social workers, who reach out to families when there are problems, and five counselors, who work with the children. The aim is to ensure that every child arrives at school ready to learn."
At the high school level, 20 hours of community service are required annually for students in grades 10 to 12. Advanced Placement courses are offered in biology, social studies, English and mathematics. Of last year's 54 student graduating class, 72 percent went on to higher education. On College Board tests, South Amboy's students had an average combined verbal and mathematics score of 851, which is 158 points below the state average.
Even without the expected influx of children because of the new construction, Mr. Bloodgood said, the system is growing by 50 children annually. Over the next five years, a new school, called an early childhood center, will be built to house prekindergarten through third grade. When that school is complete, Mr. Bloodgood said, the number of children per class is expected to drop to 18 from 20.
"We are trying to make the most of our growth to ensure that our citizens have a better town," the mayor said. "Our small train station is already receiving 1,800 train passengers per day and has just 200 parking spaces in the downtown. Southern New Jersey is developing rapidly, and we are already the state's third busiest station. The tide of commuters is coming in, and we can either be strangled by it or develop as a result of it."

BOOM TOWN: Twice, South Amboy was nearly destroyed by military-related explosions. The first, on Oct. 4, 1918, flattened the sprawling T. A. Gillespie plant, which produced 32,000 shells daily for the Allies in World War I. Seventy people were killed and the entire town was evacuated during the three days of blasts that followed the initial explosion. Again, on May 19, 1950, when South Amboy's waterfront was being used for the transfer of explosives from trains to ships, an explosion rocked the town. Some 420 tons of land mines and dynamite bound for the Far East went off, killing 31 workers, who were then known as "powder monkeys" because they handled explosives. Every window in the town was blown out, houses were flattened and mines were strewn over the nearby countryside. Mayor John T. O'Leary said the 1950 explosion marked the beginning of South Amboy's decline, from which the town is just beginning to recover.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 11-12-00: On Language;
Rollout

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
'Early in its foreign rollout," reported Daily Variety, a movie titled "X-Men" hauled in $3.4 million over an opening weekend.
A restored version of the Rolling Stones' concert film "Gimme Shelter," issued on its 30th anniversary, "will begin a nationwide rollout in a few markets," according to a Reuters dispatch from Los Angeles. 
 The Asian Wall Street Journal spread the word throughout the Far East: " 'The Broken Hearts Club' will have a slow U.S. rollout beginning in major cities."
What is this movie marketing term that has so captivated the merchants of dreams in Hollywood? Where did it begin, and what did it come to mean?
"Roll out!" as every Army veteran of World War II grimly remembers, was the unwelcome barracks call that pierced the blessed stillness of the morning. Accompanied by the admonition to "grab yer socks," the phrase has a literal meaning of "roll out of bed." It was often followed by a sardonic "rise and shine," a metaphoric allusion to the sun, and a few minutes later by "fall out on the company street!" -- an order to assemble outside, in front of the barracks.
The transitional metaphor to its use in Hollywood probably came from the aircraft or automotive industries, as vehicles rolled out of hangars or off assembly lines. Ira Konigsberg, author of "The Complete Film Dictionary," suggests a more ancient origin. "The point of the term is to suggest the growing appearance of the film much like the expansion of a carpet when it is rolled out."
How is a rollout different from a release? "A typical Hollywood release is a wide release to a national public all at once," says Konigsberg, "because of the reliance on national television advertising. Rollouts are for independent, foreign or more specialized Hollywood films that need to build interest by word-of-mouth or simply must earn the right to proceed to larger audiences."
A rollout, then, like its synonym "platforming," is a process of release, taking place in stages. This useful term for gradual release or step-by-step development was picked up by marketers in other fields. The magazine Martha Stewart Living led to Martha Stewart Weddings, which gave birth to Martha Stewart Baby, and Ms. Stewart told Advertising Age last month, "There probably will be a rollout from there."
Political usage in the recent campaign, however, vitiated the nice distinction between the simultaneous general release and the calibrated rollout. "One prominent Republican strategist said that the rollout of Mr. Cheney had been disappointing," wrote Eric Schmitt of The Times in August. "Gore's handlers are plotting yet another rollout of their candidate," wrote Howard Fineman in Newsweek a month later.
This sense suggests only "introduction," and frays the carpet's specific edge. But politics likes to seize on with-it words and fuzz up their meanings.
 
Laydown Dates
 The book-publishing industry has its own new term for a variation of a release date: laydown. "This review copy is being sent to you," Knopf Publicity notifies me, "with the understanding that you will not run your review before Tuesday, July 18 -- which is the National Laydown Date for bookstores all across the country. (Official Publication Date is July 25.)"
A vision came to me of the National Laydown Date, a date that would live in the annals of relaxation. Hammocks would be handed out, busy intersections closed for pedestrians to stretch out and take a nap, yoga teachers enlisted for supervision of supine and prone meditators, all putting out of their slackened and refreshed minds the dread prospect of the inevitable National Standup Date.
Belay that dream: a laydown date is the day that a book officially goes on sale. It is used especially when the publisher wants to restrict any sale or revelation of the news in a book before it leaks. The publication date is a week or month after that, giving reviewers time to noodle the book around and buyers the feeling that they are getting the jump on their neighbors. Laydown without the date means "distribution": Publishers Weekly (where's the apostrophe?) wrote recently about a Beatles book that "hits the stores with a worldwide laydown of 1.5 million copies."
The reclining noun has a sinister use among arms merchants (an obliterating strike is a nuclear laydown) and can also be found in the lexicon of graphic artists, construction workers and railroaders. But its most prevalent use is in gambling, as the adjective in a laydown hand.
In poker, it's the "showdown," when all hands are laid open for all players to determine the winner. In bridge, a laydown hand is a winning hand placed face up on the table all at once, rather than being played out. This bridge meaning has been extended to a general "sure thing." A Boston economist told The Times, "The Fed has more reason to tighten than not -- but it's not a laydown."
Some of us who respect reasonable embargoes resist marketing manipulation. Let's say I go to a bookstore, the bookseller sells me a book and I spot a news story in it. Would I feel free to use it in a column no matter what its laydown date or publication date? You bet I would; that's a laydown.
 
Between Prexies
 Here's a word that pops up every four or eight years: interregnum.
The Latin means "between reigns." The interregnum, or interregencie, originally meant the interval that a throne or position of leadership was vacant, as between the death or removal of one sovereign and the accession of the next. This invited trouble, as in the Cromwell era. William Blackstone, in his 1765 "Commentaries," held that in England "the king is made a corporation to prevent in general the possibility of an interregnum or vacancy of the throne."
The word now means "an intermission in the order of succession" and, more generally, "a breach of continuity." Specifically, in the United States, it means "the period between the election of a new president and his inauguration." But it is not limited to political power: the breakfast-table autocrat Oliver Wendell Holmes wrote, "Between the last dandelion and violet . . . and the first spring blossom . . . there is a frozen interregnum in the vegetable world."
The word, lest we forget, is spelled with two r's. It received a special play during the transition from Jimmy Carter to Ronald Reagan, which wags called the interreaganum.

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Thanksgiving Feast With a Rainbow of Flavors

BYLINE: By B. RUBY RICH; B. Ruby Rich is the author of "Chick Flicks" and senior correspondent for "Independent View" on KQED-TV in San Francisco.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
AT a time when most Americans have seemingly given up on this country's e pluribus unum promise, the British filmmaker Gurinder Chadha brings an unjaundiced eye to the tribulations and victories of a multiracial immigrant nation. Her new film "What's Cooking?" succeeds by means of a simple ruse: it substitutes a roasting pan for the proverbial melting pot.
And not just any roasting pan. In Ms. Chadha's big-hearted fable of big-city family life, the occasion is Thanksgiving and the focus is a rainbow of Los Angeles families, each with its own special crisis simmering along with the holiday feast and resolving by dessert. 
 Charm is Ms. Chadha's strong suit. "All my films are about celebration," Ms. Chadha said on a recent visit to San Francisco. "I wanted to make a film that could celebrate the diversity of Americans today. The American films I'd seen that actually dealt with race were almost always about problems and conflicts. We wanted to move away from that and show how the differences between cultures can actually underscore similarities."
Ms. Chadha is hardly the first to carry a camera to the Thanksgiving feast; Jodie Foster ("Home for the Holidays") and Bart Freundlich ("The Myth of Fingerprints"), among recent examples, beat her to it. But what she has done is set some new places at the table. The families in "What's Cooking?" are African-American, Jewish, Latino and Vietnamese. Each one is playing out a different drama of generational dissonance, sexual identity and emotional turmoil. And each one modifies the Thanksgiving menu to include tamales, chiles, rice or kugel. It doesn't hurt the charm factor that the families' ranks are filled by the likes of Joan Chen, Alfre Woodard, Mercedes Ruehl, Maury Chaykin, Lainie Kazan, Kyra Sedgwick and Julianna Margulies.
"What's Cooking?" (opening Friday) unites its characters with a seasoned optimism that could be held by someone only as diasporically diversified as Ms. Chadha herself. Kenyan-born, London-raised and Punjabi, when asked her own ethnicity, Ms. Chadha spent her university years studying third world economics.
She has worked as a journalist at BBC radio and in television news. Then she entered a British Film Institute New Directors program for people with no film training and made a controversial documentary, "I'm British, But --" and began a new career.
Nick James, editor in chief of the British Film Institute Sight and Sound magazine, said Ms. Chadha's first film was "really significant, with impeccable timing."
"Here was someone saying: 'I'm not Indian, I'm British,' " he added. "And then redefining what British meant."
Ms. Chadha had her first immersion in American culture in 1993, when the success of her first dramatic feature, "Bhaji on the Beach," propelled her onto the film festival circuit. One of a wave of British films exploring immigrant culture and first-generation culture clashes, "Bhaji on the Beach" tracked the adventures of a van of Indian women on a day trip to Blackpool, the seaside resort that symbolizes British kitsch. "Bhaji" used humor to sugarcoat serious issues (domestic abuse, interracial romance), and its glimpse of a different Britain won Ms. Chadha new admirers.
"I just loved it so much that I wrote her a fan letter," said the Hollywood director Jon Landis, who had never forgotten his own experience filming "An American Werewolf in London" in 1981. "In London at that time, when you called for extras, you got white people. I said, 'I really need people of color; I'm shooting in London!' And they said, 'We don't have any.' " When Mr. Landis did manage to get Chinese and Pakistani faces into his movie, it was such a big deal that British reviews "took pains to note that my film was set in a multiracial London -- as though there were any other kind." With "Bhaji," he finally saw on screen the Britain he had seen in the streets.
Another fan, Paul Mayeda Berges, booked "Bhaji" as the opening night film for the 1994 San Francisco Asian-American Film Festival and invited its director to attend. Soon after he resigned from the festival, he and Ms. Chadha were married and began writing screenplays together. Not only was Mr. Berges a co-writer on "What's Cooking?" but he also inadvertently provided its theme when he first invited Ms. Chadha home to Los Angeles for his very modern family's multifaceted Thanksgivings.
"I always have three Thanksgivings in America," she said. "One takes place early in the afternoon with Paul's father and stepmother and his half-siblings. Then we do dinner with his mother and Japanese grandparents. And then, on the weekend, we do it all over again with his mother and all her women friends who don't have their own nuclear families and we have a sort of extended and invented family dinner."
DURING a series of conversations that began last winter at the Sundance Film Festival, where "What's Cooking?" had its world premiere on opening night, it became clear that the central theme of "What's Cooking?" is the centrifugal force of family. "I'd never met people who were so estranged from family until I came to the United States," Ms. Chadha said, remembering her college years with visits home every two weeks.
Still close to her family and tied more than ever to her widowed mother in London, Ms. Chadha divides her time between the Camden neighborhood of London and Redondo Beach, Calif. She is preparing to return to London to shoot "Bend It Like Beckham," a girls' soccer film set in her mother's West London neighborhood. Three other films are in the works, including one that would mix up cultures again by taking to the screen Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni's novel "The Mistress of Spices," about an Indian herb vendor in Oakland, Calif., who psychically meddles in her customers' lives.
In the end, Ms. Chadha may be perfectly suited to Los Angeles filmmaking. "I tried to make a very traditional American movie with a 'What a Wonderful Life' sensibility," she said. "If I can say that about a film full of black people, family melodrama and comedy."
While her tastes are sufficiently mainstream -- she considers "Car Wash" one of her all-time favorites -- her roots may run even deeper here. When she was reworking her script for "What's Cooking?" at the filmmaking lab at the Sundance Film Institute, Ms. Chadha said she had trouble convincing the director Frank Pierson, one of the lab's stalwarts, that she could pull it off.
"Then he saw 'Bhaji' and changed his mind," Ms. Chadra said with pleasure. ' "Oh, now I know what you're doing.' he said. 'Thornton Wilder. You're making 'Our Town.' "

HEADLINE: 'MODEL OPERAS';
Longing for Ideals

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I read with fascination "Why This Nostalgia for Fruits of Chaos?" Oct. 29 by Sheila Melvin and Jindong Cai, on the popular revival of Cultural Revolution operas in China, but the article missed an opportunity to fully answer the question posed by its headline. It is simplistic to assume that middle-aged people flock to these operas because it is the music on which they were raised, "much the way middle-aged Americans listen to the rock music of their youth or sneak a peek at a 'Brady Bunch' rerun." In fact, despite memories of chaos and bitter suffering, many middle-aged Chinese also think back with longing on a time when they were living for ideas instead of money. The deep alienation that has come with China's blinding rate of modernization exacerbates these feelings. Cities such as Beijing and Shanghai have been torn down and rebuilt in the space of a few short years, sweeping traditional values away with the rubble and leaving anomie as well as ambition behind. 
 While researching China's Cultural Revolution revival restaurants, I had a chance to explore these contradictory attitudes. As Yu Changjiang, a lecturer in anthropology at Beijing University, told me, "Regardless of the politics, for young people at the time, the Cultural Revolution was something very exciting. It was very radical, very idealistic. Now everything is quantified in terms of time and money." Perhaps no one summed it up better than Li Zhi Tian, a successful magazine editor who explained why he liked eating "crude tea and bland rice" in the revival restaurants. "I guess I'm like a lot of people," he said between calls on his cell phone. "I'm looking for satisfaction in the past that I'm not getting in the present."
 
NICOLE MONES
Portland, Ore.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
County's Office Market Is Exceptionally Strong

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
THE amount of available space in Westchester's office market has hit historic lows so far this year, with leasing up more than 40 percent and very few large blocks of space remaining. Yet with all the good news, some brokers see harbingers of trouble for the county in the not-so-distant future.
Westchester's office vacancy rates have improved significantly in the last five years. In the first quarter of this year, the amount of available space dropped to 12.5 percent, compared with 17.6 percent at the end of 1999, according to the White Plains office of CB Richard Ellis, the commercial broker. The rate continued to go down until it reached 11 percent in the third quarter, which is a historic low for the county. At the end of 1995, by contrast, the vacancy rate was 23.2 percent. 
 According to Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company, more than 2.6 million square feet of space has been leased in the county so far this year, up 44 percent from the corresponding period a year ago and nearly equal to the 2.8 million square feet leased for all of 1999.
"Westchester has benefited by the fact that there's just not a lot of available space in surrounding markets," said Frank Tomasulo, a first vice president at CB Richard Ellis. "With space extremely tight in Manhattan and rents hitting $70 per square foot there, Westchester seems like a very attractive option." The average asking rent in Westchester County in the third quarter was a little more than $26 a square foot.
The county's fortunes have also been aided by the continued growth of local companies, many of them high-technology concerns, said Dean J. Shapiro, an executive director at Insignia/ESG in Stamford, Conn. "There have also been several relocations within the county," he added, "and no major increases in supply. But the frenzy we felt at the beginning of the year, I don't feel anymore."
One major concern, Mr. Shapiro said, is the expected relocation of Texaco once the federal government approves the company's acquisition by the Chevron Corporation, which has its headquarters in San Francisco. Texaco now occupies about 650,000 square feet at its current headquarters at 2000 Westchester Avenue, White Plains. "Such a large return of space to the market will certainly be felt in the vacancy rates," Mr. Shapiro said. "And it would take a while to see how that building could be successfully remarketed."
John Goodkind, executive managing director of Newmark in Greenwich, Conn., thinks it will be 18 to 24 months before the fate of the Texaco property and its effect on the market are determined. "Nobody can expect some big user from Manhattan to come in and take up the amount of space," Mr. Goodkind said. "The building will probably need some kind of architectural overhaul in order to attract smaller tenants."
LIKE other brokers, Mr. Goodkind also expressed worry about a slowdown in the world of the so-called dot-com companies and the impact this could have on Westchester's market. "The activity in the dot-com world has really slowed down," Mr. Goodkind said. "There was a frenzy in that market over the last 24 months, which is reflected in the office vacancy rates now, but the frenzy is over. Now it's back to business."
Despite the slowdown that has been detected recently, Westchester's office market has been buoyed for several quarters by "new economy" companies. Of the 10 largest lease transactions in three months that ended on Sept. 30, six involved telecommunication or e-commerce companies or related concerns, according to Insignia/ESG.
Nortel Networks Inc., a maker of telecommunications equipment, renewed a lease for 57,458 square feet at 200 Summit Lake Drive, Valhalla; Monstermoving.com, a relocation services provider, signed a lease for 45,270 square feet at 50 Main Street in White Plains; OnMoney.com, an online personal finance Web site, took 40,000 square feet at 287 Bowman Avenue, Purchase; and FrameWork, a software developer, leased 24,720 square feet at 303 South Broadway in Tarrytown.
By far the biggest lease in the third quarter involved industrial space and as such was not included in the office vacancy rates. Qwest Communications International Inc., a telecommunications company, agreed to lease a 435,000-square-foot former Saks Fifth Avenue distribution center in Yonkers and also to build 90,000 square feet of additional space.
"Lots of these companies have incubated in the county," Mr. Shapiro said, "and now that they've grown, they're taking more space." An example is Savvy Networks USA, which provides Web site support services. It started two years ago in 1,500 square feet in Larchmont and now has options on a total of 17,000 square feet in Tarrytown. "We're now occupying 7,500 square feet," said Christopher Furey, chief operating officer, "and we'll move into more space as our needs warrant."
Several brokers have pointed out, however, that the financing that was once available to new economy companies seems to be drying up. "We just tried to place one of these companies in a building in Briarcliff," Mr. Goodkind said, "but it fell through because the company's financials were too weak. Once, the sky was the limit, but now building owners are afraid to get burnt."
While the county has certainly benefited from the growth of technology companies, it is not dependent on them, according to Mr. Tomasulo. "That's really the good news for Westchester in the last several years," he said. "The tenant base is now diverse enough that a downturn in one market will not have cataclysmic effects on the whole market."
MR. TOMASULO also pointed to other positive factors in the market, in particular the turnaround of several of the county's most problematic buildings, most significantly 360 Hamilton Avenue in White Plains, a former I.B.M. property that was vacant for a decade and is now more than 85 percent occupied.
"The fact that a building that had been essentially written off can be turned around and attract high-quality tenants says a lot about the health of Westchester's market," Mr. Tomasulo said. "In that case the owner was willing to put in the dollars and it paid off." The building is owned by the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation.
Another success story, Mr. Tomasulo said, is the Parker Corporate Center at 1311 Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains, which was abandoned by I.B.M. two years ago and is now completely occupied. "The only properties that haven't succeeded in this market," Mr. Tomasulo said, "are ones where the owners haven't made a commitment and are waiting for the big tenant to swoop down and take a large block of space."
Both 360 Hamilton and the Parker Corporate Center were once occupied by a single user, I.B.M., and have been converted into multitenant use. Robert S. Skolnick, executive vice president of the Jack Parker Corporation, said: "The strategy paid off better than any of us expected. We never signed a tenant larger than 50,000 square feet. Now we don't have a single-tenant risk -- that if they leave, the building is vacant."
The real losers in this market, Mr. Tomasulo said, "are the owners who sit around hoping to sign up a 100,000 square foot tenant. They're still waiting. That's not Westchester's market anymore. It's now much more geared to the smaller to midsize company, and no one company or even business dominates."

HEADLINE: Bitten by, and Enjoying, the Gardening Bug

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
THE gardening bug is an insidious disease. Once stricken, some victims feel a compulsion to spend all their free time digging in the dirt and all their money buying plants and seeds. Others go even further and transform their working lives by entering the horticultural field.
John Holm, a former professional chef, is in the midst of such a career transformation. Born in Norway to a family that owned a restaurant, he was trained as a cook from an early age. Mr. Holm eventually emigrated to the United States and found work at Manhattan restaurants like La Grenouille and Restaurant 44. He also taught cooking at the French Culinary Institute and helped found a successful prepared-food business. 
 While a chef, Mr. Holm began tending a container garden on the terrace of his Brooklyn Heights apartment. Eventually he moved to a 2.5-acre lot in Bedford and began growing things on a larger scale. He applied to the New York Botanical Garden's School of Professional Horticulture, a two-year program that combines course work with hands-on training in the botanical garden itself. He expects to graduate in 2002 and start his own residential landscape design business.
Training that combines horticulture's intellectual and practical sides makes perfect sense to Mr. Holm, who has a high tolerance for the unglamorous and unpaid work in the botanical garden. "Because of my background in cooking," he saidf, "I am used to working hard and getting dirty." But "I feel a passion for this that I never did for cooking," he added. "I went into cooking because of my family. This I did for myself."
Five years ago, Mary Squires was a corporate attorney living on Long Island. Then she and her husband moved to Upper Saddle River, N.J. After finding out what it cost to hire landscapers, she decided to design her new property herself -- even though she had little experience with plants. "I started researching before I put anything in the ground," she said. Her interest increased, and after she had become a regular at her local retail nursery, a clerk suggested she take some horticulture courses at Bergen County College.
She began her studies with two courses, including Plant, Soil and Science, one of the toughest classes in the two-year degree program. Eventually she became immersed in horticulture education and went to school full time. She received a certificate in landscaping and ornamental horticulture (with honors), and went on to earn an associate's degree in applied science.
With her degrees in hand, Ms. Squires hung out her shingle as a plant consultant, installing and maintaining gardens, doing soil tests and educating her clients about integrated pest management (environment-friendly methods of dealing with garden pests).
Ms. Squires specializes in interior "plantscaping," helping her clients with selection and placement of indoor plants. On each job she uses a light meter to gauge the amount of light in specific indoor locations, so people avoid dark corners full of dying plants. This educated approach is something new for Ms. Squires. "In my past life," she said, "I would just buy a plant and water it."
Ms. Squires still does a limited amount of legal work, "just to keep my hand in." In addition to running her own business, she hopes to gain greenhouse management experience by working part time for a local nursery within the next year.
Ms. Squires has no regrets about trading case management for pest management. "The time that I spend in gardens is infinitely more rewarding than the most demanding legal case," she said.
Kathleen Nelson of Gaylordsville, Conn., spends her spring, summer and fall days growing and selling perennials, a home-based business that she began when she made a midlife career change two decades ago. Busy outdoors during the growing season, she spends the winter writing copy for her plant catalog, doing bookkeeping and planning for the coming season.
Ms. Nelson grew up in "the swamps of northern Minnesota," collecting plants in the abundant wetlands. After obtaining a master's degree in zoology, she taught biology at Manhattan Community College. "I loved teaching," she said.
But in the mid-1970's, layoffs within the City University system left Ms. Nelson unemployed. A new job at the University of Bridgeport brought an unexpected bonus -- a husband. Ms. Nelson left teaching and entered professional horticulture at the age of 41, when she had her first child.
"The first couple of years, I didn't know what I was doing," she said. Her science background helped her learn quickly, and trial and error enabled her to make the decision to focus on retail rather than wholesale customers. Her business grew, bolstered by the surge in public interest in perennial plants around the time she started in the 1980's.
Ms. Nelson specializes in shade plants, noninvasive grasses and deer-resistant species, which also feature prominently in her landscape designs for a small number of clients.
As her business has flourished, Ms. Nelson's environmental concerns have grown. A stint on a local wetlands commission changed her focus to promoting native plants. Though natives are enjoying something of a renaissance, the she thinks they need more exposure.
Ms. Nelson's child is now a college junior, and the second career continues to evolve. Though she gives occasional lectures, she said that a return to the classroom would be "emotionally draining." Running her small nursery, said Ms. Nelson, is the perfect combination of physical and intellectual activity.
That combination also appeals to Laura Leach, who made the switch to horticulture after 15 years as a sales, marketing and development executive. Like Mr. Holm, the Hastings, N.Y., resident is now a student in the New York Botanical Garden's horticulture school.
Ms. Leach, who was born in England, has a love of gardening that she inherited from her mother and grandmother. In high school she considered a horticultural career, but chose other options.
After leaving school, Ms. Leach re-encountered horticulture when she took a marketing job with Britain's National Trust, which oversees many historic structures and gardens. Later she worked as the director of development for the Welsh National Opera.
As with Ms. Nelson, marriage helped propel Ms. Leach into a new life. Several years ago, she and her husband emigrated to California, where she began part-time horticultural studies. The following year the couple moved to the East Coast. She had discovered the botanical garden's program on the Internet, and chose it because it provided "the opportunity to work alongside the best horticulturists." She praises the program's diversity. "Today I am preparing seeds for a seed exchange; yesterday I was climbing an oak tree to prune it," she said.
When she graduates in the spring of 2002, Ms. Leach may work as an administrator for a horticultural institution. She also plans to continue her education in landscape design. But she is also keeping her options open. "I am looking at where my skills are," she added.
Ms. Leach had advice for those considering a similar career change. "It's important to have some practical experience in the field first," she said, noting that the botanical garden program requires such hands-on work as a prerequisite for admission.
And, while a horticultural career may ultimately provide those who choose it with time to stop and smell the roses, she advised anyone approaching the field to be "realistic, not romantic."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Transforming a Plant From Hydrox to High Tech

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: SAYREVILLE

 BODY:
IN a sense, the plan is to switch from bites to bytes, from cookies (edible) to cookies (electronic).
From the outside, the million-square-foot former bakery and manufacturing plant doesn't look much different than it did when Keebler, and before that Sunshine Biscuits, used it to make Hydrox cookies and Cheez-It crackers. But inside, the ovens and conveyor belts have been stripped away, as have miles of piping, as part of the building's more than $50 million transformation into the Garden State Technology Center. 
 The renovation of the old bakery, made up of several interconnecting buildings, is nearly complete. And the $15 million in high-tech infrastructure to support its new use -- including access to nearby fiber-optics and electrical power to run computers and other telecommunications equipment -- will be in place by the end of the first quarter of next year, said Sidney Borenstein, a partner at Sayreville, L.L.C, the technology center's developer.
Mr. Borenstein, who is also the president of a development company in Brooklyn that bears his name, said that the plant is "a good candidate for a high-tech center." He said that the fiber-optics, the electrical power, the building's 15-foot-high clear ceilings, and its floors, which are capable of supporting more than 250 pounds per square foot, would make it appealing to the new-economy tenants -- the Web-hosting, e-commerce and Internet-related companies -- he hoped to attract.
In addition, he said, of the plant's million square feet, 750,000 are on one floor with wide spacing between columns.
Sayreville L.L.C., a group of New York City developers and investors, bought the 48-acre site last May. The plant is at Bordentown Avenue and Jernee Mills Road in the southwest corner of the 17-square mile Middlesex County community.
The seller was a New York investor, Joshua Gutman, who had acquired the property in 1999 from the Keebler Foods Company of Elmhurst, Ill. (Keebler has since been acquired by Kellogg.)
Keebler bought Sunshine Biscuits in 1996 and decided to consolidate its manufacturing operations; the Sayreville plant, from which the sweet smell of cookies had wafted for more than 20 years, was closed last September.
The plant's closing resulted in the loss of some 500 jobs. Keebler was the latest in a long series of manufacturers in Sayreville, among them DuPont and National Lead, that have pared down operations, gone out of business or left this former industrial stronghold, weakening its economic base and shifting the tax burden to its 17,000 residents.
MAYOR KENNEDY O'BRIEN said that the redevelopment of the old cookie factory was the start of his community's evolution from "a manufacturing- to a high-technology-driven town." The Garden State Technology Center, he said, "says Sayreville is an ideal place for high technology" and provides "a stamp of credibility" for other investors to follow.
Mr. Borenstein said that he and his partners were using their own money to finance the project, their second such conversion. The first was a 300,000-square-foot formerly abandoned industrial building on Noble Street in Philadelphia that they took over 18 months ago and that he said is now 70 percent leased to high-technology companies.
The Garden State Technology Center is one of a spate of projects in New Jersey intended to recycle industrial space into cyber-oriented space.
While most have been in cities in northern New Jersey, among them Newark and Jersey City, the Sayreville redevelopment is one of a few in the middle of the state, including ones in Carteret and North Brunswick, that may indicate the start of a shift to suburban areas from urban centers, commercial brokers said.
The conversion activity is being spurred by several factors. Old industrial buildings generally offer the sturdy floors and high ceilings new-economy tenants need to accommodate the heavy equipment and the abundant electrical power necessary to run their business. The buildings also have access to fiber-optic cables because they often are near the rail lines where the cables were long ago installed.
Property owners also see such conversions as a way to broaden their tenant base and increase their annual rental income well above the typical $6 a square foot that older industrial buildings command for use as distribution centers.
The state awarded $2 million last month in grants to counties, economic development groups and municipalities, including Sayreville, to plan and promote cyber districts within their borders to help attract high-tech companies and spur redevelopment. Thirty grants were awarded under the initiative, which is administered by New Jersey's Department of Community Affairs and the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority.
Mayor Kennedy said that Sayreville was given a $50,000 grant to study the possibility of establishing a cyber district in a 900-acre former industrial area that includes the old National Lead site, in a different part of the community from the Garden State Technology Center.
In the last 18 months high-tech tenants have leased about 2.5 million square feet of space at eight New Jersey projects, among them ones in Newark, Jersey City and Weehawken, according to Insignia/ESG of New Jersey, a commercial brokerage based in Saddle Brook. Those projects are among the 22 completed or planned in the state, totaling 9.3 million square feet, of which 4.4 million square feet are available, according to Cushman & Wakefield, another commercial brokerage.
SEAN P. BRADY, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield's East Rutherford office, said that demand for this kind of space had leveled off from the robust levels of 1999 as companies limited expansion plans because of the drop in the Nasdaq and a lack of available capital. But Mr. Brady said that the demand was still strong and that from now to December 2001 tenants would be in the market for 2 million to 2.5 million square feet of such space.
While annual asking rents have fluctuated over the last year they now range from $16 to $28 a square foot, depending on location and access to fiber, he said. And, he said, they can go as high as $40 a square foot in certain urban locations, like Newark.
Mr. Brady said that not all the projects being planned would move forward, because they are not in wished-for locations and do not provide tenants easy access to fiber-optic links and sufficient electrical power. He would not indicate which sites those might be.
The developers of the Garden State Technology Center said they were betting that their project would attract attention even though it is not in a major city. Andrew B. Zezas, a managing director at Insignia/ESG who is the leasing agent for the project, said its location was an asset because Sayreville is accessible to several major highways, including the Garden State Parkway and Routes 9 and 18. More important, Mr. Zezas and Mr. Borenstein said, is that AT&T's optical-fiber backbone is along the Conrail train tracks that run behind the property.
In addition, they said, the building will be connected through multiple fiber-optic rings to major telecommunication hubs in New York City, Newark and Philadelphia, as well as to trans-Atlantic links in New Jersey. As a result tenants will also be able to access multiple long-distance telecommunications carriers, they said.
The project, they added, also is near several power plants, will have its own electrical substation and be wired for electrical power to provide 100 watts per square foot. (A typical office building provides 5 to 6 watts per square foot.) The building also sits on 48 acres, leaving enough land to install backup generators.
The key concept, Mr. Zezas said, is that "the amount of power and telecommunications connectivity coming to the property" is equal to that found in buildings in northern New Jersey but will be available for rents lower than in those buildings.
Annual rents at Garden State Technology Center are $20 a square foot, he said. The idea, he said, is to try first to attract tenants expanding in or relocating to New Jersey that need from 100,000 to 500,000 square feet, before dividing the building into smaller blocks of space.
"Five such users have already expressed interest in the property," Mr. Zezas said, adding that the project will lease because "it is where power-hungry tenants can get their fill."

HEADLINE: Not the Bronx, but in Its Spirit

BYLINE: By LESLIE KANDELL

 BODY:
THE following concert program is rated PG 13: it contains 17 brawny guys with bare arms, pummeling oil drums in violent rhythms, with pickaxes. Although there is no profanity (unless it's in French) one cannot ignore the yelling, or the smashing oil cans. Earplugs are available to the audience at no charge.
Here, here, what's all this? A variant palliative for aggression? A dream evening for the hearing-challenged? Intrepid listeners will have a chance to find out Tuesday when Les Tambours du Bronx, an unusual drumming group from France, muscles into the Garde Arts Center in New London on its first North American tour. 
 To the extent that the culture of hip-hop is about rebellion, this event is a species of hip-hop -- that is, the antithesis of the classical music concert form. If there is an expected appropriate attire, the drummers of Les Tambours don't wear it. As to performing on valuable heirloom instruments: they don't play standard instruments at all, and regularly destroy what they do play on. Quiet, a concert hall norm, is a joke. Even the Bronx reference is a joke.
The men, who no longer have to hold day jobs, come from the outskirts of Nevers, an industrial town in central France known for repairing trains, and also as the resting place of Bernadette of Lourdes, whose body is preserved under a glass bubble, reportedly as fresh as ever. Before Les Tambours was founded in 1987, its members were friends who met to drink at a place in Nevers called the Broadway Bar. Some were students, some had jobs, some were unemployed, but none were musicians. Their little jest, as their evenings at the Broadway Bar ended, was that they were going back home to the Bronx.
According to the group's leader, Ludovic Le Mapihan (known as Map), they got their shot at performing during the city's annual festival of movie shorts.
"We wanted to make a small performance, but we were not sure what," said Map. (The telephone conversation is translated from an ad hoc mixture of French and English, representing a genuine dual effort.) "We had no money, but because Nevers is a city for train repairs, 55-gallon barrels were easy to find free, in gardens."
They performed 20 minutes at the festival, got all fired up, and decided to go to any nearby festival, invited or not. "We played in the street," said Map. "Presenters liked us and we began to be invited."
True to its perverse form, the all-male group, now aged 25 to 42, named its first commercial recording "Silence." It's anything but, though the label name, Naive, is more like it. The rhythms are clean, repetitive in the marching band sense, and seductive but acceptable, probably, to even to the most mannered listener. "Bombast and unity" said one reviewer. Not bad.
Nothing about their performance is gentrified. Some numbers have added clapping or whistling, while in others, oil barrel clangor is augmented by groans, howls and snorts. The recording's final number, "Etouffez la Ventoline" (a title chosen for rhythm rather than meaning) has unintelligible words that might be broadcast over a railroad station loudspeaker.
Comparing Les Tambours with Japan's Kodo Drummers, Map acknowledged the similar visceral effect, and then said something like, "Our rhythm is very basic. It goes directly to your body. Our instruments are different in the way we play. We smash very loud. When we finish the show, the instrument is destroyed. You can use both sides of the drum, so, two shows maximum."
The destruction factor is handled through copious supplies: "A big truck follows us, with 400 barrels from France, and 4,000 sticks," he said. "You cannot find the barrels outside of France -- not even in Italy or Germany. They're very thin. With thicker metal, you can hurt yourself." After trying different materials for their pickax mallets, they settled on beechwood, strong enough to survive a concert or two.
Since the drummers can't practice separately, they get together in what Map described as a hangar in the countryside. "We are not musicians," he said. "We play and move our arms a special way. We look for new members in the way we would look for a friend, not a drummer."
In European performances, there is some interaction with the audience, which Map was not sure was happening on this tour. "We try to talk to the audience," he said, "but our English is not so good. We explain and ask what they think. We know they won't sleep."
"Les Tambours du Bronx," Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. at Garde Arts Center, 325 State Street, New London. 7:30 p.m. Information: (860) 444-6766.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Signs of Slight Cooling in the Feverish Office Market

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
IS the hot market for office space in Manhattan, which has sent rents soaring, sometimes to record levels, beginning to cool off just a bit? There are hints of it in reports on market activity now being published by major brokerage companies in the city.
Just about everyone agrees that market fundamentals are strong and that rents are continuing to rise, despite uncertainties regarding dot-com and other Internet related start-up companies. But some industry professionals also note that a lot of trophy buildings are being listed for sale, suggesting that some investors think the value of their properties is close enough to the peak that it is time to cash out. 
 One report, by Williams Real Estate, noted that for the first time in six quarters, the amount of office space in all classes available for lease in the Midtown South area had increased, rather than decreased. The increase was small, about 300,000 square feet, which raised the availability rate to 4.4 percent from 4 percent, but it did represent the reversal of a trend. Williams defines Midtown South as the area between Seventh and 40th Streets, river to river.
Another indication of a slowing market was the net amount of space leased in the quarter. Although the overall availability in all of Manhattan decreased to 4.8 percent from 5.1 percent, according to the Williams report, only 1.3 million square feet were absorbed from the market, compared with 5 million square feet in the second quarter and 10.5 million since the beginning of the year.
"A little fissure in the marketplace," is the way Robert L. Freedman, vice chairman of Williams, described the situation. He said it was a positive development because it would restrain bidding wars for available space and allow more companies to remain in Manhattan.
Mr. Freedman said the pace of leasing in the first half of the year was unsustainable, no matter how good the underlying economy. "The rate of growth in the future can be expected to be at a more modest rate than in the past several quarters."
A similar report by Julien J. Studley, a company that represents tenants, noted that the overall vacancy rate remains "extraordinarily low" and that new space is not likely to be added to the market for at least three or four years. "New York City may be the home of the soft landing, if a landing is in the cards," the company concluded.
"We are in a period of digestion, and that is probably a good thing," said Mitchell S. Steir, vice chairman of the Studley firm. He said demand had been artificially inflated by Internet and new media companies, which were in such a scramble to find space for their rapidly growing operations that they almost did not care about the price.
"Now we are seeing an easing of the artificial demand on the part of the dot-coms," he said, as companies have closed down or terminated employees. But he noted that these technology companies had had a major impact on the office market. "Rents are up 25 to 30 percent in the past year," he said.
Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company, said space vacated by technology companies was being quickly reoccupied by other companies. "In the last quarter the dot-coms threw 640,000 square feet of space back onto the market," she said. "But 320,000 square feet of it is already spoken for," she added. "The space gets snapped up almost as fast as it becomes available."
"The absorption rate has slowed and some supply has come on the market, but there is no sense that we are about to fall off the edge of the world," said Anthony E. Malkin, the president of W&M Properties, an owner and developer of real estate. "These are 5,000, 10,000, 25,000 square foot blocks of space that are coming back and that is healthy," he said. "The market needs this space," he added. "There is no reason to worry when the vacancy rate is 4 or 5 percent."
Allan B. Rothschild, managing director of the New York office of CB Richard Ellis, the brokerage and services company, said: "Our view is that the market in Midtown South will be able to withstand the problems of the dot-coms. We think there will be a leveling of the rental rate instead of 10 to 20 percent a month increases." He said any weakness in demand would probably be located in what he termed "fringe areas," notably those west of Eighth Avenue.
Janice Stanton, the managing director for investment research for Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company, said, "There has been a little bit of a pullback on the part of tech tenants, but there has been a pickup in demand by financial and publishing tenants."
She said one reason the absorption rate had fallen was that there is very little space available to be occupied. "You can't absorb space if there is nothing to absorb," she said.
The Williams report noted that rents in newer buildings in Midtown continued to rise in the third quarter, while those in older properties largely leveled out. The asking rents in buildings completed after 1968 rose 7.9 percent to an average of $71.53 per square foot, while those built between 1946 and 1968 increased just 1.9 percent to an average of $68.69 per square foot. Rents in buildings built before World War II went up only 0.7 percent, to an average of $58.45 per square foot.
Overall availability in the Downtown market, which is everything south of Seventh Street, decreased to 5.1 percent from 5.7 percent in the last quarter, according to Williams, but even there the picture was mixed. Space available in buildings completed before World War II increased slightly to 7.4 percent from 7.2 percent. Average rentals in the prewar sector of the market were $41per square foot compared with $42.39 per square foot for post-war buildings.
In addition to leasing trends, some real estate executives pointed to the number of trophy buildings for sale as an indication that some people think the sales market may be near the peak. Two of the city's most notable office complexes -- Rockefeller Center and the World Trade Center -- are on the market, and such individual buildings as the Seagrams tower at 375 Park Avenue, the CBS headquarters at 51 West 52nd Street, 1211 Avenue of the Americas, 666 Fifth Avenue and 300 Park Avenue are either for sale, under contract or sold. According to Williams, the building at 1211 Avenue of the Americas sold for $561 million, or $291 a square foot, while 666 Fifth Avenue went for $540 million, or $369 a square foot. The structure at 300 Park Avenue was less costly, with a sales price of $200 million, or $276 a square foot.
T HE question is always 'How high is up,' and it may be that some people may have decided that we are up," Mr. Freedman said. "That may be an indication that the market is peaking and that owners are trying to lock in the top profit."
But others say that even if it appears that smart money is selling, the money that is buying, which includes Tishman Speyer Properties, the Jamestown Group and RFR/Davis, is pretty smart as well.
"A lot of these building were bought with opportunity-fund financing and the funds are not long-term holders," Ms. Tighe said. "They want to have what they call a 'realization event' after holding a property for three to five years to benefit from repositioning it and taking advantage of the cycle."
Mr. Malkin observed that many sellers have appeared to be trying to cash out while they still can. "In any 10 year period, there are three or so years when you can sell property well and about 18 months in that time you can sell incredibly well," he said. "The other seven years are bad to terrible."
He said it seemed clear that the 18 month hot sales period had passed and that some owners wanted to act before being pulled into a downturn. He added that it appeared there was less capital available for office investments as pension funds and other investors try to rebalance their portfolios with multifamily residential and industrial-distribution properties.
