HEADLINE: Only the Best for Man's Best Friend. And Woman's Too.

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG

 BODY:
WHEN the Wozar family of Whitestone leaves town, they rarely bring 9-year-old Sherlock along. Instead, they rent a hotel room for him and his two siblings, with color cable television, air-conditioning, a telephone, room service and round-the-clock supervision.
Sherlock is a giant schnauzer, and his siblings are two Persian cats named Kahlua and Watson. And their home away from home is Barkingham Palace in Port Washington, where vacationing dog owners can check their pets into either kennels or private rooms. 
 "There's no place like this anywhere around that I know of," said Eyal Danay, who owns the seven-year-old business.
"We knew Long Island would be a great place for this kind of business," said Mr. Danay, who once managed a hotel called "Buff Pets and More" in Palm Springs, Calif., which is now defunct. "We took care of Frank Sinatra's dog in Palm Springs. It was a great area -- very affluent with lots of people interested in giving their pets the best. Long Island is very similar."
Indeed, America's love affair with pets continues and, with a booming economy, Long Islanders are particularly well poised to indulge theirs.
The American Veterinary Medical Association reports that, as of 1996 (the most recent year available), Americans had 59 million cats, 52 million dogs, 13 million birds and 4 million horses as pets -- numbers the group said have risen since then.
 
A Room of One's Own
 With its kennel accommodations, Barkingham can house up to 35 dogs at once. But the main attractions are the seven private rooms -- or dog suites, as Mr. Danay calls them -- which cost $30 to $35 a day. The two large suites are 14 square feet; the five others measure 11 by 5 feet. Each has cable television, a bed, blankets, a sofa and individual speaker phones on which vacationing owners can talk to their pooches.
Mail is also welcome. "An owner may send a postcard, and we'll bring it to the dog so he or she can pick up the scent," Mr. Danay said. "That can reassure them a bit."
"The TV's make the dogs feel at home and as if they're not alone," he said, adding that owners can request special programming, like cartoons, CNN or boxing. "It's not that the dogs understand the shows.. It's just that they are familiar sounds from home."
As if what Barkingham Palace provides -- including 35 diet plans -- isn't enough, some owners bring in toys, blankets and beds for their pets.
"Some don't want their dogs using things that the other dogs use," Mr. Danay said. "And, some dogs just feel more secure with their own stuff."
Mr. Danay, who owns five dogs himself, is awaiting the arrival of a regular client, a Maltese from Great Neck whose owner sends him over in a limousine. "We'll be sending a truck to the house to pick up the dog's special furniture," he said. "The owner wants to essentially recreate the home environment. There's a specially designed bed, Persian rugs and a whole bunch of toys we'll be getting."
 
For Working 'Parents'
Whenever Max, a black Labrador, is left home alone, he causes trouble. And that means trouble for his owner, Susan Salk of Syosset, because she and her husband both work full time. "Max acts out because he hates to be alone," Ms. Salk said. "And I feel so guilty leaving him. When I found out there was a day care center for dogs on Long Island, it was like my prayers were answered."
Nick and Paula Burriesci didn't set out to run a day care center. Their original intention was to open a grooming parlor, but they soon realized there was a need for more.
"A lot of my longtime clients mentioned how great a day care center would be," said Ms. Burriesci, a professional dog handler and groomer for 25 years.
Since Bubbles and Barks opened in Hicksville in November 1999, most of its clients have been are working people who leave their pups for up to nine hours a day, six days a week. In the center, which includes two carpeted rumpus rooms that total 1,500 square feet and can accommodate up to 50 dogs, animals are never caged. They are free to run, wrestle, play and socialize.
Copies of vaccination records are required for all dogs. A staff of six ensures that the dogs, which are separated by size, are under constant supervision. The cost is $10 per day, per dog, regardless of size.
As for behavior problem, Ms. Burriesci said, "we haven't really had any fights. Since the dogs are on neutral territory and their owners aren't around, they're relieved of their 'protective' instinct, and that makes them playful."
Destructive behavior like chewing or soiling carpets stems from boredom, lack of exercise or loneliness, Ms. Burriesci said. "It's separation anxiety," she said. "Many dogs are afraid to be left alone. Here, they have companionship and play all day.'
The Burriescis know whereof they speak. They're able to leave their own brood of six dogs at home "because they have each other," Ms. Burriesci said.
 
For Pets With Good Taste
Ten years ago, Seth Kaplan, a commercial real estate professional and lifelong pet owner, became disgruntled after a visit to a local pet store.
"They acted like they were doing me a favor by waiting on me, and the merchandise was very limited," he said.
So, Mr. Kaplan hired a consultant, drew up a business plan, and, in 1991, opened Pet Pantry, a store in Roslyn Heights that caters to household pets, with a special emphasis on new pet owners. Business grew so rapidly that he left real estate and never looked back.
While Pet Pantry carries 12 lines of predominantly preservative-free food and gourmet delicacies, and even delivers them, it is also a high-end boutique where many of Long Island's best-dressed animals come to shop.
"Long Island has the affluence to let me carry the high-end, exotic and unique products I've always wanted for my own pets," said Mr. Kaplan, who grew up in Roslyn and owns two dogs and two cats.
His merchandise, which he finds at pet trade shows, includes designer duds for dogs, ranging from Calvin Klein T-shirts and authentic leather Harley Davidson jackets to various brands of rainwear and pajamas. Prices range from $40 to $110.
There are also catnip cigars, doggy "designer impostor" colognes with names like "Tommy Holedigger," and personalized ceramic dishes including a line called "Whisker Ware" that features special cut-outs to accommodate cat whiskers.
Currently, his most popular toys include the Rooster, a plush plaything crowned with feathers and stuffed with organically grown catnip, and Snuggle Puppy, a stuffed dog with a battery that creates a heartbeat sound to comfort puppies who miss their mothers.
Pet Pantry usually has 50 to 100 beds in stock. Customers can also examine fabric swatches and design their own. Prices range from $50 to $170. There is other furniture, too -- day beds, sofas, chairs and chaise longues designed by Beastly Furnishings of Nebraska and priced from $250 to $700.
Jayne Stone, a self-described "dog fanatic" from Roslyn, has been a client since Pet Pantry opened. "This place reminds me of the television show 'Cheers,' only with animals," she said. "Everyone is welcome -- with or without their pets."
The store is adorned with photos of its furry regulars. But Mr. Kaplan's favorite pictures lie in a special album he leaves out for his customers -- photographs of dogs and cats from the Town of North Hempstead Animal Shelter and the Glen Cove Animal Lovers' League that are in need of adoption. "We want to save their lives," he said. "This has gotten a lot of them new homes."
 
The Doctor Is Out
Most pet owners know the hassle of taking an animal to the veterinarian. Coaxing pets in and out of carriers, not to mention cars, can be trying, to say the least.
Enter Dr. Jay Berkowitz of Port Washington, a veterinarian whose business consists exclusively of house calls in the Port Washington, Manhasset and Roslyn areas. His "office" is a van stocked with medical equipment and a laptop on which the medical records of his 1,400 patients are stored.
Much of Dr. Berkowitz's day is spent calming nervous dogs with stroking and with reassuring words, or patiently coaxing fearful cats out of hiding behind radiators or down from draperies -- a favorite dangling place for felines looking to avoid their vaccinations. He doesn't treat birds or reptiles.
If a pet needs to be spayed, neutered or requires surgery, he will take the animal with him (he is affiliated with the Long Island Animal Hospital in Old Westbury) and return it to the owner.
A graduate of Cornell University's veterinary school, Dr. Berkowitz, a Long Island native, spent nine years at an animal hospital until deciding 13 years ago that it was time for a change.
"I thought that doing only house calls would not only meet a need among pet owners, but would be a lot of fun as well," he said.
It's also been an education in human nature.
"Pets are incredibly important to people," he said. "And, one of the most surprising things, which I hear all the time, are regular clients telling me they haven't seen a doctor themselves in years. They're putting their animals first.
"I don't think people love animals any more today than before," he added. "I think it's just that, as more innovative products and services become available, people are eager to take advantage of them."
 
Have Pet, Will Travel
The Willow Pet Hotel has two options for vacationing humans: a boarding facility for cats and dogs in Deer Park and a travel agency for pets whose owners want to take them along for the trip.
Since 1969, this family-run business has been making full travel arrangements -- mostly by plane and train -- for clients wishing to transport their pets
Marc Rosenzweig, the native Long Islander who is the company's executive director, said business took off immediately.
"There was definitely a need for this," he said.
The company is registered as an intermediary handler with the United States Agriculture Department and belongs to the Independent Pet Animal Transport Association.
"We recently sent a Yorkshire terrier to Saudi Arabia," Mr. Rosenzweig said. The company has transported animals, not only throughout the continental United States, but to and from Europe, Japan, Singapore, Israel, and many Asian and African countries.
Mr. Rosenzweig, who owns several dogs himself, compares Willow Pet's travel agency to one that accommodates humans. "The client advises us where and when their animal needs to be transported, and we handle all the arrangements," he said. "We call the airlines and take into account the best flights for pets and the price. (Avoiding stop-overs and hot times of day are important, he notes, as is adequate air-conditioning).
Animals require certain inoculations and a health certificate within 10 days of transport. "If the client hasn't fulfilled these requirements, we can take the animal to our veterinarian," Mr. Rosenzweig said.
Small animals in travel carriers that fit underneath seats, and guide dogs can travel with their owners on trains and airplanes, he noted, though there is a ticketing fee. Larger ones are transported separately.
"We secure the animal 24 hours before transport and get it accustomed to the shipping kennel it will be traveling in," Mr. Rosenzweig said, noting that such kennels must meet U.S.D.A. specifications.
A member of the Pet Animal Travel Agency at Willow Pet Hotel brings the animal to airport or train station, and makes sure it gets on board safely. "Like people, animals need to arrive for flights a certain amount of time in advance," Mr. Rosenzweig said.
 
She Sits, but Doesn't Stay
 Several years ago, when Theresa Cahill went on vacation, she needed someone to tend to her own pets. She has two dogs, three degus, or Chilean wood rats, and a parrot.
When she found a sitter who would come to her house, she also found a business that piqued her curiosity.
Ms. Cahill began researching pet-sitting, seeking guidance from both Pet Sitters International and the National Association of Professional Pet Sitters. (She already had a long history with animals; she had been a preveterinary student at SUNY Farmingdale, had studied animal husbandry, and had worked for a veterinarian.
In 1995, Ms. Cahill launched A-1 Critter Sitters from her Riverhead home. With some 75 to 80 regular clients who live between Riverhead and Shirley, business is brisk.
About 10 percent of her calls are for "day care" -- people who work late or are out for the day. Most, however, are the pets of vacationers and business travelers. Ms. Cahill's husband and children help her out at peak times -- summers and school holidays.
"Some pets can't be boarded," she said. "They may be too young, too old or simply not socialized. Other people simply don't want to remove pets from the home environment. And, there are illnesses like kennel cough which can be avoided by keeping your pet at home."
She sits predominantly for dogs and cats, but she has also cared for cows, geese, chickens, horses, goats, sheep and a pot-belly pig..
Ms. Cahill, who is licensed, bonded and insured, will groom animals, play with them, give them walks and change their food and water.
"I also bring in the mail and turn lights on and off, to make the home look occupied,' she added. In case of emergency, she has the family veterinarian's name on file.
Prices start at $12 a visit for one animal.
She belongs to the Long Island Professional Pet-Sitters' Association in Deer Park, a group of 32 independently owned pet-sitting businesses.
"Members aren't not really competitors," she said. "Most are one- or two-person operations which cover different areas. We meet monthly to discuss things like what type of insurance is best for us, what to do with an overly aggressive dog, etc. And, we refer clients outside our areas to one another."
"Many owners will call to check in when they're away," she added. "I can't blame them -- these animals are their family, and they really miss them."

HEADLINE: Bronx Is in the Name. Drums Are Their Game. P.S. They're French.

BYLINE: By LESLIE KANDELL

 BODY:
THE following concert program is rated PG13:
It contains 17 brawny guys with bare arms, pummeling oil drums in violent rhythms, with pickaxs. Although there is no profanity (unless it's in French), one cannot ignore the yelling, or the smashing oil cans. Earplugs are available to the audience at no charge. 
 Here, here, what's all this? A variant palliative for aggression? A dream evening for the hearing challenged?
Intrepid listeners will have a chance to find out on Tuesday when Les Tambours du Bronx, an unusual drumming group from France, muscles into the Lycian Center in Sugar Loaf on its first North American tour.
To the extent that the culture of hip-hop is about rebellion, this event is a species of hip-hop -- that is, the antithesis of the classical music concert form. If there is an expected appropriate attire, the drummers of Les Tambours don't wear it. As to performing on valuable heirloom instruments: they don't play standard instruments at all and regularly destroy what they do play on. Quiet, a concert hall norm, is a joke. Even the Bronx reference is a joke.
The men, who no longer have to hold day jobs -- if they ever had them -- come from the outskirts of Nevers, an industrial town in central France known for repairing trains, and also known as the resting place of Bernadette of Lourdes, whose body is preserved under a glass bubble, reportedly as fresh as ever. Before Les Tambours was founded in 1987, its members were friends who met to drink at a place in Nevers called the Broadway Bar. Some were students, some had jobs, some were unemployed, but none were musicians. Their little jest, as their evenings at the Broadway Bar ended, was that they were going back home to the Bronx.
The leader, Ludovic le Mapihan (known as Map), said that the group got its shot at performing during the city's annual festival of movie shorts, "Festival de Nevers de l'Aube," whose presenter was a friend of one of them.
Which one? They don't consider that important, and furthermore, in the interest of unity, they have sent no individual information or separate photos to their presenters' locales.
"We wanted to make a small performance, but we were not sure what," Map said. (The telephone conversation is translated from an ad hoc mixture of French and English, representing a genuine dual effort.) "We had no money, but because Nevers is a city for train repairs, 55-gallon barrels were easy to find free, in gardens."
They performed 20 minutes at the festival, got all fired up and decided to go to any nearby festival, invited or not. "We played in the street," Map said. "Presenters liked us, and we began to be invited."
True to its perverse form, the all-male group, now aged 25 to 42, named its first commercial recording "Silence." It's anything but, though the label name, Naive, is more like it. The rhythms are clean, repetitive in the marching-band sense and seductive but acceptable, probably, even to the most mannered listener. "Bombast and unity," one reviewer said. Not bad.
Nothing about their performance is gentrified. Some numbers have added clapping or whistling, while in others, oil barrel clangor is augmented by groans, howls and snorts. The recording's final number, "Etouffez la Ventoline" (a title chosen for rhythm rather than meaning) has unintelligible words that might be broadcast over a railroad station loudspeaker.
Comparing Les Tambours with Japan's Kodo Drummers, Map acknowledged the similar visceral effect and then said something like: "Our rhythm is very basic. It goes directly to your body. Our instruments are different in the way we play. We smash very loud. When we finish the show, the instrument is destroyed. You can use both sides of the drum, so two shows maximum."
The destruction factor is handled through copious supplies: "A big truck follows us, with 400 barrels from France, and 4,000 sticks," he said. "We break the sticks. You cannot find the barrels outside of France -- not even in Italy or Germany. They're very thin. With thicker metal, you can hurt yourself." After trying different materials for their pickax mallets, they settled on beechwood, because it proved strong enough to survive a concert or two.
Since the drummers can't practice separately, they get together in what Map described as a hangar in the countryside. "We are not musicians," he said. "We play and move our arms a special way. We look for new members in the way we would look for a friend, not a drummer."
In European performances of Les Tambours, there is some interaction with the audience, which Map was not sure was happening on this tour. "We try to talk to the audience," he said, "but our English is not so good. We explain and ask what they think. We know they won't sleep."
Les Tambours du Bronx, 8 p.m. Tuesday at the Lycian Center, 1355 Kings Highway, Sugar Loaf. Tickets: $29, $23 for children. Information: (914) 469-2287.

HEADLINE: From Tiny Acorns, Philanthropy's Oak

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER

 BODY:
IT doesn't take millions to make a difference. Philanthropists come from all walks of life and all levels of income. Some want to leave a legacy; others want to effect social change. What they share is the spirit of giving.
From the local soccer league to the Herstory Writers Workshop, a women's memoir-writing project, there are hundreds of charitable causes on Long Island and hundreds of small family foundations that help finance them. 
 A retired commodities broker on the East End uses his private foundation to help the families of prisoners. An 11-year-old girl from Oyster Bay sends the earnings from a fund started with an inheritance to her school and to the youth organization where she likes to play basketball. And a former tenor with the New York City Opera and his wife use their connections to stage an opera at a Shelter Rock church each March; the money the event raises goes into a fund they established to support women's literacy in Nassau County.
Sometimes charitable funds are established by people already in the spotlight. Billy Baldwin, one of the four acting Baldwin brothers, recently began a scholarship fund for graduating seniors at Massapequa High School, in the same district where his father, Alexander Baldwin, was a history teacher. In August, Paul Tonna, the presiding officer of the Suffolk County Legislature, established a foundation to help local foster children and then swam across the Long Island Sound to jump-start the fund-raising.
 
Learning to Give
Helping the needy and giving back to the community are lessons that children can learn and cherish. When her grandmother Hilda Weiser died three years ago, Rose Lena Glaser received $5,000 in her grandmother's memory. Lena, now a sixth grader at the Long Island School for the Gifted in Huntington Station, might have been tempted to go on a shopping spree for compact discs at Roosevelt Field. But her parents, Jordan Glaser and Hazel Weiser of Oyster Bay, had a different idea. Concerned about materialism and the values instilled in a child growing up on Long Island, they put Lena's inheritance into a charitable fund at the Long Island Community Foundation.
"Jordan and I believe philanthropy is taught," said Ms. Weiser, a consultant to nonprofit groups. "We did it so that Lena would have an opportunity to learn how to participate in her community. It wasn't her option. We set it up for her so she would know money could do more than buy stuff."
The interest generated by the Rose Fund, named for Lena's great-grandmother and namesake, Rose Epstein, is used for grants that Lena designates. "To have the Rose Fund and to be able to give money away to nonprofit organizations feels good," she said.
So far Lena has had three checks issued from her fund.
After accompanying her father, who volunteers at Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, she sent a $100 donation. "I liked the work that they were doing because it allows women to have choice over their lives," Lena said.
She also made a $125 donation to her school's scholarship fund, "because I like the school and want other kids to be able to have the opportunity to have what I have gotten," she said.
And earlier this year, Lena gave $150 to the Boys and Girls Club of Oyster Bay because she likes playing basketball there and meeting other children from her area.
Where to donate funds is often a topic of conversation at the family's dinner table. Her parents have established their own charity, the Hilda Weiser Fund, honoring Ms. Weiser's mother, with a $6,000 gift. The money the fund earns benefits the Long Island Fund for Women and Girls. Ms. Weiser, the group's co-president, said that it gives out grants and provides an avenue for women to meet and work together for economic independence, leadership and freedom from violence.
At its sixth annual awards breakfast on Wednesday, the fund will give $80,000 in grants to 27 groups, including Something Old, Something New of South Country, which teaches women of various backgrounds how to sew and weave; the Children's Scholarship Fund, which provides scholarships and school supplies to girls from low-income families; and the Committee on Domestic Harmony, which helps women from South Asia, the Middle East and Africa escape from violent relationships.
"My mother was very active in women's organizations on Long Island," Ms. Weiser said. "It's a way of guaranteeing that I'll be able to contribute to women's organizations and think about my mother when I do it. It's a way to keep her name alive. My parents didn't have money. My parents were generous with their time."
 
Ignored Families
When Alan Morton retired as a commodities broker on Wall Street in 1985, he wanted to help people with daunting problems that others had ignored. He first set up a foundation in his own name, channeling money to AIDS patients, and two years ago, to make the task easier, he began funneling his grant money through the Long Island Community Foundation. Grants now go to families of prisoners and to a scholarship program for youngsters from troubled homes.
"I had a little money, not very much, but I had enough to take care of my needs for the rest of my life," said Mr. Morton, who lives in Sag Harbor. "Anything which was surplus to that I wanted to try and do something with it. We have a general program of helping anyone whose needs aren't catered by traditional agencies. They fall through the cracks."
Families of prisoners do their time on the outside, Mr. Morton believes, because they are stigmatized by neighbors, treated curtly on prison visits and must get along without the financial and emotional support of the relative in jail. "I think they have a pretty raw deal," Mr. Morton said. "People aren't very sympathetic toward people in jail and understandably, but I think some of that rubs off on the families."
 
Friendship's Legacy
Ken Greenblatt met Alan P. Mendelsohn in the first grade at Canti ague School in Jericho. They became best friends. Mr. Mendelsohn died of Addison's disease, which affects the adrenal glands, in 1989. For the 20-year reunion of their class at Jericho High School last year, Mr. Greenblatt created a scholarship fund in Mr. Mendelsohn's name. "It's the 'nice guy' scholarship," said Mr. Greenblatt, 39, who lives in Woodbury. "In our world the nice guys finish first, bucking the trend of 'nice guys finish last.' "
Mr. Greenblatt, a vice president of the Millennium Planning Group, a money-management concern, began the fund, run by the Long Island Community Foundation, with $1,000 of his own money. At the reunion, he asked his classmates to join in, and so far, 78 people, including family members, have contributed a total of $16,000.
The first two scholarships, each $500, were awarded in June to a graduating boy and girl selected by a committee from the high school. The winners must "embody the characteristics and qualities of our friend Alan, who was one of the nicest people on the planet," Mr. Greenblatt said. "He was a great, all-around human being, a Renaissance man," he added. "That's what we wanted to acknowledge."
 
For Foster Children
As the presiding officer of the Suffolk County Legislature, Mr. Tonna, 42, assigned himself as chairman of the social services committee. The horror stories of sexual and physical abuse that child-protection workers recounted at meetings made him cry, he said. When he told his wife, Carol, 47, what was happening, she insisted they had to do something about it.
Together, in August they set up the Search Foundation, short for Seeking Avenues to Reward Foster Children, and so far they have raised $18,000, including their own gift of $1,000. To kick off the fund-raising in September, Mr. Tonna, a former lifeguard, swam six miles across Long Island Sound, from Stamford, Conn., to Caumsett State Park in Lloyd Neck.
As four of his five adopted children, all under age 5, climbed on his lap, wrapped their arms around his neck and legs and clamored for attention, Mr. Tonna said: "We have to take care of those who are least fortunate in our society. There is no group of people in our society that needs love and care more than foster children."
New York State grants payments of $400 for each foster child for school and hobby expenses, music, art and dancing lessons and summer camp. But that amount doesn't go very far, Mr. Tonna said, and the foundation the Tonnas set up will help fill the gaps.
"What we do is like a make-a-wish for foster kids," Mr. Tonna said. "When they want to go for swim lessons, or they need the soccer league or the baseball league, once that $400 is exhausted, the Search Foundation will help support efforts to pay for their other activities, to give the things all kids need. Foster kids need a childhood. That's what we're focusing on, that they get an opportunity to have a childhood like anybody else."
At any given time, there are about 1,000 foster children in Suffolk County, and an average of 53 children enter foster care each month, Mr. Tonna said. About 70 percent of these children eventually return to their families, and 21 percent are adopted. Mr. Tonna has set of a goal of raising $100,000 a year for the Search Foundation, or $100 for each foster child in Suffolk.
Mr. Tonna acknowledged that being the presiding officer of the County Legislature may have helped his fund-raising efforts. "Being a politician is not my day job," he said. "This is my avocation. Clearly for me, I have a huge agenda, a social agenda, a community agenda. And so I use the political stuff as a means to an end. This is one of those ends."
 
Close to Home
Murray and Lillian Barbash of Brightwaters believe that giving starts at home. They started the Barbash Family Fund nine years ago to give money to causes they were interested in.
"Our charity is mainly local," said Mr. Barbash, 76, a retired residential developer and a longtime supporter of the arts on the Island. "We both have a philosophy that charity is much more effective when you take an interest in the place you are putting your money. The value is enhanced by your presence."
Five years ago, the couple saw "Having Our Say" on Broadway, the story of Sadie and Bessie Delany, two pioneering black women who talk about their experiences in a racially divided society. Mr. and Mrs. Barbash later returned for a special matinee with 700 11th and 12th graders from Bay Shore, at a cost of $18,000.
"The Bay Shore school system is 40 percent minority," Mr. Barbash said. "One of the problems is to get the minority kids to come out of their shells and participate in the arts. It's been a marvelous experience getting everybody to participate and appreciate the arts creatively and passively and in every which way."
That first field trip was so successful that Mr. Barbash founded the Bay Shore Schools Arts Endowment Fund with $50,000, part of it his own money and part an anonymous donation. A year ago, he began bringing in corporate donors like the Keyspan Energy Corporation and the Roslyn Savings Bank.
In recognition of his efforts, Mr. Barbash will be honored as the outstanding philanthropist of the year by the Long Island chapter of the National Society of Fund Raising Executives on Friday.
When the Barbashes moved to Long Island in 1954, they chose Brightwaters because of the Bay Shore schools' top-notch reputation in the arts. Their three children attended Bay Shore schools, and three of their six grandchildren are now enrolled. "We bring arts to the school, and the kids to the arts," Mr. Barbash said. Perhaps as a result of getting the children involved and motivated, Mr. Barbash said, the district's SAT scores have climbed well above the state and national average.
As part of their personal involvement with the arts, the Barbashes were founders of the Long Island Philharmonic and have bailed the orchestra out on more than one occasion. "It's a hell of a problem keeping an orchestra viable in an atmosphere where the competition, not only in New York City, is ferocious," Mr. Barbash said. "On Long Island itself, Tilles gets the best orchestras in the world. How can the L.I. Philharmonic compete with that?"
The Barbashes set up their foundation at the urging of their accountant. "The foundation gives us a lot of flexibility, and it prepares for the future," Mr. Barbash said. "When the need arises we do it. We're not dot-com millionaires, but we are certainly substantial enough to give a considerable amount of money away. We just want to do these things in the community where we can see how our efforts benefit the community. It's a lot more effective than writing a big check and throwing it at an organization."
Mr. Barbash said that he and his wife found philanthropy challenging. "If some kids get turned on and lead fuller lives because they have been turned on early to appreciate the theater and music and art, then the whole thing is worth it," he said. "The bonus is that it does demonstrably help kids scholastically and throughout their whole lives."

HEADLINE: Island's Artists Create Art for Wrist or Lapel

BYLINE: By MARCIA BYALICK

 BODY:
A POTTER'S work makes its home on a shelf. A painter's work hangs on the wall. But the work of a jewelry maker can turn up anywhere: dangling from the ears of a customer waiting in line at the post office, encircling the wrist of a ticket taker at the local movie theater or adorning the suit jacket of a county district attorney.
Here's a look at several Long Island jewelry makers whose unusual, whimsical and elegant designs have helped elevate their craft to an art form.
 
Sisters in Motion 
 Ilene Barrack answers the door of her Great Neck home wearing a hot pink lace shawl, adorned with a few strategically placed crystal beads, that was, until a few days before, an antique beige table runner. The curtains behind her are rich Indian saris, held together with red rhinestone earrings.
Her sister, Miriam Miller, who lives in Roslyn, is already at work, painstakingly boring holes in the soft gray pearls she will entwine with the eight shades of blue crystals she plucks out of the plastic bowls before her.
"Today is a blue day," she explained, taking a tissue out of a magnificent crocheted bag she whipped up over the weekend.
"Sisters" reads their business card, and that relationship informs their energy, their work habits and their creativity.
After their international travel as publicists for the fashion industry was curtailed by the birth of their children, they decided to harness some of the talent first expressed during their Bayside High School years. In the 70's they haunted the stores in Flushing for yarn, trimmings and buttons, creating their own clothes. They befriended artists in Arizona and New Mexico and began designing Indian jewelry.
"We were so successful, so fast, that the phone would ring at 8 in the morning and someone would say: 'Brush your teeth, I'm coming over. I need a gift for my mother-in-law,' " said Ms. Barrack. "People would come here every day. Until the interest in Indian jewelry began to wane."
"Then," Ms. Miller continued, "a friend told us that the department stores were featuring all kinds of crystal beaded bracelets and necklaces. She knew we could create more beautiful pieces than they were selling. She was right."
In a matter of weeks they were in business. Ms. Miller ferreted out new sources for materials, using both their old contacts out West and on 37th Street in Manhattan, as well as new ones the computer came up with in India and Pakistan. Ms. Barrack bought a few pieces and studied them before coming up with her own take.
"My customers like my wacky combinations," she said. "I'm never consistent, and I love colors that clash. If someone says, 'Make that exact piece for me,' I can't. What I can do is give them a wristful of bracelets, each different, for the same price as a high-end department store charges for one."
The women use amethysts, rubies, green garnets, peridots, turquoise, tourmaline, pearls, coral and crushed oyster to accent their crystal jewelry.
"The two of us, working our 15 to 20 hours a week, barely produce enough to satisfy the orders coming in," Ms. Barrack said. "Filling the orders for bridal parties, a new venue for us, is keeping us really busy. If we were to hire other people to help us, we could . . . "
"But we don't want to do that," Ms. Miller finishes the thought. "We like our aloneness. We like having a home cottage industry that allows us time to still bake and crochet and knit."
"We don't like anything that takes us away from the kids. They're our No. 1 priority," added Ms. Barrack. "And it doesn't mean anything if we can't do it together."
 
Life in Porcelain
Although Erh-Ping Tsao's family was disappointed that he did not follow in the footsteps of his doctor father and scientist aunts and uncles, there is no doubt that his affinity for anatomy and biology is seen in the work he did choose.
Along with his wife, Cynthia Chuang, he creates imaginative interpretations of fish, birds, butterflies, grasshoppers, praying mantises and other creatures, made of specially painted porcelain, metal, and semi-precious stones.
In 1984, after attending the Taiwan Academy of Art, the two received their master's degrees in sculpture at the Parsons School of Design. The years that followed found them working out of a kiln in the bathroom of their Elmhurst apartment.
Now the couple, who have a home in Lattingtown, have a waiting list of galleries who want to exhibit their jewelry, a retail store of their own in Manhasset, and a production staff of 10 to help them.
At this point, Ms. Chuang takes care of the business end and Mr. Tsao "thinks."
"Our inspiration comes from ancient Egypt and Africa, from folk art and modern art," Mr. Tsao said. "Each of our pieces has a story behind it. I never sketch what I'm going to make. The trying part is already in my brain. The porcelain we use is soft and cannot be extended. But metal can. We have developed three-dimensional construction techniques that have never before been used with porcelain. I often solve these kind of problems in the middle of the night."
"Erh-Ping has a scientific mind with an artistic nature that is romantic and idealistic," Ms. Chuang said. "We depend on each other in both art creation and practical life. However, we still have independent space to enjoy personal meditations. We strongly complement one another."
 
Luster of Gold
Wendy Kay says she's shy so she likes to let her art speak for her.
"For me to personally sell my pieces, to have to schmooze for hours with dozens of customers, is as difficult as putting in the time and energy necessary to produce enough work for a craft fair," said Ms. Kay, a Sand Point resident who works in silver and gold. "That's why most of my work is either commissioned or sold in galleries."
Ms. Kay works out of a glass-enclosed, skylit studio overlooking the garden. Access is only from the patio or the garage, assuring that her quiet work space is completely separate from the rest of her life. Her materials, large sheets of silver and gold, are special-ordered from England. Before becoming one-of-a-kind earrings, necklaces and pins, they are shaped, rolled, hammered and melted on heat refractory counters, using anvils, torches, wheels and her tool of choice, a water welder.
Her signature design is a bimetal slide, most popularly right now in red or blue, that looks much like a piece of ziti. When the piece is slid onto a necklace, whether it be pearl or beads or crystal, the item becomes more versatile.
Ms. Kay's time is divided between her studio at home and a studio she uses as a classroom in Little Neck.
"Working at home as I do allows for flexibility but it can become very lonely and isolating," she said. "I found the energy and the focus I needed in a communal setting. The other artists work in silver and enamel. Observing their work, I got into using colors on my metals, using the water torch to form shapes and collages. If I'm tense, I might move into clay, a more pliable medium. I make masks and vessel forms, enhancing them with jewelry and feathers."
Recently her focus has been recycling old gold into more organic wearable art. When people bring her their treasures, she removes the stones and melts down the gold. Then, she designs a new piece.
"To have a trademark, if I could take a particular design and have it reproduced in a certain way so that it is my signature design . . . that would be wonderful."
 
Working Beads
Heidi Bram is that most rare of creatures: a jewelry maker who actually makes a living from her art, which she calls "bead manipulation."
An affirmation posted about the work space in her Centerport home says, "Be kind and special with yourself, being your knowing everything you need is in you."
"These sayings help me to remember who I am, why I'm here and what I'm doing this for," said the 29-year-old artist."
Today she is filling an order for one of the fashionable Long Island establishments who carry her jewelry. She creates three collections a season, each based on one color scheme and consisting of 12 to 15 necklaces, 15 earrings and 5 bracelets. This season black, garnet, smoked topaz and amethyst star in her work, accenting the glass and crystal that underlie all her pieces.
Five years ago, Ms. Bram was fired from her corporate job in upscale men's fashion. Her parents were more upset than she was.
"They have lived a safe life where you don't take risks," she said. "They were nervous that I didn't have security. It was hard for them. So I tried. I went on interviews but nothing panned out. Now I know why. It wasn't supposed to."
While Ms. Bram was collecting unemployment and pondering what to do with her degree in textiles, fashion buying and merchandising, a friend asked her if she could make her a beaded necklace similar to the one she was wearing.
Everyone in her friend's office loved it and asked her to make some for them.
"I always knew I wanted my own business but I didn't know what kind," said Ms. Bram. "When these necklaces proved so popular, I decided to create a collection and make the rounds of buyers and boutiques, both in Manhattan and on Long Island. I tried local craft fairs. I found I enjoyed interacting with people and learned pretty quickly not to take anything personally. Within a few months I was making a living."
Soon she found that the only way she could produce enough for the fairs was if she gave up selling to the stores and galleries. Or get help.
Recently she hired an assistant.
"Till now I was a one-woman operation," Ms. Bram said. "I did the designing, the bead shopping, the bead counting, the paperwork, all the production, the selling and delivering. But I didn't mind because each year, as I got better, my business grew. Happiness is very much about finding that place inside that makes us comfortable with what were doing. I'm so lucky that I have."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Work Begins on Battery Landing for Staten Island Service;
Coming Up: One Ferry Terminal, Hold the Clock

 BODY:
Remember that Staten Island ferry terminal design with the giant clock? This isn't it.
This is the one that is actually being built. 
 In September, nine years after a spectacular fire ravaged the Whitehall Ferry Terminal in lower Manhattan, ground was broken for its replacement by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island and Michael G. Carey, president of the city Economic Development Corporation, which is overseeing the project.
The $135 million terminal will look considerably different from the one planned in 1992. Designed by Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates and Anderson/ Schwartz Architects, that version was to have been topped by a 120-foot clock with the city seal.
Some New Yorkers were captivated (Mayor David N. Dinkins said it would "become a bold new symbol for the city"), but others -- Mr. Molinari most prominently among them -- were infuriated.
"Its only probable benefit would be to remind people that they're late for work -- again," Mr. Molinari said about the clock, which would have greeted Staten Islanders crossing the harbor.
Instead of a clock, the new version will have a V-shaped crown, lined with photovoltaic panels that will furnish part of the terminal's power. The three-slip structure will be faced in glass and corrugated stainless steel. Under the crown will be an open-air viewing deck. "For the first time the public can get out and have elevated views of the harbor," said Frederic Schwartz of Schwartz Architects, successors to Anderson/Schwartz, which continued on the job after the departure of Venturi, Scott Brown. Engineers of the remarkably complex project -- above three subway lines, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and the East River -- include TAMS Consultants, Robert Silman Associates and Flack & Kurtz. The construction manager is Tishman/Harris.
Benefits for commuters include an air-conditioned waiting room. The three-year project involves demolition of the existing terminal. One ferry slip at a time will be taken out of service.
It has been a long wait, but Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the development corporation, said the design is now "a very contemporary reflection of the times, both in the energy-efficient components and also in the utilization of materials."

HEADLINE: Pinning Their Hopes

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: PAULSBORO

 BODY:
THE streets of this little town along the southern Delaware River are not bursting with prosperity even in these flush times. There are lots of "For Rent" signs and boarded-up doors and windows. Mergers in the oil industry have caused layoffs at the riverfront refineries. The town hardly seems a destination for the hopeful.
Yet on every streetlight along Delaware Avenue is a large banner that reads "Paulsboro, Home of Champions" or "We've Got Paulsboro Pride." 
 Those banners mark the way to Paulsboro High School, an old multistory stone building in an era of low-slung, sprawling high school campuses. And each winter, much of the town turns out to watch the Red Raiders wrestling team overpower another opponent.
Last year, Paulsboro won the New Jersey Group 1 wrestling championship. It wasn't even close: a 56-14 trouncing of Bound Brook, making the Red Raiders 21-0 for the season.
In many ways, it was just another day at the office for Paulsboro High School wrestlers. Paulsboro has won the last 18 Group 1 wrestling titles, the most consecutive state championships of any wrestling team in the country. The team has won 243 straight Colonial Conference matches and 29 consecutive conference championships.
In fact, when Paulsboro's wrestling team loses, it's an occasion. The team has lost only 10 dual matches in the last 30 years, running up winning streaks of 55, 84 and 96 in that time.
But all those statistics, amazing though they may be, only start to tell the story of Paulsboro High School wrestling. Paulsboro and neighboring Gibbstown, which also feeds Paulsboro High, are the type of hardscrabble towns that people have been abandoning for decades, as the country has moved from manufacturing to a service economy. The Colonial Conference in which Paulsboro's teams play includes much more affluent places, like Haddonfield and Collingswood.
"We recognize the differences, I have to say that," said Walter Quint, Paulsboro's superintendent of schools for the last 10 years. "But Paulsboro kids go out of their way to break the stereotype you might think of in that regard. When you see them in public, they are always dressed better and behaving better than you would expect."
Some believe it has a lot to do with the wrestling heritage of the town, dating to 1939. That was when a young physical education teacher named Norman Hangen started a wrestling program at Paulsboro as an alternative to boxing.
"From what I heard, Mr. Hangen had a tough time convincing parents that this wasn't that fake professional wrestling," said Paul Morina, the current Paulsboro wrestling coach. "But once he did, everyone got on the bandwagon. It was seen as something to build character, something to have as a tradition."
Mr. Morina is an integral part of that tradition. He was a Paulsboro High wrestler who was South Jersey regional champion in the 148-pound weight class in 1977. His older brother, Carmel, was a state champion in the 188-pound weight class in 1975 and now coaches seventh and eighth graders in Paulsboro. Paul Morina's assistants all wrestled at Paulsboro.
"This is a family business," said Steve Anuszewski, a financial planner who wrestled with both Morinas in the mid-1970's in Paulsboro and now volunteers as an assistant coach. "And the town is always behind it. It isn't just a few kids who happen to be good. It's a whole town getting together. And kids who achieve beyond where some people from the outside would believe."
Tom Curl, for instance, is just a little worried about his advanced-placement calculus class. A junior, Mr. Curl placed fifth and third, respectively, in the state as a heavyweight (more than 215 pounds) the last two years. His friend Mike Mendenhall, another junior, was seventh in the state in the 189-pound weight class last year. He is taking advanced chemistry and is on his way, he hopes, to a career in computer engineering.
"If you are involved in Paulsboro wrestling, you see how you can reach goals," Mr. Curl said. "You extend yourself."
"I think we're recognized as achievers, here and throughout the state," Mr. Mendenhall said. "And it's because of the support we get at home and in town. When we go to away matches, there are almost always more people from Paulsboro than from the home team. They rent buses here. When we go to Virginia for tournaments, we have busloads of parents, friends, fans coming with us."
The climb to being part of the Paulsboro varsity starts early. Mr. Mendenhall started in a peewee wrestling club at age 6. Mr. Curl started even earlier.
"I was 4 when my father took me to Gateway High School to a wrestling match," he said. "I loved it. I made him watch wrestling matches on local cable. He took me to peewee classes."
When he was in third grade, Mr. Curl, who was then living in nearby Mantua, got his father to take him to Paulsboro for his wrestling because that was the place to be. The family later moved to Gibbstown and Mr. Curl was officially part of the Paulsboro tradition.
"It is both great and tough to be here," he said. "Great because of the support, but tough because our training and work is harder. I'm sure we work more than any other wrestling team. But it makes us better people, since we work hard and know that that means we can have success."
Like most of the varsity wrestlers, both Mr. Curl and Mr. Mendenhall are members of Paulsboro's other stellar sports squad, the football team. During the mid-1990's, the football team won a state-record 63 consecutive games. It has lost only two games since.
"I think it is the perfect complement," said Mr. Morina, who is thehigh school's interim athletic director as well as wrestling coach. "I know they are in good shape even before we start the season in December. And I know they come over with the right type of pride. I think it carries over to the rest of the school, and that is a good thing, especially if the town itself falls on bad times."
The halls of Paulsboro High are quiet during class time -- no tough guys bounding around, no disruptions coming from classrooms. The halls are, indeed, old and cramped, but they are without any clutter. While smoke spews out of refineries just past the football field behind the school, the grounds are neat and students pick up every piece of litter.
"Yes, this is a tough town, but the kids here are classy," said Mr. Quint, the superintendent. "I think in part it has to do with the wrestling team, which reinforces a sense of pride in the school and the town. No one here backs off from a challenge. But that also means they are not afraid of hard work."
Mr. Morina became coach in 1985, but he still reveres his old coach, Bob Frederick, whose teams lost only six matches in 15 years (three of those were in Mr. Frederick's first year as coach in 1970). Mr. Frederick, who works part-time in the Gloucester County College athletic department, still drops by to help out Mr. Morina.
"It's a matter of everyone in town doing their part," Mr. Frederick said. "There are youth wrestling teams and peewee tournaments and parents and friends doing everything to make sure they have good coaching and the proper equipment. Once again, these are tough kids from a tough community and they have always done their best."
Mr. Morina said the challenge for Paulsboro wrestling in the future was daunting. The team has had only 19 state champions, despite its 778-54-12 record since 1939, which reflects on the quality of the team overall as opposed to a handful of standout wrestlers. This is even more unusual in a school of only 747 students.
"Wrestling everywhere is bigger than it used to be, and we are in a little school, so getting a very good team is difficult," Mr. Morina said. "I can see the day where we might not be state champs, where we might get beaten a couple of times.
"That's when we'll find out how good this program really is, when I find out how good a coach I really am," he said. "But they have all been great kids, so that's what being a champion is."

HEADLINE: Giving It Away

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

 BODY:
THERE are many tales about Bernice Wall Barbour, and one of the favorites involves the winter when she heard that elk were starving to death out West. She left her New Jersey home and headed out to her Wyoming ranch, where she bought a snowmobile and spent the winter hauling hay to the hungry animals.
Her passion for animals was so great that in 1987, two years before she died, Mrs. Barbour, a lifelong New Jersey resident, set up a foundation -- the Bernice Barbour Foundation Inc., based in Hackensack. Its mission: to give grants to groups that preserve and care for animals in the United States and to groups that prevent cruelty to animals. 
 Mrs. Barbour wanted her money to continue supporting the causes she loved, long after she was here to make the donations herself. Changes in tax laws over the past two decades have made foundations a popular way to do that -- and to do it now. Instead of setting up foundations as part of a will, people are getting them up and running while they are still alive and well.
"People who set up foundations are generally interested in doing good for their community and they would rather direct their money than have the government direct it for taxes," said William V. Engel, a lawyer and executive director of the E. J. Grassmann Trust in Warren.
As of 1998, there were 1,462 active foundations in New Jersey, according to Steven Lawrence, director of research for the Foundation Center, an organization that collects, organizes and analyzes information on foundations. New Jersey has about 3 percent of the United States' 46,832 foundations, twice as many as there were in 1982.
The majority of the country's foundations are small, with less than $100,000 in annual giving, and two-thirds have less than $1 million in assets. While some give million-dollar donations, many give grants of several hundred or several thousand dollars to a few dozen local organizations.
"A foundation can have a big impact," Mr. Lawrence said. A foundation can make a difference on one issue, or in one community where the giving is centered, like the Victoria Foundation in Montclair, which gives about 140 grants a year to organizations based in Newark.
Some foundations give to set organizations each year, while others take applications for their money. All have special fields of interest, and some can be quite specific. Mrs. Barbour's foundation, for example, will not support groups that do not spay or neuter animals before giving them out for adoption.
Foundation giving in the United States was almost $23 billion in 1999, Mr. Lawrence said. About $759 million was given out in New Jersey by foundations in 1998, the most recent state data available. Here are some of the Jersey foundations and their projects:
 
E. J. Grassmann Trust
E. J. Grassmann, a lifelong resident of Elizabeth, made his money in land surveying and in a company that mined and processed kaolin, a type of clay that is used to make paper shiny.
"He was a very private individual to the point that he would be unhappy that his name was on this trust," said Mr. Engel, the executive director of the trust. Few people knew him well and many found him intimidating. Mr. Grassmann married, but there were no children. His wife Ernestine, died about 18 months after his death in 1974.
Mr. Grassmann left money for his wife, but the rest of his estate went to charity. The trust, started in 1979, was a way "the money would do a lot of good over a long period of time," Mr. Engel said.
While Mr. Grassmann was alive, his favorite charities were the three hospitals in Elizabeth that have now merged to become Trinitas Hospital.
The trust now gives 175 grants each year. What started as an $8 million trust, when Mr. Grassmann died, is now $36 million. Grants have ranged form $1,500 to $90,000 though they average $10,000 each and few are more than $20,000. The foundation gets more than 300 applications each year and awards grants twice a year. Most of the money stays in New Jersey, but some grants are also awarded to groups in mid-Georgia, where the kaolin mines are.
The board of the trust has given preference to hospitals, social service groups, education organizations and land preservation organizations in the Elizabeth area, in keeping with the types of charities that Mr. Grassmann chose when he was alive.
Organizations with low administrative costs are given preference. Organizations receiving money in recent years have included the Nature Conservancy in Chester, the New Jersey Historical Society in Newark, St. Vincent Academy High School in Newark and the Muhlenberg Hospital Foundation in Plainfield.
 
Puffin Foundation Ltd.
The puffins, birds that live off the coast of Maine, were forced to leave their habitat because their eggs were being attacked by sea gulls. A professor who studied the species figured out a way to prevent the attacks and the puffins were able to live in the area again. Perry Rosenstein believes that the assault on the puffins "symbolizes what we thought was happening with our culture today: We're losing touch with our roots."
And so, 15 years ago, Mr. Rosenstein, who is president of Brighton-Best Socket Screw Manufacturing Inc., started a private family foundation that took its name from the birds. His wife, Gladys Miller-Rosenstein, is the executive director and his three children are on the board of the Puffin Foundation, which is now based in Teaneck.
"We strongly believe in individual creativity," Mr. Rosenstein said of the foundation, whose main interests are the arts and the environment. It gives grants to all types of artists and strives for diversity by giving money to native Americans, gays and "artists of all colors and political persuasions," he said. It has also helped organizations like Doctors Without Borders and groups that promote events against capital punishment. Those seeking grants, which can range from $1,000 to $7,000, must apply to the foundation.
The family opened the Puffin Cultural Forum in Teaneck, which has weekly arts programs, many of them free, including musical performances and lectures by artists and photographers.
 
The Victoria Foundation
Catherine M. McFarland, executive officer of the Victoria Foundation, said that when she mentions a project outside Newark to the board of directors, the response is, "I'm glad you've solved all of Newark's problems."
The board's point, Ms. McFarland said, is that "by focusing we can accomplish more."
Last year, the foundation gave 147 grants in the Newark area ranging from $1,000 to $500,000, with the average grant from $75,000 to $100,000. Grants are given to benefit the environment, education, health services, the homeless, leadership development and civil rights.
Hendon Chubb, the chief executive of an insurance company, created the foundation to help the poor and to honor his mother, Victoria.
The family story goes like this, Ms. McFarland said: Thomas and Victoria Chubb were living in England and not doing as well as they would have liked. They decided to move to Australia, where Victoria got a job as a teacher. Thomas went to America to seek his fortune, and Victoria agreed to join him later with their two children. When Victoria left Australia, her boat shipwrecked on Pitcairn Island (from "Mutiny on the Bounty"), where she is believed to have been the first white woman to set foot.
She and her family eventually made it to America, where her husband started the successful insurance business.
Thomas and Victoria's son, Hendon, lived and worked in New York. The foundation's focus in the 1940's and 50's was to help children with rheumatic heart problems. But by the late 1950's rheumatic fever had ceased to be a major health concern.
Percy Chubb II became president of the foundation near the end of the 1960's and helped change its focus. Aided by board members like Robert Lilley, who was a telephone executive in the Newark area, the board became interested in helping the city of Newark.
Percy Chubb's interest was "upward mobility for inner city residents," Ms. McFarland said.
In 1999, the foundation gave money to institutions including Newark Boys Chorus School, St. Michael School, Queen of Angels School, the Chad School Foundation, the Newark Public Library, the New Community Corporation, the Newark Community Development Network, the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, Friends of the Rockaway River Inc., the New Jersey Conservation Foundation and Urban Conservation Action Partnership Inc. Grants were also given to arts organizations like the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
 
Pascale/Sykes Foundation Inc.
Families are important to Frances P. Sykes.
Two years after her father, Henry Pascale, a businessman, died in 1990, she started a foundation with her husband, Donald M. Sykes, to help poor working families in New Jersey and New York City.
"We focus on low-income families and flexible programs that promote the independence and integrity of the entire family," she said. "A lot of what we do is preventative."
Mrs. Sykes said she favored programs that worked at helping an entire family, rather than just focusing on one troubled family member. People who are living "one paycheck away from poverty," she said, really struggle when faced with situations like a troubled teenager or a child who needs expensive medicines. When a teenage son has an addiction, she said, "everyone in the family needs to adjust."
One group that the foundation has supported is St. Mary's Hospital Caritas Connection in Passaic, which has a literacy program for immigrant parents and their children. This program "strengthens the role of the parent," Mrs. Sykes said. The foundation also sponsors a bilingual Spanish-English newspaper in the Highbridge section of the Bronx, whose purpose, she said, "is to draw the neighborhood together."
The foundation also gives grants to Our Lady of Lourdes Health System in Camden to aid its programs for the homeless and the underinsured and to St. Paul's Community Development Corporation in Paterson, an offshoot of St. Paul's Episcopal Church that helps with social and economic needs in Paterson.
The foundation, which requires applications, gives about 10 grants a year ranging from $15,000 to $80,000.
 
The Barbara Piasecka Johnson Foundation
Barbara Piasecka Johnson and her husband, J. Seward Johnson, who died in 1983, set up this foundation 26 years ago. Mrs. Johnson, who grew up in Poland and still has family there, wanted to give assistance to medical, artistic and humanitarian projects in her homeland.
The grants have ranged from $221 given to a doctor so he could subscribe to The Journal of the American Medical Association, and $320 to a student so he could stay in New York while taking entrance exams for the Juilliard School of Music to $1 million to build homes in Poland for single mothers and terminally ill patients.
In the last few years, the foundation has become involved with programs whose aim is helping autistic children and adults in Poland.
The organization, based in Princeton, limits grants to organizations and groups that benefit Poland.
 
The Bernice Barbour Foundation
Two years before her death, Bernice Barbour, the widow of Robert Barbour, a businessman, set up a foundation that would benefit the animals she loved so dearly.
Eve Lloyd Thompson, a family friend and head of the foundation, used to tease Mrs. Barbour about having the fattest pigeons and squirrels around her Englewood home.
"She loved all animals," Mrs. Thompson said. "Since childhood, she had been an animal lover. She had a ranch in Wyoming and she loved horses."
The foundation awards grants from $1,000 to $100,000. Last year, the fund aided 118 organizations. They include Friends of the Bergen County Animal Shelter, Monmouth County S.P.C.A., the St. Hubert's Animal Welfare Center in Madison for animals that aren't adopted from other shelters, and Frontiers in Veterinary Medicine, a group that helps veterinary students to do research projects over the summer.
The center also finances research to benefit marine animals. The foundation's brochure with a photo of Mrs. Barbour and drawings of cats, ducks, horses and dogs best describes her mission.
It reads: "From the elk in the Rockies of Colorado who needed hay in a severe winter, to the birds and squirrels in the yard, her dedicated hands on approach to animal welfare was a wonderful thing to witness and a tradition the foundation she founded strives to continue in her memory."
To learn more about foundations in New Jersey and around the country, see the Foundation Center web site at www.fdncenter.org. The Foundation Directory, which lists the nation's foundations by state, is available in many New Jersey libraries. The directory includes financial data, application information and officers and often gives a sampling of grant recipients.

HEADLINE: Changing Fields (and Lawns and Gardens)

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
THE gardening bug is an insidious disease. Once stricken, some victims feel a compulsion to spend all their free time digging in the dirt and all their money buying plants and seeds. Others go even further and transform their working lives by entering the horticultural field.
John Holm, a former professional chef, is in the midst of such a career transformation. Born in Norway to a family that owned a restaurant, he was trained as a cook from an early age. Mr. Holm eventually emigrated to the United States and found work at Manhattan restaurants like La Grenouille and Restaurant 44. He also taught cooking at the French Culinary Institute and helped found a successful prepared-food business. 
 While a chef, Mr. Holm began tending a container garden on the terrace of his Brooklyn Heights apartment. Eventually he moved to a 2.5-acre lot in Bedford and began growing things on a larger scale. He applied to the New York Botanical Garden's School of Professional Horticulture, a two-year program that combines course work with hands-on training in the botanical garden itself. He expects to graduate in 2002 and start his own residential landscape design business.
Training that combines horticulture's intellectual and practical sides makes perfect sense to Mr. Holm, who has a high tolerance for the unglamorous and unpaid work in the botanical garden. "Because of my background in cooking," he said, "I am used to working hard and getting dirty." But "I feel a passion for this that I never did for cooking," he added. "I went into cooking because of my family. This I did for myself."
Five years ago, Mary Squires was a corporate attorney living on Long Island. Then she and her husband moved to Upper Saddle River. After finding out what it cost to hire landscapers, she decided to design her new property herself -- even though she had little experience with plants. "I started researching before I put anything in the ground," she said. Her interest increased, and after she had become a regular at her local retail nursery, a clerk suggested she take some horticulture courses at Bergen County College.
She began her studies with two courses, including Plant, Soil and Science, one of the toughest classes in the two-year degree program. Eventually she became immersed in horticulture education and went to school full time. She received a certificate in landscaping and ornamental horticulture (with honors), and went on to earn an associate's degree in applied science.
With her degrees in hand, Ms. Squires hung out her shingle as a plant consultant, installing and maintaining gardens, doing soil tests and educating her clients about environment-friendly methods of dealing with garden pests.
Ms. Squires specializes in interior "plantscaping," helping her clients with selection and placement of indoor plants. On each job she uses a light meter to gauge the amount of light in specific indoor locations, so people avoid dark corners full of dying plants. This educated approach is something new for Ms. Squires. "In my past life," she said, "I would just buy a plant and water it."
Ms. Squires still does a limited amount of legal work, "just to keep my hand in." In addition to running her own business, she hopes to gain greenhouse management experience by working part time for a local nursery within the next year.
Ms. Squires has no regrets about trading case management for pest management. "The time that I spend in gardens is infinitely more rewarding than the most demanding legal case," she said.
Kathleen Nelson of Gaylordsville, Conn., spends her spring, summer and fall days growing and selling perennials, a home-based business that she began when she made a midlife career change two decades ago. Busy outdoors during the growing season, she spends the winter writing copy for her plant catalog, doing bookkeeping and planning for the coming season.
Ms. Nelson grew up in "the swamps of northern Minnesota," collecting plants in the abundant wetlands. After obtaining a master's degree in zoology, she taught biology at Manhattan Community College. "I loved teaching," she said.
But in the mid-1970's, layoffs within the City University system left Ms. Nelson unemployed. A new job at the University of Bridgeport brought an unexpected bonus -- a husband. Ms. Nelson left teaching and entered professional horticulture at the age of 41, when she had her first child.
"The first couple of years, I didn't know what I was doing," she said. Her science background helped her learn quickly, and trial and error enabled her to make the decision to focus on retail rather than wholesale customers. Her business grew, bolstered by the surge in public interest in perennial plants around the time she started in the 1980's.
Ms. Nelson specializes in shade plants, noninvasive grasses and deer-resistant species, which also feature in her landscape designs for a small number of clients.
As her business has flourished, Ms. Nelson's environmental concerns have grown. A stint on a local wetlands commission changed her focus to promoting native plants. Though natives are enjoying something of a renaissance, the she thinks they need more exposure.
Ms. Nelson's child is now a college junior, and the second career continues to evolve. Though she gives occasional lectures, she said that a return to the classroom would be "emotionally draining." Running her small nursery, said Ms. Nelson, is the perfect combination of physical and intellectual activity.
That combination also appeals to Laura Leach, who made the switch to horticulture after 15 years as a sales, marketing and development executive. Like Mr. Holm, the Hastings, N.Y., resident is now a student in the New York Botanical Garden's horticulture school.
Ms. Leach, who was born in England, has a love of gardening that she inherited from her mother and grandmother. In high school she considered a horticultural career, but chose other options.
After leaving school, Ms. Leach re-encountered horticulture when she took a marketing job with Britain's National Trust, which oversees many historic structures and gardens. Later she worked as the director of development for the Welsh National Opera.
As with Ms. Nelson, marriage helped propel Ms. Leach into a new life. Several years ago, she and her husband emigrated to California, where she began part-time horticultural studies. The following year the couple moved to the East Coast. She had discovered the botanical garden's program on the Internet, and chose it because it provided "the opportunity to work alongside the best horticulturists." She praises the program's diversity. "Today I am preparing seeds for a seed exchange; yesterday I was climbing an oak tree to prune it," she said.
When she graduates in the spring of 2002, Ms. Leach may work as an administrator for a horticultural institution. She also plans to continue her education in landscape design. But she is also keeping her options open. "I am looking at where my skills are," she added.
Ms. Leach had advice for those considering a similar career change. "It's important to have some practical experience in the field first," she said, noting that the botanical garden program requires such hands-on work as a prerequisite for admission.
And, while a horticultural career may ultimately provide those who choose it with time to stop and smell the roses, she advised anyone approaching the field to be "realistic, not romantic."
