HEADLINE: When It Comes to Eating Out, Things Are Looking Up

BYLINE: By DAVID CORCORAN

 BODY:
AFTER years of casual experimentation with a controlled substance -- restaurant food -- I became a serious user last spring, when I began reviewing restaurants for The Times's New Jersey section. It wasn't long into this new habit that a suspicion began to sneak up on me: Was it just me, or were New Jersey restaurants a whole lot better than they used to be?
My very first visit, to a Tenafly restaurant called, simply, America, set me thinking. The place was a knockout -- visually stunning, with specially designed menus and place settings, theatrical lighting, live jazz -- and so were the food and the wine list. Prices were high (about $70 for three courses, wine, tax and tip) but hardly outrageous, compared with the competition across the Hudson. 
 At the time, it seemed like beginner's luck. But each subsequent restaurant reinforced the impression that something momentous was afoot. Few of them were as good as America. But plain or fancy, low end or high, American or French or Mexican or Thai, nearly all made me want to come back.
These restaurants seemed to have a few things in common. Most were relatively new -- five months to three years. The chefs and owners (or chef-owners) had vastly diverse resumes, but each showed a passion for food and an ability to talk about it knowledgeably and thoughtfully. Most paid more than lip service to fresh, seasonal ingredients and to exotic, even slightly naughty ones -- preserved lemons, tamarind, sumac -- that can enliven a dish without hijacking it.
To find out what was up (besides my expense account), I began asking around. I soon discovered that I wasn't the only New Jersey diner who was feeling fortunate. A wide assortment of serious eaters, academic experts and restaurant people confirmed that if these aren't the best of times, they are the best that anyone can remember. And a couple of them reminded me that good times don't last forever -- that we'd better enjoy them while we can.
During the sustained economic boom that began in the early 90's, the state became vastly more hospitable to restaurants. People have more money to spend -- per capita income is now 27 percent above the national average, the highest in history -- and restaurateurs have responded by giving them more places to spend it. The New Jersey Restaurant Association says that from 1990 to 1998 the number of restaurants grew 28 percent, to 16,000 from 12,500. (The state's population grew less than 5 percent in that period.)
"People are realizing that almost any space can house a restaurant," said Jennifer Kitchen, a Web site designer and devoted Central Jersey restaurantgoer who lives in Bridgewater. "Strip malls, the state symbol of New Jersey, used to just house pizza joints, takeout Chinese and bagel shops. Now we're seeing more restaurants opening up in strip malls, and they're turning out to be surprisingly good."
Small wonder, since they are competing fiercely for customers. "Competition brings out the best in everyone," said Rosie Saferstein of West Orange, who runs an Internet forum on New Jersey restaurants (www.foodbytes.com). "Look at Ridgewood and Montclair" -- two towns that have been carpeted with new restaurants in recent years. "Ten or 15 years ago there weren't any Malaysian, Egyptian or Turkish restaurants, to my knowledge," she went on. "Now every cuisine is represented."
The boom in ethnic restaurants reflects a boom in immigration -- in the numbers of new immigrants and their diversity, affluence and mobility. "In the 1990 census, New Jersey's immigrant population was more diverse than any other state's," said Thomas J. Espenshade, a professor of sociology at Princeton University's Office of Population Research. Italians were the largest foreign-born group in 1990, he said, but "they probably won't be in 2000." That honor will go to Cubans or Indians -- not coincidentally, two groups that have been opening new restaurants by the dozen.
All these trends -- growing affluence, rising numbers of restaurants, ethnic diversity -- have surfed right along with a tidal wave of interest in food. "Our customers are much more discriminating than they used to be," said Marc Cappellini, general manager of Cooktique, a cookware store and cooking school in Tenafly. "They're asking more pointed questions of the chefs who teach here. 'What's the difference between fresh, frozen and dried herbs?' You didn't hear that in the past."
These customers watch the Food Channel. They subscribe to food magazines like Gourmet and Cooking Light, they crowd the aisles of stores like Cooktique and Williams Sonoma, they swap finds (and horror stories) in Internet discussion groups like Foodbytes and Chow hound.com. "We've come a long way from the 60's, when Julia Child was the only chef on TV," said Fred Mayo, dean of liberal and management studies at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., which has sharply expanded its course catalog and student body in response to the wave of interest.
Restaurant owners are responding to this new sophistication. Betsy Alger was the executive chef of the Frog and the Peach in New Brunswick when it opened in 1983. "Our menu was much simpler then," said Ms. Alger, still an owner but no longer a chef. "Every main course had the same starch and the same medley of julienne vegetables. Now the public has gotten more sophisticated and demanding, and there's no way I could step into my kitchen and cook the way my chef does."
Dennis Foy, the chef-owner of EQ in Manhattan and Foy's in Point Pleasant Beach, is in an even better position to take the long view: his restaurant Tarragon Tree, which opened in Chatham in 1976 (and closed in 1988), was probably the first in the state to practice the new American style of cooking, with its attention to eclectic and seasonal ingredients.
"There's been an influx of talented chefs into New Jersey," he said. "The clientele is wiser. The resources are better. Products are easier to get. Years ago you couldn't find haricots verts, and prime dried aged meats were a problem unless you did them yourself. Now we're in a good state of food, a good head about food."
But not every indicator is so favorable for New Jersey's restaurants. From 1990 to 1998, the period in which the number of restaurants grew 28 percent, restaurant employment grew only 24 percent (to 176,000 from 142,000). Too many restaurants are chasing too few cooks, waiters and busboys, and it shows: even in expensive places, service can be offhand, poorly timed and confused to the point of cluelessness.
The best restaurants have adapted. "We don't expect as much experience coming in," said Ms. Alger, of the Frog and the Peach. "We used to send people away if they didn't dress properly for the job interview; we wouldn't think of doing that now." To keep good employees, the restaurant offers more benefits, an annual cost-of-living increase and professional training. At the Ryland Inn in Whitehouse, servers take periodic turns cooking, so they gain intimate knowledge of the food they serve.
But the staff shortage may well be emblematic of a larger problem for restaurants. They can attract good employees, and keep them, only as long as they can afford to pay them. And even in boom times, many restaurants are struggling to keep expenses down and prices competitive.
When the economy slows, as it must eventually, the explosive growth of the past decade may prove to have been more than many suburban restaurants can sustain. "In a major city," said Craig Shelton, the chef and owner of the Ryland Inn, "restaurant economics requires turning a table over three to four times a night -- a seating at 5, another one at 7, then at 9 and maybe even at 11 or midnight. You can't do that in the suburbs. Your clientele are commuters; here you do 95 percent of your business between 6:30 and 8:30. So you might ask: How is it that there are any good restaurants outside the city?"
Mr. Shelton answers his question by talking about his relentless efforts to maximize productivity. And it doesn't hurt that the Ryland Inn is one of the few restaurants in New Jersey with a national reputation. It may be able to go on serving $250 wine-and-tasting menus forever.
But others may find that they have to cut corners to stay in business. And when that happens, the best of times could be history.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Susan Cordaro, Sean Desmond

 BODY:
Susan Marie Cordaro, the daughter of Elizabeth Ann and John Benedict Cordaro of Reston, Va., was married yesterday to Sean Kenneth Desmond, the son of Dr. Anne H. Desmond and Daniel P. Desmond of Dallas. The Rev. Keith Fennessy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Earl Provenza, the bride's great-uncle, took part in it.
Ms. Cordaro, 28, is keeping her name. She is a special assistant to Stephen DiBrienza, a member of the New York City Council, who represents the 39th District in Brooklyn. She graduated cum laude from Dartmouth College. Her father is the president of the Council for Responsible Nutrition, a trade association for the dietary supplement industry, in Washington. Her mother retired as the division chief of the procurement office of the United States Agency for International Development in Washington. 
 Mr. Desmond, 26, is an editor at Thomas Dunne Books, a division of St. Martin's Press, in Manhattan, and is also a writer. His first novel, "Adams Fall," was published last month by St. Martin's. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. His mother is the head librarian at the Jesuit College Preparatory School in Dallas. His father retired as the manager of employee benefits for American Airlines in Dallas.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Dear Fearless Leader Of the Federal Reserve

BYLINE: By ALECIA SWASY; Alecia Swasy, assistant managing editor for business at The St. Petersburg Times, is the author of "Soap Opera: The Inside Story of Procter & Gamble."

 BODY:

To: Alan Greenspan
Federal Reserve
Washington
HI Mr. Greenspan! 
 Are you free for dinner next Saturday?
I'm a big fan, so I thought that you and Andrea could come on down to St. Petersburg for a long weekend of grilling some dogs -- maybe filet mignon if I'm feeling irrationally exuberant in the market.
It has been a beautiful November here on the Gulf Coast of Florida and, well, if you're like the rest of America, you surely must need a break from all those Washington types. How do you put up with all those bureaucrats?
I've wanted to ask you to dinner for years. Who wouldn't want to break bread with a Woody Allen with math skills, the man who gets credit for this long-running economic expansion? O.K., maybe George Bush -- the former president, that is -- doesn't want to have supper with you, but he's just a grouch who blames interest rates for his loss to Bubba.
But the rest of us can raise a glass to you, and to the author Justin Martin for his new biography, "Greenspan: The Man Behind Money" (Perseus Publishing, $28), a delightful account of your personal and professional journey from nerdy, swing-band clarinet player to your icon status as Federal Reserve chairman.
What is fascinating about the book is its attention to minutiae, like your love of statistics. Did you really go to a cocktail party, spot the latest Statistical Abstract of the United States on a shelf, then retreat to a corner, ignoring everyone? One fan called you the "kind of person who knew how many thousand flat-headed bolts were used in a 1964 Chevrolet and what it would do to the economy if you took out three of them."
This love affair with the economy has roots in your early years at New York University's School of Commerce, where you read Keynes, a key influence on Franklin D. Roosevelt, who put people to work building roads during the Depression. From there, your work at the Conference Board was a natural fit, a place brimming with raw data to help you study the steel and rail industries. Sorry to read that your marriage to Joan Mitchell lasted less than a year -- but at least you two remained friends.
By the 1950's you had put away your clarinet, and at the tender age of 27 that Greenspan intellect won you a partnership at Townsend-Skinner, a New York consulting firm that would become Townsend-Greenspan. It is interesting to note that studying how X number of men working Y hours produced Z tons of steel proved to be a logical alternative to a failed musical career. "I get the same kind of joy from solving a hard mathematical problem as I do from hearing a Haydn quartet," you once said. Hard to remember, with the gee-whiz technology of today, that the firm's first computer was the size of a Honda Civic, but had less horsepower than a 386 microprocessor.
BUT the author should have given more than a couple of paragraphs to how you hired women economists at a lower wage than men -- even if everyone pulled that stunt back then. Still, your skepticism about Richard Nixon redeems you. The meeting of the future president and the economist was rich. "He waxed on about the economy in the obscuromystical style that has become his trademark," the author writes of you. Nixon was impressed with you, but you once described him as "intellectually insecure" and "difficult to deal with."
The book, which reflects access to the inner circle of your pals, is especially useful for those of us who were mere punks in the 1970's. For instance, Sunday nights at my house found eight children in front of the TV, focused on the Cartwright family riding those beautiful horses across the Ponderosa. I'm reminded that Nixon pre-empted "Bonanza" on Aug. 15, 1971, to tell America that he was freezing wages and prices -- a move that your pal Milton Friedman deemed the worst mistake in American economic policy in 40 years. As a 7-year-old, all I remember is Dad complaining about grocery prices, so it's helpful to have a refresher course on double-digit inflation.
The author does give you a thump for your incredible gaffe in the fall of 1974, when you were head of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Ford administration. As inflation and unemployment were out of control, you said Wall Street brokers were "hurt the most" by inflation. That remark earned you a place on the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s dubious distinction list. That could explain why you now talk in obscuromystical ways.
But you were on your way in the mid-1970's. Newsweek put you on a cover in 1975, a year when the magazine also featured Bruce Springsteen, Patty Hearst and Jimmy Hoffa. As your political career took off, you did manage to find time to kick up your heels with Barbara Walters and your future wife, Andrea Mitchell, both TV personalities.
What's your take on the author's Freudian dissection of your relationships with women? He says your relationship with your mother gave you a comfort level with strong, unconventional women, like the TV newswomen. Maybe you just like media darlings who share their Cuban cigars, which they get directly from Fidel.
Speaking of Ms. Mitchell, the book discloses a few details of your marriage, but it would have been fun to read more. The honeymoon was in Venice. The high point: a Vivaldi concert. And Ms. Mitchell's parents gave you a Steinway piano for a wedding gift. "Sometimes he'd play it and amuse himself or me," Ms. Mitchell said of the piano. Alas, it was a busy first year of marriage, because you were fighting a global financial crisis -- the Asian contagion.
If the book has a weakness, it is the rushed feeling of the closing chapters, which condense the Reagan, Bush and Clinton years. This was prime Greenspan time, starting when you became Fed chairman in 1987, just before the stock market crash. Then came the savings-and-loan crisis, when institutions went wild investing in junk bonds, bull sperm banks and Florida swamplands. Charles Keating was the king of the mess. And Neil Bush, a brother of George W., was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan, which had to be bailed out for $1 billion. Funny how the Bush family did not trot out that brother on the campaign trail with Babs and Jebby. And I'm sure you don't want to remember that you once wrote a glowing letter of recommendation about Mr. Keating, endorsing his management of Lincoln Savings and Loan.
Your legacy will forever connect to George Bush, pouting on national television that he could've won the race against Bill Clinton if you would have acted faster to lower interest rates. "I reappointed him, and he disappointed me," Mr. Bush said of you.
But you know what? You haven't disappointed the rest of us. You nailed the Asian contagion, earning you virtual coronation around the globe. The author says CNBC has become GNBC -- all Greenspan, all the time. Then there is that famous briefcase indicator: If you carry a thick case on days when you meet to discuss interest rates, you're pondering a rate change; if you carry a thin one, you're not making a move.
Senator John McCain said it best: "If he would happen to die, God forbid, I would do like they did in the movie 'Weekend at Bernie's.' I would prop him up and put a pair of dark glasses on him."
Glad you enlisted for a fourth term. Hope you and yours will stop by to chew on those dogs, with a side of G.D.P. and C.P.I. data. And don't worry: I'll round up a copy of the Statistical Abstract.
Cheers.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Loan-Fund Yields Come With Risks

BYLINE: By RIVA D. ATLAS

 BODY:
MUTUAL funds that invest in bank loans to corporations have been marketed as higher-yielding alternatives to money market funds, with average returns of 5.9 percent over the last three years.
But many investors are now finding that the funds have a down side. Many of the loans to highly leveraged companies in which these funds invest have fallen in value as the companies struggle to pay their debts. Assets of these funds have been flat this year through September, after more than tripling, from $9 billion to $31 billion, from 1995 to 1999, according to Lipper Inc. 
 "It's become clear that these funds do have risk," said Sarah Bush, an analyst at Morningstar Inc. While the yields on loan funds make them attractive over the long term, she said, investors who depend on short-term income could be disappointed.
Despite such skepticism, Fidelity Investments, the largest mutual fund company, started its first loan fund in August. Until now, the loan fund market has been dominated by smaller mutual fund companies like Eaton Vance or Van Kampen Investments, or by brokerage firms like Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
The appeal of bank-loan funds is their protection against rising interest rates. They invest in debt with floating rates, meaning that borrowers' rates fluctuate based on the London Interbank Offered Rate, a benchmark that is repriced every three or six months.
Because the loans in which these funds invest are made to highly leveraged companies -- typically the same ones that issue junk bonds -- the loans yield a lot more than traditional corporate loans. Yet these loans are much less risky than junk bonds: after a bankruptcy filing, the borrowers are usually required to pay these loans off first, before any junk bonds.
This year through October, loan funds had a total return of 4.81 percent, on average, according to Lipper. That compares with a loss of 5.46 percent for high-yield bond funds and a return of 4.78 percent for money market funds.
Some investors also like the loan funds because of their yields, which have hovered around 8 percent over the last 12 months. But, unlike money market funds, loan funds have net asset values that can fluctuate depending on the health of the borrowers.
This year, the deteriorating finances of some highly indebted corporations, including an increase in junk-bond defaults, have taken a toll on the portfolios of these funds. Through Oct. 30, the net asset values of loan funds are down 26 to 58 cents a share, from an average price of $9.89, according to Morningstar.
The growth in loan funds has coincided with increased trading in loans to highly leveraged companies. Trading volume grew from $8 billion in 1991 to $110 billion last year, according to the Loan Pricing Corporation, a data firm in New York.
"It used to be that you could fit all the participants in this market on your speed-dial," said Christine McConnell, manager of Fidelity's new Floating Rate High Income fund. Increased liquidity is one reason that Fidelity felt comfortable starting a fund, she said.
The Fidelity fund and a new offering from Eaton Vance offer some new twists on the traditional loan-fund formula. Investors who want to redeem their shares, for example, can do so at any time. Most loan funds accept redemptions only once a quarter.
To meet redemptions, the Fidelity fund can keep up to 20 percent of its assets in money markets or other short-term paper. The Eaton Vance fund says it may invest up to 20 percent of its portfolio in junk bonds, which are more liquid, but riskier, than bank loans.
Increased ease of trading bank loans is generally positive for investors, who now have more benchmarks for assessing portfolio quality. But it also means increased volatility in the net asset values of the funds.
As more banks loans are traded, regulators and investors are increasing the pressure on managers of bank-loan funds to write down the value of their loans based on market prices. Banks, in contrast, typically carry loans at par, or 100 cents on the dollar, as long as they are still paying interest.
Many of the larger loan-fund managers -- like Eaton Vance, which runs $10 billion, and Van Kampen, which manages $9 billion -- began pricing a majority of their loans based on market values only over the last year. As a result, the net asset values of these funds are more volatile.
Especially hard hit are those funds exposed to companies whose bonds are in default or are otherwise out of favor. The $5.8 billion Van Kampen Prime Rate Income fund, the largest loan fund, had 8.5 percent of its assets invested in loans to wireless telecommunications companies as of July 31, according to its filings. A decline in the credit standing of these companies, and in the value of their loans, probably helped pull the fund's total return down to just 0.67 percent through October, the poorest showing of any of the 19 bank-loan funds tracked by Morningstar. The fund manager, Howard Tiffen, had no comment.
The Van Kampen fund's performance is far worse than its peers. But with defaults hitting 4 percent of outstanding junk bonds in the 12 months ended Oct. 31, according to Credit Suisse First Boston, loan-fund asset values could erode further. "I don't think the loan market will have a sustained recovery until the high-yield bond market improves," said Chauncey Lufkin, manager of the $2.9 billion Franklin Floating Rate fund, which had a total return of 5.58 percent this year through October. "That could take until the second quarter of next year."
Investors in loan funds take comfort in the strong historical performance of bank loans. Investors in secured bank loans have held on to 84 percent of their principal, on average, after a borrower went bankrupt, according to Moody's Investors Service. In 1990, the worst year on record for the junk-bond market, loan-fund returns averaged 9.6 percent, according to Morningstar.
Still, past performance could be a poor guide, given that the loan market has quadrupled in size since 1993, according to Sam DeRosa-Farag, who tracks the loan market at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Another factor is that banks no longer dominate this market. Investors like mutual funds now account for nearly half the buyers of loans, according to S.& P./Portfolio Management Data, up from 17 percent in 1994. When they start to lose confidence in the borrowers, the newer investors are more likely to sell loans than are the banks, which may want to preserve relationships with long-term clients.
"This is a totally new environment," Mr. DeRosa-Farag said. "For the majority of the 1990's, most of these loans traded at par. This will be a test of the market's success."
INVESTORS uneasy with short-term fluctuations in the loan market may want to stick to the new Fidelity or Eaton Vance funds, because of their ease of exit. Alternatively, five closed-end loan funds, with $3.8 billion in assets, trade on the New York Stock Exchange and can be bought and sold easily. All but one of them trade at a discount to net asset value.
As alternatives, some holders of loan funds may turn to investment grade, Treasury or mortgage bonds. Ten-year Treasury bonds boast an 8.8 percent total return this year, with investment grade and mortgage bonds returning 6.5 percent and 7.4 percent, respectively.

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles

LENGTH: 668 words

HEADLINE: Babes in the Woods: Putting 5 'Cute Utes' to the Test

 BODY:
SMALL sport utility vehicles are grabbing an ever-bigger chunk of the car market, and the hottest ones are cars at heart. They are designed like cars, with one-piece unit bodies, instead of like trucks, with separate bodies bolted to rugged frames. And they meld some car characteristics -- comfortable cabins, relatively responsive handling, compliant rides, reasonable fuel economy -- with the traits that have had people lining up for S.U.V.'s: good outward visibility, a "commanding" driving position, flexible cargo space and the bad-weather security of all-wheel drive.
At prices in the low $20,000 range, these perky S.U.V.'s -- "cute utes," in industry parlance -- are bargains compared with luxurious crossover vehicles like the $36,000 Lexus RX 300 and the $50,000 BMW X5. 
 The first of these was the Toyota RAV4 of 1996, followed by the Honda CR-V. Their success inspired a challenge from Subaru, which essentially gave its Impreza wagon a boxy body and a new name, the Forester.
For 2001, Toyota has brought out a redesigned RAV4 that is slightly larger and more powerful. The Forester has received a mild facelift. And new competition has arrived with the Ford Escape. (Mazda has a similar model, the Tribute.) Hyundai is testing the waters with its first sport utility, the Santa Fe.
In this new landscape, who is king of the hill? Three auto writers and a professional driver sought an answer as they took five vehicles into fender-to-fender combat in the woods of northern New Hampshire. Participating were James G. Cobb, the editor of this page; Cheryl Jensen, a freelance auto writer; Chris Jensen, auto editor of The Plain Dealer in Cleveland; and Tim O'Neil, a former professional rally driver who owns the Team O'Neil Car Control and Rally School near Franconia, N.H.
The test vehicles were a Ford Escape XLT; a Honda CR-V EX, a Hyundai Santa Fe LX, a Subaru Forester S and a Toyota RAV4 L. All had some form of automatic all-wheel drive. (The more rudimentary four-wheel-drive systems of truckish S.U.V.'s can generally be used only on loose surfaces or in snow or rain.)
There are a number of small truck-based utilities, too -- the Nissan Xterra, Kia Sportage, Suzuki Grand Vitara and Chevy Tracker -- but they were not invited to the party. These vehicles tend to be more capable off road but less polished in day-to-day use on pavement.
Also left out were two new vehicles that share some crossover characteristics -- the Chrysler PT Cruiser and Pontiac Aztek -- partly because they are not yet available with all-wheel drive. In any case, they feel more like minivans and cars than like S.U.V.'s.
The testing included identical drives in various conditions, including a moderately challenging off-road trail with stretches of mud (and a large black bear); a 20-mile loop on a variety of road surfaces and terrains; and slalom, braking and emergency-maneuver exercises at the O'Neil School. The vehicles were also scrutinized for their features, their comfort and their utility.
After two days of testing, a consensus was evident. All four participants voted the Escape best in class, based in large part on its prowess in every type of driving. The RAV4 was everyone's choice for second place, by varying margins.
Last place went, by acclamation, to the CR-V. The small Honda is the runaway leader in sales, but its design is the most dated. (The tested Honda was a 2000 model, though 2001's are virtually the same; a new version is due next year.) Also, the CR-V was the least-expensive test vehicle, about $5,000 less than the RAV4.
That left the Hyundai and Subaru to vie for third and fourth. The test drivers agreed that the Santa Fe was a surprisingly strong contender, marred mainly by a few cheap notes, including thin, low-rent carpeting.
The Forester seemed out of its element; despite its appearance and competence, its automobile genes were obvious, and it seemed the least convincing as an S.U.V.
What follows are the rankings of two participants.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Homeowners' Revenge: Selling Power to the Utility

BYLINE: By AMY ZIPKIN

 BODY:
WHILE some of his neighbors are concerned about rising energy prices, Thomas Hood sits comfortably in his 1820 home in Westhampton on Long Island, watching his utility meter move backward even as colder weather sets in.
Mr. Hood, 44, a software salesman and a self-described science enthusiast and environmentalist, figures that he has saved, on average, $200 a month on utility bills after installing an elaborate and pricey solar energy system. It not only powers his five-bedroom colonial-style home but sometimes generates an energy surplus that he sells to the Long Island Power Authority. 
 On the roof over the original part of the house is a solar system that heats the hot water, basement slab and swimming pool. On the roof of an addition to the home are the shingles containing photovoltaic cells that convert sunlight into electricity. Wires on the second roof under the shingles connect to an inverter that converts direct current to the alternating current used inside the home. "I'm a mini-utility," said Mr. Hood, whose home was the first to be connected to the power grid of the Long Island Power Authority. Thirty-three other residential customers are also connected.
As oil and natural-gas prices have risen, and as the deregulation of the utility industry brings uncertainty about future electric rates, an increasing number of homeowners are investigating alternative energy sources. A few, like Mr. Hood, have decided to generate and sell their own power -- a process known as net metering.
Theoretically, a home equipped with a photovoltaic system could eliminate electricity bills altogether. With the proper equipment installed, the power accumulated by photovoltaic cells during sunny summer days can even be stored until needed on less-radiant winter days. Excess energy fed back into the utility's power grid spins an electric meter backward.
The Solar Electric Power Association in Washington estimates that about 2,000 homes are now involved in net-metering programs nationwide, and it says shipments of photovoltaic cells have doubled in the last three years. Right now, 30 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have laws that require utilities to offer net metering to their customers.
Utilities and manufacturers report a slow but steady increase in interest in the programs. The Sacramento Municipal Utility District said it had 300 net-metering customers, and since April 1999, about 100 more customers have installed solar systems. AstroPower, a manufacturer of photovoltaic cells in Newark, Del., recently began test marketing residential solar systems in the Hudson Valley of New York. And Commonwealth Edison of Illinois says it has received hundreds of inquiries since last June, when it began offering a statewide program that pays customers for generating their own power.
"The vast majority of Americans don't know that the same solar cells that power their calculators can also power their homes," said Thomas J. Starrs, who runs Kelso, Starrs & Associates, a renewable-energy consultant on Vashon Island, Wash.
An exception is Stelle, Ill., a community north of Springfield in the central part of the state; one-third of its homes have solar systems. For now, though, only the home of Steven Bell, 48, a former fireman who now works as a solar technical consultant, is connected to the local utility, Commonwealth Edison.
Mr. Bell has solar panels on his roof and on a motorized track in his backyard that power a refrigerator, two freezers and a stereo, among other appliances, in his three-bedroom country-style home. He also has a battery-operated backup system to ensure against power failures and winter ice storms. Mr. Bell said he saves about $175 a year in energy costs, an amount that he acknowledges is small. But he added that money was not his primary motivation. "I'm carrying my energy burden on the planet," he said.
Small financial gains are common for solar-energy installers and net-metering participants, largely because the systems are still fairly expensive. Mr. Bell estimates that he spent $40,000 on his renewable-energy system over the last six years. Mr. Hood paid $20,000 for the photovoltaic roof and $4,000 for the solar hot water system, which were installed over the last two years. To offset his expenses, he received an $8,700 cash rebate from the Long Island Power Authority and a $3,750 tax credit from the state. Mr. Bell received a grant of $11,000 from his state's renewable-energy resources program.
The possible savings from solar systems are related to prevailing energy costs in a particular region. People who build homes in remote areas, for example, are likely to obtain substantial savings by installing their own solar-energy systems rather than paying utilities to extend power lines to their homes. The same may hold true for those living in parts of the Northeast, where energy costs are higher than in other areas. "If you're in a low-cost area of the country, the economics don't work as well as if you're in a high-cost area," said Dan W. Reicher, assistant secretary of energy.
NOT all utility companies and states are embracing net metering. Rolland Skinner, general manager of the Northwest Public Power District in Nebraska, which has no net-metering law, said renewable-energy programs amounted to a subsidy for certain customers and should include caps on payments from utilities. Otherwise, he said, a utility may have to charge its conventional customers more.
For all its environmental appeal, hooking up to the utility grid can be time-consuming. The Department of Energy found in a recent report that 25 percent of the 65 net-metering projects it surveyed had experienced delays of more than four months in hooking up with local utilities.
Jonathan Sawyer, 45, who runs a wireless communications company in Boulder, Colo., knows about such roadblocks. When he built his four-bedroom house in 1995, he investigated net metering and found his utility, the Public Service Company of Colorado, did not offer it. Instead, he said, the utility sent him a 50-page interconnection agreement about the procedures he needed to follow to become a power supplier. He gave up on the idea until two years ago, when the company initiated a net-metering program and referred him to Altair Energy in Golden, Colo. He paid the company to install $100,000 worth of photovoltaic equipment.
The program had its glitches. During the first month, the new analog meter was read incorrectly by utility workers and recorded that Mr. Sawyer owed $7,000, when he really owed less than $5. And, he said, he has yet to receive a $154 credit due for the extra 1,927 kilowatts his solar system produced over the last two years. Public Service of Colorado has acknowledged the problems and said it would soon send Mr. Sawyer a $154 check.
Despite those troubles, Mr. Sawyer said he had no regrets. "There's no good economic payback for doing it," he said. "But the country would be a lot better off if keeping up with the Joneses was who had the best solar system, instead of who had the larger car."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Teachers' Fund Happily Learns a New Math, Plus Tax

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
AT first glance, the genteel pension-fund giant with the monstrously ungainly name seems to have lost ground to upstart rivals.
For decades, when new faculty members arrived at colleges and universities, their only choice for a retirement plan was this venerable colossus, formally called the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund. But this fall, when Villanova University hired about 100 faculty and staff members, the group, known as TIAA-CREF or just as the Teachers, lagged behind the Vanguard Group in signing them up. 
 "At least 6 out of 10 used Vanguard as their only plan or split with TIAA-CREF," said James S. Kane Jr., the university's associate director of human resources. "Ten years ago, 8 out of 10 would probably go only to TIAA-CREF."
John H. Biggs, chief executive of the Teachers, a nonprofit company, acknowledged in an interview the loss of market share to profit-seeking competitors. "It's a big concern," Mr. Biggs said. "A lot of schools are now offering options."
But hold the pity. Despite the competition and the loss of its tax exemption, the huge and still somewhat paternalistic company thrives as perhaps never before, in part because it is now a full-fledged taxpayer. As such, it is emancipated from limitations that had prevented it from doing business with anyone but its traditional clientele -- faculty members and administrators at private colleges and universities.
Suddenly, in 1997, individual retirement accounts could be offered directly to faculty and staff members instead of through the institutions. And the public could be solicited for various new products: Mutual funds. Tuition savings plans. Life insurance. A trust company that offers estate planning and other advice.
In short, the Teachers, one of America's half-dozen biggest investors -- and undoubtedly the biggest that most Americans have never heard of -- has largely reinvented itself.
That reinvention was spurred in large part by the government's decision in 1997 to strip it of its tax-exempt status on annuities, its main business, which it had enjoyed since it was founded in 1918 to offer fixed annuities to educators. It was started with a $10 million donation by Andrew Carnegie, who on becoming a trustee at Cornell University was appalled at the lack of provisions for academic retirement.
The CREF element, founded in 1952 in the face of objections that it would be too risky to link retirement income to the stock market -- a contention repeated this campaign season in connection with Social Security -- is now considerably larger than its older sister. CREF has a constituency of 2.2 million college faculty and staff members.
Speaking of his failed lobbying campaign to preserve the tax exemption, Mr. Biggs said: "We fought it pretty hard. I was deeply disappointed when we lost the battle."
STILL, this low-key organization, which manages more than $300 billion from its Third Avenue headquarters in Midtown Manhattan, has revived itself while holding tightly to its nonprofit status, its obsession with low costs, its insistence on a shareholder-friendly attitude at companies in which it invests, and its focus on its academic clientele.
"The word 'customer' is beginning to creep into our language," acknowledged Mr. Biggs, 64, whose combined salary and bonus nearly doubled, to $3.7 million, between 1997 and 1999.
The CREF stock account, the world's biggest pool of equity managed as one entity, and other Teachers' money matches the combined assets of the next two big pension organizations, the California Public Employees Retirement System, known as Calpers, and the New York State Common Retirement Fund.
TIAA-CREF's total revenue jumped 21 percent in 1999, to $11.3 billion, a gain that reflects new inflows rather than a market-driven increase in assets.
And more new horizons beckon, including teachers in elementary and high schools, a group far more difficult to reach because of the entrenchment of state retirement plans. Already the Teachers has staked out a big lead in state plans for college savings.
Why did the Teachers lobby hard to keep a tax exemption that kept it shackled? The reason, its officials said, was simply to protect its annuity holders from tax liability, even at the cost of denying them the expanded product line many of them wanted. As it happened, said James A. Wolf, executive vice president for retirement services, "we were surprised" at how much taxes could be deferred and minimized.
But there was serious grumbling on campus about stodgy management and poor investment performance. "They took a lot of grief here," said Charles Paul, director of total compensation at Yale University.
Olivia S. Mitchell, a professor of insurance and risk management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and executive director of its Pension Research Council, said: "There was a fair amount of agitation in the university community to add more funds and to add more flexibility across funds. TIAA took awhile to adjust to that."
Now the complaints have largely subsided and market share has ticked up. Teachers now boasts of superior returns on its assets, overall about two-thirds in stocks and a third in fixed-income securities. All six of its mutual funds that are at least three years old -- the minimum to qualify for ratings from Morningstar Inc. -- have earned at least four stars out of five.
The performance of the public funds has been excellent, with the biggest, the Growth Equity fund, having an average annual return of 24.9 percent since inception. "They're consistently in the top quartile," said William Dougherty, president of Kanon Bloch Carre, a Boston investment adviser and manager. "It's a great service for the everyday investor to have these available. You're buying into one of the best institutional growth money managers in the country."
However, the 11 funds -- five were added last spring -- have attracted a relatively modest $3 billion, less than Mr. Dougherty had expected and a long way from realizing Mr. Biggs's prediction that the Teachers would be among the nation's top 10 fund companies by 2010.
The doubters include Burton J. Greenwald, a fund consultant in Philadelphia. "They have no marketing effort to speak of," he said, because of the emphasis on minimal costs.
Many potential customers, in fact, have gone to Vanguard, one of the biggest fund groups and one that is greatly admired by Mr. Biggs and his colleagues for its commitment to indexing and to low-cost operation. Mr. Biggs said that he and John C. Bogle, Vanguard's founder, are the two halves of a "mutual admiration society." Mr. Bogle is the fund industry's scourge because, among other things, he has called attention to what he considers unconscionably high fees.
"He says we have great variable annuities, and I say he's got great mutual funds," Mr. Biggs added. "He has said we're his only competition, and I would say that about him." Mr. Bogle confirmed this characterization.
Mr. Biggs also praises Martin L. Leibowitz, the Teachers' vice chairman and chief investment officer, whose recruitment he considers "the greatest coup of my business career." That career has included 19 years at the General American Insurance Company, a vice chancellorship at Washington University in St. Louis and a stint as chief executive of Centerre Trust, in St. Louis.
DESPITE what some critics have called stodginess, TIAA-CREF has proved highly innovative over the years. It created the variable annuity with the CREF stock account in 1952, the first inflation-linked bond for pension funds in 1997 and a real estate investment trust that directly owns and manages properties in 1995.
And, most important, TIAA-CREF was a pioneer of indexing, which it has combined with active management in a way that Mr. Leibowitz calls "certainly very rare if not unique" in the investment business.
To a degree almost unknown elsewhere, he said, the two approaches -- replicating benchmarks and selecting stocks with help from powerful computers seeking anomalies -- enjoy equal standing, a structure he said had produced "the big difference" in outperforming rivals.
Yet it seems unlikely that the Teachers will allow its increased exposure to outsiders to infect its culture; it wants to avoid the vulgar side of commerce -- separating people from their money rather than meeting their needs.
Mr. Biggs, who described himself as an "old-fashioned Democrat, liberal, populist, whatever," rules out any notion of the Teachers' becoming a publicly held company or buying another company.
"We would never do an acquisition," he said. "We're not going to do cross-marketing where you bring together a whole bunch of life insurance agents and a whole bunch of banks and expect the agents to sell credit cards and the bankers to sell life insurance policies. That's a concept that's as dumb as the old conglomerates in the 60's and 70's."

HEADLINE: November 5-11;
Putting Worries in Perspective

BYLINE: By Alex Berenson

 BODY:
Investors got a little worried about the presidential election and a lot worried about an apparent slowdown in information technology spending, sending stocks to one of their worst weeks since their April meltdown.
By the close of trading Friday, the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index stood at 3,028.99, off 12.2 percent for the week and 25.6 percent for the year. Unless the Nasdaq rallies soon, this year is likely to be its worst since 1974, when an oil shock put the American economy in recession and sent the Nasdaq, then just 3 years old, down 35 percent. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed Friday at 10,602.95, a drop of 2 percent for the week. For the year, the Dow is now down 7.7 percent, putting it on pace for its first annual drop in a decade and worst performance since 1981.
The messy dispute over Tuesday's presidential vote is only part of why investors are nervous. Wall Street remains mostly confident that Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush will solve their spat peacefully, analysts say. It is much less confident that technology companies will post strong profit growth next year.
For investors, that concern is very bad news, since technology companies like Cisco Systems and EMC depend on growth to justify their high price-earnings ratios and huge market valuations.
"The bottom line really is we've got a tech wreck in the stock market that isn't necessarily over," said Ed Yardeni, chief investment strategist of Deutsche Bank. Alex Berenson

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Waiting For the Other Shoe To Drop

BYLINE: By Gretchen Morgenson

 BODY:
AS the nation waits to hear exactly what the American people said when they "spoke" last Tuesday, investors' voices are coming in loud and clear. Stocks tumbled at the end of last week as the whiff of a constitutional crisis began wafting out of South Florida. The Nasdaq lost 12.2 percent of its value for the week, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 2 percent. The Nasdaq is down 25.6 percent this year.
An election in the balance is about the last thing stock market investors want. It is bad enough that the nation's economic growth is slowing considerably and that corporate earnings have been so disappointing. Dell Computer added its name to the pile of former glamour stocks whose managers have forecast lower growth in coming months. Its shares lost 19 percent last week after the news. 
 It wasn't supposed to be this way. Many equity investors had assumed that the market's rallies in the past couple of autumns would be prologue, and had expected a year-end jump.
But those hopes were too rosy by half. As Louise Yamada, head of technical research at Salomon Smith Barney, pointed out, the stock market has rallied in the months after a presidential election only about as often as it has declined. In the 28 election cycles since 1888, she said, the overall market rose 57 percent of the time and fell 43 percent of the time from Election Day until the end of the year.
And Ms. Yamada said she believed that a sustained rally was especially unlikely this year, even before the mess in Florida started to unfold. She has suspected for months that the 18-year bull market was beginning to unwind and that investors should prepare for several years of flat returns from the Dow.
"The market was already fragile," Ms. Yamada said. "I don't think what's happening to stocks is the result of the election, but it is certainly not helping."
The question on many people's minds is how the nation's financial markets will respond to an escalation of what is already an ugly political brawl. The vow of the Al Gore camp to fight the Florida results in court was very unnerving.
"I'm amazed the markets have handled it as well as they have," said Charles A. Gabriel, senior political strategist at Prudential Securities in Washington, on Friday. "Now we have to go through a weekend news cycle that will be very painful, with the threat of insurrection and illegitimacy claims."
Another wild card is how foreign investors will view the interparty bickering. The Securities Industry Association estimates that foreign investors' net buys of United States stocks could exceed $194 billion this year, up from $107.5 billion last year. That the overall market has fallen in spite of such buying shows how vulnerable stock prices are to falling foreign demand.
The final presidential vote count, including absentee ballots, will not be concluded until Friday. That leaves an awful lot of time for warfare between the Democratic and Republican camps to get even nastier. If it does, stocks will probably experience further gyrations.
Richard Sylla, professor of financial history at New York University's Stern School of Business, said he believes that neither candidate wants to do anything that will damage the country. And if the count goes to George W. Bush, he thinks that Mr. Gore will be gracious. "The longer Mr. Gore has his people out questioning the results of the election, the more damaging it is to his own political future," he said.
Mr. Gabriel thinks that investors may hold the key to what ultimately happens in election 2000. "If the market ever gets to the point where it feels it needs to have a tantrum to send a signal to the two parties to end this, that's when you will come to a conclusion," he said. "American politicians today are very, very cognizant that 48 percent of American households own stocks."
He added, "What an incredible election cycle this would end up being if investors have to cast the final vote."

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Downhill From Here?

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
So the election is still in doubt. As of Friday evening Mr. Bush led in Florida by a margin smaller than the enrollment in my Econ 102 class; I'm no constitutional scholar, but I think we should suspend judgment until those absentee ballots have come in and some of the votes have been triple-checked.
But however it comes out, how will economic policy fare? The answer, I'm afraid, is badly. 
 Broadly speaking, the next administration, whatever it is, will face two big economic tests. One -- the one that was the center of the campaign -- is whether it can stick to a fiscal policy, including a policy toward Social Security, that prepares this country for the demographic deluge. The other is whether it can deal adequately with the risk of economic instability, both here and, especially, abroad. Unfortunately, whoever wins we are likely to botch one or both tests.
In the last few years we actually started to have an almost responsible fiscal policy; but it was mainly an accident, the result both of an unexpected surge in revenues and of a deadlock that prevented either party from dissipating those revenues. If Mr. Gore ends up being declared president, that deadlock will continue, with an added dose of vituperation; so I guess you could say that that's a good thing.
Many commentators have been suggesting that if it's Mr. Bush, our fiscal policy will be almost equally tight -- that the moral ambiguity of Mr. Bush's victory, together with the narrowness of his party's hold on Congress, would deter him from implementing the budget-busting proposals he made during the campaign. I'm not so sure. Suppose that what we all fear turns out to be true -- that a Bush presidency is really a Trent Lott regency. Wouldn't the hard-line conservatives who run Congress try to rush through as much as possible -- tax cuts, a diversion of Social Security taxes into private accounts, whatever they can pass -- just in case they lost control of the legislature in 2002? Congress managed to run through about $900 billion of the surplus in the three months or so leading up to this election; think of what it might do in two years.
And then there's the other problem: economic instability.
It's amazing how quickly the terrifying financial crises of the 1990's have faded from memory. The globalization of financial markets created many new opportunities for things to go disastrously wrong, and they often did. In that unstable world the Clinton administration was willing to play firefighter, and -- in my opinion -- did a yeoman job of containing a series of blazes that could easily have engulfed much of the world. But would either candidate be willing and able to do the same?
Mr. Gore would have the will -- and, if he keeps on some of the key players from the Clinton administration, the skilled team -- to contain the fires next time. But one doubts whether he would have the room to maneuver. Congressional leaders violently opposed the Mexican rescue of 1995 -- the rescue that, again in my opinion, saved Mexican reform and made this year's remarkable democratic transition in that nation possible. Mr. Clinton was able to carry out that rescue only by exploiting a legal loophole that has since been closed. And until the next Congressional election anyway, a Gore administration would be even more hobbled.
Mr. Bush might have the room to act -- though he would have to fight his own party to do so -- but one wonders whether he would have the will. Mr. Bush's economic advisers are a mixed bag, but the inner circle seems to consist of men who have a purist opposition to government intervention in markets. My guess is that this would eventually change -- there are no atheists in foxholes, and no purist free-marketeers in banking crises -- but a lot could go wrong in the meantime.
As luck would have it, our election took place during a sunny interval when neither of our big economic problems seemed pressing. A booming economy and a soaring stock market had filled federal coffers; Asia had, sort of, recovered from its 1997-98 financial crisis. But the clouds are already gathering. I expect to see those projected surpluses dwindle rapidly over the next year or so. And by a number of indicators the global financial picture is deteriorating again.
So fix this year in your memory; you may not see one as good for quite a while.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
With Capital In Gridlock, It's Back To the Lab

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
AS the lawyers fulminate and election returns remain in limbo, the one sure winner is President-elect Pyrrhus. In case you forgot, this King of Epirus beat the Romans in 279 B.C., but at a huge cost.
Whoever staggers away with a Pyrrhic victory in the current contest is likely to be wounded and weak. Since the presidential race was effectively fought to a draw and the Republican majorities in both houses of Congress have shrunk, incremental change is probably the most that a Bush or a Gore administration can shoot for in the next two years. That suits industries like the big drug companies, which fear tougher regulation or health care plans that would limit costs. 
 Jami Rubin, a pharmaceutical industry analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, took time last week to talk about the election and the outlook for Big Pharma. Following are excerpts from the conversation.
 
Q. Of the two candidates, Vice President Al Gore used some of his harshest rhetoric on the drug companies. As a candidate in 1992, President Clinton did the same thing. How much bite do you think there is to the vice president's bark?
 
A. It's true that the rhetoric in 1992 led to nothing. But the thing the drug companies feared from Gore was price controls. He never explicitly mentioned them, but there was the threat that by giving a drug benefit to the entire population, that would inevitably lead to price controls. That is why the industry couldn't embrace what Gore was talking about.
 
Q. Gov. George W. Bush wants to make some changes in Medicare as well. But his proposals aren't as far-reaching, right?
 
A. His Medicare reform proposal was very similar to the Breaux-Thomas proposal, which is a model the industry supports, because it will lead to increased volumes of prescription drugs. Initially, as a stopgap, he also proposed state-funded coverage for the low-income elderly. The industry wasn't terribly supportive.
 
Q. We still don't know who the next president will be. But can you make some predictions about what Washington will do about medical coverage?
 
A. There will be a Medicare drug benefit, but it will have to have features of bipartisanship. It is too big an issue to go away. But it will be a watered-down version. And, potentially, nothing will get done.
 
Q. So, absent major intervention by the government, isn't developing new drugs the major challenge facing these companies?
 
A. There is never enough product. And over the next five years, a lot of highly prescribed drugs go off patent, like Prozac, the anti-depression drug, and Mevacor, which treats cholesterol. Many of these drugs will be available in much cheaper form very soon.
Drug pipelines usually come in waves. There was a huge wave between 1995 and 1998, then a slowdown. There will be a little bit more visibility over the next two years.
 
Q. So which companies have good drug pipelines now?
 
A. Pfizer has a good pipeline, and Schering-Plough has a terrific pipeline. Merck, which is experiencing a number of patent expirations and faces more competition from generic drugs than anyone else, is managing the risk better than anyone thought. In fact, we could go through a period where a number of these companies that are facing patent expirations will perform better than expected.
 
Q. In addition to their own research and development, drug companies have been adding new products by buying or merging with other companies. But we haven't seen these giants buying up biotechnology concerns. Why?
 
A. The biotech companies are all very expensive. A number of big pharmaceutical companies have struck deals with them, and many are benefiting from their technology. American Home Products, for example, has struck a deal with Immunex to co-promote Enbrel, a rheumatoid arthritis drug. As long as biotech valuations remain very high, these companies will not try and make acquisitions. But they will do deals.
Similarly, although we have seen a lot of consolidation among drug companies, and are likely to see more deals over time, in the near term these companies are looking to co-promote drugs, to do joint ventures. Merck and Schering-Plough struck a very interesting deal to co-promote two products.
 
Q. As a group, the stocks have done better of late. Some of that improved performance is probably due to an easing of concern about what Washington might do. But hasn't the slowing economy heightened interest in the group as well?
 
A. The economy is slowing, and drug stocks have been great defensive stocks this year. Investors are willing to pay a higher premium for good growth stocks. And the group is trading at a multiple of 30 times earnings. That is at the higher end of its historical range; it has been higher.

HEADLINE: City Culture in Danger

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Mission District Fights Case of Dot-Com Fever" (news article, Nov. 5):
Many of the people I've talked to in San Francisco bemoan the exodus of musicians and artists now leaving in droves because of the high cost of living. In the end, San Francisco will be little more than a tourist mecca. 
 Sadly, the same thing is happening here. Gentrification and exploding real estate values are undermining the cultural scene. Artists, small businesses, tenants and arts organizations are threatened and being forced to move out of Manhattan, and even out of the bustling neighborhoods of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and Long Island City, Queens.
It's time for public policies and initiatives to govern and plan sustainable housing and economic development. The costs of unfettered real estate expansion to our cultural and social life are too great without them.
 
MARSHALL REESE
Brooklyn, Nov. 6, 2000

HEADLINE: Pay Ball! Baseball's New Season

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
YOU probably believe that Hank Aaron hit more home runs than any other player in major-league baseball history. You might also be under the impression that Aaron holds the record for runs batted in and that Detroit's Ty Cobb scored more runs than any other player.
Wrong, wrong, wrong. 
 A young man from Miami named Alex Rodriguez holds those records. He has hit 778 home runs, batted in 2,432 runs and scored 2,573 runs.
Well, O.K., Rodriguez hasn't done all that yet, but judging from a 70-page briefing book that his agent recently gave to baseball executives, it is simply a matter of time. The agent, Scott Boras, compiled the book as his opening gambit in the bidding war that officially began yesterday for Rodriguez's services.
In seeking the first-ever $20 million annual contract for Rodriguez -- a shortstop for the Seattle Mariners last season -- Boras projected that over the next 15 years his client would surpass Aaron and Cobb and nearly equal the record of 4,256 hits held by Pete Rose.
"Alex Rodriguez is the best shortstop in Major League Baseball history at age 24," the book begins. Never mind that some people wonder whether Rodriguez is even the best shortstop in his own league today, given the presence of Nomar Garciaparra of the Red Sox and Derek Jeter of the Yankees, said Seymour Siwoff, the president of the Elias Sports Bureau.
Boras' boasting was only the latest example of baseball rhetoric having run amok in the last few years. One could hardly watch a game on television this season without hearing an announcer say that one player or another was one of the all-time great sluggers. Commentators called Mark McGwire the best power hitter in history. Or they favorably compared the statistics of players whom most people have never heard of -- like Troy Glaus of the Anaheim Angels or Todd Helton of the Colorado Rockies -- to members of the Hall of Fame.
The chief culprit is an offensive explosion that has changed baseball over the last decade. Today, ballparks are smaller than before, hitters are stronger, the strike zone is smaller and some say that balls are wound more tightly. Certainly, they are flying a lot further. Since 1992, the number of home runs per game has increased about 50 percent, and the number of runs is up two per game, or 25 percent. All this constitutes the sports equivalent of runaway inflation, and it has made one of baseball fans' favorite activities -- comparing players across eras increasingly difficult.
Hitting 30 home runs in a season, as Rodriguez has for four of the past five years, was once a sign that a player could be headed for the Hall of Fame. But in 2000 alone, 47 hitters reached that mark. Surely all of them are not Hall of Famers.
Carl N. Morris, chairman of the statistics department at Harvard and a baseball fan, suggests an analogy. "What if you hit .280 in the majors, and I batted .330 in the minors?" he asked. "I could say I'm a better hitter." That argument, Professor Morris said, is an extreme version of the comparisons being made today.
To avoid the problem, a government meteorologist in Washington named Clay Davenport has devised baseball's answer to the consumer price index. Among amateur baseball statisticians, a numerous and dedicated bunch, the formula has become known as the Davenport Translation. It puts players' performances in the context of league averages during their career, allowing for meaningful comparisons across eras.
The translations -- on the Internet at www.BaseballProspectus.com -- show that Rodriguez is indeed a terrific ballplayer but that an average season of his still falls well short of one by Aaron, Cobb, Mickey Mantle, Mike Schmidt, Honus Wagner (another shortstop) and a number of other retired stars.
That raises the question: What would those old players be earning today?
In the first decades of the 20th century, the best players made the equivalent of between $100,000 and $200,000. Then came Babe Ruth, who attracted fans to a stadium like no one before him. By the time the Depression arrived, Ruth was making $800,000 in today's dollars, allegedly prompting him to say he deserved to make more than the president of the United States because he had had a better year.
Lacking a union or any negotiating power, players would not again reach that level of pay until the 1970's, when salaries soared, said Doug Pappas, who keeps a salary database for the Society for American Baseball Research. Largely because of free agency, average salaries then tripled between 1984 and 1992 and have doubled again since 1992.
Still, even if the old legends could take advantage of recent developments, they probably would not be earning more than today's stars, analysts say. The economics of the game dictate the pay scale. So even if Aaron was posting numbers that were about 10 percent better than Rodriguez's, as the historical translations suggest he would, Aaron might simply displace Rodriguez as the game's highest paid player.
Perhaps the one exception is Ruth. His accomplishments were so remarkable -- hitting 60 home runs in a season, for example, when few other players hit more than 10 -- that he might reset the scale today. At a time when both home runs and hyperbole are mammoth, just imagine what his agent would be saying.

LENGTH: 1095 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Vietnam's Youth Stage A Gentler Revolution

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
CAREFREE, war-free, with multicolored sparkles in their hair, Vietnam's young people are leading a revolution in Vietnam today, and it's not a Communist one.
It is a revolution of creeping globalization, and as in Communist lore, there is a small but very influential group of the young in the vanguard. When President Clinton goes to Vietnam this week -- the first American president to visit since the end of the war 25 years ago -- he will have a chance to encounter a new postwar generation that is open, curious, acquisitive and hungry to join the outside world, if the youth one meets in the cities and at the universities are any indication. 
 "We like freedom," said Ta Thi Minh Hong, 19, a first-year student at the Institute of International Relations, expressing what seems to be a newly discovered idea. "We want to do everything we like."
At least, it's fun to talk like that. The idea of freedom is itself an experiment and it is still being defined here, by people of all ages.
In a dozen interviews here and in the capital, Hanoi, young people made it clear that they agree with their elders that traditional Vietnamese values are paramount, that willy-nilly change is dangerous.
The freedom that attracts them seems a purely personal one, focusing on behavior and consumer goods. Like youth culture in other countries, it seems notably apolitical. And indeed, the cautious youth revolution of Vietnam may fit very well into the new, open marketplace that is being permitted, step by step, by the Communist government.
"I'm really impressed by the way young people live in America," said Nguyen Cong Huy, 19, a high school student who dreams of studying engineering in America. "For example -- I don't want to talk politics -- but the way young people live, they're free to live on their own, to have the relationships that they choose, sexual freedom. But actually, there should be limits. When you have too much freedom it can lead to problems."
With that kind of worldview emerging, where better to seek cultural wisdom than at a market research company? And indeed, the Vietnam office of the ACNielsen company has an insight to offer.
"This is the first generation in Vietnam to experience a true youth culture, with shared values, identity, symbols and language," said Gordon Milne, an ACNielsen executive who has collated interviews with hundreds of young people. "In the past," he said, "you as a teenager were basically a young old person. Same beliefs. Same values. Now we are seeing a set of young people whose expectations, lifestyle and behavior are more and more different from their parents."
Advertisers beware, he said. The young are becoming savvy consumers. It is no longer enough simply to offer a foreign product. They want quality. They want brand names. They want whatever it is that young people want in other countries.
But they are still learning. Compared with other Asian nations, Mr. Milne said, "we are talking about 20 to 25 years difference in terms of youth culture."
And they are still hesitant. The youth revolution in Vietnam remains a modest and polite one.
One young rebel is notable in his crowd for wearing a nose ring. But it's a clip-on ring and he takes it off when he goes home. After all, he wouldn't want to offend his parents.
Clearly, it is still easier to be a parent in Vietnam than in many a country. But perhaps it takes a bit more work these days than it used to. "My friends quarrel with their parents because they're different from their parents in every way," said Miss Hong, the student. "But parents understand so much about life. Their advice is useful for me to be a good person. If I think my parents are not right, or they don't understand me, I talk out my ideas and we discuss it."
Even that represents a leap forward. In the past, when it came to morals and manners, parents ruled. Now there is MTV (though a tame version, vetted by the government), the Internet (though still expensive and limited), pirated foreign movies and, for the privileged, satellite television, travel and a foreign education.
Not long ago, everything Korean was cool -- fashion, makeup, music. But this is a youth culture; nothing lasts long.
"It doesn't matter, we can change quickly," said Nguyen My Nhung, 22, an auditor for a foreign company, raising her voice over the music at Hanoi's loudest discotheque, the New Century. "We have Internet access, satellite TV, fashion shows. We can try anything."
Like others with the money to go to a disco (many of them the children of the Communist elite) she was defensive about her privilege, asserting her solidarity with the great majority of Vietnamese who are poor.
MR. MILNE at ACNielsen acknowledged that his analyses are based on a tiny slice of society. "None of this extends to the guys working in the fields," he said. "Their lives have not changed significantly, unfortunately." But that does not mean that the ideas now percolating in the cities won't spread to the countryside. Indeed, a basic fact of life today is that most Vietnamese, whether rural or urban, were born after the war, and are the first for many generations to be raised in a time of peace (although it is also a time of poverty).
And yet Vietnam's history of war and the creation of an independent nation after its long colonization by the French are part of the fabric of life here. Even the bold talk of teenagers is cast in terms of the war.
"In the past they thought independence was the most important thing to focus on," Miss Hong said. "Now people in my generation don't care so much about it. We focus on music, fashion, making friends and going on picnics. My parents and their friends grew up in war, so they couldn't pay more attention to music or other habits, although they liked them. Now we're at peace, and if we want to we can learn about all fields in life."
Perhaps more than their counterparts abroad -- given the sacrifices they are constantly being told their parents made -- a number of those interviewed were sensitive about accusations that they are a Vietnamese version of a Me Generation.
"That's not true," said Nguyen Thanh Ha, 22, a graduate of National Economics University in Hanoi. "It's just the surface. You must look deeper inside."
"We are hard-working," she continued. "We want to improve our own lives first before asking others to do that for us." And she added: "You don't need a strike or a demonstration. Why should we spend our time demonstrating for democracy when we have so much more to worry about?"
