SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3184 words

HEADLINE: Can Black Gold Ever Flow Green?

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE

DATELINE: ARCTIC VILLAGE, Alaska

 BODY:
AS ridged as crocodile skin, the marshy coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge stretches 110 miles from the Canning River in the west to Alaska's border with Canada in the east. Over a few weeks in the early Arctic autumn, the mottled green length of the plain deepens to the color of coffee grounds and rust, a dark vein between the slate Beaufort Sea and the frayed northern edge of the Brooks mountain range.
The fate of this hushed span of tundra, like many other matters, may hang on the outcome of the presidential election. If Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is the new president, this plain and the oil deposits it covers may become an unlikely proving ground for the kind of company BP Amoco is and what it aspires to be: an oil company that is also a protector of the environment. 
From its base in London, BP Amoco, the world's third-largest oil company and arguably the most powerful player in Alaskan oil, has broken ranks with most of the petroleum industry and worked to build a reputation as an environmental pioneer, while continuing to promote oil development. Over the last three years, it has acknowledged the danger of global warming and embraced alternative fuels. To foster this image, BP Amoco unveiled a sunburst logo and a new motto: Beyond Petroleum.
So far, BP, which pumps slightly more than 300,000 barrels of oil a day from Alaska, has sidestepped the question of drilling on the coastal plain of the refuge, an emotional environmental issue that gained national attention during the presidential race.
Drilling proponents, including Mr. Bush, the Alaskan congressional delegation and most of the Republican Party, say the country's energy independence hinges on tapping the billions of barrels of oil that geologists suspect are below the plain's permafrost, perhaps enough to pump a million barrels a day for 20 years. For opponents of the drilling, including Vice President Al Gore, the issue is a zero-sum game: if the area is opened to development, a rare wilderness where many birds and animals bear their young would be lost.
Mr. Bush has said unequivocally that he would open the coastal plain to oil exploration and production, though he would need Congressional support to proceed. Sir John Browne, the BP chief executive, said last week that if the area was unlocked under a Republican administration, BP would be interested in new exploration opportunities there. If it bids on leases to develop fields, which is highly probable given the demands on the company to bolster production and its stock price, BP would have a chance to show what Beyond Petroleum really means.
A green oil company may seem an oxymoron, but some regulators, scientists, environmentalists and investors say they cautiously believe that the company might be trying to transform itself and an industry that has become synonymous with pollution. For the last few years, environmentalists and indigenous groups have met with BP executives and board members to try to persuade them to promise not to drill in the refuge, just as the company pledged a decade ago to stay out of Antarctica. Those who have placed some faith in BP see the Arctic Refuge, home to scarce, unique wildlife, as the crucial test of the company's environmental resolve.
The BP record so far is mixed. The company's other activities in Alaska over the last few years suggest that there is a vast geographical and philosophical gulf within the company. On one side are executives in London who preach environmentalism; on the other are engineers in Anchorage who face the pressure of oil-driven local politics and their own bottom line.
BP executives repeat a company-wide mantra of "no damage" to the environment, and its units have to meet certain environmental goals. "We have learned a lot in 30 years," said F. X. O'Keefe, the head of BP's Alaska Exploration unit. "Our record shows we can go into different areas with little to no impact."
But the company's stock price ultimately depends on how much oil it draws out of the ground and at what cost. To ensure a steady flow of oil as supplies from Alaska's North Slope decline, BP has proceeded with projects and campaigns that pose significant risks to Alaska's ecology, said many state and federal regulators, wildlife biologists, environmentalists and representatives of native peoples.
"They're trying to present a new BP, but it's business as usual," said Francis A. Grant-Suttie, who, as director of private-sector initiatives at the World Wildlife Fund, meets regularly with BP executives. "On the P.R. level, they have been successful at differentiating themselves from others, but by virtue of what they're doing on the coastal plain, you can see it's sheer rhetoric."
THIS year, the company agreed to a compliance order with the state of Alaska that prohibits it from drilling several months of the year at Northstar, the first offshore well in the North American Arctic. The state contends that BP would not be able to clean up an oil spill in the open waters off Northstar. BP was also placed under criminal probation for five years and paid $7 million in civil and criminal penalties to the federal government after fumbling a case of dumping by a contractor at another Alaska site, Endicott.
Although BP has said it is not an active party in the heated discussion about development in the refuge, it has donated tens of thousands of dollars to Arctic Power, a group lobbying to open the refuge to drilling, as well as to politicians who support such efforts, including Mr. Bush and the Republican Party.
"Being 'beyond petroleum' isn't an impossibility, but what on the ground says they are?" asked Theodore L. Rockwell Jr., who coordinates the Environmental Protection Agency's oil and gas program in Alaska.
BP built its reputation on exploration and production, first in Iran more than 90 years ago and, over the last generation, in the North Sea and Alaska. Earlier this year, when BP bought the Atlantic Richfield Company, its main rival on the North Slope, it had to sell ARCO's Alaskan fields to Phillips Petroleum in order to receive federal approval for the deal. Phillips produces somewhat more oil, but BP, on a contract basis with other oil concerns, operates most North Slope fields, making it the dominant force in Alaskan oil.
The company's makeover from a staid British energy empire to a brash maverick that embraced environmentalism is the handiwork of Sir John, the chief executive. A career company man who earned his M.B.A. in the United States and worked in Alaska in the late 1960's, Sir John, 52, has given the 154 business units within BP greater independence while demanding impressive results. He also familiarized himself with research on global warming and said three years ago that the company should take a stand on the issue, said David Rice, chief of staff for government and public affairs at BP.
Bucking industry wisdom, BP agreed with the idea that carbon dioxide emissions contribute to global warming and pledged to cut its own emissions by 10 percent by 2010. The company is among the world's largest makers of solar panels and uses solar power at many of its own facilities. It is gradually shifting the emphasis of its exploration and production from crude oil to cleaner-burning natural gas.
In a letter to employees in July, Sir John wrote that BP's values "may be manifested in different ways, but they have much in common: a respect for the individual and the diversity of mankind, a responsibility to protect the natural environment."
Shareholders take Sir John's message seriously. At the annual meeting on April, 13 percent of shareholders voted for a resolution demanding that BP terminate Northstar and stay out of the refuge, a proportion so high that it stunned company management and even those who introduced the measure.
"Maybe it is painful for BP to have this degree of scrutiny, but being held accountable will help BP improve its environmental performance over the long run," said Simon Billenness, senior analyst at Trillium Asset Management of Boston, one of the sponsors of the resolution.
The notion of drilling in the coastal plain of the refuge provokes intense debate because of what the opposing sides see at stake. Every summer, thousands of birds from as near as Washington State and as far as Antarctica alight upon the narrow strip of tundra to bear their young. About 150,000 caribou, known as the Porcupine herd, migrate almost 500 miles annually from Canada to calve on the treeless expanse.
"There are a lot of people who will never go to the refuge, but I get some peace of mind knowing that there is an area of naturalness on such a scale," said Fran Mauer, a wildlife biologist with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and an expert on the refuge. "Where else can you have such herds of caribou, so many bears, oxen roaming?"
DRILLING proponents say there are about 16 billion barrels in the refuge. But no one knows how much oil is in the coastal plain because very little exploration has been done there. One exploratory well backed by BP and Chevron was drilled years ago on land owned by indigenous peoples within the refuge. BP said the results were a proprietary secret.
Based on seismic data and information gleaned from oil wells near the refuge, the United States Geological Survey has estimated that technologically recoverable oil in the area is about 7.7 billion barrels. If the area pumped one million barrels a day, it could supply oil to the United States for two decades. In comparison, the great Prudhoe Bay field in the North Slope of Alaska, where BP staked its fortune 30 years ago, had about 9.2 billion barrels.
Whatever numbers the experts settle on, Greg Gilbert worries that they will draw oil companies into the coastal plain. A member of the 7,500-member Gwich'in Indian nation that lives scattered through the boreal forests of northwest Canada and north central Alaska, Mr. Gilbert hunts caribou to feed his family of seven. Until about 50 years ago, the Gwich'in followed the Porcupine herd in its trek. Now, they live in settlements of one-story clapboard houses heated by wood stoves and often without running water.
Arctic Village, a settlement outside the southern rim of the refuge, is home to Mr. Gilbert and about 250 other Gwich'in, most of them unemployed, who survive by hunting caribou. Every few hours during one fall day, young men rode down from a nearby ridge in their all-terrain vehicles and unloaded shanks and sides of caribou and moose into their cabins.
Bundled in a fur hat against the biting wind one afternoon, Mr. Gilbert climbed a rickety 10-foot platform on the edge of a forest of stunted birch and pine and took out binoculars to survey for caribou.
"Caribou are sensitive," Mr. Gilbert said. "The oil companies want to drill in the refuge, but the elders say the caribou will disappear. They will change their route."
He climbed down from the observation platform, and his face was tight with concern. "I think drilling will eventually happen," he said. "The oil companies have the power to do it. But I worry about the future, my kids, their kids."
Opponents of drilling say the refuge could be better protected from development if President Clinton declared the area a national monument. Congress could overturn such a designation, but there is no precedent for doing so.
BP contends that oil development would not harm caribou, pointing to the thriving herd in the North Slope. A range of independent wildlife biologists dispute BP's argument. Moreover, the coastal plain in the refuge is far smaller than the North Slope but has 10 times the caribou population, which would make it very hard for the animals to avoid oil infrastructure.
BP says it can develop oil fields on the coastal plain with what it calls "minimal" environmental impact. The acreage that its newest wells occupy, their "footprint," is much smaller than that of older wells, and pipelines are built higher to let caribou pass underneath. Often, there are no roads nearby, and workers are airlifted in.
Stray caribou roam near the Prudhoe Bay roads that rumble with trucks and pick-ups. Others graze sometimes under pipelines. One bright morning, near the Phillips Alpine field, a flock of geese lifted like a hand from the flat table of the tundra. "The drive is to do no damage to the environment," said Mr. O'Keefe of BP's Alaska Exploration unit, echoing the "no damage" theme heard so often in BP offices from London to Anchorage. "There's no conflict here. The idea runs through all levels of the company."
From the spare halls of BP's Alaska headquarters in Anchorage to the bustling company cafeteria in Deadhorse in the North Slope, green-and-yellow posters spread the new environmental gospel: "Go, Do, Think Beyond." "BP. Bold. Progressive."
BUT doubts about the company's environmental mission run deep. In London, wags say the company is Beyond Belief. In Alaska, it is said that workers on the North Slope, many of whom have weathered the harsh tundra and the industry's bad image for more than 20 years, grumble that BP looks weak for going green.
BP has made sure that its interests are protected. This year, it contributed $50,000 to Arctic Power, the pro-development lobbying group. A BP executive also serves on the board of the group. BP donates to politicians who vote regularly to open the refuge. Moreover, its donations to the Republican Party this year were $613,870 out of its total of $901,796 to political action committees and party organizations, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. The company contributed $34,421 to Mr. Bush this year, compared with $4,250 to Mr. Gore.
BP's interest in the refuge reflects its need to keep Alaska output high. At its peak in 1988, the North Slope produced an average of 2.03 million barrels of oil a day. In 1999, daily output fell to about 1.08 million barrels, according to the state Department of Natural Resources.
As the Arctic Refuge issues are worked out, BP is looking for rich new reservoirs in the National Petroleum Reserve to the west of its Prudhoe Bay fields, and offshoots of its older developments. So it embarked on Northstar, a 176-million-barrel field that, in the diminishing reservoir of the North Slope, is considered a large find.
The rig sits on a square, artificial five-acre island in the ocean beyond barrier islands. Endangered bowhead whales migrate near Northstar, and within the barrier islands two types of threatened sea ducks gather by the thousands every summer before migrating south for the winter.
When the field is operating fully, 65,000 barrels of crude oil will pass to shore daily through a pipeline buried below the seabed, an engineering first. BP will start drilling this winter, and it is seeking regulatory approval for another offshore well, Liberty, farther to the east of Northstar and closer to the refuge.
To be able to drill year-round at Northstar, BP must prove to Alaskan officials that it can clean up a spill in the ice-strewn water, should work at Northstar ever go awry. Since last fall, BP has held three clean-up drills, and each time it has failed. In every attempt, the broken ice in the water wrecked or disabled the equipment designed to collect oil. During a test last month, popcorn thrown on the water as a mock spill floated past the clean-up barges, silent testimony to BP's difficulties.
As a result of the tests, Alaska has placed BP under a compliance order that prohibits the company from drilling at Northstar when the frozen ocean around it has thawed and broken, or from about May to November.
The company, Alaska officials said, claimed in its plan that it could capture oil when up to 70 percent of the sea is covered with ice. But the state resources department contended that BP had difficulty even where there were trace amounts of ice in the water, based on what its monitors had witnessed.
"When you can't clean up oil in the Arctic, should you be going in at all?" asked one federal official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Northstar's pipeline is the first to run under the seabed of the Arctic Ocean. In winter, a process called ice scouring occurs in the Arctic, as ice breaks up, smashes together and plows into the sea floor. BP has installed a thick, single-wall pipeline that the company says is buried deep enough to avoid a puncture. The Joint Pipeline Office, a state and federal committee, tested and approved the pipe.
But other federal officials, environmentalists and an independent expert on pipelines contended that a double-walled pipe would be significantly safer. The draft version of the environmental impact statement gave the BP pipeline about a one-in-four chance of failure. The final version put the odds at 2 to 5 percent.
Ibrahim Konuk, head of the Canadian research team and a consultant for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service on the environmental impact statement for Liberty, cited concerns based on a lengthy computer modeling project conducted by Canada's Geological Survey on ice scouring and pipelines. "There's a very good chance that single pipe will fail," he said.
BP and the Joint Pipeline Office say a double-walled pipe would be more complicated, and therefore harder to monitor and repair. The company said it would stick with a single-walled pipe at Liberty.
BP has excelled in one environmental area: as part of a plea agreement to settle a federal criminal case filed against the company late last year, BP has instituted a nationwide environmental monitoring program at its exploration, drilling and production units to improve oversight and reduce the chance of accidents and spills.
In 1995, a whistleblower from BP's North Slope Endicott field reported that the contractor for which he was working, Doyon Drilling, had been illegally disposing of hazardous wastes from about 1993 to 1995. Last year, the Justice Department filed the criminal suit and a civil suit against BP. The company, which pleaded guilty to one violation of federal environmental laws, was fined $500,000 in the criminal proceeding and paid $6.5 million to settle the civil suit.
FEDERAL attorneys in the criminal case against BP contended that the company knew of Doyon's activities but looked the other way -- an accusation that BP denied. In the settlement of the criminal case, BP was placed on probation for five years. The company also volunteered over that period to put into place a stringent nationwide environmental management program at a cost of about $15 million.
While praising the extra step taken by BP, a federal prosecutor recognized the challenge that the company faces. "I think folks at their highest levels are committed to environmental issues," said Deborah Smith, deputy chief of the environmental crimes section at the Justice Department. "But does that reach down to their oil rig operator and change the thinking of an oil rig worker who is from an industry that hasn't always been concerned about the environment?"

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
During the Confusion, a Turn Toward Treasuries

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
IN the midst of all the uncertainty about the identity of the next president, the Treasury market is the place to be.
Some investors are moving -- but not yet running -- to this traditional bond haven. Bonds barely moved on Wednesday, the first uncertain day after the election. But prices rose and yields fell on Thursday and Friday. If court challenges from the Democrats delay the outcome much longer, the uncertainty will weigh more heavily on investors, making Treasury securities more attractive as a risk-reducing investment. 
 A stock market selloff because of the uncertainty, or continuing worries about earnings, would also help bonds. That happened briefly on Thursday, when stocks sold off in response to the announcement from William M. Daley, chairman of Vice President Al Gore's campaign committee, that Mr. Gore would not concede based on the initial results of the Florida recount. As the Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 150 points, bond prices rose quickly.
William Stevens, senior portfolio manager at Montgomery Asset Management, said that for the near term, the bond market would be driven more by stocks than by the final choice of who is the president-elect.
The slowdown in economic growth, meanwhile, will continue to put downward pressure on Treasury yields, pushing their prices higher. (In this situation, corporate bonds are not a haven.) If the presidential uncertainty stretches on for several weeks, it might slow the economy a bit more, especially if the stock market falls sharply and consumers curb their spending. Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, is already predicting that the economy will slow to a 2.25 percent growth rate in the first half of next year, less than half its recent pace.
The presidential uncertainty was a background irritant, not the prime cause of the sharp selloff in the stock market last week. But it added downward pressure.
For the week, the Nasdaq was down 12.2 percent, its third-worst week ever. It is now at its lowest point in a year. But most of that decline was because of bad news for growth in sales and earnings in the technology sector. A report on Wednesday warned of slowing demand for optical networking equipment, whose producers are among the most highly valued in the Nasdaq index. On Friday, a warning from Dell Computer of slowing sales growth set back the technology sector again. The Dow was off a more moderate 2 percent for the week.
The minimal political impact reflects, in part, the fact that the two parties, despite their differences on specific tax and spending proposals, are pretty close on overall economic policy, especially on the role of the Federal Reserve in its fight against inflation.
"Our guess is that it is not going to make a huge amount of difference," said Greg Jensen, senior research associate at Bridgewater Associates in Westport, Conn. "The policies are not going to be that different."
Since World War II, the best stock market results have come under a Republican White House and Congress, with the average annual total return for the Standard & Poor's 500 index at 22 percent, according to Bridgewater. The next-best returns -- 19 percent a year -- have come when a Democrat is president and the Republicans control Congress.
But economic growth is a different story. During the two years when Republicans held both the White House and Congress, 1953 and 1954, economic growth was an annualized 2.19 percent. The eight years of a Democratic White House and a Republican Congress, six of them under President Clinton, saw 4.08 percent growth, on average.
The sample size -- the years these combinations were in control -- is small, which leads Mr. Jensen to dismiss these results as inconclusive. Still, they say that the recent balancing of the federal budget, despite a split government, has been particularly good for the markets and the economy.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1895 words

HEADLINE: In This Gilded Age, Gilded Model T's

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
AUTOMAKERS have long portrayed themselves as building cars for everyday American families. Henry Ford took pride in the spartan features of the Model T, available only in black. Alfred Sloan offered a "ladder" of models, from simple Chevrolets to elegant Cadillacs, with the slogan, "a car for every purse and purpose."
Times change. Increasingly, auto companies are setting their sights on another target. The open secret in Detroit these days is that middle-income Americans are buying a slowly but steadily shrinking share of new automobiles. The people buying the bulk of the new cars and sport utility vehicles are the nation's affluent. 
 The most prosperous 20 percent of the population accounted for 45 percent of the spending on new automobiles in 1990. Now, they account for 60 percent of the spending, according to General Motors, and a rising share, currently 40 percent, of the number of new vehicles as well. "It's probably the biggest trend ever affecting the auto industry -- we continue to shift toward higher-income, better-educated customers," said Paul Ballew, G.M.'s director of market research.
Automakers still sell roughly five million vehicles a year -- or nearly a third of all vehicles -- to households earning less than $50,000 annually, the cutoff point for the bottom three-fifths of the population in terms of income. But auto executives and economists say that figure does not tell the whole story.
These buyers are often not middle-class families, the experts say. Instead, as many as two-thirds of these buyers are young people whose more prosperous parents and grandparents help them with the purchase, or retirees who have considerable assets even though they do not have large incomes, said W. Van Bussmann, the corporate economist for the Chrysler group of DaimlerChrysler.
The change matters -- a lot. It is transforming what automakers sell. More and more vehicles in showrooms these days -- with the exception of a few tiny imports from Korea -- come loaded with expensive equipment like power-adjustable leather seats, compact-disc changers and even computer navigation systems. And because high-income families care little about gasoline prices, vehicles are also getting bigger. Subject to less-stringent federal fuel-economy standards than cars, sport utilities in particular are growing so big that they no longer fit in many garages.
WITH young, middle-income families buying fewer new cars and light trucks with their own money, the market has withered for small sedans. One, the Ford Escort, the most popular car sold in the early 1980's, has faded away without much notice; Ford replaced it last year with the taller, fancier Focus.
"If you're going to sell more vehicles, and the first-time buyers are disappearing, you've got to sell more larger, more expensive vehicles," Mr. Bussmann said.
Those larger vehicles burn plenty of gasoline. High oil prices used to devastate Detroit, yet they have had little effect this year. One reason is the strong economy. But also important is the fact that the auto industry's sales have swung toward affluent Americans, whose driving habits are not affected greatly by the cost of gasoline.
Gas prices, adjusted only for inflation, would have to be $2.55 a gallon now to match the average price when oil prices peaked in 1981. But adjusted for the increase in annual income of the top 20 percent of the population, gas prices would have to be $3.66 a gallon to have the same effect on affluent families' pocketbooks that they did in 1981.
Adjusted for the increase in income of the top 5 percent of the nation's households gas prices would have to be $4.47 now to have the same effect as in 1981. These households now buy 11 percent of new automobiles, according to J. D. Power & Associates.
Affluent Americans mean more to Detroit these days not only because they buy expensive sets of wheels, but also because they buy more of them per person. Selling third and fourth automobiles to high-income families has become one of the fastest-growth segments of the industry. Although industry sales slowed somewhat in October, they remain high by historical standards and are still expected to set another record this year. The total is expected to reach 17.5 million, up from 17 million last year.
Some less-affluent consumers, meanwhile, have had to change their expectations. They are buying used cars, which have become much more reliable. In the old days -- the 1950's, 60's and 70's -- auto companies could count on planned obsolescence to keep their sales climbing. But Japanese competition ended that lucrative game. Now some engines are designed to go without so much as a tune-up for 100,000 miles, which is eight years of driving for the typical family. So instead of buying bare-bones, midsized coupes and sedans with cloth seats and nothing but an AM radio -- a staple of the auto industry from the 1950's to the 70's -- many middle-income households are now choosing late-model used cars with lots of fancy equipment.
The rise of new-car leasing is giving used-car shoppers a much broader range from which to choose. One-fourth of all new vehicles -- including half of many models of sport utility vehicles -- are now leased. While one-third of the people who lease vehicles choose to buy them at the end of their leases, the rest return them to dealers for resale.
People who actually want just cloth seats and plain radios in cars are finding them increasingly scarce. "You give me air-conditioning and a radio, then I'm not worried about all those other amenities," said Howard Jefferson, 63, an insurance agent in Houston who has been shopping unsuccessfully for a midsized S.U.V. not stuffed with luxury equipment.
The shift to bigger vehicles with more gadgets has led to a peculiarity in government statistics: inflation in new automobile prices, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, has disappeared. Yet actual prices for new family vehicles have climbed steadily. A Dodge Intrepid sedan costs as much as $30,020 when fully loaded.
The paradox is a result of government inflation calculations that assume that people choose vehicles of the same size and with the same equipment year after year.
The government reports that new-car prices were unchanged in 1998 and then fell 0.3 percent last year. But the National Automobile Dealers Association figures that the average price that customers really paid for new automobiles, including rebates, jumped 4.2 percent in 1998 and 3.6 percent last year, to $24,450. Those increases were well ahead of the over all Consumer Price Index, which rose 1.6 percent in 1998 and 2.7 percent last year.
WALK behind the showrooms to some dealerships' service areas and another sign of the times is revealed. The well-heeled people who are buying autos today want the latest compact-disc systems, not just radios or tape decks.
Alan Helfman, a Chrysler and Jeep dealer in Houston, said his mechanics had to replace so many factory-installed car radios with fancier systems that he eventually ran out of room to store all the discarded radios. He could not even find another dealer who wanted them.
"We had to throw all those radios out," he recalled, adding that automakers had recently responded by shipping a much higher percentage of vehicles already equipped with upgraded sound systems.
Robert Casey, the curator of transportation at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich. (which has little interest in those radios, either), said that when Henry Ford doubled his workers' wages in early 1914, to $5 a day, he made it possible for them to buy a new Model T with about five months' pay. Today, an average-priced car costs a median-income family about six months' pay, and even more when today's higher taxes are included.
Of course, some middle-income families have always chosen used cars out of a general sense of frugality, but the practice previously carried more of a stigma. "I always thought my family was deprived because we didn't buy new cars," said Mr. Casey, who grew up in a middle-class household in the 1950's.
In those days, his friends' families bought simply equipped new cars. Now, he said, "The day of the cheap car, the Model T-type car, has passed."
The trend toward bigger, options-laden cars bought by better-heeled customers is good news for automakers and their dealers. Manufacturers lose money on small cars, with the exception of a few hits like the Volkswagen New Beetle, and make little money on bare-bones cars, because they compete to advertise the lowest price for their models in each market segment.
The costs of making and shipping big vehicles are little more than for small ones -- a few hundred dollars' worth of extra steel, aluminum and insulation, and a couple of hundred dollars more to get them to dealers because fewer can be loaded on each railroad car or truck. Design costs vary little with a vehicle's size, though they used to be higher for large models because fewer were sold.
Automakers now derive most of their profits from big sport utilities and pickup trucks because they carry much higher markups and are sold in large numbers. The higher prices are possible partly because manufacturers had consistently underestimated demand over the last 15 years, and so had inadequate supplies until the last year or so. Adding lots of options tends to be very profitable, too, because automakers mark up their price considerably over its cost. For most of the last six years, Ford, G.M. and Chrysler earned record profits -- tens of billions of dollars.
A few people in the auto industry, however, worry whether the good times can last. In most recessions during the 20th century, affluent families often continued to buy new cars while less-prosperous families tightened their belts. But these days, higher-income families are more likely to be heavily invested in stocks. That appears to have made the auto industry much more dependent on the vagaries of the stock market.
David L. Littmann, the senior economist at Comerica Bank in Detroit, said a 10 percent drop in the three-month moving average of the Wilshire 5000 stock index now produces a 14 percent drop in auto sales -- unless automakers offset the impact by offering deep discounts, as seen this year. Sales of full-size sport utility vehicles, which tend to appeal to high-income, middle-aged buyers who may be especially dependent on the stock market, have been weak in recent months.
ANOTHER concern lies in the savings rate. According to the Commerce Department, Americans drew down their savings by an amount equal to 0.1 percent of their personal incomes in September, and by 0.4 percent in August. One popular theory has been that Americans have been willing to spend more than their earnings because the long bull market in stocks has made them feel prosperous.
Many buyers with fairly high incomes appear to spend money as fast as they earn it and then borrow even more, said Michael Coy, general manager of a Cadillac and Pontiac dealership in the suburbs of Portland, Ore. He suspects that many high-income customers with limited savings will be in serious financial trouble if the economy slows or if the stock market stumbles badly.
"I've told people, 'You really shouldn't be looking at this car,' " he said. "They get so mad at you, they leave."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Vacancy;
Stunning Estate, 130-plus Rms., 18 Acres, Rose Garden. Available.

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE nation crossed a new threshold last week: the permanent campaign became the endless election. The nightly tracking polls that showed a race too close to call turned into an election too close to call, and platoons of Democratic and Republican lawyers descended on Florida to continue the fight.
There was, unmistakably, a wave of anxiety in the political community: Had the partisan struggle gone too far? Was this the fearful coda -- think of the last scene of "Carrie," monstrous hand coming out of the grave -- to an era that has already seen unprecedented partisan struggle over judicial nominations, various and assorted investigations of speakers, presidents and cabinet officers, and ultimately the first presidential impeachment in 130 years? 
 The reassuring, healing rituals that end a presidential campaign -- concession, acceptance, transition -- were eerily stalled. In some ways, it felt familiar. Living in a near-constant state of partisan warfare has become the norm in Washington, with Democrats and Republicans as lethally and equally matched as opposing armies in World War I. The voters say they abhor it, but continue to create an uneasy equipoise in a system that works most efficiently with a majority.
Still, even to veterans of past wars, this was a singular moment: "Clearly this is as dangerous a minefield politically and governmentally as we've had in a long time," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader.
There was another way of looking at this pass the nation has arrived at. After running campaigns this fall that were, so often, framed more by the language and techniques of marketing than ideology, both parties were hungry to finish the fight. Both parties stopped obsessing, at least for a moment, about the swing voter who is tired of partisan warfare.
Maybe this brutal post-election clash was inevitable. The two parties ran such careful tactical campaigns, muted so many of their differences, co-opted so many of each other's issues that they fought to, or bogged down in, a standstill.
Their message was exquisitely calibrated for their target audience -- prescription drugs for the elderly, education money for suburban parents -- in the middle of the middle of the battleground states. Many people who listened to Gov. George W. Bush on abortion or Vice President Al Gore on guns in the debates would never have imagined the sharp line that divides the two. That's one way of making sense of this astounding virtual tie in the presidential election. Each party consolidated its core supporters and won half the independents.
But voters can be of two minds about partisanship. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, tells of a town meeting he attended a few years ago. One voter rose to complain that politicians never stood up and fought for what they believed in. Another stood up to complain that politicians should stop all the partisan squabbling in Washington.
When Mr. Gephardt noted the conflicting messages, a third voter rose and said voters wanted both: a principled stand, but "at the end of the day, we expect you to get something done." Mr. Gephardt added, "That's hard to do, when you're locked in a hard political contest."
It may be that both voters and politicians simply have to adjust to life in an achingly competitive two-party system, which has not been the norm for much of this century. The Depression-era New Deal coalition forged by Franklin Roosevelt dominated politics for decades. Medicare and the Great Society programs were passed by a Congress with extraordinary Democratic majorities, pushed by a Democratic president. By the late 1960's, though, that coalition was falling apart, opening the way for Richard Nixon and eventually Ronald Reagan, who presided over a new conservative majority, swelled by "Reagan Democrats."
BUT this election caps a decade of trench warfare by the parties. Each time one of them has proclaimed a broad governing mandate, or seemed to have achieved one, the voters have pushed back. President Clinton's attempt at a more activist government after the 1992 election, notably his attempt at national health insurance, was followed by Republican sweeps in Congress in 1994; Newt Gingrich's declaration of a Republican revolution was followed by a Clinton victory in 1996.
At this point, the parity between the two parties is extraordinary. Witness the post-election Congress, still Republican-controlled but with one of the smallest majorities of this century in the House and, at the moment, a one-seat majority in the Senate. The exit polls underscore the point: Mr. Gore carried women, Mr. Bush carried men. Mr. Gore carried the coasts, Mr. Bush most of the heartland. Mr. Gore carried blacks and Hispanics, Mr. Bush carried whites. Mr. Gore carried almost all the Democrats, Mr. Bush carried almost all the Republicans, and they split the independents.
The technology of politics -- and the immense amounts of money feeding it -- only heighten this intense competition.
Scholars say there may be no new majority coalition until a major event, like an economic downturn. "When folks feel there's nothing much at stake, that everything's going pretty well, you're probably not going to have much of a shift," said Alan Brinkley, a historian at Columbia University. Some analysts wonder whether there will ever be another truly enduring majority, like the one Roosevelt created with the New Deal. The culture is too different from the pre-television, pre-Internet, pre-suburban-sprawl days when precinct captains could reliably turn out votes and the party was an important source of identity.
Both parties can spin their scenarios. Mickey Edwards, a former Republican congressman who is now at Harvard's Kennedy School, argues that Mr. Bush's "compassionate conservatism" can go a long way toward creating a new Republican majority, particularly if the party can gradually attract more blacks and Hispanics. Representative Barney Frank believes that "showing you can combine both economic growth and equity" is the winning Democratic message.
There remains another way for the parties to break the stalemate. Politicians in both parties might try abandoning the poll-tested politics that both candidates deployed this season in favor of a more traditional definition of leadership: offering voters a vision that dares to go beyond what they think they already want.
In the meantime, there is life on the razor's edge. On Capitol Hill, Democrats like Mr. Daschle were talking about the possibility of power-sharing in the new Senate, in the allocation of committee seats and the like. Regardless of who wins the presidency, most politicians who could count were aware of two possibilities for the next few years -- coalition building across party lines, or what the voters would dismiss as "partisan squabbling."
There is not much time for bipartisanship before the pressures of the next election set in; the two-year cycle is relentless, particularly in such a competitive climate, when a kind of arms-race mentality sets in around fund-raising. And nobody is likely to feel very comfortable. Even before the winners are clear, there are already predictions that the voters will look for a midcourse correction in 2002.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1597 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Retirement Plan That Wall Street Likes

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
JUST as companies made the shift away from the fixed monthly pension to the more mercurial 401(k) plan, some politicians want to move Social Security in the same direction. During his campaign, George W. Bush offered just such a proposal, becoming the first presidential candidate to suggest so radical an alteration of the national pension system. If he takes office as president, he will surely ask Congress to act. But transforming Social Security into individual retirement accounts would condemn some older people -- perhaps tens of millions -- to smaller pensions.
Strangely, that probability has not raised an outcry. In these good times, the promise of comfortable retirement from stock market gains is too pervasive. Nor is much thought given to our longevity.
Only the wealthiest 20 percent or so of Americans can afford to live comfortably past age 90 on 401(k)-style savings. The rest of us would sink gradually toward poverty, except for that Social Security check, which rises with inflation and arrives each month no matter how long we live. 
 "We forget, or were never really taught, that Social Security is an insurance policy that redistributes a pool of retirement money from those who die early to those who live long," said Teresa Ghilarducci, an economist and pension expert at the University of Notre Dame. "I thought that Social Security, for this reason, was untouchable. But the stock market kept rising and people now believe they will get a high return forever on their private savings. There is even 'buyers' remorse,' a regret that government has not gotten them into stocks already."
Mr. Bush reflected this optimism about the market -- an optimism that Wall Street certainly encourages -- when he proposed in a campaign speech last May that the Social Security Administration finance individual accounts for workers under 50 or 55. The savings in these accounts would help to fund the monthly benefit checks of each of these younger workers when they eventually retired, greatly fattening their pensions, Mr. Bush promised.
"Right now, the real return people get from what they put into Social Security is a dismal 2 percent a year," he declared. "Over the long term, sound investments yield about a 6 percent return. Investing that 4 percent difference, over a lifetime, can show a dramatic difference."
Mr. Bush's proposal to alter the mix of Social Security benefits did not seem to sit well among many people over 65. Those who said in exit polls last Tuesday that Social Security was their most important election issue voted 3 to 2 for Al Gore. Mr. Gore has promised not to alter Social Security benefits, or to privatize any portion of them. If he wins the presidency, Congress will face the easier task of raising more funding for Social Security, unchanged. Mr. Gore would subsidize individual savings accounts set up apart from Social Security, matching with federal money a person's own savings. But as president, he could find himself pressured into proposing a partial privatization of Social Security, in effect, mimicking Mr. Bush.
The pressure would come from Wall Street, which is already lobbying for privatized Social Security accounts and the windfall they would bring to investment firms. But millions of Americans just entering the work force or in midcareer would probably join in. They seem to share Mr. Bush's faith in the stock market, his faith that the robust economy can avoid a damaging recession, his ideological preference for less government in people's lives and his skepticism that Social Security will still be solvent when they retire.
Only older people, already retired, seem to shy away from individual Social Security accounts. Perhaps they are more aware than their children that annuities bought at retirement with personal savings -- even savings that have mushroomed in the booming stock market -- do not always pay off as well as Social Security. That is particularly the case for retirees who had been low-income or middle-income workers. It is doubly so if the annuity checks have to keep coming for 20 to 30 years of retirement. People are living longer, but the extra coverage is expensive. And unlike Social Security, many annuities bought in the private sector are not adjusted upward each year for inflation.
"I have tried to explain this to a lot of audiences and they don't understand it very well," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist and an adviser to Mr. Gore. "They don't understand that Social Security is a re-distributive insurance program."
Mr. Blinder is right. Mr. Bush should have been hammered during the election campaign for proposing a plan that could shortchange future pensioners. Instead, he was hammered by various economists, politicians and Mr. Gore for what they described as smoke-and-mirrors funding. Mr. Bush, they said, had already dedicated money from the budget surplus to cut taxes and finance other projects, and now he would spend many of those same dollars for Social Security. Specifically, they contended, Mr. Bush would spend $1 trillion from the surplus over the next decade to fund individual retirement accounts, although much of the $1 trillion had already been designated for other purposes.
The Bush approach grows out of a half-dozen other privatization plans put together in recent years by economists and members of Congress. Most would divert a portion of the 12.4 percent payroll tax that funds Social Security. The rechanneled money would finance individual retirement accounts. Roughly two percentage points would be diverted. But full benefits would still be paid to current retirees and to everyone else within 10 years of retirement or much longer.
The transition costs of privatization are formidable. They would exceed existing 12.4 percent payroll tax revenue by at least two percentage points. Mr. Bush would pay this bill for the next 10 years by tapping the projected budget surplus. Others have devised different plans. Some would borrow. Others would transfer general tax revenue to Social Security and count on rising corporate tax revenue from higher profits to replace the transferred money.
The huge cost should discourage Congress from making any changes. But the privatizers insist that the big outlay up front will come back in much bigger savings a few decades from now. As the returns from the individual retirement accounts fatten future pension checks, they say, the mandated benefits would be cut back and Social Security would be solvent until at least 2075 -- without having to raise the 12.4 percent payroll tax.
At that level, Social Security as it now exists, financed by payroll taxes, runs out of money in 2037, done in by the horde of retired baby boomers and the ever longer life expectancy.
Saving Social Security has thus become the grand justification for those who in fact want to dismantle or partly privatize a government pension system that is the principal source of income today for 63 percent of the nation's retirees. "You have benefits from the new personal accounts increasingly substituting for the mandated benefits," said Peter Ferrara, a professor at the George Mason School of Law. "But there would still be a safety net."
Is privatizing or partially privatizing Social Security really the only way to save it? There is an easier way to raise new money, while still preserving the present system. What is more, counting on the stock and bond markets to enlarge pensions is more like a crap shoot than a sure thing. Let's examine funding first.
Until 1990, Congress financed Social Security by raising the payroll tax every year or two, dividing the tax equally between employee and employer, so that each now pays 6.2 percent. True, Social Security outlays are about to take a quantum leap as the baby boomers begin to retire, but many experts estimate that if the payroll tax were raised now by no more than two percentage points, combined with modest cuts in benefits, Social Security would be solvent for 75 years in its present form.
Employers could pick up most of the two percentage points, if low-income workers could not afford any additional burden. Or the tax could be left where it is, but levied on a higher maximum wage.
The payroll tax currently applies to the first $76,200 of annual income. Raising that cap to $95,000 or higher would go a long way toward the desired 75 years of solvency, said Gary Burtless, a senior economist at the Brookings Institution.
"A higher cap would have another advantage," he said. "It would dampen the enthusiasm for giving raises to upper-income workers. Employers would think twice about having to pay more payroll tax. Wage inequality might even lessen."
Let's assume that the Bush approach prevails. Social Security's fixed monthly benefits give way, at least in part, to individual retirement accounts. Those accounts will keep pensioners whole, the proponents say, if they are invested in a mix of stocks and bonds that yield 5.5 percent to 6 percent a year, adjusted for inflation. That has roughly been the average return over the last century or so.
People's savings, however, do not rise in line with the 100-year average. The return on personal savings over the past 10 years has been way above average.
But woe to the person who retired in 1982, if he had had to make ends meet with one of Mr. Bush's individual retirement accounts.
"If you had invested $100 in stocks in 1969," Mr. Burtless said, "by 1982 you would have had less than $100, even after reinvesting the dividends."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY;
It's All the Rage at Work, Too

BYLINE: By Vivian Marino

 BODY:
First there was road rage, when stressed drivers lashed out at fellow motorists. Then came air rage, when irate passengers lost their cool at 30,000 feet. Now, perhaps as an unintended side effect of the booming economy, there is desk rage.
A new survey suggests that uncivilized behavior is common in the workplace. In fact, it may become even more prevalent as employers deal with a growing shortage of qualified workers, said Sean Hutchinson, president of Integra Realty, a New York-based real estate advisory firm, which commissioned the survey. "Productivity in America is soaring, but at the price of a growing 'desk rage,' " he said. 
 Of the 1,305 American workers questioned in the telephone survey, 42 percent said yelling and verbal abuse were common in their jobs; 29 percent acknowledged screaming at co-workers themselves. One in 10 said they worked in an atmosphere where physical violence had occurred.
The survey also found that desk rage had adversely affected the health of some workers.
Thirty-four percent said they had suffered from insomnia, while 26 percent ate too much chocolate. Sixteen percent said they smoked in excess, and 11 percent drank too much alcohol. Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: The Transformation of AT&T

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The Chaos at the Core of Prosperity" (Nov. 5) rightly observed that technology and deregulation are changing the American corporate landscape. The article also reminded us that an early 20th-century economist, Joseph A. Schumpeter, believed economies grow by creating new businesses that take over old ones. 
 All of these forces are at work in the transformation of AT&T. Following the 1984 court-ordered breakup of the Bell System, AT&T's primary business was long distance, which represented the bulk of its revenue. But technology and deregulation made it increasingly clear that long distance was simply an application that could be included within other communications services. The company had to transform itself from being just a "long distance company" if it were to have a future.
Over the last three years, that is exactly what we have done and, contrary to your commentary, our restructuring is consistent with that goal. AT&T has redefined itself by transforming its networks with new digital technology. The AT&T wireless, cable and data networks are state-of-the-art facilities over which we bundle voice, data and video communications services. In fact, in the last quarter, our wireless service revenue grew more than 30 percent; business data and Internet protocol services, more than 20 percent; and broadband cable services, nearly 11 percent.
These new networks, and the new services we bundle on them, are at the core of what we are building and the heart of the new AT&T companies.
AT&T has been an American icon for more than a century. Now it will be more than an American memory.
 
C. MICHAEL ARMSTRONG
Basking Ridge, N.J., Nov. 6
 
The writer is the chairman of AT&T.

HEADLINE: Bosnia Votes With Hope to Break Ethnic Parties' Rule

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The people of Bosnia were voting today in general elections without excitement, but many expressed a determination to try to bring change to their country almost five years after the peace agreement was reached in Dayton, Ohio.
Since the old Yugoslavia began to disintegrate, and each of its six republics held separate elections in 1990, Bosnia has been dominated by nationalist parties representing its main groups: Muslims, Serbs and Croats. Those parties dominated throughout the 1992-95 war, and have retained power in the country's two halves -- the Muslim-Croat Federation and the Bosnian Serb Republic. 
 Today that may change. Opinion polls indicate that a multiethnic party of professionals, the Social Democratic Party, which has rejected nationalist politics and campaigned on trying to mend the shattered economy, may gain power in several regions and become kingmaker on a national level.
"There is a very good chance that every institution will not have the nationalist parties represented, except the presidency of the Serb Republic," said Michael Balagus, director of the National Democratic Institute program in Sarajevo.
Mr. Balagus said the three main nationalist parties -- the Muslim-led Party for Democratic Action, the Serbian Democratic Party and the Croatian Democratic Union -- have gradually slid from their wartime positions of absolute dominance.
Voters may also be influenced by the recent shifts in regional politics. Franjo Tudjman, who led neighboring Croatia to independence in 1991 and helped to spark the Bosnian war by conspiring with Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to divide up Bosnia, died last December. Mr. Milosevic lost power in Yugoslav elections last month, and Alija Izetbegovic, the leader of the Muslim Party for Democratic Action, retired this fall.
According to polls conducted throughout most of this year, the multiethnic Social Democratic Party could win 40 percent of the mandates in the Muslim-Croat Federation. "It should have no trouble at all in putting together a government," Mr. Balagus said, adding that it will find coalition partners in the smaller Bosnian parties and can thus avoid coalition with nationalists.
In the Serbian Republic, the nationalist party is likely to win the presidency. But the vote for the Serbian Parliament may prove to be more divided, perhaps affording more moderate parties enough seats to prevent the Serbian Democratic Party from forming a government.
"Voters seem to be saying that in the institutions that matter, like the national assembly, we want more moderate people, while we want to retain the nationalist symbol in the presidency," which is largely a ceremonial institution, Mr. Balagus said.
Even in the federal Parliament, which includes deputies from both halves of Bosnia, there is a chance that the Social Democrats will hold significant sway, Mr. Balagus said. Zlatko Lugumdzija, the Social Democrats' leader, predicted before the vote that his party would win control of almost all the 10 regions in the Muslim-Croat Federation.
Some of the international officials who administer Bosnia are worried that the defeat of the Muslim-led Party for Democratic Action will lead departing officials to steal or cover up previous corrupt dealings.
"There are 30 days between the elections and the hand over of power," said one official, who requested anonymity. "There is a fear there will be financial looting."
Residents of Sarajevo who turned out to vote this morning seemed united in their determination to vote out the current government and bring in a new team of professionals.
"Getting the nationalists out of power will be enough," said Biljena Crapic, a Serb doctor who lives in Sarajevo. "I hope that will happen. I'm a Serb but a normal one, born in Sarajevo."
A government economist, Sibe Bosniak, said the main reason people were voting against the government was because of the widespread corruption and misuse of funds by government officials. "I am ashamed when foreigners come to visit," he said. Referring to the three-member presidency, in which a Serb, a Muslim and a Croat take turns as chairman, he added, "They send one leader and we come up with three."
People in the Serb suburbs of Sarajevo said they also voted to change the government, but opted for the familiar Serbian Democratic Party.
Milidrag Bojan, 22, a private tradesman, said he was not interested in politics but felt that Serbs still needed their own leaders. "In 50 years, we have not had anyone who led us well," he said. "The war was the most stupid thing in my life and everyone's life. It was started by a few, and we followed like sheep."

HEADLINE: Government Gets Huge Turnout At Rally in Support of Estrada

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MANILA, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Hundreds of thousands of Filipinos today joined a government-organized prayer rally that critics said was intended to demonstrate support for President Joseph Estrada, who faces impeachment on corruption charges.
Many in the crowd, predominantly made up of poorer Filipinos, were members of several large charismatic Christian groups that have supported Mr. Estrada since his election in 1998. The day was proclaimed a national holiday. 
 Although the administration said the rally was nonpolitical, it was widely viewed as an effort to show that the president continues to enjoy popular support and can attract larger crowds than the tens of thousands of people who demonstrated a week ago in Manila for his resignation.
Mr. Estrada has been accused by a provincial governor of having accepted more than $11 million from illegal gambling operators and tobacco taxes. He has acknowledged having been offered a $4 million bribe by the governor, but says he refused it.
Mr. Estrada admitted, however, that the money went into a bank account controlled by his brother-in-law, but he said the transfer had happened without his knowledge. He said he failed to report the bribery attempt because "a president has so much work to do -- that is the duty of our national police." Under Philippine law, public officials who "maliciously" fail to report a crime like bribery are subject to up to six years' imprisonment.
Critics say Mr. Estrada should step down now without waiting for an impeachment trial to prevent more damage to the ailing economy from the political crisis. But Mr. Estrada, in his weekly television program today, accused the opposition groups of damaging the economy by enflaming political uncertainty.
The House of Representatives is scheduled to begin preparing articles of impeachment against Mr. Estrada on Monday. The articles are virtually certain to be sent to the Senate for a trial because more than the required 73 House members have signed a resolution backing impeachment.
The Bankers' Association of the Philippines, which represents the country's commercial banks, placed full-page ads in newspapers today urging a speedy and impartial impeachment process but also suggesting that Mr. Estrada resign.
"If in spite of the constitutional processes, the economy will continue to suffer because of the protracted crisis; resignation, if freely chosen, is honorable and a heroic action," the association's advertisement said.
On Friday, Mr. Estrada also denied new allegations by the former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission that he received a $20 million kickback from the sale of the country's largest telephone company and pocketed more than $16 million from a controversial stock sale.

HEADLINE: COUNTING THE VOTE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Projecting a Relaxed Air As Recount Battle Sizzles

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 11

 BODY:
As Gov. George W. Bush's representatives filed a lawsuit to stop a manual recount of ballots in certain Florida counties, Mr. Bush could not have seemed more distant from the fray.
Tieless and smiling, he chatted with reporters at his ranch near Waco about how well he was sleeping, how kindly local residents were treating him and how disruptive his dog, Spot, was being. The spaniel kept drowning out Mr. Bush's remarks with his barks. 
 "Sorry," Mr. Bush said. "The dog wanted to have a few comments. What she says was, 'Let's finish the recount.' "
He projected an image of complete assurance and ease, which was pretty much what Vice President Al Gore was doing later in the evening. Mr. Gore's only public appearance was a trip to the movie theater with his wife, Tipper; his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman; and Mr. Lieberman's wife, Hadassah.
When they left the movie, "Men of Honor," an enthusiastic crowd greeted them in the lobby with cheers and high-fives.
Both scenes were counterpoints to what was going on in Florida, which hurtled further into uncharted territory, as teams of lawyers and party officials stepped up one of the strangest political and legal battles in the history of presidential elections.
And that contrast demonstrated what a fine line Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore were trying to walk, what a delicate balance they were trying to strike. Both want the presidency, which means winning Florida, yet neither wants to be seen as doing anything extraordinary or illegitimate to get it.
Both also realize the strategic importance of every pose that they or their advisers strike, every image they project, every word they speak, every claim they stake. There are mind games at work, along with an understanding that the court of public opinion may turn out to be the decisive arena.
Thus James A. Baker III, the Bush campaign's chief representative in Florida, spoke the language of justice at his news conference today and portrayed the decision to go to court as a reactive measure, not an aggressive one.
He used words like democracy, respect, integrity, reasonable and regret. He said that the Bush campaign would withdraw its lawsuit instantly if the Gore campaign agreed to accept the results of a mechanical recount in Florida, which shows Mr. Bush in the lead, pending the receipt of absentee ballots from overseas.
And he talked about the people in Florida who had already filed lawsuits as "supporters of our opponents," implying that the Gore campaign's fingerprints were none too invisible.
Warren Christopher, the Gore campaign's chief representative in Florida, said those plaintiffs had acted on their own.
At his own news conference, he used words like principle and common procedure. He said the Gore campaign simply wanted to determine the "will of the people" and wondered if the Bush campaign was acting out of "fear."
Mr. Gore's advisers and allies trumpeted the fact that, at least officially, the Bush campaign was the first to head into court, which Mr. Baker had previously said was not the place to decide a presidential election.
By comparison, they insisted, they were sticking with actual ballots and merely striving for accuracy by demanding a manual recount -- on top of the mechanical recount -- in several counties. What went unmentioned today was the Democrats' reason for focusing on the counties in question: they are predominantly Democratic, and any change in the tallies there is likely to cut proportionately in Mr. Gore's favor.
As the campaign representatives most squarely in the public eye, Mr. Baker and Mr. Christopher tried to appear dignified, dueling former secretaries of state with wizened faces and weighty voices. They lofted insinuations of malfeasance or hypocrisy in deliberately muted manners.
But away from the television cameras, the candidates' advisers hurled less delicate accusations. Several of Mr. Bush's aides spoke acidly of a "Democratic war room" churning out lawsuits and of Democratic vote counters with sharp fingernails manipulating the ballots.
Both campaigns encountered dilemmas. If they went too far, they risked alienating voters and jeopardizing respect for their candidates. If they did not go far enough, they risked being steamrolled by more aggressive adversaries and perhaps surrendering a presidency.
So they did what they had to do, all the while presenting themselves simply as guardians of truth and the American way. And they kept the candidates more or less off the battlefield and tried to make them look presidential.
The only time Mr. Gore was publicly seen on Thursday was when he went jogging, his daughters at his side. The next day, he played touch football with his family on the verdant lawn of the United States Naval Observatory, his home in Washington, evoking memories of the kind of games the Kennedys engaged in at their compound in Hyannisport.
When a reporter shouted out a question about what was happening in Florida, Mr. Gore's only response was to say that one team in the football game was beating the other by 6 to 0.
In portraying Mr. Gore as a candidate who was not yet presuming anything, his advisers were trying to create a public impression that Mr. Bush was acting rashly and arrogantly by meeting with advisers likely to become cabinet members.
Mr. Bush allowed himself to be photographed on Friday with Condoleezza Rice, his chief foreign policy adviser, and Lawrence Lindsey, his chief economics adviser. The tableau in a living room in the governor's mansion here resembled an august gathering in the Oval Office.
Mr. Bush was clearly sending several signals: that he was ready to assume the presidency; that important business was being impeded by the Gore campaign's challenges of the vote count in Florida, and that any cool-headed analysis of the mechanical recount there gave him the victory.
Both Friday and today, Mr. Bush said he was simply trying to be responsible, a word chosen with care. During both appearances, his running mate, Dick Cheney, was at his side.
"I keep using the word responsible because I think the people of America understand that there's a very good chance that Dick and I will be the president and vice president," Mr. Bush said at his ranch this afternoon. "When that happens, we need to be prepared."
The Bush campaign thought long and hard before seeking the injunction, said several Republican officials with ties to the campaign. Mr. Bush and his advisers knew that they risked losing a public relations advantage, they said.
Another option had been to demand manual recounts in counties with a Republican advantage, but the Bush campaign believed that the quickest way to end the turmoil in Florida -- and the surest way for Mr. Bush to emerge as the winner -- was to let the mechanical recount stand.
They also believed that the mechanical recount was the fairest method, one that did not give any counties special importance and did not tweak a set of rules by which both candidates had played.
And they knew they had to do something.
"If you didn't, it would look like you weren't fighting hard enough," said one official. "It's in the back of Bush's mind -- you've got to show respect for the Constitution and not look politically cavalier, but you've got to fight hard enough so your partisans don't think you're a wimp and your potential political opponents don't think you're a wimp and a pushover."
Indeed, the Bush campaign was in part issuing a warning today that if the vice president and his aides wanted to go to the mat, Mr. Bush's advisers would meet them there. On Friday, Mr. Baker mentioned the other states, like Iowa and Wisconsin, in which the vote was narrow and local partisans might feel compelled to demand recounts.
Mr. Bush's cryptic remark today was that "all options are open, of course."
Those words were not so much a prediction as they were a suggestion that the Democrats had opened a Pandora's box -- and an attempt to build public pressure for closing it.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1447 words

HEADLINE: Disasters in the Making

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria, managing editor of Foreign Affairs, is working on a book about democracy in the 21st century.

 BODY:

6 Nightmares
 Real Threats in a Dangerous World and How America Can Meet Them.
 By Anthony Lake.
 318 pp. Boston:
 Little, Brown & Company. $27.95. 
 These are tough times for former national security officials. In the steamy years of the cold war their memoirs -- no matter how dense and dull -- became instant best sellers. Today they seem destined for discount bins. Anthony Lake has tried to solve this problem by writing not a memoir of his years as President Clinton's national security adviser, but a book about the threats facing America -- his "6 Nightmares" -- with little vignettes from his years in office interspersed throughout.
Lake begins the discussion of each nightmare with, well, a nightmare -- a fictional account of some national security disaster. He tells each story using a different technique -- from straightforward reporting to government memos to excerpts from a soldier's diary. As they would say in Hollywood, it's John Grisham meets Henry Kissinger.
Except it isn't. The opening dramas are long and tiresome. I felt as if I were reading one of those interminable human-interest articles, impatiently wondering what had happened to whom and why it mattered. The first chapter, "New Tools for New Terrorists," opens: "Ed was not a basketball fan, but he . . . certainly enjoyed any time he could spend with his daughter, Samantha." Grisham has nothing to worry about.
The book gets much better. Once into the substance, Lake shows an easy mastery of the subject, high intelligence and good judgment. The six nightmares he describes are a useful list of the real threats to American security. Most acute among them are the spread of new weapons of mass destruction -- chemical, biological, and computer-based -- that can be manufactured, moved and used cheaply and quickly.
The end of the cold war has made it easier to get hold of deadly weapons. Most readily they can be bought or stolen from Russia, where vast arsenals now lie dangerously unprotected. And if the nuclear and biochemical materials are not for sale, the scientists and intelligence experts associated with them are. Lake calls these the problems of "loose nukes,"+ "loose geeks" and "loose spooks."
And then there's Iraq. Iraq has admitted that in the 1990's it possessed, among other goodies, 2,245 gallons of anthrax agent (which can kill billions), 5,125 gallons of botulinum toxin (enough to kill the earth's population several times over), four metric tons of VX, a nerve gas one drop of which can kill. After 1998, no inspectors have been in Iraq and these materials remain with Saddam Hussein.
Were these weapons used the results would be ghastly. But Lake argues that another new form of warfare, e-terror and e-crime, could have nasty results as well. He refuses to go into details, apparently keeping government secrets, but he quotes -- and seems to endorse, writing "this is the present" -- scenarios from James Adams's "Next World War":
"A CyberTerrorist will remotely access the processing control systems of a cereal manufacturer, change the levels of iron supplement, and sicken and kill the children of a nation . . .
"A CyberTerrorist will attack the next generation of air-traffic control systems, and collide two large civilian aircraft."
The dangers of these unconventional forms of warfare have been rising in recent years for a simple reason -- globalization helps terrorism. The lowering of borders, the rise of a global economy, the revolution in information technology, all these great and wondrous things have enormous benefits for terrorists. The costs of many of the ingredients of nuclear and chemical weaponry are falling fast. Global supplies and networks make them easier to obtain. And surfing through the internet one can find "manuals for mayhem and murder" along the lines of Uncle Fester's Silent Death, which includes recipes for botulism, shellfish toxin and ricin.
America is particularly vulnerable for the very reason it is so comfortable with globalization -- its openness. America's border controls are designed to be loose. For true global assembly lines and supply chains to work, goods and people must flow speedily in and out of the country. In 1996, Lake points out, 75 million cars, 3.5 million trucks and railroad cars and 254 million people crossed from Mexico into America. Fewer than 5 percent of the vehicles could be searched. A joke circulating in the Pentagon is that if someone wanted to smuggle weapons of mass destruction into the United States, the easiest way would be to put them in a shipment of illegal drugs.
When a nation or group strikes at America, Lake advocates a firm response, though he recognizes Washington's quandary. The terrorists often remain anonymous. (We still have not solved the attacks on the marines in Lebanon in 1983, let alone the bombing of the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998 or Saudi Arabia in 1996.) Proof against such groups is always incomplete and in any case publicizing it would mean revealing intelligence methods. Yet Lake rightly urges that Washington not be hamstrung and act, as long as it is confident in its cause. He also argues for more covert operations to penetrate terrorist groups and rogue states.
Lake offers up some more general solutions as well. He wants to reorganize bureaucracies to erode traditional distinctions between law enforcement and national security: in other words, have the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. (among others) work together. He wants government to work with private businesses in the hunt for cybercrime and cyberterror. He wants more attention and more money for these problems.
All of Lake's suggestions are useful but there is a trade-off he does not fully come to grips with. The heart of the battle against today's borderless terrorism requires monitoring people within the United States. Lake quotes a government study from 1998 that claims that "the single most significant deficiency in the nation's ability to combat terrorism is a lack of information, particularly regarding domestic terrorism." For a nation that values civil liberties this presents difficult choices.
Next Lake moves on to discuss the problems of peacekeeping and "the perils of weakness." During the cold war Washington worried about the rising power of the Soviet Union, China, North Korea and North Vietnam. Now it worries about Russia and its crumbling nuclear infrastructure; China, where a revolution, crackdown, or breakup all seem possible; North Korea, which is an implosion waiting to happen; Japan, whose stagnant economy threatens the world economy; Indonesia, where stagnation seems the best option. And so on.
With regard to peacekeeping, Lake argues that America's current course -- reflecting on Somalia, Haiti, Bosnia and Kosovo -- could be "disastrous: a growing number of peacekeeping garrisons scattered around the world with no end in sight." His solution is not to walk away from societies racked by civil war but to establish a reasonable definition of success before embarking on a military intervention. Success, for Lake, means we should "limit our military mission to giving such societies 'breathing space,' "before leaving. "If we reach farther, and set as our goal the full healing of a shattered nation, we condemn ourselves either to defeat or the near-perpetual occupation of a society that will develop habits of dependency, or grow to resent our presence. or both."
Weak states and peacekeeping pose important challenges but they both symbolize the extraordinary position of power in which the United States finds itself. Its principal foreign policy concerns are how to handle its competitors, if and when they collapse, and what are the best rules of the road for altruistic interventions. Even the elevation of terrorism -- which does deserve greater attention -- is in part a reflection of the waning of other, larger threats.
Lake ends with an unusual chapter. His final nightmare is about Washington. While acknowledging that partisanship has always existed, he makes the case that it is now qualitatively worse -- partly because as ideological differences have narrowed, political battles become more personality-based. Lake is hardly unbiased. He was nominated to become director of central intelligence in 1996 but withdrew when it appeared that he would have trouble being confirmed. Whatever his own situation, however, Lake makes a persuasive case on this general subject, not exempting his party, or indeed his president, from guilt in any way. But changing the political culture in Washington is a daunting task. It might prove easier to tackle international terrorism.
