SECTION: Section 4A; Page 12; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: COLLEGE PREP;
Learning How to Learn

BYLINE: By Glenn C. Altschuler; Glenn C. Altschuler is dean of the School of Continuing Education and Summer Sessions and the Thomas and Dorothy Litwin Professor of American Studies at Cornell University.

 BODY:
As they begin their first year of college, many students do not know how to study -- in no small part because they have not been challenged in secondary school, where their transcripts are embellished by grade point inflation.
A nationwide survey by the University of California at Los Angeles of over 364,000 students in 1999 found that only 31.5 percent reported spending six or more hours a week studying or doing homework in their last year of high school. That was down from 43.7 percent in 1987, when the question was first asked. And 40.2 percent said they studied fewer than three hours a week, while 17.1 percent owned up to studying less than one hour a week. 
 No surprise then that so many college freshmen who insist they know all the material wonder why their first battery of exams do not go so well. No surprise either that offering courses that teach "learning strategies" has become a cottage industry. (Professionals think the term "study skills" too narrow, and they have banished the stigmatizing word "remedial" from the lexicon of higher education.)
For the bookish, "How to Study in College," by Walter Pauk, the standard text in the field, is available in its seventh edition, at more than 400 pages. For those inclined to the Internet, hundreds of institutions have established web sites with mcnuggets of advice on how to study and to advertise the services of learning strategies centers. The University of St. Thomas, in St. Paul, Minn., for example, insists that successful students commit daily MURDER (Mood, Understand, Recall, Digest, Expand, Review).
Over 1.6 million students are enrolled in learning strategies courses in two- and four-year colleges and universities, according to the National Association for Developmental Education; an additional 900,000 take advantage of tutoring and supplemental instruction, individually or in groups.
At the Learning Resource Centers at the New Brunswick, Newark and Camden, N.J., campuses of Rutgers, about 13,000 students in 34,000 visits a year are supported in a variety of settings. They include workshops with descriptions like "Cramming for exams -- and the consequences -- in the social sciences" and "Identifying and understanding one's individual learning style for success in ecology courses."
Nonetheless, it is not easy to get the students who most need assistance to use the resources available to them. Doing so, suggests Janet Snoyer, a learning strategies specialist at Cornell University, means "breaking down the relentless high school mind-set that 'help' is designed for laggards and ill-equipped minds." Professionals know that although they will require those with manifestly inadequate preparation to see them and will exhort all first-year students to come in early in the semester, many students will not make an appointment until they receive a disappointing grade, and others not even then.
Sometimes, a lack of motivation, procrastination and difficulty managing time on the part of students are symptoms of emotional or personal distress. For such students, Ms. Snoyer says, "Study skills tips barely reach the tip of the iceberg," and a referral to peer counseling or psychological services is appropriate.
But for many students learning how to learn is the iceberg. Fortunately, it can be chipped away at, or even melted. Professionals begin by getting students to acknowledge that being an undergraduate is a full-time job, requiring 35 or 40 hours every week including attendance in class and course-related work. Accounting for how they have spent every hour for a week or two (including snoozing and schmoozing) helps students assess their ability to set priorities, manage time and, if necessary, to create a new schedule and monitor their adherence to it.
When they hit the books, students should also consider where, how long and with whom they will study. Will proximity to a telephone, television, refrigerator, friend or potential date lead into temptation? Can extended exposure to an isolated library carrel cause narcolepsy?
A Cornell student, Paul Kangas, discovered that trying to study "while lying in bed was a good antidote for insomnia but not the best way to memorize a list of German vocabulary words." But no matter how conducive to studying their accommodations may be, few undergraduates work more effectively at night than during the day.
And even fewer can concentrate for more than 90 minutes without a break. That is why, as Michael Chen, an instructor in the Center for Learning and Teaching at Cornell, puts it, "Time between classes is prime time, not face time."
In his book, Mr. Pauk advises undergraduates to carry pocket work so that they can read an article or memorize vocabulary for Spanish class while waiting at the doctor's office or the airport. Even if this approach seems a bit compulsive, a specific goal -- one chapter, three problem sets -- and a reward when it is reached, makes study less daunting. That reward, whether it is a coffee break or an update on the Jets game, works only if it lasts no more than half an hour.
Although students often spend their study time alone, study in groups can be extremely helpful. Carolyn Janiak, a Cornell student, said she found that she always learned more when working with others because discussions "force me to focus on the bigger picture and argument." As she clarified her opinions, she said, she was able to memorize details as well.
Group sessions work best if each student has already reviewed (and if necessary memorized) all the material required for an assignment or exam; parceling out the work for vicarious learning is risky. Leslie Schettino, who teaches learning strategies courses in New York State at Tompkins Cortland Community College and Ithaca College asks members of study groups to compare lecture notes, read problems aloud, pretend they are tutors in, say, the math lab and end a meeting only when everyone understands the most important concepts. Often students discover that the best way to master material is to be forced to explain it to someone else.
But groups are not for everyone. Andrew Janis of Cornell tries to study when his roommate is out because "complaints about organic chemistry distract me." He plays "quiet jazz" or turns his radio to "an AM station that is all fuzz." As he examines notes, handouts and review sheets, he uses an online encyclopedia to help with dates and other pertinent information.
Effective note-taking is essential. It takes time for students, who are used to high school teachers who signal them with the phrase, "Now this is really important," to recognize the "architecture" of a lecture -- the introduction and summary, inflection, emphasis and pause, the use of "therefore," the digression -- and to figure out what is worth taking down. Successful students read over their notes nightly, identifying the theme and two or three crucial points. If anything is not clear, they ask the instructor for clarification as soon as possible. To review notes for the first time the night before an exam is to court disaster.
Notes on a text should be taken on a separate sheet of paper or a computer. Students might begin by skimming to identify the "geography" of the book -- its subheadings, graphs, maps and tables and its main lines of argument. I advise students to throw out their highlighters: those who use them are passive learners who do little more than paint their books yellow. Students who summarize a chapter in their own words, in a few paragraphs, tend to understand the material better and remember it longer. Questions might be recorded in the margin of the book, to be raised in discussions or in office hours.
Learning how to learn is not easy. It requires will and discipline, what the 19th-century English biologist Thomas Henry Huxley called "the ability to make yourself do the thing you have to do, when it ought to be done, whether you like it or not."
But just about everyone can do it. And the rewards -- emotional, intellectual and financial -- reach well beyond a grade in a college course.

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD: NEW USES FOR TECHNOLOGY;
Lizzie Borden Online: Learning How to Research Primary Sources

BYLINE: By Eric Goldscheider

 BODY:
Did Lizzie Borden murder her father and stepmother with an ax in 1892? A jury acquitted her, but for more than a century some historians have questioned her innocence.
Now, students enrolled in History 201 at the University of Massachusetts can look into the crime more closely themselves, at the same time acquiring knowledge of the period known as the Gilded Age and learning how to ply the historian's craft. The basic "text" for the course is at http://ccbit.cs.umass.edu/lizzie/. 
 It is not exactly a Web-based course. The class meets, and students hand in papers, but much of the content is online. That includes such research material as trial transcripts, census data, probate records, news reports, maps and hundreds of period photographs.
There are virtual tours of Fall River, Mass., the industrial city where the crime and Lizzie Borden's trial took place at a time of great social and economic flux. Students might follow the route Andrew J. Borden walked to survey his financial interests by pointing and clicking on blue arrows to see photos of the buildings and streets he saw the morning of the day his skull was split open as he napped on his couch.
David Hart, executive director of the Center for Computer-Based Instructional Technology at the university campus in Amherst, started working with history teachers to create the Lizzie Borden Web site five years ago when O.J. Simpson's travails were a national sensation. Parallels between the two trials were striking, he said. Not only were high-toned defendants represented by high-powered lawyers (Ms. Borden had a former governor on her team), but hot-button social issues, like race in Mr. Simpson's case and gender in Ms. Borden's, figured prominently in the trials.
And contemporary media technology facilitated the prominent coverage given both trials -- cable TV in the Simpson trial and The Associated Press wire in the Borden case.
Students sleuthing for the truth regarding Ms. Borden look at wealth disparities in the city and within her family. The scope then widens to the social and cultural climate of the day. Finally, students examine how economic, political, labor and gender issues of the Gilded Age fit into the sweep of history.
The computer puts a large collection of primary sources "literally at the students' fingertips," Mr. Hart said. They learn how to read and draw inferences from undigested material. The next step, marshaling arguments to support historical hypotheses, requires them to evaluate that material for relevance and signs of bias. He is considering using the technique to develop sites for other famous events in history, as well.
Victoria Getis, a historian who helped develop the curriculum, said students generally concluded that Lizzie Borden was guilty, but that she was acquitted with the help of clever lawyers, along with some complicity on the part of Fall River's upper classes.

HEADLINE: Chicago Girds for Big Battle Over Its Skyline

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
On a crisp October afternoon, a giant crane ripped into an old brick building on Maxwell Street, once a hive of pushcarts and tenements, now hailed by cultural historians as the birthplace of the electric blues. The demolition crew did not stop to take down the old hand-lettered placards in the windows, advertising "Stereo Players" and "Blues Jazz Gospel."
Jimmie Lee Robinson, an elderly musician, arrived carrying a stool and a guitar. He sat on the empty street in front of the building while the bricks crashed down behind him and played an elegy: "The Maxwell Street Blues." 
 Chicago, the "stormy, husky, brawling, City of the Big Shoulders," as Carl Sandburg wrote, is in the midst of its biggest building boom since the 1920's, lagging behind only Atlanta and Phoenix in the number of construction permits issued in the last two years. Hundreds of buildings are being leveled for apartment towers, malls and college dormitories.
Along Maxwell Street, more than 50 buildings are being demolished for a campus expansion and pricey condominiums; in the Near North, Coe House, a showy Queen Anne apartment house, has just bitten the dust, along with the Italianate town houses next door. Two weeks ago, demolition started on the Hesing Mansion, a mansard-roofed villa. After protests and a petition to the Illinois Supreme Court, destruction of the Platt Luggage Building, a 1907 Georgian Revival building on Prairie Avenue, was halted last month, but not before wreckers had knocked a hole in its upper corner.
And developers are eyeing the prime sites that remain -- from a big chunk of a block of Lake Shore Drive to a low-rise street of boutiques along North Rush Street to a long swath of Michigan Avenue, the city's most picturesque vista, where three 50-story towers have been proposed for one vacant lot.
In this preservation-versus-development debate, more is at stake than a few 19th-century villas. When the construction debris from the biggest boom in decades is finally carted away, Chicago will have determined the fate of its famed lakefront skyline and its low-rise streetscapes.
While many politicians applaud the demolitions as progress, an example of a great metropolis doing what it has always done since the Great Fire of 1871 -- ripping down and building anew -- others shake their heads in dismay.
"Chicago's great contribution is its architecture," said David Garrard Lowe, an architectural historian. "And every day, they knock down a piece of its heritage. Chicago's vitality is getting zapped." Mr. Lowe said the new edition of his book "Lost Chicago" (Watson-Guptill, 2000) contained 50 percent more photographs of demolished buildings than the 1975 original.
Chicago, the birthplace of the skyscraper, has increasingly tried to preserve the works of its architectural masters: Louis Sullivan, Frank Lloyd Wright and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe.
But many here worry about losing other, less celebrated buildings, which give context and form to the skyline and the center city. "There is an 'I will' spirit here: if it's economic development, it must be good," said Stanley Tigerman, an architect who has designed 40 buildings here since the 60's. "Mies van der Rohe himself said, 'Build it, don't talk.' "
Christopher R. Hill, the city's planning commissioner, said that Mayor Richard M. Daley was a "preservationist, absolutely," and that the city had done a good job of saving the "truly significant" buildings. But because of still-swelling development pressure, he said, "not all of the buildings can be saved."
Social historians talk about Chicago's "ambiguity," a reflection of its location in the middle of the country, pulled between the Wild West and the Cultured East, between rough-and-tumble stockyards and black-tie nights at the opera. These tensions add up to a poignant debate over whether progress and the rights of property owners are more important than preserving the architectural spectrum.
"Of all the cities we can think of, except maybe Hong Kong, we associate Chicago with new things, with building new," said Witold Rybczynski, a professor of urbanism at the University of Pennsylvania, who wrote about Chicago's past in his book "City Life" (Touchstone, 1995). "Combining that with preservation is a difficult task, a tricky thing. It's hard to find the middle ground in Chicago."
This week, the Chicago City Council will try.
On Tuesday, the council will begin hearing arguments on whether to create the city's first two large commercial historic districts, where development would be regulated. The first to be discussed will be the Motor Row District along South Michigan Avenue, includes Henry Ford's first showroom. For preservationists, it is not a moment too soon: the showroom's owner has already applied for a demolition permit.
Up for discussion in January is the Historic Michigan Boulevard District, a world-famous thoroughfare that city historians compare to the Bund in Shanghai and Central Park West in New York. This is the streetscape seen across Grant Park and from Lake Michigan. "The overall effect of the ensemble seems as if some of the best of Chicago architecture gathered along the lakefront, and posed for a group photo," the Commission on Chicago Landmarks wrote in its report.
Mr. Hill called the hearings "the great battleground." Many property owners oppose designation, and there is a tradition here of bowing to a property owner's wishes. "I have quite a few problems with both of those districts," said Burton Natarus, the alderman from the 42nd Ward, which includes the proposed Michigan Boulevard District and part of the Motor Row District. Until recently, Chicago politicians generally observed the old-fashioned courtesies; Mr. Natarus still proclaims that "if the owner has problems, I usually do, too."
Some Chicagoans have problems with the landmark process, which many compare to freezing buildings in time. Mr. Tigerman said Chicago's wealth of great architecture can actually work against preservation.
"Look, there are 45 Mies buildings, 75 Frank Lloyd Wright buildings, and God knows how many buildings there are by the first Chicago School and the second Chicago school," he said, with some exaggeration. "So there is an attitude that if one or two come down, what's the big deal?" (Preservationists did fight to keep Mies van der Rohe's 1951 Arts Club interior on North Michigan Avenue, but the building was demolished five years ago, replaced by a retail mall.)
In Chicago, there are 17,371 buildings and sites listed in the city's four-year-old official survey of architecturally and historically significant buildings. At least 52 buildings have fallen in the last 18 months, preservationsts say. Last year, the city designated five new ones. (Altogether the city has 151 individual landmarks, compared with New York City's 1,048.)
Although Chicago does have 30 historic districts, they are primarily residential, like Hyde Park's Kenwood District, and outside the Central Business District, where development pressures are most intense. The business district boasts most of the city's finest public buildings, including the strip known as the Magnificent Mile and the (undesignated) Wrigley Building.
To Chicago developers like Steven Fifield, preservation is nice in principle but can be a hindrance. Mr. Fifield had announced a plan to knock down the grandiose Medinah Temple, owned by the Shriners, and to demolish the core of Tree Studios next door, an artists' enclave, to build a 47-story tower. He withdrew the plans after Chicagoans sent thousands of postcards to City Hall. In the end, most of the artists will still be displaced, but the temple has been saved -- more or less. Part of the interior will be demolished to house a Bloomingdale's home furnishings store; some rejoice that the shell has been saved.
In Chicago, tearing down a building and re-erecting its facade is considered preserving it. In the last year, at least six important buildings have received this treatment, including the ornate Harris and Selwyn theaters, the Old Heidelberg restaurant, and the Perkins, Fellows & Hamilton architectural studio, built in 1917. Several weeks ago, the city announced that Platt Luggage would be saved by demolishing everything but its grand front. The University of Illinois, for its campus expansion, will reuse the facades of six of the 60 Maxwell Street buildings it will demolish. A plan to put silhouettes of street scenes in second-story widows, masking modern apartments, is being reconsidered. Critics have called the silhouettes "Disneyesque" and "Potemkinesque."
Even official landmarks are not safe from progress. The McGraw-Hill Building, built in 1928, was torn down last year, and its facade was re-erected with a 16-story shopping mall and hotel behind it.
With a surplus of city money, there is also pressure to demolish abandoned houses in urban neighborhoods to curtail their use by drug dealers and addicts.
Jim Peters, director of the city's landmarks commission, said he believed property owners could benefit from historic districts. Mr. Peters pointed to the country's most famous landmarked commercial districts -- Ladies' Mile in New York and Pioneer Square in Seattle -- where, he said, property values "have gone sky-high."
"The problem is, we haven't been able to convince Chicago's owners that values in a Chicago commercial landmark district go up, not down, because we don't have any commercial historic districts -- yet," he said.
"We're going into a real battle."

HEADLINE: How High School Students Did on the Regents Exams

BYLINE: By Kate Zernike

 BODY:
For the first time since it required tougher English tests for high school graduation, the State Board of Regents has released scores that capture the progress of an entire class.
 The data presented here are for New York City students who entered ninth grade for the first time in fall 1996. To reflect that many students did not make it to senior year in the typical four years, the state released the data both for the entire group - whose general education enrollment is tabulated below - and for the smaller group of students who were seniors last year. 
 The state also released data on all students who took and passed the Regents math exam, which became a condition of graduation for those entering in fall 1997 (this year's senior class).
 In both the English and math exams, a passing score is 55 out of 100. Beginning with students who entered in fall 2000, the passing grade on the English exam will be 65. The passing grade on the math exam will rise to 65 for those entering ninth grade in fall 2001. KATE ZERNIKE

HEADLINE: Less Austerity, More Diversity at PREP SCHOOL Today

BYLINE: By VICTORIA GOLDMAN and CATHERINE HAUSMAN; Victoria Goldman and Catherine Hausman are co-authors of "The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools" and write the Junior Ivy League column for Our Town and West Side Spirit in Manhattan.

 BODY:

Fifty years after Holden Caulfield despaired of life at Pencey, prep schools are far less forbidding. They welcome a variety of students, from Park Avenue to the inner city. And with e-mail contact, friends and family are not so far away.
It has been half a century since Holden Caulfield bounced around a frozen archipelago of boarding schools before flunking out of Pencey Prep. Turning his back on the "phonies" and the casual cruelty of his classmates, Holden walked out of the school's wrought iron gates and into the night, the snow swirling around his red hunting cap; bound for home and his younger sister Phoebe -- sweetness and light. 
 To generations of students whose syllabuses include J.D. Salinger's "Catcher in the Rye," boarding school represents the winter of their adolescent discontent; a cold, distant place where parents threaten to send their children if they don't measure up. In Holden's day, third-generation legacies -- children of alumni -- knew that in the fall of their 13th year they and their monogrammed suitcases were going to prep school. Parents dropped their children off in September, picked them up again in June and let the schoolmasters worry about what went on in between.
If Holden Caulfield were to return to school for Alumni Day 2001, he would find that the world of proctors and prefects, dorm teas and Mr. Chips has undergone a millennial thaw. Most of the approximately 36,000 students at boarding schools packed their bags willingly and are in daily e-mail contact with mom and dad. The ivy is no longer one shade of green. Students are as likely to room with a real prince of Thailand as with the fresh prince of Bel Air, as the schools reach farther into the public high schools for the majority of their students, making admissions more competitive than ever.
The monastic life of formal dinners, daily chapel and cold showers has given way to international theme meals, contemporary ecumenism and interdorm dances. Instead of debating whether to go coed -- the schools did a quarter-century ago -- trustees now debate same-sex relationships within dorms.
Faculty members, the shrill martinets of yore, have mellowed into compassionate mentors. Perhaps the biggest change is that the elite prep schools are no longer a sure ticket to the Ivy League; most of the prep schools have graduates at a variety of colleges. One thing that will never change is that many students at the top schools still pull all-nighters just to get a 4.5 average out of a possible 6.0. Stress junkies thrive here.
It was May in Massachusetts, and the lilac and dogwood were in voluptuous bloom in the town of Groton. At the wrought iron gates of the Groton School, a plaque commemorates Auchincloss family alumni. The Gothic Revival chapel is on the left. Groton is a small school with 340 residential students. Perhaps this was the Whooten School that Holden briefly attended. Frederick Law Olmsted, the landscape architect who planned Central Park, designed the campus. The buildings in Georgian and Kentish Manor House style, red brick with white trim, enclose an island of emerald grass known as the Circle.
Quincy Fennebresque, 18, a squash player with an easy grace, has been at Groton since ninth grade, or third form. He wore an untucked Oxford shirt, no tie, khakis and a pair of reef sandals -- the all-season preferred preppy footwear. His close-cropped hair is still tinged with the bleached blond color that he sported most of sixth form, or senior year.
Growing up on Park Avenue, Holden's home turf, Quincy attended a private day school that ends at ninth grade. After much discussion with his parents in the family library, Quincy decided to go away, as do only one-tenth of 1 percent of all high school students. "I felt like I could govern my own hours, eat, sleep and study when I wanted to," he said.
What finally persuaded him to go to Groton was his revisit to the school. "My ninth-grade host and I went to dinner, and Thursday is parlor night at the headmaster's house: cookies, milk, Twister, air hockey, Ping-Pong and football," he recalled. "Then there was the pillow fight in the hallway, it was so much fun."
But it is not all fun and games at Groton, a rigorous school with Saturday morning classes and mandatory chapel attendance four days a week. In ninth grade the school instills study skills, "In tenth grade when they bestow all this free time on you -- hopefully you'll know what to do with it," Quincy said. Apparently he did, undertaking a six-academic course load every semester, including Greek and Latin, and completing seven advanced placement courses.
When asked what he missed most about being away from home, Quincy replied, "Watching my little sister grow up." Echoes of Holden's yearning for sister Phoebe and maybe his lost youth.
In the dining hall, seating is informal, and because the school is so small, it is easy to get to know one another. Three days a week students sit down to a formal meal under the John Singer Sargent portrait of Endicott Peabody, the founder, rector and head of Groton School from 1884 to 1940, a 56-year reign. Groton was founded to educate the sons of New England's socially prominent families.
For decades Groton was a portal to power whose graduates trod a well-worn path to the State Department and the C.I.A. The Groton "honor roll" of public servants includes Dean Acheson, W. Averill Harriman, Paul H. Nitze and Presidents Franklin D. and Theodore Roosevelt.
Today, the idea of service is still paramount, but students give back in more personal, less political ways. Quincy spent one summer working for Amigos, a public health program in Mexico that helps villagers combat dehydration and disease. Quincy said he and two other young men lived in a shack with one light bulb and no running water and dug holes, mixed cement, and built latrines and stoves.
Hardwick Simmons, Groton '58, parent '84, said: "About four years ago, Groton hired a consultant to help with the design of current capital campaign. He told us that we would have a hard time, not because the alumni didn't have the means, but because he had never seen a group of alumni with so many charitable interests."
Mr. Simmons, known to friends as Wick, retired this fall as chief executive of Prudential Securities at age 60. In his office in downtown Manhattan a pillow embroidered with the Groton school crest sat on his school chair. Mr. Simmons, a patrician-looking man with chiseled features and salt and pepper hair, is president of Groton's board of trustees. He entered the ninth grade at Groton when he was 14.
"At that time, boarding school essentially provided a piece of your upbringing," he recalled. "When you went away to boarding school, it was because you had a parent who believed like mine did, and I believe this for my own kids, the most important thing I do is put you on your own two feet. We were pushed out of the nest."
Groton was a place of discipline where boys wore a coat and tie to breakfast, lunch and dinner. "I used to sneak into the fine arts library music room and play Elvis Presley, which I couldn't do any other place," Mr. Simmons said. For amusement, he and his friends sometimes "trundled off and walked down the train tracks to Ayer," a nearby town.
"The only time you saw a girl was at three glee club concerts a year and a dance in February. You could invite a girl up for that weekend and she would stay at a master's house," Mr. Simmons said. Preppies had to work extra hard to meet girls over the summer and on breaks.
Beginning in the early 1970's, coeducation changed the landscape of boarding schools forever. What was once the old boy network became the old school network. Mr. Simmons says girls softened the edges of the school. "It isn't the English boarding school it once was," he said wistfully. "It doesn't have the same hierarchical thunder." Sixth form prefects -- seniors -- no longer rule the school, doling out black marks. Students no longer "work all that time in that incubating community to be the top dog," he said, adding, "Life's broader."
Groton enrolled a black student in 1952, a move that made the newspapers at the time. In the 1999-2000 school year 76 students of color were enrolled at Groton, accounting for 22 percent of all students.
Steve Ruzika, director of the Association of Boarding Schools, said, "There is so much more diversity on campus today. There's been a conscious effort to have kids of color, kids from abroad and from Latin and South America, and the recognition that they have enriched the life of the school." Elitism is a label the boarding schools avoid like poison ivy, but they still consider themselves academically elite.
The role of admissions director at the top schools has changed from that of gate keeper to door opener, said Richard Schubart, former director of admissions and chairman of the history department at Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H. Once a haven for the upper crust, these schools have increasingly attracted intellectual students from the inner city. Of the 334 new students entering Exeter last year, 55 percent came from public schools. Children of alumni, valued for community building and nurturing the endowment, are still given a second look, provided they meet the rigorous admission standards.
While recruiting students is nothing new -- the schools have been stocking their athletic teams for decades -- marketing is. Admissions officers hold receptions in small towns and urban neighborhoods at the homes of families whose children are currently enrolled. Each year the association of boarding schools sponsors a tour to Asia, where it holds boarding school fairs in six countries.
It was the day after advanced placement exams. Speakers in dorm windows blared the music of "No Doubt," while Frisbee players ran barefoot over the grass.
Rachel Thompson, a junior from Washington, came to Groton through Project Match, one of a dozen diversity programs that open the doors to boarding schools for academically talented minority students. "I never thought this would be a part of me," she said. "I love the fact that my Spanish teacher not only teaches Spanish but he's written the book we are reading out of."
In addition to carrying six academic courses, she is head of the gospel choir, a member of the Alliance for Student Harmony, and plays soccer, ice hockey and basketball. She is also the first black woman to be awarded the Wallace Scholarship, given by a Boston family in recognition of scholastic excellence and outstanding character.
Project Match is run by Wanda Hill out of her home in McLean, Va. In the 1970's she sent her two sons to Groton, calling it a "leap of faith."
"We're not wealthy, and we were older parents," Ms. Hill said, "and we knew that we could not leave them anything but a good education." Over the last 20 years she has placed more than 400 students in 78 schools. Some of her students cannot afford to buy the school T-shirt, while others pay full tuition. One of the changes she has seen is a greater inclusiveness of minority students on campus. "It evolved from an African-American society or a black student union to organizations for all kids, white kids included," she said.
Admission to boarding school is getting more competitive, even for talented minority students. In 1956 fewer than 5,000 students took the entrance exam for secondary schools. Last year, approximately 51,000 students sat for the exam. Barring a sudden downturn in the economy, the number is expected to increase through 2007 before dropping off, according to Regan Kenyon, who runs the Secondary School Admission Test.
For all the changes, the soul of old Groton resides in Rector Peabody's chapel, but here again tradition occasionally collides with modern mores. Although no longer a daily ritual, students still fill the pews most mornings at 8 as part of the school's mission to "cultivate manly, Christian character." Students have been known to show up for morning chapel with their jackets thrown over their pajamas. The centerpiece of chapel is the chapel talk, a rite of passage for seniors. Recently, a senior came out in chapel, trusting in the support of the community, which he received. At Sunday chapel on Alumni Day, seniors replaced the opening hymn in the Groton School Hymnal, "Thy temple gates stand open wide" with Britney Spears's "Baby, One More Time."
"There's less of a Groton product today than when I went," Mr. Simmons said. "We're turning out a more diverse group of individuals. We were kind of incubated; we were a product that came out the other end."
Exeter is a large school of approximately 1,000 students, 16 percent of whom are day students. The founder, John Phillips, was known as a strict Calvinist with a liberal spirit, and the school still mixes Puritan values with a democratic ethos.
At its founding in 1781, Exeter charged no tuition, and the trustees voted that "no student shall wear silk of any kind." Students still dress down, but tuition not only arrived but has climbed sharply: For the academic year 2000-2001 tuition is $25,100 for boarding and $18,900 for day students. Book fees total $600. The approximate value of Exeter's endowment as of June 30 was almost $500 million. Last year 35 percent of the student body received financial assistance grants, totaling more than $6 million. The average grant is $18,000.
Although Exeter admitted girls in 1973, the original motto, "Come hither, boys, that you may become men" is still engraved over the front entrance. The academy bell still chimes on the class change, not the hour; Lily of the Valley graces the entrance to Phillips Church, and children of faculty members, affectionately known as fac brats, ride their tricycles down the paths.
Exeter and Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., remain archrivals, and Exeter's sports scores, which are updated twice weekly, get the most hits on Exeter's Web site. Like Groton, the school has mellowed considerably. "Classical Exeter was harsher and more forbidding," Mr. Schubart said, "You got the feeling that every Exeter course was almost a secondary admissions committee, out to prove that the admissions office got it wrong."
Bernard Helfat, Class of '34, parent '69, spent his senior year at Exeter. His younger son attended the school, his older son, a late-bloomer cum millionaire who "wasn't that interested in school," was not admitted. Mr. Helfat, a lawyer in New York, is a class agent and visits his alma mater annually. "The instructors were the heart and soul of the school," he said. "My Latin teacher would take that window pole, raise it over a student's head and slam it down on the middle of the table. It got everybody's attention. And he was a very popular instructor."
There is much greater interaction between faculty and students today. Dorm faculty prowl the halls telling students to "get off the phone," "get to bed" or "clean up this mess." The TV in the common room goes off at 8 p.m. Dorm proctors check students into their rooms at 9:30, and lights go out at 10:30. If students request too many "late lights," the dorm proctor will look into their study habits. They are also alert to signs of social and psychological distress.
Three years ago Exeter put phone and computer connections in every dorm room. Students can now be in daily contact with their parents, and term papers can be e-mailed home for editing, although that is frowned upon. A junior who talks to her mother on the phone every night said, "I'll never stop missing my family, I miss them, like, every day, but I know how to handle it."
The attrition rate, defined as the number of students who do not re-enroll at the school even though they are invited to do so, varies from school to school. According to statistics of the National Association of Independent Schools for the 1997-98 academic year the median attrition rate for boarding students was 10.6 percent.
In midafternoon, in a common room, a few boys were watching "Air Force One." In a room down the hall a tie, jacket and khakis lay strewn on the floor and wet towels thrown over the lintel. Holden might have just ducked out to meet with his rheumy adviser, "old Spencer."
Computers, printers and stackable CD players are on every desk except a few. Some students come to school with little more than a toothbrush. One faculty adviser took a student shopping for posters, curtains and a throw rug to make her stark room cozier.
Will Frazier, a senior from Cleveland who has deep dimples when he smiles, came to Exeter almost by accident. When he took the private school entrance test he marked the box for Exeter because he liked the name. Raised by his aunt who reared 10 other children -- his mother is deceased -- Will didn't know what to expect when he decided to prep. "I come from a pretty rough neighborhood, not many kids finish high school," he said. "There's a lot of drugs and violence. When I came to Exeter, it was a total socioeconomic jump that I wasn't really prepared for." At first Will and a Hispanic student "were the diversity of the dorm."
Will connected with the Exeter community by joining the Exeter Social Service Organization, the Ionian Society, the concert choir and the Exceteras, an a cappella singing group. Spring breaks were spent with his roommate's family, and they also helped him get a summer job in a law firm.
Will describes his years at Exeter as a "joyous struggle." He found the academics challenging, but asking for help was especially difficult, and there were not many faculty members of color to turn to.
He managed to get the grades but took only one advanced placement course, in French. "Boarding school has been a life line for him -- it's filled his summers, given him a peer group of other high-achieving kids, and he has the internal fortitude to make it work," said Lynne Harwell Algrant, executive director of a New York City program that sends minority students to private schools.
"But not being part of a larger black community during the developmental years can lead to an insecure identity as a black man; socially, he'll have to navigate a much more diverse world at college," she said.
"If you can persevere through Exeter, you can persevere through just about anything I think," Will said. "It's really hard on so many levels." When asked if he kept in touch with friends from home, Will replied, "I don't have any home friends."
Ms. Harwell Algrant said, "It can be a painful realization that in order to continue on this path of ambition, motivation and mobility -- to know that you can't go home again."
Exeter was always tough, but getting into college used to be easier. "The biggest difference in the school today," Mr. Helfat said, "is if you got out of Exeter and you were interested in going to Harvard, Yale or Princeton, that's where you went. The colleges figured that students at Exeter had basically been preselected for them. This world is gone."
Phyllis Steinbrecher, an educational consultant in Westport, Conn., said, "High School is the best time to invest in your child's social and intellectual skills because that is the time when these skills come together and take off." Still, she acknowledged, colleges and universities "are looking for more than what a few select schools can produce."
In April, the Exonian, Exeter's school newspaper, published the Class of 2000 admissions statistics. It is a tradition at many elite prep schools to publish the list of graduates and the schools they will be attending but this was the first year the Exonian did so. Many students responded with outrage. "This was something that should be kept private and not thrown on the front page of the school newspaper," wrote one student. The issue of racial preferences in college admissions is particularly sensitive.
"We've had a really hot debate about the whole college admissions thing and being a person of color versus being a normal majority," Will said. "It's really frustrating to me, well, because I'm black, and I don't want people to think that the only reason I got into the school that I got into is because I'm black. People just don't feed you off a silver platter just because you grew up in the projects. I mean you have to work." At Exeter's graduation, Will wore a white shirt, tie and a blazer like the other young men. The girls wore white dresses. The class of 2000 voted not to wear the traditional cap and gown. After the last diploma was handed out, almost everyone lit up a cigar.
On Prize Day at Groton, Quincy Fennebresque, wearing the Groton School tie given to every graduating senior, joyously threw his straw boater into the air. Will and Quincy are now members of the Class of 2004 at Yale. Fortunately, they do not resemble Holden Caulfield.
"You could see a few Holden Caulfields here and there," said Sarah Curtis of Greenwich, Conn., a junior at Exeter. "You learn to appreciate people. You just don't just dismiss them as phonies." But Holden fell through the cracks, and found that his own two feet were too wobbly to support him, so young and so far away from home
The boarding schools were forced to change with the times or risk becoming as anachronistic as a faded letter sweater. Although they have relaxed the rules, they keep raising the academic ante. It takes a teenager with a combination of maturity, stamina, an outgoing personality and a lot of self-discipline to succeed away from home. Yet, teenagers will always identify with Holden, a misfit whose vulnerability is a reminder of their own growing pains.

 CORRECTION:
An article in the quarterly Education Life section on Nov. 12 about changes at boarding schools in the last 50 years misstated the date of the first admissions of girls to Phillips Exeter Academy. They were admitted as day students in 1970 and as boarding students in 1971, not in 1973. The article also referred incorrectly to the traditional chiming of the school's bell. It takes place on the hour and for dormitory check-in, breakfast and assemblies, not just to signal the class change.

HEADLINE: Turn Left at the Shoe Store . . .

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
It's probably safe to say the Internet has saved Americans millions of gallons in fuel, formerly wasted by people driving aimlessly along back roads with directions from someone who never quite figured out the whole left-right thing.
By now, in fact, it's second nature to many people to get onto the Web for door-to-door directions before they leave the house on a long driving trip. But in their haste to hit the road, a lot of those people -- myself included -- have never bothered to pause on any of the mapping Web sites, and, well, get lost.
 A few years ago, such exploration would have yielded little, as sites like mapquest .com and mapsonus.com provided mostly basic features like directions and maps. But that's changing quickly. More recently, the map sites have expanded their offerings to include much of the information you'd want before leaving, including attractions along the way, road construction, weather maps, gas station stops, accommodations and even travel games to keep the back seat from becoming a war zone. 
 Those improvements come not only from new technologies but also from new competition from off-line companies that are synonymous with mapping. At the top of that list is Rand McNally, the Chicago-based company that has thrown life preservers to directionally challenged travelers for 144 years. Randmcnally.com rolled out a new version of its map site this summer, and quickly made its way into the five most frequently visited such sites on the Web -- behind maps.com, mapsonus.com, mapblast.com and mapquest.com. While mapquest.com is by far the most visited map site on the Web, according to Media Metrix, an Internet research firm, randmcnally.com has pulled nearly even with it in another important category: the number of minutes an average user spends per month on the site.
Part of this may be because randmcnally .com is simply a slower site than the others, but it is also a good example of everything you can do on a map site in addition to getting directions. On its new version, randmcnally.com includes a feature called the Road Trip Guide, which allows users to chart a course from one point to the next, as you would expect, but also type in information about whether they're traveling with children or pets, how long they plan to be on the road, and what sorts of entertainment or activities they might be interested in.
I recently kicked the tires of the Road Trip Guide, so to speak, by setting up a driving itinerary from Connecticut to Boulder, Colo. -- purely imaginary, as my family, with three children from 15 months to 11 years, could never survive such a trip. But the itinerary was enough to get me thinking that it might be a good idea to try one day, perhaps when they invent more effective children's sedatives. The guide alerted me to construction zones en route, as well as activities like hiking and museum visits.
Unlike other mapping sites, though, randmcnally.com did not give users a way to make hotel reservations, nor did it offer real-time traffic updates.
The traffic update feature is among the more helpful ones offered by mapquest .com. By clicking on a nearby city, you get information about traffic jams and their causes, so you can plan accordingly if, for instance, the backup is related to roadwork that is unfinished, or that is about to be cleared. Unfortunately, the site's technology can't yet take that information and give you an alternative route. Mapquest.com also understands what some of the other mapping sites apparently do not: that users often need to print out their maps -- and don't need all of the logos and advertisements thrown in. The site recently added a feature that allows users to get a printer-friendly version of its maps, thereby saving you lots of paper and ink and valuable minutes waiting for yet another page half filled with links and ads.
But while the printed versions of online maps are improving, they are still far from achieving the quality of those found off-line. In part, that's because highly detailed maps and road atlases are so dense with information that sites that try to reproduce them online slow to a crawl. Meanwhile, the average computer printer is unable to process those maps clearly enough to make them useful. When bandwidth and printers improve, executives for the map sites said, users will be able to print road atlases that are comparable to the ones now found in bookstores and gas stations.
Another feature starting to creep onto the pages of mapping Web sites is one that allows you to find fast-food restaurants and hotels. While getting directions from MapQuest, you can get information about a handful of such establishments. Such a feature is nice, if you happen to have a Six Flags, Microtel or a Denny's on your route, to name a few of the limited choices. But for more detailed information about restaurants, hotels, A.T.M.'s and other stops, mapblast.com is the most effective site.
Mapblast.com gives the locations of about 370 companies -- hotels, gas stations, restaurants, bookstores, even shoe stores. The site will put together an itinerary with those stores shown on the map and will provide information about where exactly to find them (though the markings are difficult to distinguish from one another). The only drawback is that if you are on a stretch of highway that doesn't include the five brands of gasoline listed on mapblast.com, you might pass by an exit with a gas station.
An alternative to the Web map sites -- at a cost -- is the navigation systems that are becoming increasingly common in cars. Luxury and economy auto makers alike are building Global Positioning System units into their cars, while companies like Garmin, Alpine, Magellan, Visteon and Clarion sell systems ranging in price from a few hundred dollars to a few thousand that consumers can install. The pricier systems will even speak the directions to you and plot detours if you run into a traffic jam after you've given the address of your destination verbally, and will alert you to points of interest along the way.
In other words, they're a far cry from the Internet's map sites, but then again, the map sites are free. And if handheld wireless devices improve, as they should, they will be able to deliver an array of information from the mapping sites that could rival the offerings of G.P.S. units.
Of course, even those who are not driving still need directions at times. In the Alaskan woods, or a city subway system, a map is a lifesaver. On this score, the map sites come up short. For back-country travelers, several sites -- including maps.com and mapquest.com -- now offer topographical maps, courtesy of another site, topozone .com. The maps, which show the contours of all 59,000 quadrants of land in the United States, are helpful for anyone planning a backwoods trip. But again, the fidelity of such maps on the average printer is poor.
City bus and subway maps are conspicuously absent from map sites; the best way to find them is to use search engines like Alta Vista and Google, which frequently lead you to the site of a city's transit authority. Most of those sites do offer maps -- often in a printer-friendly format. But as far as map sites go, the message for transit users is clear: find a cab.

The site does give users the option to link to another site to make hotel reservations; but reservations cannot be made on randmcnally .com itself.

HEADLINE: CITY LORE;
The Timetable of Age Overtakes Stations

BYLINE: By BEN UPHAM 

 BODY:
SIXTY-THREE years after the last trains slowed for their platforms, after the last late commuters hurried through their handsome doorways, under their elegant roofs and colorful tiled archways, a few abandoned stations of the long-defunct Harlem branch of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad still cling to life in the Bronx. But they endure in a condition that barely hints at their original architectural beauty.
The stations, completed in 1908, were the work of the renowned architect Cass Gilbert (1859-1934), who designed them in a variety of styles so as to make each station unique. But Gilbert, whose many credits include the Woolworth Building, might be startled to learn that his stations were now housing such activities as a gun club, a pizza parlor and an adult entertainment establishment. 
 "They were widely admired stations that got the New Haven Railroad excellent publicity," said Steven Flanders, who is an author of the book "Cass Gilbert, Life and Work: Architect of the Public Domain," due next year from W. W. Norton. "And, as a result, he got the commission for the monumental Union Station in New Haven."
Writing in Architectural Record magazine the year they were finished, the critic Montgomery Schuyler described the stations as "great fun" and added, "The architectural pilgrim who gives a whole day to the branch will find himself not only repaid but rewarded."
The 11.5-mile Harlem branch ran from freight yards at 132nd Street in the South Bronx north to New Rochelle in Westchester County. The first tracks were built in 1866 and were bought in 1904 by the New Haven, which expanded them and added the stations. The branch, which was once intended to be the main route from New York to Boston, ended service in 1932 after years of declining revenues. Another local line used the stations for five more years, after which the tracks were used only for freight and express trains, including, currently, the Amtrak New York-to-Boston Acela service.
Of the 13 stations planned for the line, only 4 still stand. The others were torn down or never built. One reason they remain after decades of disuse is that they were built to last, according to Wayne Drummond, president of the New Haven Railroad Historical and Technical Association. "They built them for the ages," Mr. Drummond said, "unlike today, where they expect to tear them down in 20 years."
The station at Hunts Point, with its Dutch-style roof, has become a strip mall of sorts, with restaurants, a bar and a bodega sharing space in a structure that sits on Hunts Point Avenue in the shadow of the Bruckner Expressway.
The Morris Park Station, a dilapidated structure, surrounded by weeds, at the intersection of Paulson and Sacket Avenues, was once an exquisite bungalow of poly chromed tile and brick. The station has been used as a firing range since 1942; the walls are so thick that the shots reportedly cannot be heard outside.
The Italian palazzo-style station at Westchester Avenue, near the Bronx River, is abandoned but can be viewed from the Dyre Avenue IRT, which passes above it.
The fourth station, City Island, on Pelham Parkway, lies in near-ruins, its roof having caved in after a fire. This station has the most interesting history: it was once served by the city's first and only monorail. The monorail, which was built in 1909 and was just over a mile long, connected the station with City Island, an isolated community off Orchard Beach. The single car, named the Flying Lady, was capable of reaching speeds of 50 to 60 miles an hour, supported by one track below and two electrified tracks above.
On July 17, 1910, packed with 100 passengers, double its capacity, the Flying Lady fell off the track while rounding a curve. Several people were injured, and the company went bankrupt after several lawsuits. The monorail was closed in 1914 and replaced with safer and more economical cars running on a two-rail track.
The failure of the Harlem line and its closing only 24 years after its grand stations were completed was the result of an unlucky gamble by the New Haven Railroad on the future of New York. By the turn of the century, the New Haven was chafing at the fees it had to pay upon entering Grand Central Terminal. To avoid them, the company planned a massive new terminal on the Harlem River.
Being far from Midtown, the new terminal was a risk, but there was precedent: In 1871, Cornelius Vanderbilt had moved the Grand Central Depot from Park Row up to 42nd Street, "which was considered nowhere," Mr. Drummond said.
"People considered it nuts," he added. "However, the city moved north," and the New Haven "figured that within another 50 years the center of the city would be somewhere around 125th Street."
As it turned out, the city's 1916 zoning act, which restricted commercial development north of 59th Street, knocked the foundation out from under the New Haven's ambitious plans, and the Bronx lines withered with a tenth of the expected passengers.
But the old Harlem line may be resuscitated in a new form. Metro-North Railroad is considering a plan to run local commuter service along the tracks for the first time since 1937.
"Where people used to come from the suburbs, now people are traveling, during rush hour, north out of Grand Central and the Bronx to places such as White Plains, Stamford and Greenwich," said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North Railroad. Local groups would also like to see the line reopened.
The stations, meanwhile, have gained acclaim along with their architect (a retrospective of Gilbert's work is at the New-York Historical Society, through Jan. 21.), and several campaigns are under way to rescue and preserve them. The New York Landmarks Conservancy, a nonprofit building conservation group, wants to save the stations, and the Point Community Development Corporation has nominated the Hunts Point Station for inclusion on the Great American Station Foundation's Most Endangered Station List.
"The stations were built to demonstrate to a waiting world that the New Haven was upgrading this line very sharply, and intended to make it permanent," Mr. Flanders said, "but permanency lasted only 20 years."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: NOVEMBER 6-10;
The Clouds of Technology and Politics

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of political gridlock welcomed by no one on Wall Street, stocks fell broadly last week as the market absorbed yet another series of unnerving developments in high technology.
 Though it had little effect on the bond market, the election clearly cast a pall over stocks. "Buy-and-sell programs have been unplugged by the stalemate" in the presidential election, said Robert H. Stovall, senior market strategist at Prudential Securities. "People have moved further into cash." 
 Declining in every session, the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index ended the week at 3.028.99, down 12.2 percent. It was the Nasdaq's third-worst week on record.
 Other major gauges also gave ground, although some blue-chip stocks attracted money fleeing technology.
 Drug and tobacco stocks, in fact, climbed for the week, benefiting from the view that if George W. Bush won the presidential sweepstakes, political pressure on these industries would be reduced.
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 10,602.95, down 2 percent for the week. ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 34; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

HEADLINE: ADMISSIONS;
Financial Aid Free-For-All As Students and Colleges Seek Deals

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE; Edward B. Fiske, a former education editor of The New York Times, is editor of the annual "Fiske Guide to Colleges" and co-author, with Bruce G. Hammond, of "The Fiske Guide to Getting into the Right College" (Random House).

 BODY:
When Simon Kendall was applying to college four years ago, he set his sights on a small liberal arts college in the Middle Atlantic region knowing that cost would be a factor in his decision. Haverford College was his first choice, but, like other elite private colleges, it offers financial aid only on the basis of a family's "demonstrated need."
Franklin and Marshall College, however, which boasts that it was founded in 1787 "to bring culture and civility" to what was then the Pennsylvania frontier, operates under no such restraints. It offered Mr. Kendall a package that included a merit scholarship that was nearly half again as large as the $18,000 that Haverford had calculated he would need. To seal the deal, it even threw in a free computer and a $3,000 travel grant. 
 Last June he graduated from F.&M.
Stories similar to Mr. Kendall's are becoming increasingly common as the financial aid practices of American colleges -- a system once marked by generally accepted rules and shared educational and social values -- are evolving into a nihilistic free-for-all. Colleges that once viewed scholarships as a way of opening their doors to needy students now view them primarily as tools for enhancing their own institutional prestige. Families of college-bound students are fighting back by using an offer from one college as a lever to squeeze extra dollars out of another one.
"Applying for financial aid used to be a relatively straightforward process," said Phyllis Steinbrecher, an admissions counselor in Westport, Conn. "Now it's a maze."
Students and parents attempting to get through the maze of financial aid should understand the language of the terrain well before they confront the application deadline, which is usually in February. Following is a guide to the rhetoric of financial-aid-speak:
Need-based financial aid -- In the mid-1950's, when American colleges and universities were facing an enrollment slump after an influx of Korean War veterans, some institutions began using scholarships to compete for the most attractive students. To avoid the academic equivalent of a gasoline price war, the country's leading colleges and universities formed the College Scholarship Service of the College Board and drew up a questionnaire to calculate the demonstrated financial need of families.
The principle of directing scholarship resources to the most financially needy was consistent with the social idealism of the 1960's and 1970's, and hundreds of colleges and universities embraced the mantra of need-based aid. Although their ranks are declining, the most wealthy and selective private colleges -- including, as Mr. Kendall discovered, Haverford -- still hold to this principle.
Need-blind admissions -- Hundreds of private colleges boast that they are "need-blind" in the sense that admissions decisions are made without regard to whether the student will be applying for scholarship assistance. Harvard College even goes so far as to require that members of the admissions committee who know the details of a particular student's financial situation recuse themselves from voting on that candidate.
Meeting demonstrated need -- For practical purposes, the key issue is not whether a college admits the most qualified students without regard to their financial circumstances but how far the college will go in meeting the demonstrated need of those they accept. Virtually all public institutions have need-blind admissions policies, but few, if any, agree to meet the full needs of their students. No one knows exactly how many colleges do meet the demonstrated need of everyone they accept, but informed estimates put the number at somewhere between 25 and 50 and dropping. They include Stanford, Duke and all of the Ivy League schools except Brown, as well as some elite small liberal arts colleges like Amherst, Pomona and Wellesley.
Charles Karelis, the president of Colgate University, said that his institution was forced to take financial need into consideration for about 50 students each year and that he hoped to find the funds to make the university need-blind in the pure sense. "It's not just about equity; it's about quality," he said. "A lot of what students learn in college comes from each other. If I am a full-pay parent, I want to know that the students my child will go to school with are chosen because of who they are, not because of how much money they have."
Merit scholarships -- Need-based financial aid policies began to erode in the late 1970's, when the last baby boomers were working their way through the higher education system, and admissions directors faced the prospect of empty classroom seats. Second- and third-tier schools began to offer merit scholarships to attract academically able students. That practice has now spread to highly selective schools, including some that are need-blind and meet full demonstrated need. Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., for example, offers a $5,000 tuition discount to any student who is a National Merit Scholar regardless of financial circumstances.
Many in the admissions world are troubled that most merit scholarships go to students who would attend college anyway. "The idealism that existed in financial aid about wanting to make it possible for students from any background to come to college is being lost," said Paul Thiboutot, dean of admissions at Carleton College. "We are no longer using limited funds in the most equitable way."
Preferential packaging -- Colleges compete for students not only on the basis of how much aid they offer but on how the aid packages are divided among grants, on-campus jobs and loans. The most sought-after students are offered packages loaded toward grants, while those lower down the preference scale get packages with a higher proportion of loans.
Preferential packaging is common, even among selective schools like Cornell University that do not offer merit aid. "Preferential packaging has become the equivalent of merit aid for some institutions that wish their financial aid programs to remain fully need-based," wrote James Monks, a senior economist at the Consortium on Financing Higher Education.
Subjective definitions of need -- The days when families and colleges could rely on the College Scholarship Service questionnaire to define how much a family would be expected to contribute to their child's education are now long gone. Congress has established a separate federal methodology for the distribution of public funds. Peter van Buskirk, associate vice president for enrollment management at Franklin and Marshall, said colleges varied the standard depending on how eager they were to enroll a particular student. "You look for the strongest leveraging point," he said.
Offer matching -- Like appliance dealers who make a point of meeting the advertised price of any competitor, many institutions, even Harvard, now actively encourage prospective students to show them other offers and give them a chance to respond.
"Our message to students is: if you get a better package from one of our competitors, let us know," said Michael Steidel, director of admissions at Carnegie Mellon University. Last year Carnegie Mellon received 773 requests to take a second look and responded positively to 442 of them, with an average increase of $3,900 a year.
Early Decision -- The most striking recent trend in college admissions has been the push by colleges toward more "early decision." Many colleges, including some of the most prestigious, now fill more than a third of their classes this way. College admissions directors like early decision because, by locking up a high proportion of seats in December, colleges can send out fewer offers in March and thus appear to be more selective. But early decision complicates the situation for financial aid applicants, who are left with only one take-it-or-leave offer. "We tell students right up front: If financial aid is important to you, it is best to apply for regular admissions," Mr. Steidel said.
As occurred in the 1950's, something of a backlash is now developing against the extent to which colleges are using financial aid to promote their own institutional prestige rather than the broader social goal of enhanced access to higher education.
Michael S. McPherson, the president of Macalester College, and Morton Owen Schapiro, the president of Williams College, have called for a "national effort to restore the commitment of colleges and governments to the principle of meeting students' financial need."
They want Congress to pass a law that will permit colleges to enter into agreements to apply common standards for assessing need and awarding aid "without running afoul of antitrust laws." They have also called for a new federal student-aid program that would provide extra funds to students at colleges that adhere to need-based principles of awarding financial aid.
Ronald G. Ehrenberg, director of the Cornell Higher Education Research Institute, suggests that colleges are asking for trouble by using financial aid primarily to advance their own interests rather than those of students and society at large. Noting that Congress requires private foundations to spend at least 5 percent of the value of their endowments each year to maintain their tax-free status, he wrote:
"Although there were good reasons for their having done so, selective private institutions that continue to raise tuition by much more than the rate of inflation, that back off of their commitment to maintain accessibility and that continue to exhibit large endowment growth may well be courting potential disaster. They will be almost 'asking' to be regulated."
 
Maximizing the Chances of Getting a Good Aid Package
 
Students and families can take a number of steps to maximize their chances of receiving satisfactory financial aid packages. Following are some tips from financial aid professionals:
 
1. Have a family discussion early on about the role that price will play in selecting a college. "If parents are not able, or not willing, to pay $30,000 a year for college through current income and loans, then this should be understood from the beginning," said Kalman A. Chany, an author and financial aid counselor in New York City. "April is not a good time to have this kind of discussion."
 
2. Do an early projection of the aid for which you are likely to qualify. Many colleges will assist families in doing this even before they apply. Parents can get an appointment with the financial aid office while the child is doing the campus tour.
 
3. Look beyond sticker prices. Schools with the highest tuition rates also tend to have the most financial aid. You may end up paying less at a private college than at a public university with few scholarships to offer.
4. Include one or two financial aid "safety" schools in your application list. "Just be sure that these are schools you would like to attend," Richard Avitabile, director of admissions at New York University, said.
 
5. Push schools about their financial aid policies. "Get ballpark information on whether a school is need-blind, what proportion of students receive financial aid, the average size of an award and so forth," said William C. Hiss, vice president of Bates College.
 
6. Keep merit scholarships in perspective. A large merit award from College of the Perpetual Magnolia may be flattering, but it may also be a sign that the college needs to "buy" qualified students. "Students who are offered large merit scholarships should ask themselves whether they want to be in a situation where they are the elite," said Elizabeth J. McCormick, director of financial aid at Wesleyan University. Saving a few thousand dollars in the short run may undermine the long-term value of your investment in higher education. EDWARD B. FISKE

HEADLINE: What Venezuela Needs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Ambitions of Hugo Chavez" (editorial, Nov. 6): 
 Having just returned from Venezuela, I saw more poverty, more misery, a lot less employment and more talk from local employers about closing down more companies and laying off more employees.
More money is needed for education and health. Less damaging talk is needed to keep the rich from closing factories and laying off thousands of unskilled workers who make less than $200 a month.
And less damaging talk is a must to bring in investment from the United States, Europe and Asia. Associating one's regime with failed leaderships in Cuba, for example, will not do that.
 
OSCAR BOSQUE JR
Cheshire, Conn., Nov. 7, 2000

HEADLINE: Dissecting the Deal;
If AOL and Time Warner Do Merge, Regulators, Competitors and Analysts Wonder How the Pieces Will Add Up

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
THE two companies promise to create a 21st-century bridge between the new Internet economy and the venerable entertainment and publishing industries.
Government antitrust officials, meanwhile, are trying to prevent the companies from building too powerful an information-age monolith. 
 So what exactly is this new entity, AOL Time Warner, which is intent on completing its long-planned merger in the coming weeks -- unless the Federal Trade Commission decides to block it?
On Wall Street, the emerging entity is clearly seen as America Online, which used its high stock price last January to clinch an agreement to buy Time Warner's hard assets cheaply and is now installing its own management. But seen from the trenches of the movie, television, music, publishing and online industries, AOL Time Warner looks remarkably similar to the old Time Warner -- with a big new Internet division.
Time Warner, after all, has long been a company that combined substantial content -- movies, TV shows, music and news -- with a range of distribution conduits, including cable systems, cable channels, a broadcast network and publishing companies. The new opportunities and pitfalls that come with AOL's huge online distribution system are simply new variations on themes that have been playing out at Time Warner for years:
* Cross promotion. AOL and Time Warner executives have made much of their early attempts to promote Time Warner movies and magazine subscriptions on the AOL service and their plans to put AOL disks in Time Warner magazines.
* Bundling. The companies talk of offering advertisers packages with everything from banner ads to licenses to Bugs Bunny.
* Preferred distribution. Just as Time Warner must now decide whether Home Box Office will feature Warner Brothers movies or the fare of other studios, the new company would have to carefully judge how much to use its online presence in 25 million homes to favor its other properties.
These issues, especially as they relate to high-speed Internet access and interactive TV, have been the sticking points in the federal review. Last Thursday, the F.T.C. gave the companies three more weeks to reach a compromise. The package of articles, outlined below, examine the prospects and competitive issues -- business by business -- in the merger. SAUL HANSELL
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: DISSECTING THE DEAL: MUSIC;
Tapping the Internet's Power As an 'Obsession Incubator'

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
It is difficult to find a consensus on what the pending merger of Time Warner and America Online means for the music industry.
Some music industry analysts contend that the combination would give Warner Music, which is now third in market share in the United States, an enviable edge in competing against rivals like Seagram's Universal/ MCA and Sony for a bigger share of the nation's highly competitive music business. 
 Those holding this view see AOL as a valuable means for promoting Warner releases at the expense of rivals. "The Internet is a very effective obsession incubator," said Pat Keane, a senior analyst at Jupiter Research. "It makes it easier to hype an artist by seeding chat rooms and fan rooms."
Michael J. Wolf, a media strategist at the management consulting firm Booz-Allen & Hamilton, agreed. "There is better shelf space, better promotion, so they have a better chance at building a relationship with the consumer," he said.
But Christopher Dixon, an analyst at UBS Warburg, said any edge Time Warner and AOL gained through Internet marketing would be eroded by alliances being formed by rivals.
Mr. Dixon said Bertelsmann, for example, would gain clout if it succeeded in current efforts to merge its music business with the EMI Group -- the British recording company that Time Warner would have acquired if European regulators had not blocked the deal. And he noted Bertelsmann's recently announced investment in Napster, the Internet music file swapping service.
But AOL is already weighing its own subscription music service. Certainly, AOL customers are already conditioned to paying for product, several music industry experts pointed out. And analysts say that by aligning with AOL, Warner Music could be more effective at selling its back catalog in the form of digital music files.
But why would consumers be content to pay for a service that offered only Warner Music, said Bruce Greenwald, an economics and finance professor at Columbia University. And if AOL offered music of other companies, then how much advantage does the merger give Warner Music over its rivals?
"Why did they need to merge to get those advantages?" Professor Greenwald asked.
