HEADLINE: OPEC Delays Decision on Raising Output

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries chose the Venezuelan oil minister, Ali Rodriguez Araque, as its new secretary general today, paving the way for the producers' group to deal with pressing questions of oil output more expeditiously at a time when prices remain stubbornly high. But OPEC put off until January any decision on changing current production levels.
The selection of Mr. Rodriguez, which OPEC members made after meeting in informal sessions in their hotel rooms here, was unofficially disclosed by Qatar's oil minister, Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah. It is expected be announced at a news conference here on Monday morning. OPEC chose not to hold an official meeting today in observance of an Austrian day of mourning for more than 150 victims of a cable car fire. 
 Mehdi Varzi, director of research at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, praised the selection of a secretary general. "This is very good," he said, "because now they can get to the real matters of production at hand."
Despite oil prices that have stayed above $30 a barrel for months, oil ministers of the 11-member group said they had decided to forgo yet another increase in production now. Late last month, OPEC chose to lift production by 500,000 barrels a day because of the persistent high prices, its fourth increase since March. OPEC nations produced roughly 29.5 million barrels a day in October, according to the International Energy Agency in Paris, or almost 40 percent of the world's crude oil.
OPEC will most likely take up the production question again at a meeting on Jan. 17, Mr. Attiyah said.
The main reason the producers' group is reluctant to increase output is that almost none of the members, except Saudi Arabia, have the excess capacity to pump more oil. Moreover, OPEC members fear that yet another increase, in response to constant pressure from importing countries, like the United States, would lead to a glut of petroleum early next year and set off a steep drop in the commodity price of oil.
Production increases take time to work themselves through ports, pipelines and refineries, so their effect on retail oil prices and on national economies is often delayed.
OPEC members maintain that the full effect of their production increases this year has yet to be felt. Indeed, the International Energy Agency forecast on Thursday that at current output levels, crude oil supplies will exceed demand by 1.3 million barrels a day in the first quarter of 2001. Even now, OPEC members, whose economies depend almost entirely on revenue from oil exports, recall how a production increase in late 1997 caused a free fall in the price of oil, driving it down at one point to about $10 a barrel.
So despite the high retail prices now for gasoline and heating oil, if crude oil prices start falling too fast by the mid-January meeting, OPEC may even choose to cut production.
Mr. Rodriguez, 63, who has served as OPEC's presiding officer, will take over as secretary general on Jan. 1. He has spent most of this year trying to calm the oil markets and to unify the cartel. While the markets often treat OPEC pronouncements with skepticism, Mr. Rodriguez has built close ties with the oil ministers of several member nations that commonly quarreled among themselves and delayed key decisions.
"This is positive for OPEC because he represents them well," said Falah Aljibury, an independent oil consultant in Palo Alto, Calif. "He is capable of saying diplomatic things to the market, but he leaves the actions to the members, which is what they like."
In order to remain independent of national concerns, Mr. Rodriguez, a lawyer and economist, will probably have to leave his post as Venezuela's minister of energy and mines. He will be replaced as OPEC president by the Algerian oil minister, Chakib Khelil, OPEC officials said.

HEADLINE: Yugoslavia Is Cheered but Faces Cheerless Times

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The new Yugoslavia has been welcomed back to the world almost uncritically by a United States and a Europe that cannot quite believe their luck. Slobodan Milosevic, the autocrat who stirred such turmoil in the Balkans for so long, is gone.
But the new Yugoslav and Serbian governments are finding that Mr. Milosevic's rule left enormous holes in their budgets for basic needs like electricity, food and pensions, and a West that never believed Mr. Milosevic would fall so quickly has been caught unprepared, promising quick aid but scrambling to deliver it. 
 Elections for a new Serbian Parliament and government -- and Serbia is where the real power lies here -- are on Dec. 23, and should be the vital moment when the anti-Milosevic coalition, already bickering viciously, is consolidated in power.
But since Mr. Milosevic was overthrown in early October, the people of Serbia have suffered prolonged electric shortages and power cuts and price rises on basic foods that brought inflation in October alone to 27 percent, after the artificially restricted increases of 2 to 3 percent a month under Mr. Milosevic.
The weather has been mild but will soon turn cold, putting sharp new strains on energy supplies before the election; the pension system is broke, and there are significant shortages of cooking oil, sugar and medicine.
Western diplomats and officials recognize the need for speedy support for the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, and his allies in the 18-party coalition still known as DOS, or the Democratic Opposition of Serbia.
Serbian officials say they need $500 million in energy, food, medicine and pension support to get through the winter -- $2 million a day alone for electricity and natural gas. Western help is coming, but slowly, tied up with bureaucratic and political restrictions.
"Serbia needs assistance right now and a timely supply of the fuel and electricity will consolidate democratic processes in the country," said the Serbian deputy prime minister, Nebojsa Covic.
Goran Pitic, an opposition economist who has suddenly become the Serbian minister for foreign economic cooperation, said: "People are proud of getting rid of Milosevic and will put up with lots of sacrifice. But already people grumble about why we seem incompetent at providing basic needs."
Nada Maricic, a pensioner of 78, said she lacked electricity for six hours a day and most of the night. "When we were bombed, we had electricity until the end, and now, not," she said, referring to the 78 days of bombing by NATO last year. "The new ones will learn. I just hope they will learn fast."
Katarina Bogicic, a student of 18, said, laughing: "It would almost be better to cut off the electricity altogether. It shuts off when I come home and starts up just when I'm ready to leave. It really gets on my nerves." Still, she said, "I'm proud of people."
"We know if we don't have electricity now, we'll have it next year," she said.
The Milosevic government used most of its reserves to get through the election of Sept. 24, said Miroljub Labus, the federal deputy prime minister. Now, he said, the opposition must prove its mettle, and it needs help from the West that promised it.
"Frankly speaking, we have enough in promises, and we're grateful," he said. "But disbursement is another problem -- it's a question of timing. The European Union is moving incredibly fast by their standards, but it's not fast enough for us. We're in the middle of an energy crisis, and below that, we have a deep social crisis, with low wages and people very nervous about their future."
Mr. Pitic said: "We appreciate all help but we need more, especially from the big players. Our message is: cash. We don't have to see that cash, but there are bills to be paid. We're a transitional government before the elections, and our main task is heating, electricity, food and wages. Then we can worry about price stability and economic transformation."
The European Union, spurred by Christopher Patten, its foreign-policy commissioner, has been pushing its varied countries and officials to get electricity and oil to Yugoslavia as fast as they can.
"We've been bending every rule to get help here even a day sooner, especially energy, food and medicine," said Michael Graham, the European Union ambassador here. "But with the best will in the world, it's complicated."
When Mr. Milosevic fell, "money for Serbia wasn't even there," Mr. Graham said. "Three months ago, everyone yawned and said Milosevic would be in power for at least another year."
Mr. Patten and the European Union wrenched 200 million euros ($165 million) for Serbia out of special reserve funds. Some $66 million will go for energy, and the rest for food, medicine, schools and support for the news media. But even that aid cannot flow until after a European ministerial meeting on Nov. 20.
The United States is offering a total of $100 million for this year (nearly three times the $35 million given last year), but the first $10 million, to be used urgently to buy electricity, is being held up by Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican who wants assurances on American policy toward possible independence for Montenegro.
Congress has also put conditions about Belgrade's cooperation with the Hague tribunal on war crimes on the use of the aid after March 31. Washington has authorized an extra $20 million in emergency food aid to be distributed by the World Food Program, aimed at pensioners and internally displaced people in Serbia -- which now has more refugees from its wars than any other country in Europe -- and the Europeans have done the same. The average salary here is now about $40 a month, down from $100 in 1997.
But most of the American aid will not arrive until next year.
To get started quickly, the European Union resurrected a program devised last year to help cities then ruled by the anti-Milosevic opposition to get oil. The first shipment arrived at the border of Bosnia and Serbia on Saturday, with 10,000 tons of fuel, worth some $1.5 million, arriving over the next 20 days for those seven cities.
"It's not enough," Mr. Graham said. "But it takes a strain off the system."
Serbian officials have been scrambling, with Bulgaria supplying extra electricity in return for promises of money from the United Nations mission in Kosovo, which owes Serbia $19 million for electricity used last year. Even the Serbian republic in Bosnia has been providing extra electricity to Belgrade.
Mr. Kostunica went to Moscow to get promises of natural gas supplies, vital to heat large parts of Serbia, but the Russians, already owed nearly $300 million, are offering only about a month's supply, and that on credit. Mr. Labus is grateful, given Moscow's own financial problems, but more negotiations are necessary.
There have also been offers of aid from individual European countries, including Italy (some $50 million), Germany ($25 million), Greece ($7 million for electricity imports) and Norway ($9 million and a loan vital to Belgrade's reentry into the International Monetary Fund).
The British are offering just $1.75 million over the next two months, half of that for energy. In general, Mr. Labus said, promises of aid total about $455 million, "but timing is everything."
Still, opinion polls show that Mr. Kostunica and his allies are widely popular, while Mr. Milosevic's Socialists are scrambling to redefine themselves. Despite the economic problems and internal squabbling, the democratic coalition is expected to hold together long enough to win the elections next month and form a government.
"But then the real problems begin," said Jurij Bajec, a respected economist. "There are 10 years of isolation to fix," with a painful process of economic change and market transition that will inevitably create further unemployment, inflation and political unhappiness.
"People will vote for DOS, but after a few months they will ask, legitimately, for real improvement in their lives and their wages," Mr. Labus said. "I need to boost economic activity in the spring, and right now I really don't have any instruments to do it."
Serious aid for reconstruction will not arrive until mid-2001, he said. "But what do I do between February and June?"

HEADLINE: Illegal Tobacco Traffic

 BODY:
For years now European authorities have been trying to combat the growing black-market trade in American cigarettes in Europe. Earlier this month the European Union's executive commission filed a damage suit in federal court in New York against the Philip Morris Company and the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. It charged the cigarette makers with money-laundering and taking other fraudulent actions to pursue a "massive, ongoing smuggling scheme." The European officials estimate that they lose more than $1.5 billion annually in cigarette tax revenues as a result of smuggling operations.
The lawsuit, which accuses the companies of violating federal racketeering law, will no doubt face jurisdictional challenges by the defendants over the use of American courts to collect another country's taxes. But the filing of the suit is not surprising. More than two years ago, European authorities sought help from the United States on the contraband problem. They have long believed that American companies knowingly sell billions of cigarettes to dealers who supply criminal rings. The lawsuit accuses the defendants of facilitating, through their distribution routes and mechanisms, the smuggling of cigarettes into Europe. 
 Experts estimate that perhaps as much as one-fourth of the billions of American cigarettes sold overseas end up in the contraband pipeline. In the last decade, the volume of smuggling has nearly tripled. Tobacco executives have insisted they have no knowledge of smuggling. But it is hard to imagine that manufacturers could sell shiploads of cigarettes without knowing where the product was going. Besides, their failure to cooperate with foreign authorities shows they have no interest in destroying a lucrative market.
Over the past decade, American tobacco companies have set their sights on increasing their market share abroad, particularly as they faced staggering lawsuits and public hostility at home. The European Commission's suit contends that supporting and encouraging smugglers was done to lure new customers to American brands by helping them evade high taxes and import duties.
The tobacco industry record in this area has been highly suspect. In 1998 a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds pleaded guilty to criminal charges and paid $15 million in penalties for its involvement in a scheme to smuggle cigarettes into Canada. Canadian officials long ago concluded that their cigarette makers, affiliated with American and British tobacco companies, were aware of smuggling rings that evaded high Canadian cigarette taxes.
The Canadian government sued R. J. Reynolds in federal court in Syracuse for $1 billion for its involvement in smuggling. That suit was dismissed on jurisdictional grounds, and Canada is appealing the ruling. Meanwhile, Colombia has filed a smuggling lawsuit against Philip Morris.
The tobacco companies deny that they direct or condone illegal traffic. But there is no doubt they benefit enormously from it. Foreign governments are right to take action to crack down on American contraband. The companies should be made liable for their failure to prevent a large percentage of their products from entering the illegal pipeline.

HEADLINE: Bodies and Questions in an Austrian Tunnel

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: KAPRUN, Austria, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Evacuation workers struggling through the night in a dark and cold Alpine tunnel began extracting the bodies of about 155 people, including eight Americans, who perished on Saturday when a cable car they were riding to a ski run was destroyed in an inferno of flames.
Officials said the bodies of those killed in Austria's worst Alpine disaster were so badly maimed that they could be positively identified only by DNA testing, which is expected to begin on Monday. 
 The rumble of rescue helicopters could be heard through the day over this mountain village, population 3,500, as about 80 rescue workers entered the tunnel to begin carrying out the bodies on stretchers. The bodies were then transported by helicopter to a tent at the foot of the cable car rails, which stretch about two and a half miles to an Alpine glacier favored by skiers.
On Saturday morning, the cable car, which can transport as many as 180 people, wormed its way through the tunnel that pierces the Kitzsteinhorn mountain. Skiers and snow boarders, many of them teenagers and younger children, were traveling to the snow-dusted glacier for a morning of skiing. But as the cable car moved through the mountain, fire broke out, transforming the tunnel into a chimney of fierce smoke and flames.
The Austrian government declared a state of mourning, and in Vienna, the capital, dignitaries including the Austrian president, Thomas Klestil, joined thousands of people at a service in the city's cathedral. Public buildings, including the Vienna State Opera, were draped in black, and flags flew at half staff.
The deaths "leave us speechless, since nothing more now can be done," the chancellor, Wolfgang Schussel, said at an ecumenical service here, near the foot of the cable car tracks. "Consolation can come only from our faith and our church."
The accident has sent Austrians into a frenzy of soul-searching. The Alpine region lives increasingly on tourism revenue, and the question of just how safe its winter sport facilities are has been cast into stark relief. Mr. Schussel, at a news conference in a local gymnasium, said Austria spent millions of dollars annually to ensure "an extremely high level of safety" in its skiing centers. But he said experts would search to find out what more should be done. The Kaprun cable car, he said, would not be put back into service until the cause of the accident had been determined and corrective steps taken.
The accident is certain to fuel discussion of the safety of Alpine tunnels in general. In May 1999, a fire in the Tauern auto tunnel in Salzburg Province killed 12 people. Earlier last year, a raging fire in the Mont Blanc tunnel that connects France and Italy left 39 people dead.
Emergency crews could begin entering the Kitzsteinhorn tunnel only this afternoon, after the tunnel had cooled and toxic gases formed by the fire had dissipated. Electrical lighting had to be assembled so workers could pick their way through the burned and twisted wreckage, strewn with the bodies of the victims.
An Austrian police officer overseeing the evacuation, Maj. Franz Lang, described the inside of the tunnel as "relatively dark, cold, with some smoke in some areas." He said that the exact number of victims was still unknown, but that it could be as high as 175.
Walther Thaler, a regional deputy to the Austrian Parliament in Vienna, said a rescue worker had told him the scene in the tunnel was "so horrific he did not want to describe it for the sake of the families."
Officials said the victims included more than 90 Austrians or Germans, 2 Slovenes, a Croat, 10 Japanese and 8 Americans from the United States Army's Leighton Barracks, near Wurzburg, Germany, who were members of a military ski club vacationing in Austria. Other members of the American group were apparently spared the disaster when they chose to go shopping on Saturday rather than ski, a member of the group said.
Maj. Drew Stathis, one of the American group, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying that among the Americans not accounted for was a family of four, including two children.
But Franz Schausberger, governor of the province of Salzburg, which includes Kaprun, said the identification of the victims by nationality was based only on circumstantial information, like tourist lists and indications from friends or family members, and thus had to be taken "with corresponding caution."
Positive identification of individuals will be possible, he said, only by means of DNA testing. Beginning on Monday, the bodies will be transported to forensic laboratories in Salzburg, about 60 miles northeast of here, and relatives of the presumed victims will be asked to supply material for genetic comparison.
As a cloudless sunny day gave way to a crisp cold night and full moon, many had no idea whether their loved ones had been found or removed from the tunnel. "The waiting, the waiting is awful," said the Rev. Peter Hofer, the local Catholic pastor, who celebrated a Mass of mourning for the victims today. In the Gothic chapel of St. Margaretha, perched above the tiny village of chalets straddling a mountain stream, townspeople came through the day to light candles and pray.
Along the streets, residents placed candles in front of their homes. .
Wolfgang Poiger, a dairy technician in his 30's who had come from the neighboring resort of Zell am See with his wife and two children, said he first realized something was wrong on Saturday when helicopters passed through the Alpine valleys with increasing frequency. His wife said they were awaiting news of the 8-year old daughter of friends, who was believed to have been aboard the cable car.
Like many villages in the Austrian Alps, Kaprun subsisted from farming until after World War II. To spur the economy, the government erected a major hydroelectric plant nearby after the war. But it was not until the region discovered its full tourism potential based on hiking in summer and skiing in winter that it gained in affluence.
Among the old Alpine farmhouses, with their peaked roofs and gingerbread balconies, are now cozy hotels created in similar style. Blessed with the presence of one of Austria's two or three glaciers, affording almost year-round skiing, the region attracts skiers from across Europe and beyond.
Mr. Thaler, the legislator, said Kaprun drew an estimated 100,000 skiers and other vacationers each year.
The cable car, more than 90 feet long, travels on rail tracks but is pulled up the tunnel by cable, much as San Francisco's cable cars are moved. It had gone about 600 yards into the two-and-a-half-mile tunnel when the fire erupted.
Officials said the cause of the fire was not yet known. But Mr. Schausberger, the governor, said that "we are assuming that the fire spread with lightning speed," making the use of fire extinguishers or other emergency measures aboard the cable car impossible. Other officials said a metal stairs of more than 10,000 steps went the length of the tunnel as an escape route, but were also impossible to use.
Major Lang said the bodies of victims had been found behind, in front of and underneath the charred and twisted remains of the cable car.
Twelve passengers escaped the inferno, when a man described as a burly Bavarian smashed a cable car window and urged others to follow him through the window and down the tunnel to safety.
Others not even in the cable car were less lucky. The driver of a cable car that was descending the tunnel at the same time was burned to death by hot smoke and flames sucked up the tunnel by the draft. Three people waiting for the next cable car at the station atop the line were similarly burned to death.
Mr. Schausberger said the rescue workers were entering the tunnel from above and through an emergency shaft that leads into the tunnel about a third of the way down its mountain course. Other workers, he said, were seeking to secure the remains of the cable car.
Because of possible damage to the cable, it was feared that the twisted remains could break loose and race down the track to the base, causing further damage, he said.

HEADLINE: 2 Weeks Starting Today to Argue Fine and Crucial Details of Cutting Greenhouse Gas

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
After four years of tortuous negotiations, a treaty aimed at curtailing global warming faces its greatest obstacles yet in the next two weeks as officials from around the world meet in the Netherlands to tussle over the fine print.
The pivotal talks, which begin today in The Hague, come on the heels of new scientific reports with the strongest evidence so far that people, mainly through the burning of fossil fuels, have contributed substantially to a warming trend that could disrupt weather patterns, ecosystems and agriculture around the world. 
 The treaty, called the Kyoto Protocol, requires industrialized nations to reduce releases of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, which trap heat in the atmosphere. It has been signed by representatives of more than 100 countries, including the United States, but cannot take effect until a substantial number of the industrial nations ratify it.
So far, none have done so. Most important would be the approval of the United States, far and away the world's largest producer of heat-trapping gases, and without whose participation, specialists say, the effort is bound to falter.
Even if the details can be worked out over the next two weeks, the presidential election may have further clouded the accord's future.
Gov. George W. Bush has questioned the science pointing to a warming trend caused by human activity, and he opposes the treaty, which bears the imprint of the Clinton administration -- and particularly of Vice President Al Gore, who flew to the pivotal session in Kyoto, Japan, in 1997 to prod feuding delegates into agreement on key points.
Mr. Bush has said, however, that he would support a requirement of some reductions in carbon dioxide emissions from power plants.
If Mr. Gore wins, some treaty experts say that in a few years he might be able to build sufficient support in the Senate to approve the treaty, but it would be an uphill fight, requiring the consent of 67 of 100 members of the Senate, which with the current election is close to evenly divided.
In other countries, negotiators say, there is a great enough sense of urgency to give the sessions at The Hague a chance of success.
Pressure for action in Europe to reduce fuel use has intensified partly because of recent spikes in already high fuel prices and a string of devastating floods and storms that have been cited as a taste of what may lie ahead if the world's climate is disrupted. Other countries are feeling pressure, too, if indirectly.
"It's the bottom of the ninth, and the bases are truly loaded," said John W. Ashe, a negotiator and ambassador to the United Nations from Antigua and Barbuda, a Caribbean country of 67,000. Island nations, which are vulnerable should the melting glaciers and polar icecaps raise sea levels, have been some of the most passionate proponents of the treaty. "It's time for countries to step up to the plate."
If enacted, the treaty would commit industrialized nations over the next 8 to 12 years to reduce their emissions by at least 5 percent below the levels of 1990, the year chosen as the benchmark.
Developing countries, including giants like China and India, would pledge to seek emissions limits in the future, but would not be legally bound to do so. These countries emit far less greenhouse pollution than industrial nations now, but are expected to surpass many of them within two decades. Many American senators say this lets the developing nations off the hook.
Even as negotiations over the treaty have dragged on, emission levels of many of the world's big producers of greenhouse gases have continued to rise, particularly as economies have grown. This in turn has increased the pressure on negotiators for cheap solutions that are the least politically risky.
The United States, for instance, is producing nearly 22 percent more warming emissions now than in 1990, while under the treaty it would be required to reduce those gases by 7 percent below 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012.
In fact, energy experts say, of the 34 industrial nations involved, only Germany and Britain have a good chance of meeting their emissions targets, and they are likely to do so because of policies that are being pursued in any case. Britain, for instance, is closing obsolete coal mines, and Germany is dismantling the grime-belching factories left behind during Communist rule in the east.
As a result, private environmental groups say there are many efforts under way to increase loopholes in the proposed treaty. "They are trying to renegotiate the meaning of the numbers, making it easier to meet the targets," said Alden Meyer, director of government relations for the Union of Concerned Scientists, a private environmental group in Washington. "The result could be we'll have a treaty, but the atmosphere would still be suffering."
As it stands, even the current treaty is seen by many climate experts and ecologists as baby steps toward addressing the effects of a century in which fuels were burned with abandon. And much remains to be done before it can take effect.
The United States disagrees sharply with other countries on central points of the accord -- like how to penalize nations that fail to reach targets and whether to give credit for shifts away from coal and oil that involve alternatives like nuclear plants, hydroelectric dams or new systems that burn a dirty fuel, coal, with fewer emissions.
The United States, which potentially stands to face the greatest economic cost from cutting emissions, is one of several countries that think nothing should be rejected out of hand. It, for instance, along with Australia and other countries with lots of open space, prefers allowing more credits for efforts to sop up carbon dioxide by planting trees, while more crowded European countries want to limit this option.
Such disagreements and the politics surrounding the conference, many participants in the negotiations say, are helping to make the forthcoming sessions in The Hague a make-or-break effort.
The thousands of delegates and observers gathering in the Netherlands represent agendas as varied as the geography, economies and cultures of the countries from which they come.
There are Washington lobbyists representing oil-producing kingdoms who have succeeded for years in slowing the treaty with challenges aimed in part at compensating their clients once the world begins to wean itself away from petroleum.
There are European lawyers representing low-lying island nations and those of other poor countries seeking a range of payments to help fend off rising seas and to absorb other effects of climate change.
There are environmental campaigners who plan to build a dike of sandbags around the conference hall to illustrate the threat of future flooding.
And in the middle of all this are more than 160 national delegations, many of which have formed negotiating blocs.
The list of differences over differences and details is enough to dizzy the most seasoned negotiator, participants said.
The 15 nations of the European Union, pressed by an influential Green movement, are insisting on strict limits on how much credit a country can gain by investing in emissions-cutting projects abroad. Their goal is to have most cuts occur on home soil, through increased energy efficiency or by replacing old coal-fired power plants with clean-energy sources like windmills.
By contrast, the United States seeks to be able to spend money on emissions reductions wherever they can be done most cheaply, and to harness market forces through a global trading system for carbon dioxide similar to an American system for reducing sulfur pollution that causes acid rain.
Another key dispute is over how much forests can be used to gain credits for absorbing carbon dioxide. Environmental groups and the Europeans oppose large-scale use of this tactic, saying that planting trees where others have been cut down results in no net carbon reduction and that preserving one forest may simply prompt the cutting of another forest somewhere else.
Also, critics say, forests are not a secure repository because the carbon dioxide can easily be freed up d by fires, assault from pests or as climate shifts occur.
The United States, in turn, has criticized the European position on penalties for failure to meet targets. Europe proposes a simple cash payment for each ton of carbon dioxide missed. But American negotiators, and some environmental campaigners, say this would allow nations simply to buy their way out of legal obligations.
"Some rivers in Europe have schemes where you pay to pollute," said Fred Krupp, the executive director of Environmental Defense, a private group. "On this point," he said, "they are for ripping the teeth out of" the treaty.
The United States has proposed penalties in the form of larger subsequent cuts in greenhouse gases -- essentially payment with interest. But critics say that this would simply put off the emissions reductions.
To take effect, the protocol must be ratified by any combination of industrialized countries with combined 1990 greenhouse emissions of 55 percent of the industrial world's total. This could happen without the United States, which accounted for 36 percent of total emissions in 1990.
The European Union, with 24.2 percent of emissions, has said that it might seek an alliance with Russia, at 17.4 percent, and Japan (8.5 percent), and so reach the threshold for the treaty to go into force. Still, many participants say, the effort is bound to falter if the world's largest source of greenhouse pollutants does not sign on.
For now, at least, the leader of the American negotiating team, Frank E. Loy, under secretary of state for global affairs, said he is committed to seeking changes in The Hague that produce real cuts in greenhouse gases that are affordable and fair, and thus acceptable to the Senate.
In an interview last week, Mr. Loy said that the strengthening scientific evidence behind the greenhouse effect will help build support for the treaty in Congress, as will recent decisions by companies like Ford, Shell, Polaroid and DuPont to press ahead with cuts in greenhouse gas emissions and efforts to create new pollution-free technologies.
"With the increasing clarity of the science and increasing participation of the business community," he said, "it gets clearer and clearer that no administration is going to be able to ignore this issue."

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Another Difficult Week Looms for Weary Israelis
When a hijacked Russian passenger plane landed in Israel, it heightened a prevalent feeling among Israelis that this tense period is bound to be defined by unpredictable and unsettling events. The incident temporarily diverted Prime Minister Ehud Barak, who was en route to Washington for talks with President Clinton. Israel later learned that Yitzhak Rabin's widow, Leah Rabin, had died. A1 

Mr. Barak met with President Clinton at the White House for what promised to be a sober accounting of what the two men could achieve -- or prevent -- in the short time the president, and perhaps the prime minister, remain in office. A10
 
Leaders of the world's Muslim nations attending the meeting of the Organization of the Islamic Conference bitterly condemned Israel and promised the Palestinians their full political and financial support. A10
 
Aftermath of Horrific Fire
The Austrian government declared a state of mourning, and workers began extracting the bodies of about 155 people, including 8 Americans, who perished in Austria's worst Alpine disaster when a cable car was destroyed in a tunnel inferno. A1
 
Tommy Suharto Still on the Run
Hutomo Mandala Putra, the youngest son of former President Suharto of Indonesia, has remained free through legal maneuvers and mishaps six weeks after being sentenced to prison on corruption charges. The failure to capture the fugitive, known in Indonesia as Tommy, is raising questions about the government's commitment to establishing a new rule of law. A12
 
Plea for Aid After Milosevic
The people of Serbia have suffered prolonged electric shortages and soaring inflation rates since former President Slobodan Milosevic was overthrown in October, and officials say they need $500 million in support to get through the winter. A3
 
Investigation of Fujimori Funds
Peru's state prosecutor ordered an investigation after a magazine reported that Pablo Escobar, the slain Colombian drug baron, gave $1 million to President Alberto K. Fujimori's now fugitive intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, to contribute to Mr. Fujimori's first electoral campaign. A8
 
NATIONAL A14-27
 
Battle for the Presidency Continues as Fronts Shift
As lawyers prepared to square off in federal court over Gov. George W. Bush's efforts to block hand recounts of Florida's disputed vote tallies, election officials in at least two counties conducted manual recounts and spokesmen for Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore again took to the airwaves in sharp disagreement over how to end the deadlock. A1
 
Many prominent Republicans and party operatives are questioning Mr. Bush's strategy in the last days before the election, saying the campaign's top advisers were so confident that they made mistakes that probably cost Mr. Bush a comfortable victory. The biggest complaint is that Bush strategists were so certain that they had locked up many swing states that in the closing days of the campaign they sent the candidate on a victory lap to states he had little chance of winning, like California and New Jersey. A1
 
Immediately after the hand recount in four precincts in Palm Beach County, Fla., ended, the Palm Beach County Canvassing Board approved an unprecedented recount of all 462,657 presidential ballots, saying it was the only way to determine the true intent of all the voters. A20
 
In Broward County, Fla., 6,686 voters handed in ballots seemingly without marking a choice for president. The Republicans say they believe the counting machines. The Democrats say a hand recount will prove that it is a matter of poorly set equipment that refilled holes punched by voters. The dispute might be resolved today when county officials plan to inspect a sampling of ballots. A17
 
A full day behind schedule, after tangled legal wrangles, serious deliberations over what color pens to use and squabbles over such grave matters as the passing of notes, human hands finally got to work to manually recount the ballots in Volusia County, Fla. A19
 
DNA Takes On Boston Strangler
Two parallel efforts are under way to determine if the woman known as the infamous killer's youngest and last victim, 19-year-old Mary Sullivan, was in fact killed by the man who long claimed to be the Boston Strangler, Albert DeSalvo. The efforts offer two chances that DNA evidence will finally lay to rest the most terrifying crime mystery ever to strike Boston. For years, some have argued that the strangler, or stranglers, might still be out there. A14

Teacher Talks Turn Tense
The contract for New York City's 78,000 public school teachers expires on Wednesday, and labor negotiations have become tense as the city seeks major changes that could reshape its schools, including merit-based raises for teachers, a longer school day and and faster, easier ways to dismiss incompetent teachers. City officials are looking to these negotiations as a rare opportunity to win sweeping changes to improve New York's troubled schools and loosen contract restrictions, like tenure protections, that they view as impediments to better education. SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 497 words

HEADLINE: The American Role in Mideast Peace

 BODY:
A new round of White House visits by Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, has ended without any clear schedule for resuming peace talks. The two sides even seem to disagree on how future negotiations should be structured. The Palestinians have expressed a desire for increased international involvement, complaining that Washington has abandoned the neutrality required of a mediator. Israel rightly resists any shift to a more international format. Only the United States has sufficient authority and credibility with both sides to help them bridge their remaining differences.
On Friday, Mr. Arafat pursued his quest for a greater international presence by asking the United Nations Security Council to dispatch a 2,000-member armed international force to protect Palestinian civilians. Israel strenuously objects to this misguided proposal, which should be the end of it since, as a rule, the U.N. only sends forces into a conflict when all sides agree. The more practical way to protect civilians is for Mr. Arafat to put the truce arrangements he has repeatedly agreed to into effect and for Israel to carry out the commitments it made. 
 Once that happens, a return to serious bargaining would be the best safeguard against renewed fighting. Ideally, the two sides should start talking to each other directly. That is how the original Oslo peace agreement was reached. But given recent violence, outside diplomatic help will probably be needed.
Several world leaders have worked hard in recent weeks to urge an end to the bloodshed, among them the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, and Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak. But the recent history of Mideast diplomacy suggests that only Washington can supply the consistent and effective leadership needed to secure an agreement. Years of American steadfastness have earned it the trust of Israel. Nearly a decade of diplomatic engagement with the Palestinians, including significant financial assistance, has given Washington a good working relationship with Mr. Arafat as well, despite his current protests.
If a peace agreement is eventually reached, Washington's help will be indispensable to making it work. Generous additional American aid will be needed to help Israel finance construction of roads, possible relocation of some settlers and security arrangements and to revitalize the Palestinian economy. The Central Intelligence Agency will continue to provide communication and coordination between Israeli and Palestinian security forces.
Many uncertainties cloud the immediate future, including the final outcome of the American presidential election and the political survival of the current Israeli government. But Mr. Arafat and Mr. Barak both assured President Clinton that they look forward to an eventual resumption of peace talks. Whenever negotiations resume, American leadership will be needed to help bring them to a successful conclusion.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Agencies Announce Acquisition Deals

BYLINE: By Patrick McGeehan 

 BODY:
Three companies are making acquisitions.
Rabasca & Company in Melville, N.Y., is acquiring and absorbing AM/PM Promotions in Babylon, N.Y., which specializes in graphics, direct mail and promotion programs. Financial terms of the deal, mostly in cash, were not disclosed. After the acquisition, Rabasca will have 20 employees and billings estimated at $17 million from clients like Arrow Electronics. 
 Fisher Design in Cincinnati acquired Index Design Associates in Cincinnati. Terms were not disclosed. Index, with 15 employees working for clients like General Electric and Sunbeam, will operate as the product design and development division of Fisher. Phil Brookshire, 62, president at Index, becomes senior vice president for the division.
And Taylor Nelson Sofres in London, which owns Competitive Media Reporting, the service that tracks advertising spending, is acquiring Wallace Marx & Associates in Minneapolis, which supplies data for coupon promotions, for $15 million in cash. Wallace Marx will operate as a division of Competitive Media. Wallace Marx, president at Wallace Marx, becomes managing director.

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
BROOKLYN: SUBWAY CONDUCTOR ATTACKED
A passenger attacked a subway conductor yesterday on an N train bound for Coney Island, the police said, apparently after a dispute about an announcement. The passenger, Rafael Stern, 64, of 381 Central Park West in Manhattan, was charged with assault and criminal possession of a weapon after the scuffle at 11:35 a.m. near the 53rd Street station in Sunset Park. The conductor was walking from one car to another when he was confronted by a man who punched him in the cheek and stabbed him in the abdomen with a sharp object, possibly an ice pick or carpenter's awl, the police said. Other passengers restrained the man. "The dispute was about directions, but that's all we know at this time," said Sgt. Brian Burke, a police spokesman. The conductor, 33, whose name was not immediately disclosed by the police, was listed in stable condition at Lutheran Medical Center in Sunset Park. (NYT)
 
ALBANY: BRUNO REJECTS TAX RISE FOR TRANSIT
With 51 percent of state voters having rejected the $3.8 billion transportation bond act last week, state officials are trying to figure out how to pay for transportation projects. The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, left, ruled out tax increases, saying the current state budget appeared to have a surplus. "I, for one, do not see myself while in office voting for tax increases," he said. Bernard Brooks of the conservative fiscal group Change-New York, which opposed the bond act, contended that the surplus and the taxes already collected under budgets that increased state spending beyond the rate of inflation should cover the transportation projects. (AP) 

NEW YORK: CIGARETTE SALES TO MINORS
Vendors in New York City are less likely to sell tobacco to minors than are stores nationwide, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday. Jane Hoffman, the consumer affairs commissioner, said that of the more than 7,800 inspections conducted in the five boroughs, just over 1,300 violations were found. Ms. Hoffman said the city's 83 percent compliance rate surpassed the average national compliance rate of 71 percent and the New York State average of 74 percent. The sale of cigarettes is prohibited to those younger than 18, and sellers are required to request photo identification from customers who appear younger than 25. (AP)
 
SUFFERN: ARREST IN CHURCH ARSON
A man was arrested Saturday and charged with setting a fire on Friday at the Presbyterian Church of Suffern, the police said yesterday. The man, Andrew Z. Gardner, 28, of Spring Valley, a part-time security guard and artist's model, was charged with arson and burglary. Detective Craig H. Long, a police spokesman, said Mr. Gardner was also suspected in attacks at two other churches and a synagogue. In each case, the attacker left graffiti, including, at the Presbyterian church, "Satan rules the earth," the detective said, and someone who knows Mr. Gardner noticed similarities in the writing. No one was hurt in the latest attack, which caused about $40,000 in damage. The fire appears to have been caused by an accelerant, not a firebomb as first reported. (NYT)
 
HAMILTON: 4 STUDENTS DIE IN CRASH
Four college students were killed and two were injured when a Jeep driven by a student the police say was drunk slammed into two trees on Colgate University's campus early Saturday. Three of the dead were hitchhikers who had just been picked up at the campus entrance. The dead were identified as Kevin King, 20, a student at Hudson Valley Community College in Troy; Emily Collins and Rachel Nargiso, both 18-year-olds from Norwich attending Hobart and William Smith Colleges; and Katherine Almeter, 18, a Colgate freshman from Norwich. All except Ms. Almeter were tossed from the vehicle after the driver, Robert Koester, 20, a Colgate junior from Troy, lost control around 1:45 a.m. No one was wearing a seat belt, the police said. (AP)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
PATERSON: INFORMATION ON YOUTH GANGS
The police are urging teachers to watch their students for signs of gang activity and pass the information to officials. Educators have been told to notice when students gather in groups, and to look at clothing and notebook doodles. Some educators, civil libertarians and politicians question the effort, saying it turns teachers into a tool of law enforcement. The police estimate that six major gangs there have 1,000 members total. (AP)
 
WILLINGBORO: YOUTH DIES IN GARAGE FIRE
The authorities were investigating an explosion and fire at a home here late Saturday that killed one teenager and seriously injured another. The explosion at the one-story house happened shortly after 11:30 p.m., starting a fire that was brought under control about 45 minutes later, officials said. The police said seven young people were in a converted garage that was heated by propane space heaters when one of the fuel lines came loose and the gas began to fill the room. A 15-year-old Willingboro boy was killed in the fire. A 13-year-old boy who suffered burns to his face and arms was in critical condition yesterday. Officials said the fire was accidental. (AP)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
HARTFORD: MAN SHOT BY POLICE
A Hartford man was being treated yesterday at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center after being shot at least twice by police officers. The man, Clifford Gamble, 25, was shot Friday by two officers responding to a 911 call about a confrontation between him and a woman in a parking lot at 881 Garden Street, officials said. Mr. Gamble resisted arrest and escaped an officer's grasp, said Lt. Mark Pawlina, commander of the major-crimes division. He said Mr. Gamble then pulled a knife from his shirt, held it against the woman's throat and stabbed her several times. He was advancing toward one officer when he was shot, Lieutenant Pawlina said. The woman's name and condition were not immediately released. A hospital spokesman would not disclose Mr. Gamble's condition. (NYT)
 
NEW BRITAIN: ELECTRIC HYBRID VEHICLE
The city is joining a growing number of Connecticut municipalities that are relying on vehicles powered by alternative fuels. New Britain is applying for a state grant to offset the purchase of a Toyota Prius sedan that would be the city's first gasoline-electric hybrid vehicle. The state would supply about $7,000 of the $20,000 price tag. (AP)

HEADLINE: Walls Talk, But Their Story Has Changed;
A Home to Immigrants Now Draws Trendsetters

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
If the walls of 96 Orchard Street could talk, they would speak at least 10 languages. If they could share their stories, they might tell of 3 people sleeping on a couch, or 16 sharing a single toilet, or of dark rooms shut off from fresh breezes.
But those are the old stories, from around the start of the 20th century, when the blocks of the Lower East Side were among the most densely populated in the world. 
 Now there are new stories at 96 Orchard Street, of students moving to the Lower East Side to practice their music, of young architects and makeup artists who wanted to live in a neighborhood they knew was vibrant, historic and talked about.
Immigrants who moved in at the turn of the century paid $6 to $15 a month for a 325-square-foot apartment and got the first month's rent free as an incentive. (It was not unheard of for the tenants to move out after the first month and find another building to get a similar deal.) Today, residents pay almost $5,700 ($1,500 for the first month's rent, $1,500 for the security deposit and $2,700 for the broker's fee) for roughly the same apartments, four to a floor.
A biography of the building, a tenement like so many others in the neighborhood, sheds light on how a changing city houses its residents, sometimes in buildings that do not change much at all. One thing has remained surprisingly constant since the five-story brick tenement was built more than 130 years ago: the sense of new beginnings people have as they move in, whether they are immigrants, trendsetters or trend followers.
Orchard Street was named for the dirt road that led from the house to the orchard of the 300-acre Delancey farm, on what is now known as the Lower East Side. During the American Revolution the land was confiscated from the Delanceys, who were sympathetic to the British, and distributed among various landlords, including John Jacob Astor.
The lot was purchased in 1865 by a man named Adam Stumm. The building was built in 1867, and was designed in the Italianate style by Louis Berger, an architect, said Andrew S. Dolkart, a professor of architectural preservation at Columbia University.
The 1870 census showed that 23 people lived in the building. Eight of them were born in New York. The oldest was 53, the youngest was 2, and the breadwinners included a cooper, a watchman, a cabinetmaker, a steamboat steward and a doctor. Everyone was white, all but one of the adults had foreign-born parents, and only two were unable to write. (The census also asked if there were deaf, dumb, blind, insane or idiotic people living in the building; there were none.)
Twenty years later, the population of 96 Orchard Street had more than tripled, reaching 85, most having lived there only two or three years, and 34 of them were children. None of the 1870 residents, mostly from Ireland, Germany, Scotland or France, remained. In 1890, there were many more people whose names ended in -vich or -stein, signifying a shift to immigrants from Eastern Europe.
By 1900, there were 122 people shoehorned into the tenement, half of whom had arrived in the previous 10 years. Most were from Russia, with a few from Austria and Romania. There was a preponderance of tailors, as well as a carpenter, a diamond seller, a cigarmaker, a buttonmaker, a waiter, a plumber and a doctor.
After 1901, a new law, part of a movement to improve conditions in tenements, required a toilet for every two apartments. Later, it was required that the toilets be ventilated, usually via an air shaft.
In 1903, according to a tenement inspector's report, there were 2,200 people living in the block formed by Orchard, Allen, Broome and Delancey Streets, or 1,000 people an acre. The building at No. 96 was bought by Mayer Brauner in 1905, and sold to M. B. Helpern Realty in 1919 for $60,500. The Helpern family kept the building until the late 1990's, when, after a series of deals, it was finally sold to 96 Orchard Inc. for $570,000.
By 1920, census reports suggest, the number of residents at 96 Orchard Street had decreased to 56; they spoke five native languages -- Yiddish, Russian, Spanish, Greek and Italian. One tenant worked as a peddler in a moving-picture house. Another was a repairman at a chandelier factory. A third was a piano teacher.
Judging from the restored decor of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum across the street, the hall was probably papered in burlap and decorated with medallions painted with pastoral scenes. (When No. 96 was being renovated, the curator of the museum, Steve Long, tried to rescue the medallions, but workers threw them out before he could recover them.)
In 1936, after a law was passed requiring that tenement buildings have a staircase made of metal rather than wood, the upper floors of No. 96 were closed off and used for storage, which was apparently more economical than making the required renovations and heating the apartments.
At that point, the basement floor of the building held a retail dress shop and a shoe store, and the stoop floor had a ladies' dress store and a retail gift store. A jewelry wholesaler on an upper floor had to stop operating, and the windows above the second floor, front and rear, were boarded up. The upper floors of No. 96 stayed shuttered until 1996.
Serge Hoyda, the building's current owner, remembers what it was like to open up those floors again, and to try to make them habitable.
"It was like any other building that had been abandoned for the past 50 years," he said. The roof was leaking and there was virtually nothing salvageable.
But Mr. Hoyda said he felt the neighborhood was becoming ripe for revitalization. It had lots of ready-to-renovate housing in historic buildings, all in a convenient location. Mr. Hoyda became one of the first people to start rehabilitating buildings in the area.
"After doing a few properties, a lot of people followed," he said. "The area is extremely exciting today," with discount stores operating by day, and a hipper crowd filling new bars and restaurants at night.
He said the old-time merchants along Orchard Street, famous for its bargains, would probably not be able to afford the higher rents that come with new leases.
"The old type of stores, really unfortunately, is dying," Mr. Hoyda said. "They cannot survive. They're still there, but it's a question of time before, unfortunately, they're going to be out of there."
Next door, 94 Orchard Street is in the middle of a gut rehabilitation project. Chris Tomassi, a building management consultant with Brownstone Management, which will be renting out the building, said many owners in the neighborhood are renovating.
"For years they kept them empty, but now that it's profitable for them to rent them, they're doing it," he said. "Many people own them outright, and it pays for them to get construction loans, renovate them top to bottom and turn them into something profitable."
By 1999, 96 Orchard Street's total market value was assessed at $1 million, although the grandmothers of many of the current tenants might shake their heads at the thought.
In January, one loft-style condominium three blocks away from No. 96 sold for $1.1 million. Some nearby studios rent for up to $3,000 a month.
Downstairs at 96 Orchard Street, Cougar Men's Fashions sells shoes made of ostrich belly and alligator skin for up to $1,200. A store manager, who would not give his name, said he regretted not buying the building for $400,000 several years ago, when he had the chance. Now he pays $32,000 a month in rent.
Several of the building's tenants come from families with roots on the Lower East Side. Peter Scalettar, 22, a filmmaker, pays $1,500 for a two-bedroom apartment. "For down here, now, that's good," he said, although he added that his living room had no windows and could get unbelievably hot.
His grandmother was born two blocks to the south in 1927. "She was pretty excited when I moved down here," he said.
His next-door neighbor, Jay Goldberg, 40, said his father had also grown up on the Lower East Side, and was born and raised a couple blocks away.
Another tenant, Deborah Augustine, 30, said she visited the Tenement Museum and was interested to see that its floor plan was identical to No. 96, down to the window, required for ventilation, between the living room and the bedroom.
"I thought it would be really fun to see how eight people lived in a place this big," said Ms. Augustine, a furniture designer. "Now there are just two of us, and we think it's too small."
But more people are eager to try fitting into a neighborhood once known for its crowded masses. A poster on a lamppost outside the building recently described a professional single male, without pets or a roommate, looking for a studio or one-bedroom apartment in the area for up to $1,300 a month. The reward, said a sign punctuated with dollar signs and exclamation points, was $800 in cash.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Yes, America, Clean Air Begins at Home

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The United States is by and large opposed to the most efficient way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions (news article, Nov. 13), through raising prices of carbon-laden fuels. With recent United States Congresses ruling out regulations or efficiency standards, and with no one likely to accept shipping billions of dollars to Russia and Ukraine to buy the emissions rights those countries won't need, the world's greatest emitter doesn't have many options, and the rest of the world knows it. 
 And few believe that by aiding "clean development," America's interests can even account for a few percentage points of its emissions reduction pledge. So the United States must look at its own domestic options carefully.
Cleanliness begins at home, and it's time America's politicians and population were told that. No one has to give up a sport utility vehicle today, but everyone has to think about which vehicle to buy next time, and next time is around the corner.
 
LEE SCHIPPER
Paris, Nov. 13, 2000
 
The writer is an energy economist.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Public Hires Director To Oversee Finances

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Fran Reiter, a former deputy mayor in the Giuliani administration, will become executive director of the Joseph Papp Public Theater today in a move to strengthen the theater's business operations, the Public's chairman said yesterday.
The nonprofit theater and its producer and creative leader, George C. Wolfe, have been criticized in the theater industry for two consecutive expensive Broadway flops, "The Wild Party" and "On the Town." These projects lost about $14 million for the Public. 
 The chairman, Kenneth B. Lerer, said Ms. Reiter's appointment had nothing to do with curbing Mr. Wolfe's spending. Rather, he said, the Public is in the best financial shape in its history, and its $50 million building-improvement plan, which includes the construction of a new 499-seat theater at its Lafayette Street base in the East Village, requires full-time oversight. Mr. Wolfe, he said, needed to be allowed to concentrate on the artistic side of the operation: producing and directing.
"The goal was to free George to do what he really wants to do: he wants to produce and he wants to direct," Mr. Lerer said. "This lets him do that. We won't succeed at this next long-range plan unless we have someone like Fran Reiter in house. It's just too much."
Mr. Wolfe, in his eighth year at the Public, said he welcomed the help. "I think it's great," he said. "It makes it easier for me to do what I do and at the same time allows the institution to grow."
As to whether he felt his degree of control had been compromised, Mr. Wolfe said: "I don't feel diminished. As a matter of fact, I feel enhanced by the possibilities."
Founded by Joseph Papp in 1966, the Public Theater has been a leading cultural center in New York City, prominent not only for generating commercial hits like "A Chorus Line" under Mr. Papp and "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk" under Mr. Wolfe, but also for advancing the work of voices that might otherwise remain marginal.
Recently many theater devotees and professionals have expressed disappointment in the Public's offerings, arguing that under Mr. Wolfe the theater has generated few exciting projects and too often left some of its five theaters dark.
The Public's board has stood by Mr. Wolfe. When "Wild Party" was losing money on Broadway, the Public put up an additional $1.1 million to keep it running, although Mr. Lerer also put three board members in charge of overseeing the show's finances.
Mr. Lerer would not disclose Ms. Reiter's salary but said it was close to Mr. Wolfe's, which is $210,000. She will focus on finance, development and fund-raising, marketing, capital projects and board relations, Mr. Lerer said. Although she was selected after a yearlong search, Mr. Lerer said, Ms. Reiter was his first choice. "She has great business experience, she has great City Hall experience, and she has great political experience, and she has great theater experience," he said. "She had all the characteristics of the person we needed."
In her three years as deputy mayor for economic development and planning and for community relations and planning, Ms. Reiter, 46, got high marks for helping the city's cultural institutions.
"She was an absolute soldier," said Gordon J. Davis, the new president of Lincoln Center Inc. and a member of the Public's board.
Ms. Reiter then served for 19 months as president and chief executive officer of NYC & Company, formerly known as the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.
She left that post to explore a bid for the mayoralty in 2001, a move she decided against last winter. She runs her own consulting firm through which she recently served for three months as interim chief executive of the Dance Theater of Harlem.
Although Ms. Reiter has not worked in the theater recently, it was her focus earlier in life, she said. Growing up in the East Village, she regularly attended productions at the Public.
She majored in drama at the High School of Performing Arts, attended Boston University's School of Fine Arts as a directing major and went on to work as a director and stage manager at regional, summer stock and Off Off Broadway theaters. Her new job, she said, "represented the opportunity for me to go back to something that I loved."
When asked how she viewed the Public's last two experiences on Broadway, Ms. Reiter said she respected its decisions.
"If either of those productions had been big hits, George would have been a genius," she said. "Whatever process they went through, I don't think it's going to change any. Some of the things we do will be financially successful, some of them won't."
Despite the forceful hand of Mr. Wolfe at the Public -- and the fact that Mr. Wolfe's previous business counterparts have not lasted long, though they were not invested with comparable authority -- Ms. Reiter said she was not concerned about his ability to share power.
"I have the highest regard for him as an artist," she said, "and to be partners with him is a great opportunity."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Barth Healey

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: AMERICAN LOSES COURT ROUND -- A court rejected an appeal by an American accused of spying to call additional experts to determine whether documents about torpedoes that he received were top secret, as prosecutors allege. The American, Edmond Pope, was arrested in April and charged with trying illegally to obtain plans for the torpedo. He says the information had already been sold abroad. (Associated Press) 

MONTENEGRO: YUGOSLAV CURRENCY DROPPED -- Montenegro, Serbia's partner in the Yugoslav Federation, abolished the dinar as legal tender and replaced it fully with the German mark, thus ending the dual currency system started on Nov. 1, 1999. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
GERMANY: PROTEST OVER EXECUTIONS IN U.S. -- Germany called on the International Court of Justice to rule that the United States had violated international accords by executing two German brothers in 1999. Karl and Walter LaGrand were condemned to death in 1984 for killing a bank manager in Arizona in 1982. Germany accuses the United States of violating the 1963 Vienna Convention by not informing the brothers of their right to consular assistance when they were arrested. A verdict is expected within four months. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
TURKEY: PLAN FOR CYPRUS REJECTED -- Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit rejected an appeal by the European Union that Turkey support a United Nations proposal to resolve the dispute over divided Cyprus. In its blueprint for opening membership talks, the Union suggested last week that Turkey back the plan, which calls for a two-zone federation, a central administration and greater integration between the Greek and Turkish sides. Turkey and Turkish Cypriots favor a confederation with far less integration. Mr. Ecevit said Turkey would not accept a link between Cyprus and membership in the European Union. Douglas Frantz (NYT)
 
EUROPEAN UNION: 'MAD COW' TESTS -- The European Commission wants to test all beef cattle in the European Union above a certain age for "mad cow" disease before they are sent to slaughter, and has called a meeting with veterinary experts tomorrow to fix the details. The Commission is expected to cover up to half the cost, about $65 a head, said a Commission spokeswoman, Beate Gminder. Paul Meller (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: S-H-H-H-H -- Queen Elizabeth II has ordered her staff not to carry mobile phones, Buckingham Palace announced. "No one wants phones going off during a banquet," a spokesman said. Only staff members who must have mobiles, like press officers, will be allowed to have them. There was no response to a question whether the queen has her own mobile phone. (Reuters)

ZIMBABWE: BLACKS MOVED ONTO WHITES' FARMS -- Government officials moved thousands of landless blacks onto white-owned farms over the weekend, despite a Supreme Court order banning the resettling. The woman and three relatives in Masindi have died, raising the toll since mid-October to 110. The earlier oubreaks were in Gulu, 225 miles north of Kampala, and Mbarara, 175 miles southwest of Kampala. Masindi is on the Nile, 100 miles south of Gulu. (Associated Press)

The constitutional court ruled in 1998 that Mr. Akayev was eligible to run again last month because the Constitution was adopted after his first election. (Agence France-Presse)

In one completed Saturday of 1,050 Canadians, support of the Liberal Party of Prime Minister Jean Chretien fell to 40 percent, while support for the Alliance party of Stockwell Day rose to 28 percent. James Brooke (NYT)

HEADLINE: Philippine Congress Impeaches President on Graft Charges

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Without a formal vote, President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines was impeached by his country's House of Representatives today on corruption charges centering on millions of dollars in payoffs from illegal gambling.
The bill of impeachment now goes to the Senate, where wavering members are sampling the political winds in advance of a trial that could end in Mr. Estrada's removal from office. 
 To shouts of protest from Mr. Estrada's supporters, witnesses said, House Speaker Manuel Villar asserted that no vote was necessary because more than the required one-third of the 218 House members had already signed a petition supporting impeachment.
"It's official now that the impeachment rap is with the Senate," Mr. Villar said after gaveling it through. "We have indicted the president."
Mr. Estrada is the first Philippine president to be impeached, though impeachment motions have been raised unsuccessfully against others. Removing him from office requires a two-thirds vote of the 22-member Senate.
The Senate trial promises to be lurid, with plans to call a variety of Mr. Estrada's cronies and possibly some of his mistresses, whose homes he is said to have acquired through questionable means.
He has reacted to the charges by rallying his base, the poor majority of Filipinos, playing once again the role that made him a heartthrob as a movie actor: the simple, scrappy guy who faces down the powerful elite.
"My conscience is clear," he said today in a nationwide radio broadcast shortly before the House acted. "I did not become president to rake in money."
He was impeached on four charges involving bribery, corruption, betrayal of public trust and culpable violation of the Constitution.
They grew out of allegations by a provincial governor who is a crony of the president that Mr. Estrada accepted nearly $11 million in payoffs from illegal gambling as well as a cut of provincial tobacco taxes.
Mr. Estrada repeated today his assertion that he had not received "a single centavo" from illegal gambling. Last week he did acknowledge that he had been offered what he called a $4 million bribe from the governor, Luis Singson, but he insisted that he had refused it.
After the initial accusations a month ago, Mr. Estrada has come under intense pressure to resign. The powerful Catholic Church and much of the business community have called on him to step down, and key members of his party in the House and the Senate have turned against him.
His opponents -- including his two immediate predecessors, Fidel V. Ramos and Corazon C. Aquino -- have held huge rallies calling for his ouster. A coalition of his opponents, ranging from millitant labor unions to mainstream business associations, scheduled a nationwide general strike for Tuesday.
In his radio address today, Mr. Estrada sounded like a man pursued by a pack of hounds. "I appeal to you not to go through with it," he said of the strike. "We have a crisis. Let's join hands and pull out of this, for the sake of the nation."
But as a barometer of the national mood, the stock market and the currency do not favor the president. Whenever word passes around that he might step down, the market and the currency strengthen; when it seems that he will hang tough, they plummet.
When he dug in his heels two weeks ago, the peso fell to an all-time low of 51.95 to the dollar. Today, as it appeared that the impeachment battle might drag on for weeks or months, the stock market sagged by 2.2 percent.
That volatility grows out of a mounting unhappiness with Mr. Estrada, who is seen to have allowed the economic gains of the Ramos administration to slip away. Among investors and businessmen, the Estrada administration has acquired a reputation for mismanagement, corruption and cronyism.
Political analysts in Manila said Mr. Singson's allegations might not have gained momentum if they had not underscored a growing sense of dismay over Mr. Estrada's leadership.
"It's been building up," said Paulynn P. Sicam, editor in chief of an online newsmagazine called Dyaryo. "I think mainly it's shame. It's terrible when your moral standards begin to accommodate this person's lifestyle. We've lowered our standards of propriety and morality till we realize we've been wallowing in it. It just feels so dirty. This has got to stop."
Still thrilled by their "people power" ouster of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1986, many Filipinos are working energetically to recreate the passionate political theater of their great moment.
Before the House session today, opposition congressmen prayed and lit candles near a Philippine flag. They wore peach-colored ribbons on their shirts signifying, naturally, "impeachment."
Mr. Estrada's fall has been precipitous. In May 1998 he was elected by one of the largest margins of any president in history. But his support came largely from the poor, who loved his persona as a tough man of the people when he was an actor in cheap popular movies.
The political and business elite was mortified by the image of a shambling, mumbling, confessed drinker and womanizer who looked less like a president than, indeed, like an actor in cheap movies.
What the Philippines saw was what it got as president -- a lackadaisical leader with little interest in economic management, famous for his karaoke-style "midnight cabinet" meetings and his late-morning arrivals at his office.
It is said that when a group of business leaders held a luncheon for Mr. Estrada soon after his election, he asked to see the kitchen staff, saying he wanted to meet some people who had actually voted for him.
His accuser, Mr. Singson, was a participant in the president's happy hours, where among other things Mr. Estrada recently admitted that they had played mah-jongg for millions of pesos.
An illegal gambling lord himself, Mr. Singson said he had turned on the president when he was cut out of the profits of a new legalized form of gambling. He cheerfully asserted that he was part of a falling-out of thieves.
Mr. Singson presented a Senate hearing with lists of payoffs that he said he had made to Mr. Estrada and members of the president's family. Those included $8.6 million in profits from an illegal but highly popular numbers game called jueteng, as well as $2.8 million in provincial tobacco taxes.
Despite the public clamor for Mr. Estrada's removal, preparations are under way for a hard-fought battle in the Senate. Mr. Estrada's allies still hold majorities in both houses, and they moved today to replace the House speaker and the Senate president, who broke ranks a week ago.
Mr. Singson said today that he felt vindicated by the impeachment. "If President Estrada is ousted, I want it to serve as a lesson to all public officials," he said.
That might possibly include himself.
When asked recently whether he might be incriminating himself with his testimony about Mr. Estrada, he said, "It would be an honor to go to prison with the president."
