SECTION: Section B; Page 16; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 1570 words

HEADLINE: Dot-Coms Intrude in the Land of Needle and Thread

BYLINE: By GUY TREBAY 

 BODY:
Jack Ratusch knew something was amiss when he ran into his friend the button man, prowling Midtown with a real estate agent. Bad news is often no news in the garment business. But Mr. Ratusch, who is president of the Garment Center Congregation, a conservative synagogue on West 40th Street, has been around the rag trade for more than 50 years. That's long enough to know that while coat men come and go and better dresses can be fly-by-night, buttons are forever. Or at least they used to be.
"I asked him, 'What are you doing walking around?' " Mr. Ratusch said. "He explained, 'I'm paying $10 a square foot all these years and now the landlord wants $35. I can't pay that kind of money on buttons.' I asked what happened. And he said, 'You know who's coming? The dot-coms. There's no protection anymore.' " 
 Small guys are the garment center's mine canaries -- button vendors in shoe-box showrooms, jobbers in upstairs lofts, street-level retailers who make a living selling the amazing stuff that doesn't merely clothe the world, but keeps it from looking dowdy. According to local wisdom, if the small guys fall, the end is near. And while it's been evident for some time that the garment center's hold on its precious chunk of Midtown was shaky, the district now seems increasingly tenuous, threatened by manufacturing trends favoring offshore labor, the successful redevelopment of Times Square, the planned renovation of the 34th Street corridor and an influx of advertising agencies and Internet companies drawn to loftlike industrial spaces and rents that, in relative terms, are cheap.
Although the garment industry remains the city's largest industrial job source, both its manufacturing and employment figures are down considerably. Citywide, employment in the apparel and textile portion of the industry has fallen to 78,200, according to the Labor Department, well below a 1991 total of 104,415. More alarming, perhaps, are figures indicating that fashion industry employment now represents, for the first time in the area's history, less than half the overall jobs in the center's core.
What is that core? Roughly, it extends from Ninth to Fifth Avenue, from 34th to 42nd Street, with the densest concentration between 37th and 40th Streets, Seventh to Eighth. The actual area is somewhat larger, however, and extends beyond any boundaries demarcated by ZIP code or census blocks. One good way to characterize the area is the simplest: you know it when you're in it. It is a cultural geography whose landmarks are street-level windows crammed with shoulder pads or bridal lace or buckram hat forms or dress dummies. Like notches in a cliff wall, the layered strata of immigration and labor history are revealed along its streets.
"So many people trace their roots in this country back to someone who started in that industry," said Linda Dworak, executive director of the Garment Industry Development Corporation, a nonprofit consortium of business, government and labor. Even today, the garment center is the portal to the work force for immigrants and working women, mainly from Asia and the Caribbean basin. "If those jobs disappeared," Ms. Dworak said, "I don't know where those people will get work."
With the jobs go the traditional kosher dairy restaurants, the immense cafeterias like Dubrow's, the tony, members-only dining rooms like the 500 Club. The button and trimmings wholesalers, too, are fast disappearing. Even houses of worship have been affected, like the Millinery Center Synagogue on Sixth Avenue, which was once so well attended that workers scheduled their arrival in shifts. "This you wouldn't believe," said Edward Ginsburg, president of the William N. Ginsburg Company, a 75-year-old novelty trim and braid company on West 38th Street. "They're selling bed sheets now in front of that synagogue."
It was not long ago that "there were no trendy retail ground-floor restaurants," said Susan Cowell, vice president of the Union of Needletrades, or Unite. "It was just garmento places." Those were the days when a side-street takeout order was more likely to be a corned beef sandwich and an egg cream than a Kathleen's cookie with a double mocha skim latte (no foam.) "The culture is vulnerable," said Ms. Cowell, referring not just to the district's traditionally Jewish and Italian immigrants, but to the Chinese and Korean Americans who followed them. "The people are vulnerable."
Just how vulnerable is made plain in the locutions of property brokers. "We talk about it as a new garment center," said Faith Hope Consolo, vice chairman of Garrick-Aug Associates, a commercial leasing firm. Characterizing the old garment center as "rinky-dink, run-down and ugly," Ms. Consolo said, "The whole profile has changed out there." In an area that had been a real estate "black hole," its street-side trade characterized by immigrant shoppers, hot-dog stands and menacing garment racks, Ms. Consolo now points to the arrival of global advertising firms like Bates USA, which occupies five floors at 498 Seventh Avenue. She says businesses not related to fashion will give the area a "new face." A new name, too, may be in the offing. Some newcomers, eager to shed the old label, have already begun to call the western edge of the district NEChe -- pronounced NEECH-ee -- for Northeast Corner of Chelsea.
"All these things conspire," said Eric Hertz, executive director of the Fashion Association, a trade group. "There's a tremendous amount of consolidation of large organizations. The business is decentralized. The smaller manufacturers don't have the resources. It's a very, very different business from what it was 20 or 30 years ago. A little trimmings guy can't hold out against a high-tech company."
Despite rarely enforced zoning regulations enacted in 1987 to protect the garment center by restricting space conversions on side streets from apparel to other uses, the reality, said Ms. Cowell of the garment workers' union, is that virtually any national corporation "is paying a lot more than showrooms can pay."
"It would be disastrous for the apparel industry if it disappeared as a center," she added. "Buyers come from all over the world. And it's not one buyer, it's a thousand buyers."
Mel Cohen, president of B&J Fabrics, a bustling three-story emporium that has been on West 40th Street for the last 42 years, said: "A lot of these dot-com people come from higher-rent areas and drive out our people. And they don't relate to our industry at all."
"You can special-zone something," Mr. Cohen added, "but if people who are going to remain can't afford to pay the rents, how can you keep them there?"
The desire to maintain unified business precincts is not merely a matter of nostalgia. Garment manufacturing continues to generate an estimated $9 billion for the local economy. Although many manufacturing jobs have been relocated to the outer boroughs, the garment center remains a hub. As in the meat-packing district, Wall Street or the diamond district, being close to related businesses serves a number of subtle functions. "It's a tremendously efficient way to operate," said Adam Friedman, executive director of the New York Industrial Retention Network, a citywide nonprofit group. "There are all kinds of competitive advantages that industry enjoys when production, sales and design are clustered."
Those advantages, Mr. Friedman pointed out, are not lost on the arrivals to Silicon Alley, who, despite being in the business of universal access to information, he said, "make it their first initiative to gather in a single neighborhood."
Essentially, Mr. Friedman said, the dot-com people reap the same benefits from proximity that the garment district types have always enjoyed: "You run into someone," he said, "and find out what's happening that's plaid this year."
An unreleased study conducted by the New York Industrial Retention Network and Unite suggests that while part of the garment center remains intact, the nature of the district is, as Mr. Friedman said, "down to the core." That core still accounts for more jobs than Youngstown and Akron, Ohio, combined, even after three decades of competition from foreign manufacturers. Yet the strongest threat to the garment center doesn't originate offshore. "It's real estate pressure," Mr. Friedman said.
When Mark G. Rubin's father opened an Eighth Avenue branch of Arnold Hatters, a retail chain, in 1960, no bareheaded gent in any profession could consider himself properly dressed. The natty types in the garment center were especially good customers for hats. A time traveler from the Eisenhower era would still find plenty of finery with which to attire himself at Arnold Hatters, which is on Eighth Avenue at 41st Street. Next to the popular Kangol caps in the windows sit derbys and such Fred and Ginger anachronisms as collapsible silk toppers. But the bulk of the store's customers, said Mr. Rubin, are from the theater.
"People don't wear hats like they used to," said Mr. Rubin, 29, who has worked at the store since he was 12. Even dedicated clients have been forced to move on under pressures that, in their own way, are not unrelated to the forces of real estate. "I miss the pimps from the old Times Square," Mr. Rubin said, surveying a display of leopard-print borsalinos and burnt-orange bowlers. "I mean, who else wears a hat like that?"

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Regain Most Losses On Late Buying

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The tug of war between bears and bulls intensified yesterday as financial markets plunged early on fears of slowing economic growth before regaining most of their losses on late-day buying from investors seeking value in beaten-down stocks.
For the fourth consecutive session, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index led the markets lower, falling 62.27 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,966.72. The Nasdaq ended the day below 3,000 for the first time since Nov. 2, 1999. 
 Other indexes also slid. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 14.72 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,351.26. The Dow Jones industrial average, hurt by a drop in Hewlett-Packard, which reported lower-than-expected earnings, fell 85.70 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,517.25. Hewlett-Packard fell $4.44, to close at $34.81.
After five years of strong growth and little inflation, the United States economy has cooled drastically since the summer, and further slowing is possible if consumers rein in their spending in response to the stock market's decline. Skeptics warn that the average public company may show little or no growth in earnings next year, shocking investors and analysts, who are expecting profit gains of 12 percent.
"We're getting what we asked for, which is a slowing of worldwide economic growth," said Duncan W. Richardson, who runs the $7 billion Eaton Vance Tax-Managed Growth Fund. "If the world slows, the best companies in the world must slow relative to expectations."
Mr. Richardson said he expected that technology stocks would remain extremely volatile over the next year and that the Nasdaq could fall as low as 2,000 or rise as high as 4,000. He noted that optical networking companies, which have fallen furiously since September but remain very expensive by all historical measures, "could be cut in half and still be expensive."
Indeed, many technology companies seesawed 5 percent or more yesterday. The optical equipment maker Juniper Networks ranged from $154.50 to $179 before closing at $164.55, a loss of $6.39, while Cisco Systems traded as high as $52.38 and as low as $48 before closing at $50.38, a 31-cent gain. Dell Computer ranged from $22.38 to $25.47 and closed at $24.13, a $1.13 gain.
But bulls counter that many nontechnology stocks are already depressed and have room to rise. Many leading companies are trading at less than 15 times their expected 2000 earnings, with Chevron trading at 11 times earnings, Bank of America at 9 times earnings, and Goldman Sachs at 14 times earnings. Although information technology companies are still expensive, even they are more reasonably priced after the 40 percent decline in the Nasdaq since March, bulls say.
"For the first time in a while, we're buying some tech stocks," said Doug Phillips, president and chief executive of Trusco Capital Management, which is based in Atlanta and manages $50 billion. Mr. Phillips said he believed that the Federal Reserve had managed a "soft landing," slowing growth and the risk of inflation without sending the economy into recession.
Now, with inflation under control, the Fed has the flexibility to cut short-term interest rates and bolster the economy and corporate profits, which will help stocks, Mr. Phillips said. "The next step by the Fed is to reduce rates, rather than raise them," he said.
Michael Strauss, managing director for Commonfund, which manages $25 billion, said he was cautiously optimistic. Mr. Strauss expects the United States economy to grow 3 percent next year, corporate profits to rise 7 to 9 percent, and the Federal Reserve to begin lowering interest rates by mid-2001. Under those circumstances, stocks should perform solidly next year, he said.
But if that economic growth does not come, the market's rocky ride could continue into 2001, Mr. Strauss said. Though the S.& P. 500 has fallen 8 percent this year, it still trades at about 23 times expected earnings for 2000, well above historical averages. "The market still isn't cheap by historical standards, if you're worried about the momentum of the economy," he said.
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the Pittsburgh-based PNC Financial Services Group, which manages $230 billion, said he thought that economic growth next year would be the lowest since 1996 but that the risk of a recession was low. The Federal Reserve will act quickly to lower interest rates if the economy loses too much momentum, he said.
Under those circumstances, the S.& P. 500 is "perhaps below fair value," Mr. Hoffman said.

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Most bonds rose yesterday as the unresolved presidential election drove investors to the haven of government securities.
"You have the equity market taking a long walk off a short pier and that's traditionally when people will load up with Treasuries," said Mitch Stapley, who invests the $3.5 billion in fixed-income assets at the Kent Funds in Grand Rapids, Mich.
The price of the 10-year note rose 7/32 , to 99 31/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.75 percent from 5.78 percent on Friday. The 30-year bond rose 15/32 , to 105 27/32 . Its yield fell to 5.83 percent from 5.87 percent.

HEADLINE: Expanded Logging Ban Is Proposed for National Forests

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Forest Service recommended today that President Clinton expand the scope of a planned environmental initiative by banning virtually all commercial logging from the remaining roadless areas of the national forests.
The new proposal would extend that ban even to the Tongass National Forest in Alaska, which is the nation's largest national forest but had been exempted from a draft proposal made public last May. Altogether, it would broaden what was drafted as a ban on road building alone to put a total of 54 million acres of national forest off limits to all but extraordinary timber sales. 
 The revised approach, which now awaits Mr. Clinton's approval, follows the more ambitious outline that Vice President Al Gore spelled out in his presidential campaign as the surest way to protect public lands from development. It runs sharply counter to the approach advocated by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who had criticized the administration's initial blueprint as an excessive use of federal power.
Mr. Clinton vowed last year to make the protection of the roadless areas his most important public-lands legacy, and environmentalists who had criticized the earlier draft plan said today that the new proposal came closer to making good on that vision.
"This is a real breakthrough, and it moves a long way toward delivering on the historic promise that the president delivered a year ago," said Nathaniel Lawrence, director of the forest project for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group.
Altogether, the new proposal would extend a ban on road building and virtually all logging to more than 58 million acres of national forest, about 30 percent of the total. The earlier plan, which excluded the Tongass, had covered 43 million acres.
Although the plan would allow some logging under narrow circumstances, administration officials said that if put into effect, it would bring about a 93 percent reduction in timber sales within roadless areas from the level now anticipated.
Most of the prohibitions would take effect immediately if Mr. Clinton accepts the Forest Service proposal. Under the plan, however, the restrictions on the Tongass would not be imposed until 2004, in a bow to pressures from Alaska's congressional delegation and others who have said a continuation of logging there is vital to the region's economy.
In a further effort at conciliation, the Forest Service plan calls for $13 million to $20 million in spending over the next four years to create jobs and industries in Alaskan communities that now depend heavily on timber operations in the Tongass forest.
Matt Zencey, director of the Alaska Rainforest Campaign, criticized the proposed four-year phase-in period for the Tongass forest and warned that the delay would allow Alaska Republicans and a potential Bush administration to scuttle any protection for the forest.
"There still is no good reason to discriminate against the nation's largest national forest and deny it full protection," Mr. Zencey said.
The revision of the Forest Service plan comes after a public comment period that included some 300 public meetings and generated more than 1.5 million letters and pieces of electronic mail in response to the initial proposal. The timber industry and loggers have taken a strong stand against the initiative, but administration officials have said the overwhelming public reaction has been positive.
Ken Rait, who as director of the Heritage Forests Campaign has been a leader in pressing for broader protection for roadless areas, said today that the Forest Service had moved "toward a common sense and responsible policy of wild forest protection."
But Mr. Rait and other environmental activists also said any final policy must include strict limits on what kinds of logging might be allowed under the loophole proposed by the Forest Service, which could allow timber to be cut in roadless areas for fire prevention and other "stewardship" purposes.

HEADLINE: Rise in Health Care Costs Rests Largely on Drug Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Prescription drugs accounted for 44 percent of the increase in health costs last year, researchers said today.
In a report published in the journal Health Affairs, the researchers said overall health costs for services covered by private insurance rose by 6.6 percent last year, while drug spending increased by 18.4 percent. The study did not separately examine costs for people without insurance. 
 Paul B. Ginsburg, an author of the report, said prescription drugs accounted for more of the 6.6 percent increase in health costs than either hospital care or doctors' services.
"Drug spending is growing much faster than other components of health care," said Mr. Ginsburg, an economist who is president of the Center for Studying Health System Change, a private research institute. "Drug costs are having a bigger and bigger effect on overall health costs."
Inflation is back after several years of low growth in health insurance premiums, said Mr. Ginsburg, a former director of health care studies at the Congressional Budget Office. The higher premiums mean higher costs for employers and, in many cases, for employees, he said.
Another author of the report, Jon R. Gabel, said the resurgence of health care costs was alarming.
"It appeared that health costs were under control from 1993 to 1997, and even into 1998," said Mr. Gabel, a vice president of the Health Research and Educational Trust, a nonprofit group affiliated with the American Hospital Association. Christopher Hogan, a health policy researcher, helped write the report.
Judith H. Bello, executive vice president of Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, said she had not read the study and could not comment. But she insisted, "Prescription drugs are often the most effective and least costly way" of treating an illness.
The rise in prescription drug costs has stimulated interest in proposals to rein in drug prices or add drug benefits to Medicare, the federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled.
Representative Tom Allen, Democrat of Maine, has introduced a bill that he said would make prescription drugs available to Medicare beneficiaries at the prices negotiated by large government purchasers like the Department of Veterans Affairs.
Mr. Allen and other Democrats complain that elderly people often must pay far more for prescription drugs than do the drug companies' most favored customers, like health maintenance organizations.
But a federal appeals court last week upheld the right of pharmacies to charge higher prices for drugs sold to people who are uninsured.
The decision, by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, involved Rite Aid drugstores in Alabama. The court said that retail pharmacies had no duty to disclose whether they charged higher prices to uninsured consumers than to insured customers. It said such disparities did not constitute fraud and did not violate the law.
"Variable pricing is the norm in many industries," said the opinion, by Judge Charles R. Wilson. "Airlines frequently charge different groups of consumers different rates for the same seat, hotels often charge different rates to different consumers for the same room and car dealerships sell identical vehicles for a variety of prices, depending upon the identity (and savvy) of the consumer."
The report in Health Affairs said that about one-third of the increase in drug spending last year was attributable to higher prices. The remainder, it said, was attributable to a higher volume of sales, reflecting the advent of new medicines and the increased use of existing drugs.
While prescription drugs accounted for 44 percent of the increase in health costs last year, the report said, doctors' services accounted for 32 percent, and outpatient hospital care accounted for 21 percent, while inpatient hospital care was responsible for only 3 percent.
Spending at hospital outpatient clinics grew "at a consistently high rate throughout the 1990's," the report said. By contrast, it said, per capita spending for inpatient services declined in 5 of the last 10 years.
"The period from 1994 to 1998 was a time of record-low rates of growth in health insurance premiums and in the underlying medical expenses that are covered," the article said.
The premium for a typical private health insurance plan grew an average of 2 percent a year from 1994 to 1998 -- less than the increase in per capita gross domestic product, the output of goods and services, the authors said. Premiums this year rose an average of 8.3 percent for all businesses and 7.5 percent for companies with 200 or more workers.

HEADLINE: A Nascent Internet Takes Root in Vietnam;
Gleaning Lessons Of What Is Called The 'People's War'

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
Ask Truong Gia Binh whom he looks to for inspiration in running Vietnam's largest technology company, and he doesn't name William H. Gates, Steve Jobs or any other Silicon Valley warrior.
Mr. Binh instead cites some real warriors -- the retired Vietnamese army generals who vanquished France and the United States in two of the 20th century's most remarkable military victories. 
 His perspective is a personal one: Mr. Binh, 44, is the son-in-law of Vo Nguyen Giap, a confidant of Ho Chi Minh and the general who masterminded Vietnam's campaigns against the French and the Americans.
"Business and war have different objectives," Mr. Binh said, "but the North Vietnamese army has much to teach software developers. We're applying the lessons of the People's War to the computer business."
At the moment, Mr. Binh's company, the Corporation for Financing and Promoting Technology, has just 750 employees, $50 million in sales, and is controlled by the Ministry of Science and Technology. Like other companies in emerging markets, F.P.T. began in outsourcing -- pumping out software for clients like the International Business Machines Corporation and Olivetti of Italy.
By harnessing the principles of guerrilla warfare -- among those used in Vietnam, nimble versatility in the face of a more powerful opponent and the willingness to endure a long struggle -- Mr. Binh hopes to transform F.P.T. into a diversified technology company that produces its own software, installs and maintains computer networks and provides Internet access, as well as online programming.
Jumping up from his seat to illustrate this novel management theory on an erasable markerboard, Mr. Binh seems utterly at ease -- even enthusiastic -- in drawing parallels between the new economy and an old war. But his comments would raise almost as many eyebrows here as in the United States.
Twenty-five years after North Vietnamese troops marched into Saigon, people speak little about the Vietnam War, or as it known here, the People's War. It is rarer still to hear such talk from the relative of a former official, particularly one in a business as future-oriented as technology.
To be sure, many sons and sons-in-law of Communist Party and military leaders have emerged as business leaders in postwar Vietnam. But most of these "princelings" say little about their forebears, even if these family ties are responsible for much of their success.
Of his father-in-law, however, Mr. Binh says: "I learned so much from him. That was a huge advantage for me."
People who know Mr. Binh said his candor reflected a self-confidence not unlike that of General Giap. They say he also has an unswerving belief that F.P.T. will become Vietnam's first global technology player.
"He's the only Vietnamese businessman I know of who thinks in those terms," said Greig Craft, an American entrepreneur who has lived in Hanoi for 11 years. "He's ambitious, and he doesn't hide it."
The most obvious sign of his ambition is in Vietnam's nascent Internet business. In 1997, the Vietnamese government granted F.P.T. one of five licenses to sell Internet access to businesses and consumers. Today it is Vietnam's second-largest and fastest-growing Internet service provider, with 30,000 subscribers, almost one-third of the country's minuscule market.
With aggressive marketing, solicitous service and discounts for students, Mr. Binh has transformed F.P.T. into one of Vietnam's few genuine brand names. Next to the stodgy Internet service provider owned by the Vietnam Post and Telecommunications Corporation, F.P.T. seems positively user friendly.
Mr. Binh hopes to burnish that image by hiring 25 people to produce news, sports and entertainment for the Web. If the Vietnamese government were to relax its curbs on the Internet, Mr. Binh said his annual growth in subscribers would jump from its current rate of 40 percent to 70 percent.
That is a big if. Like their counterparts in China, Vietnamese officials view the Internet as an unruly child in need of discipline. While Vietnam has licensed five Internet service providers, the government allows only the Vietnam Post and Telecommunications Corporation to connect the country to the outside world.
This allows the state to monitor -- and often restrict -- data traffic for political, social or cultural reasons. Through a system of firewalls, Hanoi blocks access to sites that it deems subversive.
The tight grip of the Post and Telecommunications Corporation also makes Internet access expensive and slow. The single international connection, with a capacity of 15 to 20 megabits a second, is shared by all 100,000 Internet users, which translates into glacial transmission speeds during peak times.
And because of its monopoly on international traffic, the Post and Telecommunications Corporation charges the other four Internet access providers high monthly rates for leased lines, fees that they pass on to users. The hourly access rates of 86 cents to $1.71, in a country with an annual per capita gross domestic product of $350, put the Internet out of reach of most of the population.
At the Emotion, an Internet cafe in Hanoi that was originally backed by Mr. Binh, the clientele on a recent afternoon consisted mainly of expatriates and Western tourists who were checking their messages from home. A few local customers logged on for some hurried moments to check for e-mail.
"To most Vietnamese, it is too expensive to do anything more than that," said Do Kim Linh, a 26-year-old teacher who considers herself lucky that she can afford to go online for about 20 minutes a day.
The combination of high prices and slow transmission speeds has kept the Internet a novelty in Vietnam. With a population of 79 million and barely 100,000 users, the penetration rate lags far behind that of China or Indonesia, let alone that of more developed neighbors like Thailand or Malaysia.
Government officials defend the high costs, saying the Post and Telecommunications Corporation had to invest heavily to wire the country. But even they acknowledge that the growth of the Internet here has been sluggish.
"In the Western world, the Internet developed without regulation," said Tran Quang Cuong, policy director of the Ministry of Post and Telecommunications. "In my country, the Internet is regulated from the top down."
Still, Mr. Cuong said Hanoi was determined to lift Vietnam's Internet penetration, now about 0.1 percent, to the global average by 2010. Given that Vietnam presumes that this figure will be 10 percent, Mr. Cuong acknowledged it would be a huge stretch. To reach for that lofty goal, he said the state may license additional private Internet service providers, as well as allow other companies to establish international connections.
Some issues might be forced by a trade agreement that Vietnam and the United States signed in July, but that Congress has yet to ratify. Under the terms of the deal, American phone companies will be allowed into the Vietnamese market, starting three years after it takes effect.
For his part, Mr. Binh said he had detected a shift in the state's attitude toward the Internet, even in the last month.
"The government is starting to talk about the new economy, starting to talk about software development," he said. "They view the Internet as a powerful tool to lead Vietnam into the new economy."
But Mr. Binh is a realist. He says he thinks it will be another three years before the state throws off enough fetters to allow the Internet to flourish. In the meantime, he will grind away at his outsourcing business.
Patience is a virtue born of necessity for Vietnamese of Mr. Binh's generation. His own journey into business began in 1985, when he returned to Hanoi after earning a Ph.D. in mathematics and physics in Moscow. Mr. Binh said he and several friends wanted to start a company, but at the time Vietnam was in ruins economically. They had no money, no office and no prospects.
"All we had was a room to sit together and drink tea," Mr. Binh said, laughing ruefully at the memory.
In 1988, however, his family connections paid off. Mr. Binh won a coveted government stamp, which permitted him to start a company. He wanted to break into high technology, though he was not sure what kind of technology to pursue. At the time, the government was heavily focused on agriculture. A senior official suggested that Mr. Binh call his company Food Processing Technology, or F.P.T.
Mr. Binh quickly refocused F.P.T. on computers, winning a contract in 1990 to build a reservations network for Vietnam Airlines. Soon, F.P.T. had won an outsourcing contract from Olivetti of Italy. When President Clinton lifted the United States trade embargo on Vietnam in 1996, his company signed a deal with I.B.M.
Today, F.P.T. accounts for 20 percent of Vietnam's information technology market. Mr. Binh is scouting for an office in the United States. By 2002, he said the government would privatize the company. And in two years, Mr. Binh hopes his company will be listed on the stock exchange in Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon.
Despite his country's meager resources, Mr. Binh is convinced that F.P.T. will be able to take on much larger global companies. This is where he draws on the example of the North Vietnamese Army. Noting that the North Vietnamese were badly outgunned by the Americans, Mr. Binh said the Vietnamese responded to the superior force with flexibility, agility and adaptability.
Mr. Binh has invited several retired generals, though not his father-in-law, to speak to his employees on the importance of these qualities -- as well as having unanimity of purpose -- in dealing with larger rivals.
Striding to the markerboard, Mr. Binh drew a matrix with the North Vietnamese Army and the present-day American economy in one column, and the Vietnam-era United States Army and the present-day Vietnamese economy in the other.
"The U.S. economy is like the Vietnamese military was during the war," he said. "And the Vietnamese economy is like the U.S. military."
Far from forgetting Vietnam's war-torn past, Mr. Binh says he believes his country's future depends on embracing it.

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 888 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Remaking Baseball Diamonds in the Rough

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
SHOCKED and outraged!" shouts Richard A. Kahan, shirt sleeves rolled up above his elbows as if there's manual labor that needs doing, as he competes with the rush hour din emoting upward from Madison Avenue into his donated office space at the Loews Corporation. "I couldn't have lived without baseball. No kid should have to," adds Mr. Kahan, 54, who has appointed himself official restorer of New York City's diamonds -- public school baseball diamonds, that is.
What has rendered Mr. Kahan, president of the Urban Assembly and former chief executive officer of the New York State Urban Development Corporation shocked and outraged is the nightmarish condition of the city's public school playing fields. Football fields with pothole-size divots. Baseball diamonds decomposing into the landfills that they were built on. Swimming pools with gang graffiti where the water ought to be. Zero dollars in the budget for fixing the woebegone fields at 50 city schools. 
 He gets red in the face just thinking about it. And inspired. The last time he felt this way he had just quit an uninspiring position as chief executive officer of the Continental Management Group and hopped a plane to South Africa -- on impulse -- to be in on history when Nelson Mandela left prison. Trouble was, he found that his expertise (urban planning and development) wasn't required, so after a month he came home and helped to found the Urban Assembly.
"It took me until 1990 to realize my happiest times were in public service; I was never happy in real estate," says Mr. Kahan, grateful nonetheless for the "bricks and mortar education" he received from the builder Samuel J. Lefrak. (It's why Mr. Kahan can build anything.)
Through the Urban Assembly, Mr. Kahan turned his attention to education, a subject "that used to make my eyes glass over, but then we opened our first New Visions School, the Bronx School for Law, Government and Criminal Justice, and I was hooked. When I walked out of there after opening day, I said to my wife, 'Now I can get hit by that proverbial 250-ton truck, because I've finally done something that really matters with my life.' "
But he isn't finished with the feel-good projects.
This year Mr. Kahan and some deep-pocketed philanthropists including Preston Robert Tisch, the co-chairman of Loews and co-owner of the New York Giants, formed Take the Field Inc., a nonprofit organization dedicated to reconstituting fields needing face lifts. For every $1 the group provides, city government has agreed to pledge $3. So far, $16 million has been raised, with seven projects set for completion by July.
The first, a $2 million revamping of the fields at George Washington High School in Washington Heights, is almost finished. (Today, Mr. Kahan and his group will receive $600,000 from the State Assembly toward its second project, rebuilding fields at Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side.)
Next year, Mr. Kahan said, his group intends to double its workload and budget.
THIS field of dreams thing goes back a long way with Mr. Kahan. Ask him why gave up the piano for baseball when he was 14 and he'll say that his mother made him do it. There he was, in uniform and cleats, dutifully seated at the instrument in his Mount Vernon, N.Y., living room, trying to squeeze in a 15-minute practice session before his night game. His mother insisted he practice longer. He refused. She told him to choose between piano and baseball. Guess what he picked?
He was too short to play first base beyond junior high but too resilient to quit, so he settled for being a decent outfielder in high school, then switched to wrestling and the martial arts at college, where his little-boy dreams of becoming a major league slugger were replaced by a curriculum mouthful that Mr. Kahan calls International Diplomatic History. Then that was replaced by urban policy, and instead of going off to China to be a trade lawyer, Mr. Kahn stayed home. And got deeply into real estate, public and private.
He never quite became "the next Robert Moses" the way he says The New York Daily News predicted he might when he was 32 and juggling the development of Battery Park City and the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center with one hand and concocting a preservation strategy for Radio City Music Hall with the other. Burnout intruded. As for his 1998 gubernatorial bid, he didn't make it onto the Democratic primary ballot, much less win what he calls his dream job.
But Mr. Kahan, who confesses he has had a problem deferring to authority figures since kindergarten -- hence his preference for being one -- has always been a master at coming up with new missions that make a public statement.
He graduated from Columbia Law School but has never practiced law: there's been too much else to do. Now he is back to baseball. Not playing it himself (along with the bum shoulder that saved him from the draft and Vietnam, there's a rebuilt hip and cornea trouble that limits his boxing to bouts with the speedbag), but raising $100 million so children in public school can.
As a capitalist, he concludes that he has been a flop: "I liked money, but I didn't care enough about it. When I was at the U.D.C., I woke up each day and felt like I could chew through a wall. We were on a mission."
Here he goes again.

HEADLINE: Lawyers Give Plan to Split Auction-Case Settlement

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
The lead lawyers representing the more than 100,000 buyers and sellers in a recently settled class-action lawsuit against the Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses have detailed for the first time how they propose to divide the $512 million settlement.
In court papers that were filed on Friday and made available yesterday, the lawyers, from the firm of Boies, Schiller & Flexner, proposed that the buyers and sellers, who say they were victims of a scheme to fix commissions on the part of the two houses, receive proportionate amounts of money based on their purchases and sales. 
Using a formula developed by Jeffrey Leitzinger, a pricing and markets analyst retained by the firm, sellers would receive about 1 percent of the sales price of their offerings. Buyers would receive 5 percent of the sales price on each purchase of $50,000 or less and a flat $2,500 for each purchase above $50,000.
The figures represent the increases in the buyer's premiums that Sotheby's and Christie's instituted in 1993. Increases in seller's commissions, which were more variable, were computed through the use of economic models.
The papers, submitted in a motion for preliminary approval of the $512 million settlement filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, did not disclose the amount set aside for legal fees, which were arrived at in a proposal the firm filed months ago with Judge Lewis A. Kaplan.
The class-action suit stemmed from a far-ranging federal investigation of the two auction giants that moved into high gear when a former chief executive of Christie's delivered papers that documented years of collusion between two companies. Christie's received conditional amnesty from prosecution in exchange for cooperating. Last month, Sotheby's pleaded guilty to violating antitrust laws as did Diana D. Brooks, its former president and chief executive.
In September, Sotheby's and Christie's agreed to pay $512 million -- $412 million in cash and an additional $100 million in coupons -- to settle the claims by the customers represented in the class action.
The documents filed on Friday state that the settlement is 1.79 times the amount buyers and sellers were overcharged, which was estimated at $286 million by Mr. Leitzinger. He estimated that the auction houses overcharged buyers $201.2 million during the period from Jan. 1, 1993, through December 1999. Of the $201.2 million, $89.2 million is from Christie's and $111.9 million from Sotheby's. Mr. Leitzinger also estimated that the auction houses overcharged sellers $85.3 million, with $49.7 million of that from Sotheby's and $35.5 million from Christie's.
Within 30 days of preliminary approval by the court, Sotheby's and Christie's would each deposit in an escrow account $100 million in cash. An additional $106 million in cash would be deposited within 30 days of the final approval by the court. Each house would also deposit another $50 million either in cash or discount certificates within 30 days of the final court approval. Boies, Schiller & Flexner is to submit a plan of allocation on Nov. 27 that will provide more details of the distribution.
Also on Nov. 27, Sotheby's and Christie's will present to Judge Kaplan further details about the payment of the $100 million worth of certificates to clients wishing to use them as credit against seller's commissions and certain consignment-related charges.
No hearings have been set on the motion for preliminary approval or on final approval of the settlement.
As is typical of most class-action cases, members will have a certain number of days, still to be specified by the court, to opt out of the class.
A separate class-action suit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by the law firms of Cohen, Milstein, Hausfeld & Toll of Washington and Milberg, Weiss, Bershad, Hynes & Lorach of New York seeks to represent foreign buyers and sellers although no class has been certified by the judge.

HEADLINE: Weyerhaeuser Bids for Willamette

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Weyerhaeuser Company disclosed yesterday that it had made a $5.3 billion, $48-a-share cash offer to purchase Willamette Industries, setting the stage for a hostile takeover battle.
Weyerhaeuser, the nation's third-largest forest products company, said it made its offer in a Nov. 6 letter from its chairman and chief executive, Steven R. Rogel, to Duane C. McDougall, Willamette's president and chief executive. 
 Willamette's board met last week to consider the offer, but has not reached a decision.
In a letter on Sunday to William Swindells, Willamette's chairman, Mr. Rogel said that as a result of the board's failure to act, "We are forced to assume that we must consider other alternatives to consummate a transaction."
The offer that was disclosed yesterday is not the first time Weyerhaeuser has approached Willamette about a possible combination. The company said it held such discussions with Willamette two years ago.
Willamette, based in Portland, Ore., said in a statement that its board continued to review the proposal, "and will respond in due course."
"It is unfortunate that Weyerhaeuser chose to make its proposal public at this time," the statement added.
With the industry in the throes of consolidation, Wall Street analysts said the combination made good sense.
"This is a great fit," said Linda Lieberman, a senior managing director at Bear, Stearns. "It gives Weyerhaeuser a nice add-on in most of the businesses they are in."
Investors reacted by sharply bidding up the price of Willamette's stock, which gained $11.06 a share, or 32 percent, closing at $45.81 on the New York Stock Exchange. Weyerhaeuser, whose shares have been slumping since December, closed at $41.69, down $1.19.
Weyerhaeuser's offer represents a 38 percent premium over Friday's closing price of $34.75 for Willamette's shares. In addition to the cash offer, Weyerhaeuser would assume $1.7 billion in Willamette debt.
Chip Dillon, a paper and forest products analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said the bid, while attractive, might need to be sweetened to be accepted by Willamette shareholders. But Mr. Dillon also said a competing bid from another forest products company was unlikely.
"There has never been a deal I have seen where all cards were put on the table at once," he said. "Since at least 75 percent of Willamette's stock is in institutional hands, the company will have to come to the table. We are assuming that Weyerhaeuser will end up paying about $50 a share" to complete the acquisition.
Mr. Dillon said that International Paper and Georgia Pacific, two potential bidders for Willamette, were busy absorbing companies they had recently purchased, and that European paper companies were not likely to express an interest.
"I don't think you will see any other bidders emerge," he said. "That is one reason Weyerhaeuser is being so bold."
Mr. Rogel, who was the chief executive at Willamette before moving to Weyerhaeuser in 1997, said in a telephone interview that his company had lined up financing to pay for the acquisition.
"This is a good value for Willamette shareholders," he said. "We would hope their board will sit down and work on these issues. Working together, we can reach a conclusion rapidly."
Ms. Lieberman of Bear, Stearns said that adding $7 billion in fresh debt to Weyerhaeuser's existing debt of about $5 billion would not put the company in a terribly difficult position.
"As you are going into an economic slowdown, any debt is a burden," she said. "But Weyerhaeuser has assets they could monetize if they wanted to take down debt fast. Would it be prudent to take down some debt immediately? Yes, it would be."

HEADLINE: Lawsuits Block Path of a Catskills Casino

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In the seven months since Park Place Entertainment Corporation announced that it would build the largest casino resort in the world in the Catskills, the project has attracted more lawsuits than gamblers.
Rival developers and others have challenged what they described as the deception and bare-knuckled tactics that Park Place, the world's largest casino company, used in trying to seize control of Indian gambling in New York State. 
The resulting fray has worried many residents of Sullivan County, who had thought that after 30 years of effort, gambling -- and the hundreds of thousands of visitors it would attract -- was finally going to come to their economically depressed corner of the state.
Yesterday, one such rival, Catskill Development, filed suit against Park Place in United States District Court in Manhattan claiming that the gambling company had wrongfully engaged in a secret, seven-month campaign to persuade the St. Regis Mohawks to scuttle the tribe's longterm contract with Catskill Development to build a $500 million casino at the Monticello Raceway.
Catskill Development's plan gained federal approval on April 6, but eight days later, the Mohawks abruptly signed a deal with Park Place, giving the company exclusive rights to develop tribal casinos in New York in return for a $3 million loan.
The suit contends that Park Place intended to eliminate "competition to its Atlantic City casinos; or, it would steal the rights to develop and manage what would become the most profitable casino in the world," in order to monopolize New York casino gaming.
Thomas P. Puccio, a lawyer for Catskill Development, said: "There was a concerted effort on the part of Park Place to undermine our deal with the Mohawks in a way that violates state law. They induced the Mohawks to break their agreement with us."
Clive Cummis, general counsel for Park Place, refused to comment, saying he had not seen the lawsuit. Park Place has insisted that it is going forward with plans to build a casino resort called the Anawana Club at Kutsher's Country Club, a 1,400-acre property about five miles north of Monticello.
But word of the lawsuit sparked dismay in Sullivan County, where many of the area's once vibrant hotels and resorts lie in ruins. Anthony P. Cellini, the supervisor of the town of Thompson and a member of the county's gambling committee, said he still held out hope that Park Place would cut a deal with Catskill Development. But he said he feared that the opportunity for gambling was waning.
"It's not looking real promising today," Mr. Cellini said yesterday.
The suit comes a month after secret negotiations between the two sides fell through. In early October, Arthur Goldberg, chief executive of Park Place, was seeking a deal to buy out Catskill Development for $300 million and build a casino and hotels at the Raceway. But the deal appeared to hit a snag on Oct. 16 and Mr. Goldberg died three days later.
A dissident group of Mohawks has filed a separate suit in tribal court against Park Place, claiming that the company duped the Mohawk chiefs into breaking its contract with Catskill Development. The dissidents say that Park Place wanted to stop any casino project in New York to protect the company's three casinos in Atlantic City. A default hearing is scheduled for Nov. 17.
"We don't believe Park Place will ever open a casino for the Mohawks and never had any intention of doing so," said Michael Rhodes-Devey, a lawyer for the dissident Mohawks.
In another lawsuit filed in state court in Nassau County, Ivan Kaufman, whose company ran the Mohawk's small, money-losing casino on the Akwesasne Reservation, contended that Park Place doublecrossed him by ruining his relationship with the Mohawks and reneging on a $30 million deal to take over the Akwesasne casino.
To further muddy the waters, the Appellate Division ruled last week that a lawsuit challenging Gov. George E. Pataki's right to approve Indian gambling without the State Legislature's consent could proceed in State Supreme Court. Gambling advocates fear that as a rule, casino gambling would not get legislative approval.
Governor Pataki has long said he favored Indian casinos in former resort areas like the Catskills. But after Park Place began battling with Catskill Development in May, he said he would take no further action until the Mohawk situation was clarified.
The confusion has not prevented other proposals from surfacing. David Flaum, a developer from Rochester, has said that he is putting together a deal with the Seneca-Cayuga tribe of Oklahoma for a casino on the Shawanga Lodge property south of Monticello in Mamakating. And Catskill Development recently told county officials and the town of Monticello that it plans to substitute the New York Cayuga tribe for the Mohawks for a casino at Monticello Raceway.
But Kevin Gover, an assistant secretary of the Interior Department in charge of the agency's Bureau of Indian Affairs, has made it clear that they would all have to file applications and wait for two years or more. He said Federal approval of the Mohawk casino at the Raceway could not be transferred to either Kutsher's Country Club for Park Place, or to the Cayugas for Catskill Development.
The Catskill Development lawsuit also claims that Donald J. Trump, who also owns casinos in Atlantic City, lobbied against Indian gambling in New York while he was cooperating with Mr. Goldberg, who secretly wooed the Mohawk chiefs. Catskill Development said that Mr. Goldberg had turned down its earlier offer to make him a partner in the Monticello casino. Instead, the suit states, Mr. Goldberg got the Mohawks to kill its deal with Catskill Development by linking his commitment to salvage the tribe's nearly bankrupt Akwesasne casino to an exclusive right to develop and build casinos for the Mohawks in New York.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Weyerhaeuser Makes Offer For Willamette Industries
The Weyerhaeuser Company, the third-largest forest products concern in the United States, disclosed that it had made a $5.3 billion, $48-a-share cash offer to buy Willamette, which could lead to a hostile takeover battle. Willamette's board met last week to consider the offer, but has not reached a decision.
Investors reacted by bidding up the price of Willamette's shares, which gained $11.06, or 32 percent, to $45.81. Weyerhaeuser, whose shares have been slumping since December, closed at $41.69, down $1.19. Page C2. 

Hog Producer Bids for Meatpacker
In a move that typifies the rapid consolidation of the food industry, Smithfield Foods, the nation's biggest hog producer and pork processor, made an unsolicited bid to buy the meatpacker IBP for about $2.7 billion in stock. C2.
 
I.B.M. Is Forming a New Alliance
I.B.M. plans to announce an alliance today intended to help communications carriers expand and revamp their networks, company executives said. Lucent Technologies, Alcatel, Nortel Networks and other companies have joined the new initiative. C4.
 
W.T.O. Sets Date to Discuss China
The World Trade Organization has set a new date, in early December, to try to complete China's entry into the organization. Negotiators plan to meet Dec. 5-8 in the hope of sealing China's entry either by the end of this year or sometime early in 2001. Before it can become a member, however, China must iron out agreements with its trading partners in a number of crucial areas, including intellectual property rights. World Business, Section W.
 
CMGI to Close Two Businesses
CMGI, a holding company that had been one of the Internet's highest fliers, said that it would close two of its businesses and that its sales for the quarter would fall short of expectations. The company attributed the problems largely to falling demand for Internet advertising, on which the company had placed big bets. C19.
 
MarchFirst Plans to Cut 1,000 Jobs
Since two dot-com companies completed a merger on March 1 to form MarchFirst, the Internet consulting firm has had hard times. To help revive its sagging stock price, the company will cut 1,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force. An e-mail message from the chairman, Robert F. Bernard, has done little to calm employees' nerves. C6.
 
Leucadia to Invest in Finova Group
The Finova Group, an independent finance company struggling to overcome a liquidity squeeze, announced that it had reached a preliminary agreement for an investment of up to $350 million by Leucadia National, a financial holding company considered one of the savviest investors in troubled companies. If the Finova deal succeeds, it will be the largest investment to date by Leucadia. C8.
 
Payouts Proposed in Auction Case
The lead lawyers representing the more than 100,000 buyers and sellers in a recently settled class-action lawsuit against Sotheby's and Christie's detailed how they propose a $512 million settlement be divided. C14.
 
E.P.A. Still Has Questions on Corn
New scientific data submitted by the maker of StarLink corn does not dispel concerns that the gene-altered crop may cause allergic reactions in humans, the Environmental Protection Agency said. In what it described as a preliminary evaluation and not a final ruling, the agency said it still questioned whether some people might have allergic reactions if they eat the corn. C19.

HEADLINE: COUNTING THE VOTE: THE REPUBLICAN RESPONSE;
For the Most Part, the Republicans Close Ranks Behind Bush After a Defeat in Federal Court

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
With rare exceptions, Republicans backed Gov. George W. Bush's approach to Florida's murky election returns today, even after the Bush campaign's suit to block further recounting by hand was thrown out by a federal judge in Miami.
Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, for example, said the campaign's lawsuit was necessary because many Republicans felt "we were not defending our position well enough and whatever the Democrats were doing, we ought to be doing more of it." 
 Republicans seemed to be more united behind their candidate today, after the legal setback, than Democrats were last week when many criticized the campaign of Vice President Al Gore for even talking about suing. One friend of Mr. Gore sarcastically put it today, "I guess all the statesmen are in our party."
Representative David Dreier of California, chairman of the House Rules Committee, complained of the Gore campaign seeking "recount after recount -- to push for recounts until you get the outcome you want."
Mr. Dreier said he supported today's decision by Florida's secretary of state to enforce a Tuesday evening deadline for certifying the results of last week's voting in the state.
But there were some Republican dissenters. Former Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, who was a supporter of Arizona Senator John McCain during the primaries, said: "I think everything should be done to establish the real vote. I think artificial deadlines are a mistake. The electoral college doesn't meet until December."
Mr. Rudman added, "If you want to be fair to the American people, then there ought to be a very careful recount of all the ballots. The American people ought to have full confidence that the winner is the winner."
Representative Peter T. King of New York said he disagreed with the Bush campaign's attempt to prevent a hand recount. But, he said, "there should be one all over the state."
Reflecting the view of many of his colleagues, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania said: "If you go to a hand count, it will take an interminable amount of time and there will be an enormous amount of controversy. Judges will be looking at ballots and there will be appeal after appeal. It's a bottomless pit."
Others argued that hand recounts were inherently suspect. "The lack of a uniform standard in this hand recount ought to be raising real big flags for all of us," said Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut.
Bill Brock, a former Republican Party national chairman, said, "The reason most of us have gone to machines is that they are more accurate." And he ridiculed the idea of following arguments made by William M. Daley, the Gore campaign chairman, who lives in Chicago where, Mr. Brock said, vote fraud was made into "a new art form."
Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, said he could not imagine "how somebody discerns the will or intention of the voter in a hand count."
But Senator George V. Voinovich of Ohio said he felt the Bush camp should not have gone to court first. "If I were in their position, I probably wouldn't have done it," he said.
Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio said he was not sure if filing a federal lawsuit was a mistake because, "It's inevitable that the courts will intervene in this process." Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert of New York defended the decision, "There is so much at stake that they have got to protect what they think they earned -- the required number of electoral votes."
Mr. Armey said, "Neither side can just sit down and let the other side walk away with the presidential election based on partial results." An upstate New York colleague, Representative Amo Houghton, even sympathized a bit with the Gore campaign, saying "If I were behind, I would try to pick over the votes as long as I could." But he said a quick end was needed.
Hardly anyone agreed with Mr. Rudman's view that there was no real hurry. Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut said, "I think both sides should say 'By Friday, one of us will concede and one of us will be president.' " But he said he did not know "which of these two candidates will provide a selfless moment."
Representative Mark Sanford of South Carolina said, "For a society that's used to getting a Big Mac within 15 seconds, this is not at all what we have grown accustomed to."
Representative Ray LaHood of Illinois, said: "We need to move on and decide. I don't think people will stand to have much more of this recounting going on. I think at some point one of them will quit."
Without prompt closure, warned Senator Gordon H. Smith of Oregon, "we will have an aftertaste that will never go away."
Several lawmakers warned of the consequences of delay.
"A great many people are underestimating the threat to our system of government the longer this goes on," Mr. Boehner said. "The people of Rome never thought their government would ever collapse. The Greeks never thought they'd lose it. Americans, being the great pollyannaists of the world, I don't think realize the great threat."
A less apocalyptic set of concerns was offered by Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, who said he hoped both candidates realized that electoral indecision "might lead someone who wants to strike at the United States to do so," someone who failed to understand "that we're strong, that the chain of command is strong." He said he also hoped they understood that delay "could be the cause of undermining the economy and loss of confidence."
While there was little dissent from the position taken by their party's candidate for president, a number of Republicans declined to discuss it. They included Representatives Phil English of Pennsylvania and Constance A. Morella of Maryland.
Others said they simply did not know what should be done in Florida. Senator Warner was one of them. So was Representative Shays, who said, "I think it's a state issue."
Representative Jim Leach of Iowa said: "I'm personally staying out of this. This could come to Congress and I want to be open-minded about it."
While several lawmakers had precise solutions, calling for deadlines like Tuesday or Friday, others acknowledged that the situation was not simple. "Getting it right is easier said than done," said Mr. Boehner.
The most upbeat view came from Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska.
"I actually think -- and maybe because I am an optimist -- that this might in fact force the next president to deal with some of the urgent challenges and issues of our time and develop a coalition agenda, a bipartisan agenda," Senator Hagel said. "It might in a strange way unhook us from the special-interest groups."

HEADLINE: Rate Commission Clears Way for Penny Rise in Price of Stamp

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Mailing a letter in the United States will probably become a cent more expensive in January.
The Postal Rate Commission, an independent agency that sets rates, today granted a United States Postal Services request to raise the price of one-ounce first-class mail to 34 cents from 33 cents. 
 The increase will take effect by Jan. 7 at the earliest. The Postal Service Board of Governors, which normally approves such measures, must vote on the proposal.
Commission officials said the increase, which is expected to bring an additional $2.5 billion in revenue, was needed to offset rising costs. It falls short, however, of the $2.8 billion requested by the Postal Service in January.
Other plans include a 30-cent increase in the one-pound Priority Mail service, to $3.50 from $3.20; a 50-cent increase for 8-ounce Express Mail service, to $12.25 from $11.75; and a 50-cent increase in certified mail, to $1.90 from $1.40. Postcard postage will remain 20 cents.
Magazine publishers succeeded in lobbying for a somewhat lower rate increase than first proposed for periodicals, a category that includes most consumer magazines. The Magazine Publishers of America fought a proposed increase of 15 percent. According to the publishers, that would have cost the industry $300 million over the next two years. The commission called for an increase of 9.9 percent.
Nina B. Link, president of the publishers' group, said today that she was pleased that the commission had met the group's goal but added that the group would continue to fight steep increases.
Christopher M. Little, president of the Meredith Publishing Group, said the increase was too high.
"I appreciate that this has come down all the way from 15 percent, but this is still significantly higher than the rate of inflation," he said. "I think the magazine industry has to maintain the same level of intensity and effort going forward to never let this happen again."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
SIGNS OF A SLOWING ECONOMY

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
New York City's torrid economy could be on the verge of a slowdown, according to a report released yesterday by economists working for Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller. Their report found that help-wanted advertising, a traditional indicator used to forecast economic conditions, declined slightly in the third quarter. Another indicator, initial unemployment claims, rose; many temporary government workers lost their jobs in the third quarter as the federal census was completed. On the other hand, private-sector job creation was still strong, the unemployment rate fell and income tax collections rose.
 Leslie Eaton

HEADLINE: Documents Shed Light on Assassination of Chilean in U.S.

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS and DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
A month before the assassination of a Chilean diplomat and an American colleague in downtown Washington in 1976, the United States government ordered its envoys in Latin America to try to avert a plot to murder leftist opponents of the region's governments, documents released today show.
But the American ambassador in Chile, David Popper, refused to convey what Washington had learned of the plot or even the government's concerns to the leader of Chile's military junta, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, saying he did not want to offend the general by associating him with the plot, known as Operation Condor, the documents show. "He might well take as an insult any inference that he was connected with such assassination plots," Mr. Popper said in a cable to Washington. 
 General Pinochet's secret police chief, Gen. Manuel Contreras, was later convicted in Chile of ordering what was, up to that time, the worst act of foreign-sponsored terrorism on American soil: the bombing on Sept. 21, 1976, of the car in which Orlando Letelier, a former confidant of the deposed Chilean president, Salvador Allende, was traveling to his job at a Washington research institute along with two colleagues. He and Ronni K. Moffitt were killed; her husband, Michael Moffitt, survived the blast.
While there is no evidence that an American warning to General Pinochet or General Contreras would have thwarted the attack on Embassy Row here, critics of the American government's role in Chile during the 1970's said today that it represented, at a minimum, a lost opportunity.
"An extraordinary tragedy," said Peter Kornbluh, senior analyst at the National Security Archive, a private clearinghouse for declassified documents. "Such a meeting might well have prevented that act of assassination from taking place."
The information came to light today as the Clinton administration released more than 16,000 documents on America's relationship with Chile from the years before the 1973 military coup in which the junta deposed President Allende to 1991, after the country's transition to democracy. It was the final release in a declassification project ordered in February 1999 by President Clinton.
The documents, including more than 450 on covert operations that the Central Intelligence Agency earlier sought to withhold, support those who argue that General Pinochet was complicit in the assassination conspiracy, Mr. Kornbluh said.
While critics of United States policy in the region have long said that the Letelier murder could not have been carried out without General Pinochet's knowledge, the documents released today include a State Department cable showing that he called President Alfredo Stroessner of Paraguay asking him for "an urgent favor." The favor was that Paraguay issue passports to two agents of the Chilean secret police, according to the State Department document, which was marked "secret" and apparently written in the summer of 1976.
The government of Paraguay complied, but the American Embassy there barred the agents from traveling to the United States, asserting that they had lied about their plans and their reason for going to the United States. The two later entered using Chilean passports.
Those two men, Michael Townley and Armando Fernandez, were convicted years later for their role in arranging the car bombing.
General Pinochet returned to Chile this year after being held under house arrest in Britain at the request of a Spanish judge who wanted him tried under an international torture treaty. But the general was released after he was ruled to be too ill to stand trial.
The newly declassified documents also show that General Pinochet's intelligence chief, General Contreras, tried to fend off demands for his extradition to the United States after he was indicted here for the Letelier murder with threats that he could implicate American officials in the killings. The documents provide no proof that General Contreras could produce such evidence.
In 1991, the documents show, the C.I.A. destroyed its file on General Contreras, who had been a paid informant for the agency.
Mark Mansfield, the agency's spokesman, said the documents "speak for themselves." But he urged people to "view them and the events they describe within their proper historical context."
"C.I.A. activities were conducted within the framework of U.S. foreign policy at the time," he said, "and covert actions were undertaken at the direction of the White House and interagency policy coordinating committees."
The outlines of Washington's role in Chile are known, including the Nixon administration's support of groups plotting to prevent Mr. Allende from assuming the presidency after his election in 1970, and its subsequent efforts to destabilize his socialist government.
In 1975 the Senate Intelligence Committee reported that from 1963 to 1973, the C.I.A. spent more than $8 million on disinformation campaigns, propaganda and financial aid to groups plotting a coup.
And this September, a C.I.A. report to Congress acknowledged that the agency had a relationship with General Contreras from 1974 to 1977, and that he received a one-time payment of an undisclosed sum in 1975.
A senior administration official said the new documents "reveal the evolution of U.S. policy quite well."
The documents released today show American officials moving from open enthusiasm for the coup that toppled the Allende government and brought General Pinochet to power, to reservations about his junta's human rights abuses, to support for the democratic opposition that unseated the general.
Minutes of high-level meetings released today show that President Nixon feared that the election of Mr. Allende could set off a drift toward Communism in South America. And he appeared determined to undermine the Allende government.
"We are going to cold turkey them on the economy," Mr. Nixon said, suggesting that the United States would flood world markets with copper to force down the price of Chile's main resource. His advisers warned that such dumping would be illegal.
After General Pinochet's coup, the junta arrested vast numbers of people they suspected of being leftists -- Chileans and foreigners living in Chile. Imprisoned in soccer stadiums, they were interrogated. Many were tortured and some 3,000 were killed, according to a investigation in 1990 by the Chilean National Commission on Truth and Reconciliation.
The documents reveal that one of the Americans killed at a stadium in Santiago, Frank Teruggi, had been labeled a subversive by the C.I.A.
Mr. Mansfield said the agency had "no prior knowledge" of the circumstances leading to Mr. Teruggi's death.
Documents declassified by the Clinton administration have shown that American officials were aware of plans for assassinations in foreign capitals nearly two months before Mr. Letelier's killing. In late August 1976, Philip Habib, then under secretary of state for political affairs, ordered United States ambassadors throughout Latin America to voice American disapproval.
But more than a week after the Letelier assassination, Mr. Popper, the American ambassador in Chile, cabled the State Department to reject approaching General Pinochet. Instead, he suggested that an intelligence official convey Washington's concerns to General Contreras.
Mr. Popper declined to comment on his actions then. "It was a long time ago," said Mr. Popper, who is 88. "I'm a very old man."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 16, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about newly declassified United States government documents on the relationship with Chile in the 1970's and beyond misstated the date of a cable sent to Washington by an American ambassador in Chile. The cable, in which Ambassador David Popper rejected an order to convey Washington's displeasure with plans by governments in the region to assassinate opponents overseas, was dated Aug. 24, 1976. It was thus sent before -- not after -- Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean diplomat, was assassinated in Washington on Sept. 21, 1976.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
For the Thanksgiving Meal, An All-American Choice

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
WE have always been a drinking nation; the rise and fall of Prohibition proved that. Even so, serving wine at the Thanksgiving table 50 years ago would have seemed somehow un-American, almost subversive.
In Norman Rockwell's classic Saturday Evening Post depiction of this holiday dinner, not a drop of alcohol is to be seen. But don't the ruddy cheeks of Rockwell's menfolk hint at an earlier pass or two at the communal jug? And Grandma's comely blush -- is that from kitchen heat, or the cooking wine? 
 Next Thursday, hundreds of thousands of us will pour some kind of wine with the most American of all meals. The wine may not yet have the cachet of the creamed onions, but we've come a long way.
What wine to drink? Certainly it should be American, as Thanksgiving remains an American festival -- unless the French appropriate it the way they have filched Halloween. And it should be moderately priced wine; Thanksgiving is not an elitist celebration.
Sadly, moderately priced is easier said than done. In going after the more affluent market, the American wine industry has brushed off the customer of limited means. There is no lack of low-price wine, but most of it is mediocre. The lower end of the market has been left to the French, the Chileans and the Italians.
Even so, there are some good American wines to be had at reasonable prices. I had hoped to come up with a list of good wines at $10 and under. I could do this only with chardonnays, and even in this category, raising the bar to $15 improved the picture markedly.
There are actually more white wines, even chardonnays, in the $10 range than there are reds. That is fortunate, because for many Americans, wine is chardonnay. My chardonnay list would include Estancia, Gallo Sonoma, Indigo Hills (another Gallo label), Meridian Santa Barbara, Kendall-Jackson and two from Washington State -- Columbia Crest and Hogue Cellars. All of them are 1998's and less than $10. I particularly liked a chardonnay called Morro Bay; it has good acid.
In the $15-or-less group, I liked Rodney Strong Chalk Hill, Edna Valley and Simi. They are worth the extra money. Don't expect Burgundian elegance from any of these wines, but they do offer interesting flavors and can stand up to almost any Thanksgiving meal.
This is mostly a search for red wines, however. When it comes to American reds, zinfandel is by far the most intelligent choice. First of all, it is the most American of the top varietals, even though, like most of us, it came from somewhere else. We are deluged with dull cabernets and merlots, one virtually indistinguishable from another, but somehow, zinfandel seems to cling to its individuality. What's more, its bright spicy flavors make any meal taste good.
A lot of thin zinfandels were made in 1997, but in fact, some were quite good. Particularly attractive is a 1997 from Rancho Zabaco, yet another Gallo label. This wine, which includes 12 percent petite sirah, is made from Dry Creek Valley grapes, and is $16. Dry Creek is one of California's premium zinfandel sources.
Gallo's own label, a zinfandel from the Barelli Creek ranch in the Alexander Valley, is outstanding. From the same appellation, Alexander Valley Vineyards' Sin Zin is a bit more smoothly textured and should appeal to people who like goofy names. Both are around $15.
The 1998 zinfandels, which, over all, are probably better than the 1997's, are also more expensive. Of the few I've tried, I can recommend Mother Clone from Pedroncelli Winery in the Dry Creek region in Sonoma. This is a good chunky wine with intensity. It's around $12. Seghesio Winery's Sonoma Zinfandel has good spice in the taste and bouquet. Seghesio has long produced fine zinfandels, and this is one of its latest at a truly reasonable price. These wines are in the $16 category.
The $10 cabernet sauvignon is still around, but it is in disguise. Lots of cabernets selling for $20 are the old $10 wines, unchanged except for the price. A few are more affordable. Beaulieu Vineyards' Rutherford, for example, is around $15, up from $9 a few years ago. But given the wild inflation of wine prices, it is still a good buy. Likewise for St. Francis, and it sells for a dollar or two less.
Both these wines are 1997's, as is the most recent release of R. H. Phillips's Toasted Head Merlot. R. H. Phillips is a winery in the northern Central Valley, in an area the Giguiere family, who own the place, call the Dunnigan Hills. This is an intriguing wine with touches of malbec, petit verdot and cabernet sauvignon. R. H. Phillips also makes an Australian sort of blend with 55 percent Mendocino cabernet sauvignon and 45 percent of its own syrah. These two wines sell for around $15.
R. H. Philips has another merlot, into which it tosses two different petite sirahs, some petit verdot and alicante bouschet. It is aged in oak for a year, then sold for around $9. At that price you can invite those cousins you haven't seen for years.
If you are still into merlot -- not everyone has switched to syrah yet -- consider one from Francis Ford Coppola's Diamond Series. This is not a wimpy merlot with no backbone. It comes from the same winery as Mr. Coppola's famous Rubicon.
If you're adventurous, there's Pelligrini's merlot from Long Island's North Fork. This is merlot in the St.-Emilion style. Elegant and delicious.
