HEADLINE: REPORTERS' NOTEBOOK;
An Oil Barony Knows How to Entertain Important Visitors

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei, Nov. 15

 BODY:
After hitting a rough patch for a few years, the sultan of Brunei is feeling pretty good again.
Oil prices are back up, bringing smiles throughout this corner of Borneo, where people were talking for a while about finding another line of work. Sure, Bill Gates may still hold the sultan's old title -- world's richest man -- but the plunge in Microsoft stock has not exactly gone unnoticed here. 
 And it appears that the courts are finally settling all those cases involving the sultan's playboy brother, Prince Jefri, who managed to spend $2.7 billion of the family's cash on aircraft, yachts, fancy cars and jewelry. Along the way he generated some rather unpleasant headlines and was sued by a former Miss America who said she had been held against her will in the Royal Palace, which she described as a 1,700-room bordello.
But all that was forgotten this afternoon as the sultan, known among his subjects as His Majesty Haji Hassanal Bolkiah, bounced on his toes and, one by one, welcomed the leaders of more than half of the world's people to his modest land.
He looked like a salesman who couldn't believe his luck: all of his best customers had just dropped in, and tonight they were coming over for dinner. There was Bill Clinton and Vladimir Putin, chatting in the hallway of a huge meeting center that the sultan had built just for the occasion, an Asian summit meeting with the thinnest of agendas. Over in the corner was China's president, Jiang Zemin, and the latest winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea.
Most dignitaries pulled up in some of the 493 luxury cars purchased for the occasion by the sultan's nephew, who is planning to resell them afterward.
It proved once again that this is first and foremost a family business, one that counts among its assets a farm in Australia that is larger than this country itself and hotels from Rodeo Drive to Park Avenue to Park Lane. Oh, and a seat at the United Nations.
 
This Isn't Florida
"I can safely predict that this will be my last APEC summit," President Clinton declared this morning, using the acronym for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. "I just don't know who will be here next year."
That did not stop many of his fellow leaders from asking, including several who probably feel a lot better today about holding one-party elections, or no elections at all. Mr. Clinton said late this afternoon, at the beginning of a meeting with Mr. Kim, that "I told them it would all be worked out." Presumably that was easier than explaining in detail the laws governing recounts in the state of Florida.
Most of Asia's leaders seemed satisfied with Mr. Clinton's vague optimism -- at least in public. Except, of course, for the Malaysians. They have resented American lectures about Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's treatment of those who challenge his power, starting with his jailing of the former finance minister and deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim.
Dr. Mahathir's sharp-tongued trade minister, Rafidah Aziz, who once called Vice President Al Gore "disgusting" for his support of pro-democracy protesters in Kuala Lumpur, couldn't resist inserting the needle.
"We are very puzzled how the great democracy can get into such a mess," she said. "Maybe we, all developing countries, should send an election watch every time they have a presidential election."
Of course, elections are not a pressing problem for the sultan. His family has been running this territory, which is roughly the size of Delaware, for 600 years.
To avoid challenges to his power, he turned the country into what Asian neighbors call the "Shellfare state," because Shell Oil is one of the many oil companies whose operations here pay for the country's universal health care system. Prescription drugs included.
 
Polo, Anyone?
Not surprisingly, Prince Jefri is nowhere to be found this week. But the summit meeting is a tribute to his profligacy.
When President Clinton spoke this morning inside the gleaming Empire Hotel, he looked around in marvel. "Now this is an amazing place," the president said of the marbled hotel, which has a soaring six-story atrium and floor-to-ceiling windows that offer a sweeping view of the deep-blue sea.
Bruneians use the same adjective, but not happily. Prince Jefri spent $800 million on the hotel -- ripping out the marble floor after he decided he didn't like the color, according to some accounts -- before the sultan pulled the plug.
But there is a silver lining in all that waste: without it, there is no way a country this small could hold a summit meeting this big. Reporters are being housed in a sports complex the prince helped build for the 1999 Southeast Asian Games.
He also constructed a vast polo club, with a vaulted gold ceiling. It will serve on Thursday as the site of a "leaders' retreat," a nice place to paper over the leaders' widening disagreements on a new round of global trade negotiations.
 
It Takes a Sultan
Asked this morning about his plans after Jan. 20, Mr. Clinton made a strong case for his need to start producing some serious revenue flow. "Now I have a United States senator to support," he said. "I understand that's an expensive proposition."

HEADLINE: Peru Opposition Picks Successor for Fujimori's Ally in Congress

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Two days after ousting a head of Congress loyal to President Alberto K. Fujimori, opposition lawmakers named their candidate today to lead the legislature, threatening to undermine further Mr. Fujimori's fading hold on power.
Also today, the police used tear gas to disperse hundreds of leftist-led construction workers who were demonstrating outside the Government Palace. The protesters carried an effigy with two heads, Mr. Fujimori's and that of the former spy chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, in a cage. Tear gas canisters flew after some protesters, carrying wood poles and shouting, "There is no president!" charged at the police. 
 The demonstration was held after opposition parties agreed to put forward Congressman Valentin Paniagua to replace Martha Hildebrandt, who was voted out as president of Congress, 64 to 51. Mr. Paniagua will face Congressman Ricardo Marcenaro, the candidate for Mr. Fujimori's Peru 2000 Party, in a vote scheduled for Thursday. If the opposition gains control of Congress, that would will be the first time since 1992 that Mr. Fujimori did not dominate the body.
A representative of a small opposition party said Mr. Fujimori had applied for political asylum in Malaysia after his arrival today in Brunei for the meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group.
Second Vice President Ricardo Marquez, who is now in charge of the government, denied the allegation, by Jose Barba Caballero, a leader of the Avancemos Party.
Agriculture Minister Jose Chlimper told a radio station, Radioprogramas, that Mr. Fujimori was planning to fly home early from Brunei to end the uncertainty. Mr. Chlimper said he had called Brunei and spoke to Mr. Fujimori's personal military attache, who said the president was resting, but gave specific instructions to deny the asylum rumor. Mr. Chlimper said Mr. Fujimori was planning to return through Tokyo. His arrival time was not specified.
Mr. Fujimori announced in September that he would step down in July after new elections in the wake of a corruption scandal that erupted around Mr. Montesinos. But pressure is building for Mr. Fujimori to step aside sooner as reports of Mr. Montesinos's misdeeds mount. The scandal surrounding Mr. Montesinos, who remains a fugitive, began with a leaked videotape in September that showed him apparently bribing an opposition congressman.
Mr. Montesinos is under investigation for laundering at least $58 million in foreign bank accounts. He faces criminal complaints here that include directing state-sponsored death squads and skimming profits from the narcotics trade in his 10 years as Mr. Fujimori's top aide.
Mr. Paniagua, a moderate, said if he became leader of the 120-member legislature, there would be no rush to force Mr. Fujimori from office on grounds of "moral incapacity," as permitted by the Constitution.
"That is a theme that must be played out with the utmost caution," he said, "taking into account the grave repercussions that this can lead to in the political stability of any country."
Two of Mr. Fujimori's top ministers said he might not remain in the presidency until July. Finance Minister Carlos Bolona was widely quoted in newspapers as saying the crisis would make it difficult for Mr. Fujimori to remain until July.
Prime Minister Federico Salas agreed, saying in a radio interview, "The political scene is so unstable in Peru that I would not rule out anything at this moment."

HEADLINE: Longing for Authenticity;
Is the Jazz Really Jazz in Harlem Without the Locals?

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Around midnight, the jazz was live and straight-up in the Zebra Room of the Lenox Lounge, the legendary Art Deco nightclub in Harlem. Cocktail glasses clinked around tiny candle-lit cafe tables. The jazz vocalist, leaning against the baby grand, hushed the room with a big soprano voice that was like a soft, strong wind.
These should be heady days for the club's owner, Alvin M. Reed Sr. Since the lounge reopened in April after eight months of renovations, the night spot has been featured in national magazines like The New Yorker and Esquire. The club appeared in this summer's remake of "Shaft." And on weekends, a steady procession of jazz patrons makes its way past the bustling bar to the back room, with its black-and-white hide walls. 
 Yet Mr. Reed is upset. The owner, who is African-American, is wondering how in the world he can persuade local residents to visit his club in the heart of Harlem, in the trumpeted capital of black America, to listen to jazz. He says he is not hurting financially, but he is hurting in his heart.
"It's been 100 percent white on certain nights," said Mr. Reed, who was born in Richmond, Va., in 1939, the same year that the original Lenox Lounge was built, but grew up and was married in Harlem. "I thought I was bringing jazz back to Harlem for black folks. I thought I would bring out a lot of locals. I don't want to become a tourist place."
As Harlem has spruced up storefronts and streets in an economic rebirth that has been called its Second Renaissance, Mr. Reed's problem reflects in many ways the neighborhood's hopes and anxieties. Though the nightclub owner wants very much to attract outsiders -- and their dollars -- to Harlem, he does not want his club to lack authenticity, to become a kind of "Harlem lite" joint that has no soul.
There is no simple explanation for the jazz crowd's makeup at the Lenox Lounge. Economics is probably part of it. (The lounge's cover charge for jazz is $15 on Friday and Saturday nights.) It also may be an issue of marketing and promotion.
Lloyd A. Williams, president of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, is convinced that some Harlem residents may be wary of the club's location on Lenox Avenue between 124th and 125th streets, a stretch that he said was no longer treacherous.
"It was predominated by drugs until very, very recently," Mr. Williams said. "The Europeans and the Asians who are coming don't know any of that. So what we need to do is to reach out to the people in our community and say, 'Hey, it's happening again.' "
Still, many jazz musicians, bartenders and club owners in Harlem say the links between jazz and blacks have diminished, even as much of the best jazz continues to be made by black musicians.
Musicians like Bill Saxton, an African-American saxophonist who played on a recent Friday night at St. Nick's Pub in Harlem, is surprised that Mr. Reed is surprised.
"If it wasn't for white people, we wouldn't be able to work at all," said Mr. Saxton, navigating the smoky basement club and its racially mixed audience to the small stage, where a large portrait of Miles Davis was draped like a national flag. The saxophonist said many black jazz patrons turned to other music forms with the advent of bebop in the late 1940's. Dance halls gave way to intimate clubs and smaller jazz bands, geared for listening instead of dancing as in the preceding big-band era.
"When jazz became art music in the late 40's and early 50's, we lost a lot of black people to rhythm and blues," Mr. Saxton said.
David Levering Lewis, the author of "When Harlem Was in Vogue," (Penguin, 1997), said jazz appeared to have taken on a patina similar to classical music's. "It's so established and so mannered," he said. "It just may not have the grab. But it's a tribute to the art form that it belongs to nobody and to everybody."
Michael Henry Adams, a historian and preservationist in Harlem, has been a harsh critic of some revitalization efforts there. He derides the new shopping plaza on 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard called Harlem U.S.A., which includes a Magic Johnson multiplex, a Disney store and an HMV record store, as "Las Vegas imported to Harlem."
Yet, Mr. Adams is sanguine about the Lenox Lounge. He said that the Harlem Renaissance, the explosion of cultural life that began in the 1920's, could not have been accomplished without the patronage of whites who flocked nightly to Harlem.
"Even if the Lenox Lounge becomes a venue where busloads of whites come nightly, ultimately that kind of popularity is going to cause more black people to come, as well," Mr. Adams said. "It's nothing very different from the whole history of Harlem, particularly entertainment in Harlem."
On a recent weekend at the Lenox Lounge, the audience for jazz was about 60 percent white on Friday night and 85 percent white on Saturday. The customers came from as far away as Istanbul, Berlin and Japan.
At times, the owner said, white patrons and tour guides have grumbled about the complexion of the crowd.
"A lot of whites are very disappointed because they are coming for our culture," said Mr. Reed, a retired police officer and postal worker who bought the club in 1988. "They want to see how we pop our fingers and get with it, and they get in here, look around and it's nothing but white folks."
The irony is not lost on Mr. Reed. The Lenox Lounge was conceived as a fancy place for white patrons when it opened in 1942, though famous black entertainers and celebrities frequented it. Billie Holiday had a regular table. Louis Armstrong stopped by. So did Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Ella Fitzgerald and James Baldwin.
"It was the bar for the elite," said Dominic Greco, 81, who was a young bartender when the lounge opened and a nephew of Ralph Greco, who was then the owner. "They were the only ones who could afford the prices."
The Lenox Lounge has operated nearly nonstop since its grand opening more than half a century ago. Mr. Reed resurrected jazz at the club three years ago, after it went through a hugely popular disco phase. Now, with Harlem's night life heating up and the crime rate down, Mr. Reed wants his neighbors to embrace his labor of love. (He invested $200,000 and got a loan for $550,000 from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.)
Observing the late-night scene, a glass of chilled chardonnay in hand, Mr. Reed said he was considering knocking on doors in Harlem and asking, "What gives?" He said he might start at Lenox Terrace, an apartment complex about 10 blocks north at 135th Street, where a number of leading black politicians and professionals live in luxury high-rise buildings.
"Is it that you don't go out anymore?" Mr. Reed said he would ask. "Is it a financial thing? Are younger blacks not into jazz history? I want some questions answered. You don't have to come. Just explain to me. I am confused."
The other evening, the jazz vocalist Melba Joyce, in a glittery caftan, was raising the microphone high and scatting in the tradition of Sarah Vaughan. But Ms. Joyce's voice had to compete with the jukebox in the boisterous bar, which was cranking out James Brown and other rhythm-and-blues tunes.
The lounge's bar and the Zebra Room are like two distinct clubs, separated by swinging glass doors. The bar has mostly black customers.
Mr. Reed is not convinced that the $15 cover charge accounts for the makeup of the crowd in the Zebra Room. He said he had watched some bar regulars, who profess to love jazz, run up bar tabs of $60 to $70, without so much as a peek into the Zebra Room.
He has his theories. He is embarrassed to say that his 35-year-old son, Alvin Jr., the lounge's general manager, told him that he disliked jazz; he's into hip-hop. (Mr. Reed told his son to keep it to himself.)
Between sets the other night, Mr. Reed was joined at a table by Ms. Joyce, a Harlem resident, who performed once with Louis Armstrong and appeared in the Broadway musical "Black and Blue."
"I think we take our music for granted," said Ms. Joyce, shrugging. "The music belongs to black people. We're born into it."
At another table, an elegant young black couple, Pascally Toussaint and Edward Davis, were settling into their chairs. They, too, were struck by the large number of whites. Ms. Toussaint, an aspiring Haitian-American singer in her mid-20's, said she had only recently learned of the Lenox Lounge from Ms. Joyce, who was her instructor at a gospel singing workshop. Ms. Toussaint suggested that the club get a better promoter, perhaps bring in a jazz-inflected hip-hop performer like Erykah Badu, and lose some of the jazz standards.
"Maybe they should do a spoken-word night," offered her friend, Mr. Davis, an African-American record producer and musician whose long dreadlocks were bundled inside a knit cap. "A lot of blacks are into that."
A burly bass player, Wayne Batchelor, from the jazz trio pulled up a chair during a break. He said the jazz scene in Harlem was a novelty for many whites, but not for blacks.
"If you have lived in Harlem all of your life and jazz has been on your corner, it just blends into the whole landscape," said Mr. Batchelor, a black Londoner. "In general, the black population has turned away from what was culturally theirs in the first place."
In a darkened corner of the Zebra Room that night, Tommy Tomita, a tour guide, swayed to the jazz, his eyes closed. Mr. Tomita, who lives in Harlem, takes small groups of Japanese tourists on what he calls "Harlem Soul Tours." The Lenox Lounge was just one stop. The tourists listened appreciatively and snapped pictures of one another before moving on.
Mr. Tomita said his group did not expect to see so many white customers. "The image is maybe all black people," he said. But he had a few other places in mind. He mentioned a little soul food restaurant at 116th Street, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues, called Amy Ruth's, where there would be a sea of black faces.

HEADLINE: Presidential Journey to Vietnam

 BODY:
The last American president to visit Vietnam was Richard Nixon, who traveled to the South Vietnamese capital of Saigon in 1969, at the height of a war that eventually took 58,000 American and three million Vietnamese lives. Today, Bill Clinton begins a three-day trip to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, as Saigon is now called. Mr. Clinton's visit is striking evidence of how far the two countries have moved beyond the rancor of that conflict. But if a healthy new relationship is to be built, Hanoi must ease bureaucratic restrictions on foreign investment and show greater respect for the civil and religious liberties of its people.
Mr. Clinton's itinerary inevitably looks back to war-related issues, like repatriating the remains of Americans lost in action and helping remove land mines still buried in Vietnamese soil. But he should also use his visit to press for a faster pace of political and economic reform. 
 Much has changed in Vietnam over the past three decades. Most of its 79 million people have been born since the war ended, and younger Vietnamese, in particular, look admiringly upon American prosperity and personal freedoms. While the Communist party still jealously monopolizes government power and public political debate, ordinary Vietnamese are no longer afraid to talk about politics in private.
But anyone who speaks out for more accountable government or wider freedom faces stern repression. Hanoi continues to jail open critics, persecute religious believers, censor newspapers, restrict the Internet and otherwise suppress dissent.
 It routinely violates provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which it acceded in 1982, guaranteeing freedom of expression, association and religious belief and prohibiting arbitrary detentions.
After a disastrous decade of trying to impose North Vietnam's austere and repressive Communism on the more freewheeling South, the country's leaders reversed course in the late 1980's and began encouraging Southern style entrepreneurship. But over the past three years, Vietnam's program of market liberalization has stalled as the country's political leaders have grown concerned about decentralizing economic power. Foreign investors have become frustrated with the Vietnam's bureaucratic hurdles and have taken their investments to China and other Southeast Asian nations.
When Mr. Clinton talks to university students in Hanoi on Friday he should speak plainly about the merits of human rights, democracy, free markets and the rule of law, as he did during his 1998 trip to China. He also needs to raise these issues in his discussions with government and Communist Party leaders as well.
 Establishing firm legal protections for Vietnamese-Americans who want to return home to do business should be an important part of his agenda. He would also do well to follow the advice of Senator John McCain and others and seek to expand legal exchange programs to cover press and human rights issues as well as commercial law.
By opening Vietnam's markets, the Clinton administration believes that it is paving the way for eventual steps toward greater political freedom. The president's visit is an excellent opportunity to press for a faster pace of change.

HEADLINE: Tolls May Rise For Rush Hour Across Hudson

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is considering a plan that could double the basic fare on the PATH train to $2 from $1 and increase tolls at several bridges and tunnels to $7 from $4 during rush hours, officials said yesterday.
The increases, which would be the first for the PATH train since 1987 and the first for the bridges and tunnels since 1991, have been discussed by top officials in both states since at least the summer, when Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey settled a longstanding feud over the operations of the Port Authority, a fight that had stalled billions of dollars in projects for both states. 
 One of the sticking points in that dispute was a contention by New York officials that the Port Authority had oversubsidized the PATH train for too many years, providing a disproportionate benefit to New Jersey residents, who are its primary users. And that benefit, New York officials said, was just one example among many of how New Jersey received more than its share of funds from the bistate agency.
The proposed increases, which could be subject to extensive changes after they are presented to the Port Authority's board members for the first time today, would affect the Holland Tunnel, Lincoln Tunnel, George Washington Bridge, Bayonne Bridge, Goethals Bridge and the Outerbridge Crossing, where round-trip tolls are now $4. The agency collects about 350,000 tolls at its bridges and tunnels each weekday.
According to the proposal, the bridge and tunnel tolls would rise to $7 during rush hours, which could end up being defined during the morning as 6 to 10 a.m. The tolls would then drop to a slightly lower price, except for the evening rush hours. E-ZPass users would also get some type of discount. And trucks, which pay substantially more than cars at the tollbooth, would be given large discounts for traveling late at night, in an effort to relieve the grinding congestion that trucks can cause at the Hudson River crossings during the day.
The proposal would also double the PATH train fare to $2 for passengers who pay with cash, but for those who use the QuickCard, which allows multiple trips, the fare would be $1.50 or slightly less depending on the number of trips on the card. There are about 240,000 riders each weekday.
The extra money from the increase would be a welcome infusion for New York State, where voters rejected a bond issue on Election Day that would have paid for several huge transportation projects. But yesterday it was hard to find a commuter who thought the plan was a good idea.
"I think that's a pretty big increase," said Bethany Grohs, 30, who was on her way home to Westfield, N.J., last night at the PATH station at the World Trade Center. "So many other things are overpriced, it's nice to have something like this that's only a dollar."
Joe Garcia, who was driving a van at the Canal Street entrance to the Holland Tunnel, said: "You're kidding. That's crazy. That's a terrible idea."
His passenger, Eric Acevedo, leaned over and said, "It's going to be congested regardless of how much you pay."
The main purpose of the increases would be to help the Port Authority pay for its ambitious capital plans, which could cost as much as $13 billion over the next five years for a range of projects that include buying new PATH trains, repairing bridges and tunnels and making extensive rail, port and airport improvements.
"When you're talking about a major five-year capital plan, obviously a critical part of the discussion is, 'How is this going to be financed?' " said Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority, who confirmed yesterday that the agency would present a toll and fare increase plan to the board. It is unknown how much support for the plan exists in the two governors' offices, but it is unlikely that the proposal would have advanced this far without some agreement in principle.
Another idea behind the plan is to try to use the increases creatively to fight congestion, which officials from both states estimate costs the region several billion dollars a year. A related goal is to try to bring both the tolls and the PATH fare more into parity with what is charged for tolls and mass transit elsewhere in the metropolitan region, officials said. For example, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority charges $7 for a round trip on its bridges and tunnels around the city, including the Triborough Bridge, the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.
The standard subway fare in New York City is $1.50, with discounts for MetroCard users. And Port Authority officials said structuring the fare increase the way they have proposed for the PATH could lay the early groundwork for combining MetroCard and QuickCard so that one card would work in both transit systems some day.
That kind of merging of regional transit systems is one that many economists and transportation experts have been urging for more than a decade. "This would be long overdue," said Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group specializing in transportation and planning issues. "We see this as a regional transportation system and having a big difference on one side of the river really doesn't seem to make any sense."
Port Authority officials stressed yesterday that any increases would be considered by the Port Authority's 12-member board only as part of its overall discussions about the agency's capital plan. If the capital plan eventually adopted by the board were trimmed, the political justification for fare and toll increases would be weaker and the increases would probably be less, the officials said.
Under one scenario, the toll and fare increases would generate an extra $120 million a year for the agency, which would be split so that New York State would receive something more than half.
That would be good news for New York State officials, who are trying to find the money to pay for several projects that would have been aided by the failed $3.8 billion transportation bond act. Among the projects that bond money would have gone to support was a connection to Grand Central Terminal for the Long Island Rail Road and initial work on a Second Avenue subway line.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Governor Pataki, said the administration had not been briefed on any toll or fare increase proposals, and he stressed that any plan was, at this point, something that existed only on a Port Authority staff level. "We can't comment on what we haven't seen," Mr. McKeon said.
Laura Otterbourg, a spokeswoman for Governor Whitman, said last evening that Mrs. Whitman has "neither been briefed nor signed off on any toll increase." Robert E. Boyle,
the executive director of the Port Authority, did not return a call to his office seeking comment.
While the fare on the PATH train can be raised by a vote of the authority's board, the bridge and tunnel toll increases require public hearings before any vote. Officials said those hearings could be held in December and January if the board agreed to pursue a toll increase.
Board members will meet today only to get the plans for an increases and to discuss them, not to vote. But Mr. Gargano said that while Port Authority board members had not seen the proposal, he believed that they all understood the need for some kind of increases.
"These things have been too low for too long," he said.

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: TAX CUT APPROVED -- The New York City Council voted 39 to 3 yesterday to approve a reduction in the city's personal income tax that would save taxpayers an average of $52 a year. The cut is much smaller than the one proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani nearly a year ago. It was scaled back by the mayor and the Council because of concern that the larger cut might have left the city with budget deficits. It would take effect in January.
 Eric Lipton (NYT) 

BROOKLYN: REDEVELOPMENT DRIVE -- High costs and a shortage of available office space are hurting Brooklyn's economic development, Mark Green, the public advocate, left, said yesterday. Overall business costs are lower and incentives are higher in northern New Jersey than in Brooklyn, said Mr. Green, who plans to run for mayor. To encourage economic growth, Mr. Green recommended a wide-ranging development corporation. He also called for a technology zone in which private companies would receive tax incentives to create jobs and businesses. He said state and local officials should cut taxes, provide incentives for residential development, and build a trolley loop to connect downtown Brooklyn with other neighborhoods. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: BUS LINE SUES CITY -- New York Apple Tours has filed a lawsuit charging city officials with trying to destroy the company. The tour company asserts in the suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, that since the summer the city has harassed the company through selective and unfair law enforcement while trying "to inflict maximum harm." Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, the State Department of Motor Vehicles and 10 "John Does" who are city and state employees are named as defendants. The company's court papers say the city's actions stem from an accident on May 22 in which a pedestrian was killed by an Apple Tours bus. (AP)
 
MANHATTAN: SUIT IN DISAPPEARANCE -- The father of Etan Patz, who disappeared in SoHo as a 6-year-old in 1979, plans a wrongful-death civil suit against the prime suspect in the case, Jose A. Ramos. A search of a Lower East Side apartment in June failed to link Mr. Ramos to the disappearance. Yesterday, Mr. Patz signed legal papers in preparation for a suit in civil court. Brian O'Dwyer, Mr. Patz's lawyer, said a criminal indictment of Mr. Ramos was "becoming less and less likely." (NYT)
 
WHITE PLAINS: NOT GUILTY PLEAS -- Patrick Baxter, 31, pleaded not guilty yesterday to 15 counts of second-degree murder in the deaths of three young women in Westchester County more than a decade ago. He was also accused of sexually assaulting all three victims and robbing two of them, said Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester district attorney. Mrs. Pirro said there was no obvious motive for the slayings, which were only recently linked to Mr. Baxter by DNA tests. Mr. Baxter, imprisoned for an unrelated offense, would have been eligible for parole next year. David W. Chen (NYT)
 
HAUPPAUGE: SWINDLING INDICTMENT -- Christopher Rocancourt, the confidence man who spent the summer in the Hamptons posing as a Rockefeller and who is accused of swindling the well-to-do out of nearly $250,000, was indicted in absentia in Suffolk County Court yesterday. Mr. Rocancourt left the country last month, and the judge issued a bench warrant for his arrest. Mr. Rocancourt's aide, Dante J. Daniello, was in court and was charged with 13 crimes, including grand larceny and false impersonation. Bail was set at $1,500. According to the indictment, Mr. Daniello, 52, helped Mr. Rocancourt defraud investors.
 Charlie LeDuff (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: FINAL N.Y.U. UNION VOTE -- When the National Labor Relations Board counted votes last week to determine whether graduate students at New York University wanted the United Auto Workers as a bargaining agent for a new union of teaching and research assistants, some ballots were in dispute. On Monday, N.Y.U. and the students agreed to count 155 of the 295 disputed votes. Yesterday, a final tally showed the winning margin for the auto workers had narrowed from 179 votes to 68. The final tally is 619 to 551. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
ELIZABETH: SCOOTER LAW PASSED -- Elizabeth has become the third town to require kickboard scooter riders to wear a helmet, nearly two months after a 6-year-old boy was killed when he rode his scooter into traffic. The City Council approved the measure Tuesday night, and Mayor J. Christian Bollwage has said he will sign it. The measure, which applies to adults and children, was introduced Sept. 12, 10 days before the boy, Andy Pino, died after being struck by a car outside his home. He was not wearing a helmet. (AP)
 
JACKSON: TIGER AREA THREATENED -- Joan Byron-Marasek, left, known as the Tiger Lady, is fighting a possible government shutdown of her tiger preserve. Valter H. Must, her lawyer, said yesterday that he would fight a violation order filed last week by the State Department of Environmental Protection for unrefrigerated deer carcasses and failure to prevent tigers from breeding. The state has been trying to shut down her tiger preserve in Jackson Township since last year, when the state contended that one of her tigers escaped. The state had given Mrs. Byron-Marasek until Saturday to file a plan for the removal of her 20 tigers, or face closure of her preserve. But Mr. Must said he would seek a stay from an appellate court. Maria Newman (NYT)
 
ATLANTIC CITY: CAESAR'S CHIEF RESIGNS -- Two days before a hearing on his license renewal application, Gary DiBartolomeo, the president of Caesars Atlantic City Hotel Casino, announced his resignation. Investigators recommended last month that the State Casino Control Commission reject the renewal application of Mr. DiBartolomeo, who has acknowledged being a compulsive gambler. He had promised not to gamble, but then posted $389,000 in gambling debts in one 18-month period. In a statement, Mr. DiBartolomeo said he wanted to be treated for his gambling. Caesar's owner, Park Place Entertainment of Las Vegas, named as a successor Paul Henderson, president of Atlantic City Hilton Casino Resort. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
STAMFORD: SKAKEL SEPARATION -- Michael C. Skakel, the Kennedy relative charged in the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley, has separated from his wife, Margot, who filed to divorce him last month after nine years of marriage. A Juvenile Court judge in Stamford is now deciding whether Mr. Skakel, 40, will be tried for murder as an adult. He was 15 years old when Miss Moxley, his neighbor, was found bludgeoned to death in Greenwich. Mr. Skakel's defense lawyer, Michael Sherman, made no mention of the marital separation at a court hearing late last month, but confirmed it yesterday after it was reported in The New York Post. Mr. Sherman said the Skakels, who have a 2-year-old son, were working toward an amicable settlement.
 David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)
 
NORWICH: DEVELOPMENT PLAN SET -- A Boston-based development company will market the former site of a state mental hospital to corporations around the world as the Brewster Point Corporate Center. The company, Spaulding & Slye Colliers International, which has been hired by the state to lure high-tech businesses to the 470-acre site, presented its marketing plan on Tuesday.(AP)

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Navajo Birth Is a Surprise For a Jew

BYLINE: By Neil Genzlinger

 BODY:
With more dot-coms dropping into the dustbin every day, it's nice to get an occasional reminder that the Internet isn't completely useless, and "The Lost Child," Sunday's movie on CBS, provides one.
As it has for many others, the Internet lets Rebecca, the centerpiece of this tale, find someone with whom she had lost touch. The someone is herself: she grew up in a Jewish household on the East Coast but learns through a Web posting that she is a Navajo and has an extended family in Arizona. 
 The premise might sound improbable except that "The Lost Child" is inspired by a true story, the autobiography "Looking for Lost Bird," written by Yvette Melanson with Claire Safran. In fact, from snippets of dialogue in the film we learn that stealing and selling Indian children was not uncommon just after World War II.
But "The Lost Child" is not a documentary, and anyone wanting to know more about this tantalizing subject will have to look elsewhere. So will anyone craving one of those adoptee-reunion tales that end with the separated family members' finally meeting and sharing a joyous hug. The reunion is just the beginning of this story, which tells what happens when Rebecca, nicely played by Mercedes Ruehl, tries to return to her Navajo roots and drag her skeptical family with her.
Karen Arthur, the director, and Sally Beth Robinson, who wrote the teleplay (taking considerable latitude with Ms. Melanson's book), try to walk a precarious line between compelling story and sentimental mush, with only partial success. The dialogue frequently veers toward the maudlin with phrases that ring as if they were plucked from a "1,000 lines you can use in your screenplay" book. ("When my mother died, I couldn't cry." "I don't know why I walk the path I walk; I only know I have to.") Drippy music adds to the problem.
Yet there are intelligent decisions in evidence as well. One was to make Rebecca's Jewish upbringing a minor factor once she reaches Navajo land; there are no silly scenes of her trying to teach the Indians to braid a nice challah.
Another was to take an oblique, understated approach to the well-known problems of American Indian life, like alcoholism and unemployment. It would have been easy to have a stereotypical Indian drunk stagger through a few frames. Instead there is a quick, telling scene between Jack (Jamey Sheridan), Rebecca's very white husband, and Eddie (Michael Greyeyes), her newfound brother-in-law. Jack, who was a bartender in his younger days, is embarrassed because he has failed to recognize Eddie even though they have already met once. "Sorry," Jack says, "I'm lousy with faces; must be getting old, I guess. I used to remember everybody's name, everybody's face, everybody's drink." His look as he stops himself short, realizing his gaffe, and the glare that Mr. Greyeyes gives him say all that needs to be said.
It's too bad that such moments of honesty are matched by ones not as credible. Rebecca's father (Ned Romero) and aunt (Tantoo Cardinal) are pleasant to listen to at first, but after a while it's like a two-hour session with Yoda; they speak in nonstop aphorisms that surely misrepresent the way older American Indians actually communicate. Similarly, although the film bravely dashes Rebecca's idyllic initial impressions of Indian life -- Navajo, it turns out, have their own racist and sexist streaks -- in the end a cute horse makes everyone forget all their troubles.
Still, for those with a high tolerance for sentiment, "The Lost Child" has enough rewards to be worth the trip, not the least of which is the chance to watch American Indian actors in substantive roles. It's an educational exercise as well, assuming that the depiction of Navajo life is somewhat accurate. It's even humorous at times: "Mom," Rebecca's elder daughter (Julia McIlvaine) complains after being dragged out of bed to experience a sunrise, "we are only half Navajo, and the white half needs more sleep."
In fact, an enterprising network executive could do worse than to jettison some of the junk on the current prime-time schedule and turn this into a series. When "The Lost Child" is over, viewers are left thinking it would be interesting to check in on Rebecca and family at some future date to see how their grand experiment is progressing.
 
THE LOST CHILD
 
CBS, Sunday night at 9
(Channel 2 in New York)
 
A Hallmark Hall of Fame production written by Sally Beth Robinson and based on the book "Looking for Lost Bird" by Yvette Melanson with Claire Safran; directed by Karen Arthur; Richard Welsh, executive producer; Brent Shields, co-executive producer; Tom Neuwirth, director of photography; music by Mark McKenzie.
WITH: Mercedes Ruehl (Rebecca), Jamey Sheridan (Jack), Irene Bedard (Grace), Dinah Manoff (Helen), Tantoo Cardinal (Aunt Mary), Michael Greyeyes (Eddie), Ned Romero (Yazzi) and Julia McIlvaine (Caroline).

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF;
'A Class Act' Is Moving Up

BYLINE: By Jesse McKinley

 BODY:
After more than a decade in the works, the ascent of "A Class Act" to Broadway appears to be complete.
Producers of the musical, which opened to generally good reviews at the Manhattan Theater Club on Nov. 9, said this week that they would move the show to Broadway in February, probably to the Ambassador Theater. Previews are to begin on Feb. 14, with an opening in March. 
 Marty Bell, who has been associated with the musical since the beginning, said the decision was made almost immediately after the opening. "We feel the critics said the kind of things we wanted them to say," Mr. Bell said. "And we think there's a place out there for this show."
"A Class Act" is based on the life and times of Ed Kleban, the Tony Award-winning lyricist of "A Chorus Line," who died of cancer in 1987. Mr. Bell said that on the very day Mr. Kleban died, he approached the writer's longtime girlfriend, Linda Kline, and told her, "We're going to get Ed's music out there."
That promise did not reach fruition quickly. The piece, which is directed by Lonny Price and stars him, worked its way through several incarnations before picking up steam in recent years. Arielle Tepper and Chase Mishkin joined Mr. Bell on the production team.
Detractors might say that the producers' love of Mr. Kleban and his story has clouded their judgment, since the show's reviews were good but not perfect. Typical was the one in The New York Times, in which Bruce Weber called the musical "a polished, frequently charming work" but questioned its appeal beyond aficonados of quirky theatrical tales.
Mr. Bell dismissed those concerns. "It's a very emotional show," he said. "And we think that anyone who sees it, feels it."
 
'Bells' Tinkling
 "Bells Are Ringing" is thinking smaller. The musical revival, starring Faith Prince as a muselike switchboard operator, had been scheduled to open at the 1,752-seat Broadway Theater, home of the soon-to-close "Miss Saigon." But now the musical is headed to the 1,079-seat Plymouth, home of the soon-to-close "Jekyll and Hyde."
The economics of the move are intriguing. "Bells," directed by Tina Landau, faces a much lower potential gross at the Plymouth because it has fewer seats. Producers of "Jekyll" cited the limited capacity last week in explaining their struggles to recoup that show's $7 million investment. (Mind you, the show also received unflattering reviews.)
Mitchell Maxwell, the lead producer, said he was unconcerned by the smaller house and added that the move had lowered the show's capitalization to some $5.8 million from $6.6 million because the scale of sets and other design elements would shrink. He said the transfer also made creative sense. "The show was originally conceived to be in a more intimate home," he said.
Mr. Mitchell also confirmed that Marc Kudisch would join the cast as Ms. Prince's love interest. Mr. Kudisch is now in "Thoroughly Modern Millie," another musical headed for Broadway, at the La Jolla Playhouse in California. Rehearsals for "Bells" are to begin in January, after "Millie's" California run ends.
The shift to the Plymouth may open the door at the Broadway for a possible run of "Blast!," a brassy musical revue of the miracles of the marching band, though a spokesman could not confirm that.
 
Liev Schreiber's Roles
When Liev Schreiber was growing up on the Lower East Side, he was a self-described Shakespeare geek, the "obnoxious kid who raised his hand to read in English class."
That may not have won him fans back then, but Mr. Schreiber's more recent efforts at acting, as the heartstruck seducer in a revival of Harold Pinter's "Betrayal" at the Roundabout Theater Company, are winning him some of the best reviews of the season. Not that he has seen them; Mr. Schreiber says he tries not to read reviews until the run is over.
"I love to read them later," he said in a interview at the American Airlines Theater. "But I can kind of tell how they went by the way the cast reacts to me when I come in." (With that, a press agent shouted "Congratulations!," and Mr. Schreiber said, "Thanks," and shrugged.)
The son of a part-time actor and an artistic mother who sometimes drove a cab, Mr. Schreiber attended Brooklyn Tech High School before being accepted by the Yale School of Drama. After graduation he returned to New York City, appearing in a few Off Broadway plays.
It was in another Pinter play, the Roundabout's 1995 production of "Moonlight," that Mr. Schreiber broke through, getting strong reviews for his portrayal of a layabout son. That role coincided with several film roles, including a memorable turn in the low-budget 1997 cult flick "The Daytrippers." (Greg Mottola, the film's director, remains one of his good friends.)
And while his film work continues -- "I try to sell out on a regular basis," he jokes -- he remains proudest of his work in productions of "The Tempest" (1995), "Macbeth" and "Cymbeline" (both 1998), and last year's "Hamlet," all for the New York Shakespeare Festival.
"I go after good texts; I get amped by good plays," he said. "And wherever I can find that text, that's where I want to be."
 
'Jitney' on the Road
"Jitney," August Wilson's acclaimed drama playing the Union Square Theater, looks to be taking the show on the road. Negotiations are under way for the play to transfer to the West End of London early next year, said Richard Kornberg, a spokesman. The production, to be presented in conjunction with the Royal National Theater, would include the American cast.
That would mean that the Union Square, considered one of Off Broadway's more desirable theaters, would become available soon, and shows are already circling. Among those waiting in the wings are two light-theme musicals.
One is "Reefer Madness," a musical version of the 1930's scare film about the danger of marijuana. The second possibility sounds even more far out: "Bat Boy: The Musical," a comic musical by Larry O'Keefe, Brian Fleming and Keyth Farley based on the freakish character from the tabloid newspaper The Weekly World News. Scott Schwartz, son of composer Stephen Schwartz, is to direct.

HEADLINE: In Yugoslav Misery, Investors Knock

BYLINE: By PETER S. GREEN

 BODY:
Just over a month has passed since Yugoslavia's emerging democrats sent President Slobodan Milosevic packing and Western countries began lifting sanctions. Already, foreign investors are sifting through the physical and economic wreckage for investments and markets in Yugoslavia, a country they say should be the engine of Balkan recovery.
Trade delegations from Greece, Austria and the Czech Republic have visited. American and European companies are considering investing or reviving dormant links, and some that weathered the storm have expansion plans. 
 "My client list has doubled since the changes," said Benoit Junod, a former Swiss diplomat in Belgrade whose Geneva-based consulting firm, A&S, is scouting Serbia on behalf of foreign clients, particularly construction concerns.
In 1989, Yugoslavia was the wealthiest and most open country in the Communist world. Ten years of ethnic hatred, economic mismanagement and war have left its economy devastated and its infrastructure in tatters. But where many citizens see misery, investors see opportunity.
With eight million people in Yugoslavia, plus or minus two million Kosovars and two million Serbs in the diaspora, it is one of the Balkans' biggest and most important markets. Brand-conscious consumers with a surprising amount of money are thirsting for a better life. Labor is cheap, and the country sits astride the main road, rail and river routes linking Europe and the Balkans.
The economic reformers behind Yugoslavia's new president, Vojislav Kostunica, say speedy privatization is a high priority. Crucial assets for sale include the huge tobacco factory in Nis; electric, oil and gas companies; cement factories; and the government's 51 percent stake in Telekom Srbija.
The possibilities have piqued interest. An Austrian construction company, Bau Holding Strabag A.G., is exploring the loans and grants promised to Serbia for rebuilding by the European Union and others. "We are looking at projects like reconstruction of bridges over the Danube, highways, etc.," said Bau's chairman, Roland Jurecka.
Svetozar Janevski, managing director of the Pivara Skopje brewery in Macedonia, said he hoped to recapture Serbian markets lost when Macedonia seceded from Yugoslavia in 1992. "We have to think that Serbia is a market of 10 million people, and we can't cover that with one brewery in Skopje," Macedonia's capital, he said. Pivara Skopje, 51-percent- owned by a joint venture of the Dutch brewer Heineken N.V. and the Greek Coca-Cola bottler, the Hellenic Bottling Company, will be looking at some of the 10 major breweries in Serbia and at mineral water bottlers.
The Austrian bank Raiffeisen Zentralbank Group, a leading lender across the former Austro-Hungarian Empire, is moving to set up in Yugoslavia. "We have already made contacts with several Yugoslav banks to become their correspondent partner, and the second step would be to open our own operation," said a spokesman, Andreas Ecker.
Experts say the key is whether the government that emerges from the December elections can push significant reforms through the regional parliaments in Serbia and Montenegro and whether the governments can hold together through the pain of reforms. Serbia makes up 95 percent of Yugoslavia's population; Montenegro, its tiny sister republic, constitutes the rest.
Statistics show that average incomes are under $50 a month and unemployment is over 50 percent, and the economy is shrinking at over 7 percent a year. But that is not the full story, said Srdjan Bogosavljevic, director of the Strategic Marketing and Media Research Institute, a privately owned concern in Belgrade.
"There is no gas, but people are driving cars everywhere," he said. "There are no visas, but people are traveling. There are no salaries, but the restaurants are full."
Vastly skewed official statistics and a thriving gray economy help explain the apparent paradox. And remittances from Serbs abroad, Mr. Bogosavljevic said, are an estimated $100 million to $150 million a month.
So with even a small sign of recovery, markets for consumer goods in particular are likely to take off. "The future looks very bright," said Ephram Jeffy, general director of IBP Beograd A.D., the authorized Coca-Cola bottler in Yugoslavia. IBP operated during the Milosevic regime.
Anti-American sentiment during the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia last year did not dent sales, he said; Coke sold 24 million cases of soft drinks in Yugoslavia and he expects to double that in two years.
"The war has shifted into subconsciousness," said Srdjan Saper, chief executive of the I&F McCann Erickson Group, an advertising agency in Belgrade. Mr. Saper says he is already hiring to meet an expected advertising boom.
Vladimir Joksic, the deputy general manager of the agency, a unit of the Interpublic Group, added: "One of the huge potentials here is the mindset of Yugoslav consumers. They know how to read advertising, and most of the Western brand goods were already here -- they were present on the black market."
The McDonald's Corporation has 16 restaurants in Yugoslavia. At the height of economic sanctions, it was able to obtain locally some 80 percent of its supplies and keep operating. That loyalty to the local market has built customer loyalty. "A lot of people will be surprised how fast this market will pick up," said Branimir Lalic, vice president for purchasing at McDonald's Central Europe operations, who is looking at sites for new restaurants on Serbia's highways.
Other businesses are already reaping the benefits of President Kostunica's arrival. ICN Pharmaceuticals of Costa Mesa, Calif., whose chairman, Milan Panic, is a former Yugoslav prime minister and opponent of Mr. Milosevic, won back control of its Belgrade pharmaceuticals factory, which had been confiscated by the Milosevic government. The company sees the Belgrade plant as crucial to winning export markets in the Caucasus and Turkey.
Yugoslavia's open past should help it avoid the slow learning curve that has dragged down development in other former Communist nations.
"We are at the center of the Balkans here, and have many people who for 20 or 30 years have been doing business with the West," said Dusan Mitevic, general manager of ICN Yugoslavia. "If the government assures stability, this country has the resources and the people, so it can very quickly rejoin the world."

HEADLINE: Russia to Seek Easier U.S. Rules for Steel Exports

BYLINE: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Russia plans to ask Washington next month to change trade rules that have reduced steel exports to the United States by as much as 90 percent since 1998.
Russian government officials met today with 26 of the country's largest steel producers to map out a strategy for easing quotas and revising the way minimum prices are calculated and give Russian metal better access to the vast American market. 
 Last year, amid concern that its producers would be shut out of the United States, Russia agreed to quotas on hot-rolled steel just one-tenth of their 1998 volume. The agreement also set a minimum price, which currently exceeds the United States price by 30 percent.
"It would be very difficult to explain domestically if this agreement is continued," said Maksim Medvedkov, deputy minister of trade and economic development. "We want to compete freely and we want intervention to cease."
The old Soviet Union was the world's largest steel maker, producing more than 160 million tons a year for its heavy industries. But after the Soviet collapse in 1991, demand declined, and steel producers sought buyers in foreign markets like the United States. By 1997, Russian producers were exporting 60 percent of what they produced -- compared with zero in Soviet times.
Mr. Medvedkov said that next month's talks might not produce quick results because of opposition from American steel companies. The Americans say Russian steel makers have an unfair advantage in their low costs and remaining state subsidies. But Mr. Medvedkov said they no longer had access to government loans or big wage arrears that gave them competitive advantages.

HEADLINE: Japan Asks for an End to Debate on U.N. Security Council's Shape

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Japan, which is campaigning for a permanent seat on the Security Council, called today for an end to the inconclusive debate on whether the Council should be expanded and asked that major nations, especially the United States, come to concrete agreement on its future shape.
As a starting point, Japan's ambassador to the United Nations, Yukio Satoh, formally recommended that the Council be expanded to 24 members from the current 15, and suggested that the Japanese would support restrictions on the five permanent members' use of the veto, a position popular with developing nations. 
 In an interview after his speech to a General Assembly session devoted to Security Council reform, Mr. Satoh said his next step would be to negotiate with the new American administration for specific, acceptable new numbers of permanent and nonpermanent members. He said that 155 of the organization's 189 member nations had now committed themselves to a larger council, and that debate should be considered closed. Mr. Satoh and Japanese Foreign Ministry officials who have worked on Japan's campaign say that they are increasingly frustrated by the General Assembly's inability to move beyond endless debate. Japan now pays 20 percent of the United Nations budget -- more than the combined contributions of all permanent Council members excluding the United States. But it lacks any official voice in Council decisions.
Speaking in the same debate, Ambassador James B. Cunningham of the United States reaffirmed American support for permanent Council seats for both Japan and Germany, based on their economic and political power. But he ruled out any change in the veto, which Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States, as permanent members, can use to block any Council action.
At the end of the day, while numerous speakers repeated the call for change, there was no agreement on what the next steps would be, only the familiar deadlock that has stymied a working group of member nations for seven years.
"What is taking so long?" Mr. Cunningham, a career diplomat and deputy chief representative of the United States, asked in his speech. "There is not yet, regrettably, even an emerging consensus on how to proceed. We are not surprised."
He pointed to some of the problems: regional competitions for proposed new seats, disagreements between rich and poor nations about how to strike a balance among them, and the final shape the Council should take. There have also been disputes over whether new permanent members would get veto powers.
When a proposal was made several years ago to add five members to the Council -- permanent seats for Germany, Japan and three developing countries -- it was soon apparent that there would be no consensus in Africa, Asia or Latin America behind a single candidate from each region.
Nigeria, Egypt and South Africa are all seen as potential African contenders for a permanent place. India wants a permanent seat, but in its own right, not as a representative of Asia. Several Latin American nations, among them Brazil and Mexico, are seen as contenders, too.
The United States, which for years held to an upper limit of 21 members, edged closer last April to the Japanese figure of 24, though Americans are concerned that expansion might make the group unwieldy and ineffective.

HEADLINE: By Deals With Burmese Junta, Minorities Thrive

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN

DATELINE: KEKKU, Myanmar

 BODY:
Freedom's just another word for cutting a deal with the generals.
That is what the business manager of the Pao National Organization explained over a lunch of spicy chicken and avocado salad here in the rebel outback of a country that is a perennial contender for the title of world's most repressive state. 
 By agreeing to a cease-fire with the generals who run what used to be called Burma, the Pao, an ethnic minority of about 400,000 people in a country of 50 million, have won themselves civil rights and economic opportunities all but unimaginable to most Burmese.
A look at the semi-good life in Pao land explains why, in the last decade, at least 15 armed ethnic minorities in Myanmar have been willing to end decades of bloodshed and do business with the generals.
"It is not a perfect arrangement," said the Pao business manager, smoking a cigarette through a bamboo water pipe after lunch. "But it is better than war."
The Pao are prospering primarily as hoteliers, garlic farmers and jade miners. But other ethnic minorities -- the Wa and the Shan, in particular -- have used cease-fires to expand their interests in the heroin and amphetamine trades, according to the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. They have also been encouraged by the government to launder drug profits through the legitimate Burmese economy.
For the generals, ceding "contingent sovereignty" to groups like the Pao, Shan and Wa has been a win-win deal.
The agreements have, for the most part, ended a series of expensive insurgent wars that had become a way of life in the mountainous fringes of this country. Fighting continues against the Karen National Union, but that group has only 2,000 to 3,000 fighters, a fraction of its strength before the generals made deals with Karen subgroups.
Probably more important, cease-fires have freed the generals to focus state resources on saving their own skins. Since killing hundreds of pro-democracy marchers in 1988 and ignoring an election they lost in 1990, the generals have used an ever-expanding web of repression as the key to their continued rule.
The long, strong arm of that repression is an agency called Military Intelligence that locks up opposition leaders, spies on citizens and forces potential troublemakers like students out of cities.
The general in charge of Military Intelligence is the one who came up with the idea of making peace with the Pao and other rebel groups: Lt. Gen. Khin Nyunt, who is often described as the brains behind the government. In its Orwellian argot, he is called Secretary One.
Secretary One is widely feared by members of the Burman ethnic group. They live in the lowlands and make up about 65 percent of the country's population. But among the hill people, Secretary One is not considered to be such a bad guy.
"He has a very sophisticated political mind, and he keeps his word," said the business manager of the Pao. Although he generally has good relations with Secretary One, he is somewhat afraid of him. To protect him, this article omits his name.
The business manager, though, was more than happy to explain how life is better in a world where the generals are no longer your enemy. "The most important benefit for our people is that they are no longer being forced to work as slaves for Slorc's army," he said.
Slorc is an acronym for State Law and Order Restoration Council, a name by which the junta was officially known until 1997. The generals then changed the name of their government to the State Peace and Development Council. But most Burmese continue to call the government Slorc.
Human rights groups and the State Department say forced labor has been and remains a common practice here, with Slorc forcing thousands of citizens to build roads and bridges and serve as coolies during military campaigns.
Besides freedom from forced labor, the business manager said the benefits of making peace with the generals include freedom to travel abroad without paying bribes for passports, to import cars without paying bribes for import licenses and to run businesses without generals' extorting profits.
For most Burmese -- the tens of millions who have not been able to fight the generals to a standoff -- all of these difficulties persist, along with a fear of being jailed and tortured by Military Intelligence.
One freedom the business manager enjoys, but did not mention, is the right to carry a gun. He hides an automatic pistol in his four-wheel rig.
As it turns out, the right to keep and hide weapons has been a primary guarantor of the cease-fire agreements that the Pao and most other ethnic groups have made.
"We keep our weapons, and we don't tell them where they are or how many we have," the Pao leader said. "If Slorc does not deliver on its promises for schools, roads and health clinics, we have the option of going back to war."
So far, he said, Slorc has mostly delivered.
What the generals buy with these expenditures, according to experts and diplomats, is the ability to isolate their primary political threat, the Burman majority, from their primary military threat, the well-armed minorities in the hills.
The deals that the ethnic minorities have made with the generals appear to have weakened the already weak hand of the country's primary opposition group, whose leader is Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize. She is again under house arrest in the capital, Yangon, as she has been for much of the last decade since her party, the National League for Democracy, won an overwhelming victory in parliamentary elections.
For the Pao, as for many of the ethnic minorities here, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi is not the saint-like, charismatic political figure that she is for many Burmese and for human-rights champions around the world.
"We are neither for her or against her," the business manager said. "What we are for is getting the best deal possible from the government so that we can have a maximum amount of political and commercial freedom."
Among the ethnic groups that have profited from peace, the Pao National Organization is probably the most successful in legitimate (that is, non-drug-related) business.
The organization owns two popular tourist hotels on scenic Inle Lake. With profits from the hotel, the Pao are investing in orchid farming and manufacture of commercial-grade dyes, and they are soon to open a tourist restaurant here in Kekku.
It was here at the restaurant, which offers a splendid view of ruins of medieval pagodas and Buddhist shrines, that the business manager made an international appeal for the commercial interests of the Pao.
"Tell people to come and visit us," he said. "The restaurant will be open to the public by January."

HEADLINE: New York-Presbyterian Begins Work on Hospital for Children

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
New York-Presbyterian Hospital broke ground for its new children's hospital in Washington Heights yesterday, becoming the third medical center in the region to begin construction of a children's hospital in the last few years.
The new center will be known as Morgan Stanley Dean Witter Children's Hospital of New York, reflecting the investment bank's gift of more than $55 million, which included donations from employees. The nine-story building, at 165th Street and Broadway, will replace the Babies and Children's Hospital, which will be renovated and turned into an outpatient center. The new hospital is expected to open in 2003. 
 Construction of the hospital comes at a time when the rest of the health care industry is scaling back many new projects and facing fiscal troubles. However, New York-Presbyterian and one of the other hospitals building a children's hospital, Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, both drew upon philanthropic donors for their projects. Montefiore hopes to complete its children's hospital in November 2001. Westchester County Medical Center plans to open a children's hospital in 2003.
Officials at New York-Presbyterian cited a strong need for hospitals devoted to the care of children.
"As tough as our economic position is," said Dr. Herbert Pardes, chief executive, "our intention is to do everything we can do to make our children's hospital top notch. We are here to do cutting-edge care, but you have to have the physical plant to do that."
While New York-Presbyterian's Babies and Children's Hospital has some of the best-known pediatric specialists and researchers in the world, the hospital itself is antiquated and crumbling. The oldest section of the hospital dates to 1928. The ceilings are about 12 feet high and cannot accommodate the wiring needed for the latest technology. Rooms are small and reflect a time when parents played only a minor role in their children's care -- almost all the rooms in the new hospital will be private, with sleeping areas for adults.
John J. Mack, president and chief operating officer of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, has been on the board at New York-Presbyterian since 1992. In 1994, he helped raise $3.5 million for a new pediatric intensive care unit. "Wall Street has been very fortunate in the last few years," Mr. Mack said yesterday. "We felt that if we could get people to focus on one good project they would look back later and be proud."
